Kent cautioned Wednesday that ``while the worst of the production loss is behind us, any unforeseen production problem could cause market reactions since the world is now operating at near capacity production levels.'' In another development, the DOE announced that it had awarded the first contracts for the test sale of crude oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Sun Refining and Marketing Co. purchased 540,000 barrels and Shell Oil Company bought 95,000 barrels. The two were among 11 companies selected for purchases totaling 3.9 million barrels of oil from the reserve under the test drawdown.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Warns Against Mercury in Latex Paint
DOC.TEXT: Homeowners should air out their houses when painting inside with latex paint because of the possibility of mercury fumes, health experts said today. Federal researchers reported in the New England Journal of Medicine that hazardous traces of mercury were found in people's bodies after they painted with latex paint containing mercury as a preservative. Mercury poisoning can cause a variety of problems, including leg cramps, rash, low fever, personality changes and nerve problems. Because of the danger, the Environmental Protection Agency prohibited ading mercury to paint after Aug. 20. However, paint manufactured before the ban can still be sold. Experts estimate that until recently, one-third of all interior latex paint contained mercury. It was added to prevent fungal and bacterial growth and prolong shelf life. Oil-based paint contains no mercury. ``If I was a consumer, I would contact the paint company to determine if the paint I was using had mercury in it,'' said Dr. Mary M. Agocs. ``Whether or not paint has mercury, we recommend that people ventilate their houses when painting.'' She said mercury levels are probably highest during the first few weeks after the paint is applied. She did not recommend removing latex paint from walls. Agocs is a researcher with the federal Centers for Disease Control in Sacramento, Calif. Her study was conducted on 74 people living in 19 suburban Detroit houses that had been painted about a month earlier with mercury-bearing paint. Their bodies contained almost four times as much mercury as did 28 people in 10 houses who did not use the paint. None of the people exposed to the paint appeared to be sick. However, some had mercury levels that have been associated in the past with symptoms of mercury poisoning. The mercury levels were highest in children. Concern about mercury in paint arose last year after a 4-year-old Michigan boy suffered mercury poisoning when his home was painted.

DOC.HEAD: Former Stock Exchange Chairman Sentenced To 4 Years
DOC.TEXT: A former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange who helped transform the British colony's bourse into one of the best-known in Asia was sentenced today to four years in prison for corruption. Ronald Li, 61, was also ordered to pay an estimated $1.4 million in court costs and profits reaped from his corrupt acts. The high-rolling stock exchange chairman was convicted in High Court on Wednesday on two counts under Hong Kong's Bribery Prevention Ordinance. Li was found guilty of accepting preferential offerings of shares in Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. and Novel Enterprises Ltd. in 1986 and 1987 in exchange for helping obtain listings on the market for the companies' shares. Justice Kemal Bokhary sentenced Li to two years in prison for each count. He had faced a maximum penalty of seven years in prison and $64,000 in fines on each count. Prosecutors contended that Li made more than $100,000 in profits by selling the shares he was awarded. Michael Kalisher, the lead prosecutor, said court costs reached $1.3 million. Li's lawyer, John Lloyd-Eley said he would ``most probably'' appeal the verdict. Li faces other charges along with seven former members of the exchange scheduled to be tried in February. In sentencing Li, Bokhary said he took account of mitigating circumstances in the case, such as Li's good behavior in the past. Li was a powerful figure in this British colony's stockbroking community for two decades and is the one of the most prominent figures ever tried in Hong Kong. In the trial, Kalisher painted Li as the patriarch of an exclusive society funded by friendly merchant bankers. ``It was a very cozy little club,'' he said in court. Li was instrumental in merging the colony's four exchanges into the Hong Kong Stock Exchange four years ago, turning the bourses of this British colony into one of the most dynamic in the world. His decision to levy a small fee for each stock purchase put the exchange on solid financial ground. But his move to close the exchange for four days during the world stock market crash in October of 1987 made him a controversial figure and led to calls for his resignation. He stepped down as chairman of the exchange one month before he was arrested in January 1988. Between Li's arrest and his appearance in court, prosecutors dropped 13 charges lodged against him under the colony's Bribery Prevention Ordinance because of lack of evidence.

DOC.HEAD: House Favors Normal U.S.-Czech Relations
DOC.TEXT: The House has moved to normalize U.S. relations with Czechoslovakia for the first time since World War II and to dramatically reduce tariffs on that nation's exports to the United States. The House, by a voice vote Wednesday night, approved a trade agreement signed last April by the Bush administration and the newly elected Prague government under which each country would grant the other most-favored-nation trade status. That status would qualify the exporting country for the lowest tariffs in effect on the goods it ships to the buying country. The agreement is the first U.S. bilateral trade accord with a former Eastern Bloc country since the Warsaw Pact began collapsing more than a year ago. The Senate also must approve the pact before barriers to trade with the formerly communist-ruled Czechs are removed. President Bush signed the agreement in April but did not send it to Capitol Hill for congressional approval until last month. The accord will effectively reduce by 90 percent the tariffs paid on some $82 million in Czech exports to the United States last year and open the way for increased business ties between the two countries. The effect will be to give Czechoslovakia a much broader U.S. market for its exports by cutting their prices to wholesalers, retailers and ultimately American consumers by as much as up to 40 percent. It also will open the Czech economy to more U.S. exports while also protecting American companies' patents and copyrights.
DOC.HEAD: Consumer Groups Urge Boycott of Cars Without Air Bags
DOC.TEXT: Three consumer groups want American car buyers to refuse to buy automobiles not equipped with air bags. Motor Voters, the Center for Auto Safety, and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group staged news conferences and demonstrations in 12 cities to propose the boycott, focusing their ire on Japanese economy models. Rosemary Dunlap, president of Motor Voters, noted that many automakers equip only luxury vehicles with air bags, claiming the $320 devices would drive away bargain hunters. She noted that Chrysler has several economy models with driver air bags as standard equipment. ``If Chrysler can put air bags in a car for under $8,000, what's Honda's excuse for leaving them out of the Civic CRX, which costs over $11,000?'' she asked. But the groups faulted even Chrysler for not equipping its popular minivans with air bags, and for not moving more quickly to make them standard equipment for front-seat passengers in cars. Chrysler is providing driver-side air bags in virtually all of its 1991 cars. Honda has announced it will make air bags standard equipment in all cars in 1994. Currently, the only Honda-built car sold in the United States with an air bag is the top-of-the-line Acura Legend. According to industry projections for the current model year, 45 percent of Ford's cars and 33 percent of General Motors' cars will be sold with at least a driver air bag. Six companies, BMW, Isuzu, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche, Saab, and Volvo, equip all their U.S. cars with air bags, while five others - Hyundai, Peugeot, Suzuki, Sterling and Yugo - have no such models. The figure for Toyota is 27 percent, for Nissan 20 percent, for Mazda 15 percent, and for Mitsubishi, 1 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill To Pay Reparations to Seneca Indians
DOC.TEXT: The Seneca Indians would receive millions of dollars in back rents on leased lands under a bill approved by the Senate. The bill directs the federal government to pay $35 million to the Senecas, admitting that Congress wrongly forced the tribe to lease its land for 115 years to the city of Salamanca, N.Y. ``We took advantage of the Seneca Nation and now we ought to correct this injustice,'' said Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., one of the Senate sponsors. The bill was adopted on a voice vote late Tuesday. It passed the House on Oct. 10. The Bush administration has said the government is not financially liable for the low rents paid to the Senecas and opposes the measure because of its cost. President Bush has 10 days in which to sign it, veto it or simply allow it to pass into law unsigned. The bill would ratify an agreement reached by Salamanca, three nearby villages and the Seneca Nation to replace a 99-year lease accord expiring Feb. 19, 1991. Under the agreements, about 85 percent of the city of Salamanca is leased from the Senecas at rents that were frozen as low as $1 per year. The state of New York must also pay $25 million, which will require state legislation.

DOC.HEAD: Existing Technologies Could Slow Global Warming, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Boosting energy efficiency and stopping the destruction of forests around the world could prevent the most disastrous consequences of global warming and save money, says a new report. The report, prepared for delivery to the Second World Climate Conference in Geneva beginning Oct. 29, says the technical means to slow global warming are here. ``Whether those technologies get implemented depends on the agressiveness of policies,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, one of the report's authors. ``Some of this can be done at a cost saving, because some of the technologies are cheaper to use than what we already use.'' For instance, energy efficiency measures can cut energy use, thereby reducing the emission of carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide is the most important of the so-called greenhouse gases, which warm the atmosphere by trapping the sun's heat like the windows of a greenhouse. ``It is projected by us that energy use will double by 2020 if no action is taken,'' Oppenheimer said. ``We can cut that growth in half by simply implementing energy efficiency measures which are cost effective.'' The report concludes that a rise in world temperatures of 2 degrees may be inevitable. But it says every effort should be made to avoid rises higher than that, Oppenheimer said. ``A rise of four degrees entails the risk of grave damage to ecosystems,'' said Oppenheimer, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund in New York City. ``Those sorts of warmings also entail rapid sea level rise, and rapid sea level rise is difficult and expensive for society to respond to,'' he said Wednesday. ``The trouble is, we may be already be committed to a warming on the order of two degrees Fahrenheit.'' Even that level of global warming could cause extensive ecosystem damage, concluded the scientists, members of the Advisory Group for Greenhouse Gases. The Oct. 29 meeting in Geneva could set the stage for an international treaty to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and other greenhouse gases, Oppenheimer said. Negotiations on the details of such a treaty are expected to follow in Washington in February, he said. Energy efficiency isn't the only means for reducing global warming, Oppenheimer said. ``We think that a very large emissions reduction can be obtained by ending deforestation, which we think can be done by the year 2005, and then by planting trees which will suck some carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: President, Congress Share Procrastinator Club's Award For Putting Things Off
DOC.TEXT: Some criticize the snail's pace of the budget talks on Capitol Hill. Others give it their highest praise. The Procrastinators Club of America has given its Procrastinator of the Year award to President Bush and Congress. The club, which champions delayed decisions and postponed projects, announced the honor Wednesday - and said it will begin working on a ceremony for the winners sometime in 1992. Or maybe later. Bush and Congress did ``an outstanding job'' of putting things off, said club president Les Waas. ``The procrastinators were aware of what was going on with our taxes because we eventually read Bush's lips,'' Waas said. ``But we also like Congress, and people in politics, because they are just like us, they procrastinate.'' The Procrastinators Club, established in 1956 by employees at a Philadelphia advertising agency, says it has about 8,500 members and half-million who haven't found the time to sign up. The award was accompanied by advice for the president and Congress: ``Spend the money first,'' Waas said, ``then determine the budget later. That way, they will always come out even and without any need for quibbling.'' Previous winners included comedian Jack Benny for putting off turning 40 for so many years and topless dancer Julie Gibson - the first winner in 1957 - for always putting things off.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges Further, Stocks Surge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar's continuing plunge took it to a 22-month low against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while stock prices surged for the fourth consecutive day. The dollar closed at 124.40 yen, down 1.40 yen from Wednesday's 125.80-yen finish and its lowest close since 124.05 yen on Jan. 4, 1989. The dollar has now fallen 13.55 yen in the last 13 trading days. After opening at 125.60 yen, it ranged between 124.15 yen and 125.85 yen. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where the yen's rise encouraged buying, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average finished at 24,367.08, up 507.72 points, or 2.13 percent. The close was the highest for the blue chip index since 24,365.60 points on Sept. 17. Trading was energetic, and volume on the first section was estimated at 700 million shares, up from 590 million Wednesday and the highest since June. ``The strong yen is definitely the predominant sentiment,'' said Katsumi Oshima, a researcher at Sanyo Securities. The dollar's dip to the 124-yen level at one point in New York Wednesday had a psychological effect, he said. The dollar closed at 125.43 yen in New York. Traders said many factors discouraged investment in dollars, including the American deficit, declining support for President Bush and the Middle East crisis. Oshima said the dollar is likely to fall to 120 yen before the end of the year. Recent reports that Bank of Japan officials favor the yen's rise helped drive the currency up, traders said. Meanwhile, the dollar was hurt by remarks by U.S. officials that a lower dollar could help boost American exports by making them cheaper overseas. ``The strong yen is the main factor today behind the stock prices. The other factor is the drop in interest rates. The market has recovered notably, both in strength and volume,'' said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer at Nikko Securities Co. Investors were buying construction, steel and finance issues. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was 84.36 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT), close to Wednesday's 84.40-point finish. Their yield stayed at 7.825 percent.

DOC.HEAD: India's Minority Government Threatened
DOC.TEXT: A right-wing Hindu party has threatened to pull out of Prime Minister V.P. Singh's already shaky government in a dispute over a holy site claimed by both Hindus and Moslems. The threat Wednesday by the Bharatiya Janata, or Indian People's Party, raised fears that the coalition government will collapse next month, less than a year after taking office. The Bharatiya Janata Party said it would withdraw support if the government tries to stop a Hindu procession to the northern town of Ayodhya intends to dismantle a mosque and replace it with a Hindu temple. ``This is not a communal issue. It is a matter of national honor,'' the party said in a resolution passed at an emergency metting. The National Front government has repeatedly said it will not allow the mosque's demolition. Lal Krishna Advani, head of the Bharatiya Janata Party, plans to lead thousands of Hindus to Auodhya, 300 miles east of New Delhi, on Oct. 30 and begin the temple construction. Hindu fundamentalists claim the mosque, known as Babri Masjid, replaced a temple destroyed in the 16th century by Moghul conquerers. Moslem leaders dispute the claim and refuse to leave the site. Advani is traveling across India to build public opinion for what he calls a case of majority rights. He has completed half of the 6,000-mile journey in a Toyota pickup converted to look like a chariot and used during festivals to carry Hindu idols. Hindus represent 82 percent of India's 880 million people, while Moslems represent only 12 percent. Members of the two faiths commonly clash in most Indian states, leaving dozens of people dead every year. Earlier Wednesday, Singh called a multiparty meeting to resolve the issue, but it was boycotted by the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, which is now in opposition. Other parties passed a resolution at the meeting that said the government was committed to protecting the mosque. Singh's government relies for its survival on the support of the Bharatiya Janata Party and the Left Front, a coalition of Communist parties. Withdrawal of support by either group would topple the government. The National Front, a loose coalition of five parties, took office Dec. 2, 1989, after no party was able to get a clear majority in national elections the previous month. The Bharatiya Janata Party also used the resolution to criticize the government's performance in the last 10 months, citing rising prices, growing separatism in Punjab and Kashmir and street protests by upper-caste Hindus against the government's job policy that favors lower castes.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Bird Flies Atlantic Only To Die On Hitting Bird Sanctuary Door
DOC.TEXT: A rare bird that apparently flew 3,000 miles across the Atlantic was killed when it crashed into a plate-glass door at one of Britain's leading bird sanctuaries, the facility reported. The gray-cheeked thrush is thought to have been blown off course while migrating from its summer home in Canada to South America, ornithologist Basil Hughes said Wednesday. It died Sunday when it flew into the door of the visitors' center at the headquarters of the Wildfowl and Wetland Trust at Slimbridge in the county of Gloucestershire in western England, Hughes said. Hughes, a researcher with the trust at Slimbridge, said a man selling nesting boxes heard a loud thud and then watched the six-inch-long bird fall to the ground. Hughes identified it as one of the northern sub-species of gray-cheeked thrush from its drab olive color, speckled breast and white underside. He has preserved the body in a refrigerator so that it can be stuffed by a taxidermist and put on permanent display. ``If it had survived there would have been thousands of twitchers (bird watchers) traveling from all over the country to see it,'' he said. Hughes said the bird apparently became disoriented after winds blew it off course last week as it flew south. Strong winds, occasional gales and a succession of mild winters have been responsible for the appearance in Britain of a succession of birds rarely seen in this country in recent years, ornithologists say.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Korean Students Attack U.S. Embassy With Firebombs
DOC.TEXT: Radical students armed with steel pipes, firebombs and clubs tried to storm the U.S. Embassy today but were quickly arrested by riot police. Police said one protester was injured. U.S. officials reported no injuries or damage inside the compound. The sidewalk about 10 yards from one of the embassy's entrance was scorched by firebombs. About 50 people, mostly Koreans, were waiting outside for the offices to open when 11 students launched the attack, witnesses said. ``They tried to throw the firebombs over the walls and they waved big sticks,'' one man said. Witnesses said the students bumped their van against an iron barricade near the embassy's visa section and tried to scale the walls from the van's roof. Riot police quickly surrounded and arrested the assailants. The protesters scattered anti-U.S. leaflets before being driven into a police bus to a nearby police station, police said. The protesters were members of Chondaehyop, a nationwide alliance of radical students. Among the slogans they shouted was ``Oppose Uruguay Round!'' - a reference to the multinational trade negotiations designed to remove trade barriers. South Korean dissidents and farmers say the free trade talks favor the United States and other industrialized nations. Farmers worry they won't be able to compete with cheaper imports if South Korea opens its agricultural markets. The embassy compound is surrounded by stone walls about 12-feet-high topped by additional wire fencing. It cannot be entered without passing through locked doors that are heavily guarded. Korean riot police are stationed outside the compound 24 hours a day. Radical students have also staged violent protests demanding the withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in Korea. They claim the troops hinder talks on unification with North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Denies Reports of `Inhumanity' in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has acknowledged that there might have been ``isolated'' displays of ``inhumanity'' by its soldiers in Kuwait but denied that they represent government policy. Responding to reports of mistreatment of people in Kuwait - including alleged summary executions, beheadings and stripping babies from incubators - Iraq's embassy in Washington denied that any such incidents were widespread and said it was the government's policy to ``observe basic human rights.'' The statement released Wednesday was the most thorough of any Iraqi denials of the reports, which came mostly from refugees in Kuwait, including some who testified before Congressman Tom Lantos' Committee on Human Rights. Some Western and Kuwaiti leaders have used the atrocity reports to press for military action to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait, which it overran in an Aug. 2 invasion. ``We were taken aback by the widely reported stories of flagrant and rampant disregard for human rights which these reports asserted were committed by our servicemen,'' the embassy statement said. ``While we acknowledge that in any conflict which involves the use of force, there are likely to be isolated incidents in which individuals misinterpret their mission and display inhumanity, we categorically deny that such incidents, if they occurred, represent any official policy of any level of our government. ``Moreover, we dismiss any suggestion that there have been widespread such incidents,'' the statement said. It accused the media of reporting the congressional hearing testimony ``without examining the reasons why the hearings were conducted, the veracity of witnesses or the lack of completeness of the testimony.'' The statement said at least one American who had been in Kuwait at the time of the invasion, Dr. Mohammed Said, was refused an opportunity to testify before Lantos' committee although he would have disputed some of the other testimony. ``It is the policy of the Republic of Iraq to observe basic human rights. Anyone who is found to have committed any of the acts would be dealt with according to our laws,'' the embassy statement said. ``The war mongers who slander Iraq with propaganda about make-believe atrocities in a kind of pep rally to build enthusiasm for the big game will have to dispose of the ashes of the bonfire built from their youth,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Prison Chief Thomas Murton Dead at 62
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Murton, the controversial reform-minded Arkansas prisons chief who was the inspiration for the Robert Redford movie ``Brubaker,'' has died of cancer at age 62. He died Oct. 10 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Oklahoma City. He was buried here Saturday. Murton, who advocated treating prisoners with respect and opposed the death penalty, rose to prominence as head of Cummins State Prison in Arkansas in the 1960s. Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller appointed him head of the prison system in 1967. Redford's 1980 role in ``Brubaker'' - as a reform-minded prisons chief who gets little support from his state's political establishment - was loosely based on Murton's career in Arkansas. A year after Murton's appointment, a national scandal erupted when authorities dug up three bodies at Cummins that a prisoner claimed belonged to fellow inmates. The prisoner said they had been beaten and shot by trusties and guards. Murton said he believed as many as 200 inmates were buried on the grounds, but only the three bodies were found. Police and a forensic anthropologist said they had been buried in what was an old but well-known paupers' grave. Rockefeller accused Murton of turning the investigation into a ``sideshow,'' and a grand jury accused him of seeking publicity for himself. Murton left Arkansas shortly thereafter, forming the Murton Foundation for Criminal Justice in 1968. He acknowledged years later that the foundation, designed to help current and former inmates and officers who had suffered abuses in the prison system, never was successful. Through most of the 1970s Murton taught criminology at the University of Minnesota and later worked on his mother's farm. He wrote two books, ``Accomplices to the Crime: The Arkansas Prison Scandal'' and ``The Dilemma of Prison Reform.'' Survivors include his father, mother and four children.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Turning to Big Business for Financial Help, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress, which for years has called for nationalizing big business, is now asking corporations for financial help, a newspaper reported today. ANC leaders, including Nelson Mandela, have approached at least two major corporations in South Africa and are expected to approach a third soon, said Business Day, the country's leading financial daily. No financial commitments have been made, the newspaper said, quoting unidentified business sources. Corporate representatives said they were wary of offering money, given the ANC's past hostility toward big business. ``We would certainly first demand answers to questions about their intentions on economic policy, and particularly whether they expect us to support a party whose strategy is to break us up,'' it quoted one business spokesman as saying. For years, the ANC supported nationalizing mines, banks and other large businesses. Recently it has been more vague, saying utilities should be nationalized and the future of other corporations left open to debate. The ANC has an ideological preference for socialism, saying there is an urgent need to bridge the gap between white wealth and black poverty. But the anti-apartheid organization has acknowledged that the private sector will play an important role in creating jobs and other opportunities for the country's 30 million blacks. According to Business Day, the ANC is hoping to raise millions of dollars to pay for a range of activities, including resettlement of returning exiles and the purchase of office equipment. It said one of the businesses approached was Anglo-American, a gold-mining corporation that is South Africa's largest conglomerate. Anglo-American chairman Julian Ogilvie Thompson met with Mandela on Oct. 3. The company refused to comment on the meeting. Another large South African corporation has been asked for money, and a third expects to be approached soon, Business Day said. Representatives of both spoke to Business Day on condition the corporations not be identified. Both said the idea of funding party political activities also was of concern, and they might be inclined to limit donations to social projects, such as resettlement of exiles.

DOC.HEAD: Reds Go Up 2-0 in World Series
DOC.TEXT: The Cincinnati Reds opened up a two games-to-none World Series lead over the Oakland A's when Joe Oliver singled home a run in the 10th inning off ace reliever Dennis Eckersley for a 5-4 victory. Reds outfielder Billy Hatcher enjoyed his second consecutive perfect night, making him 7-for-7 with four doubles and a triple. He now holds the Series record for consecutive hits. On Tuesday, the Reds beat Dave Stewart, the A's four-time 20-game winner, 7-0. Teams that have taken a two games-to-none lead have gone on to win the World Series 31 times in 41 chances. Game 3 of the best-of-seven series will be in Oakland on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: New York's Fiscal Savior of '70s Says City Again Facing Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The fiscal watchdog who helped rescue New York from the brink of bankruptcy 15 years ago says the city is spending its way toward an even worse financial crisis - and he's getting out now. Felix Rohatyn, who has run the Municipal Assistance Corporation since its creation in 1975, said Wednesday he will step down as chairman at the end of the year. The 62-year-old investment banker said he wants to spend more time with his wife, who is recovering from surgery, but he also expressed frustration at his inability to persuade Mayor David Dinkins of the seriousness of the city's troubles. He said the city's problems are financial, economic and social and are of proportions that ``I haven't seen in 40 years.'' Dinkins replied, ``Reasonable people can differ. I don't know that his position and mind are so far apart anyway.'' Rohatyn has headed MAC since its creation in 1975 to assist the city by using sales tax revenues to back municipal bonds. New York was near bankruptcy at the time and Rohatyn was one of the architects of its recovery. Among the current financial problems Rohatyn cited are a predicted budget shortfall of $300 million to $500 million for fiscal 1991 and a gap for fiscal 1992 that begins at $1.4 billion. He also said union leaders are helping lead the city toward financial ruin by making unrealistic salary demands. He urged that a 5.5 percent raise recently promised teachers be rescinded and the money put into city coffers to strengthen New York's credit rating. Teachers union president Sandra Feldman said Rohatyn ``is really meddling with things that are not really his affair.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge To Order Probe of Paramount Books
DOC.TEXT: The judge in Art Buchwald's lawsuit against Paramount Pictures named an entertainment accountant to look at the studio's books. Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider is trying to establish how much Paramount owes Buchwald and his producing partner for their script that ultimately became the Eddie Murphy blockbuster ``Coming to America.'' Franklin Johnson, a managing partner of Price Waterhouse of Los Angeles, was chosen Wednesday by the judge to help him figure out how risky moviemaking is. The judge previously ruled that Paramount stole Buchwald's idea and owes him a share of the profits. Paramount claims that the film, which has grossed some $300 million, has never shown a net profit and Buchwald and his partner, Alain Bernheim, are owed nothing. The two claim they are owed between $6.9 million and $14.6 million. Paramount says ``winners pay for losers'' in the movie business and profits from hits are diluted by losses incurred by box office bombs.

DOC.HEAD: Reading the Woolly Worm Fur: Brace For a Cold Winter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT spelling of Vermilion.
DOC.TEXT: Start rummaging for your long underwear, flannel sheets and electric socks. The ninth annual Lee County Woolly Worm Survey, issued today, says there's a cold winter ahead. The folksy forecast of Kentucky's winter weather is based on the coloring of caterpillars, known locally as woolly worms. The number of foggy mornings in August, inner designs of persimmon seeds and the height of hornet's nests also are factored into the forecast. ``The Lee County woolly worms are never in error,'' said Rosemary Porter Kilduff of Beattyville in rural eastern Kentucky. Mrs. Kilduff compiles woolly worm sightings in and about Lee County and releases the winter forecast in time for Lee County's annual Woolly Worm Festival, which begins Friday. Organizers expect Lee County's population of 7,000 will double with visitors for the woolly worm races, crafts show and a '50s street dance. A parade will feature Tasha Harris of Beattyville, Miss Woolly Worm Festival Queen for 1990. Lee County residents hope the caterpillar's predictions someday will gain the same status in forecasting as Punxsutawney Phil. Movements of the Pennsylvania groundhog foretell the coming of spring on Groundhog Day. This fall, 88 of the 188 woolly worms sighted were black. ``With black in the lead, it pains me to say that we can predict a very, very cold winter from beginning to quit,'' Mrs. Kilduff said. The 25 foggy mornings in August mean there will be 25 days of snow. A sighting of a hornet's nest low to the ground means the snow won't stay around long, she added. The communities of Vermilion, Ohio, and Banner Elk, N.C., also forecast winter's severity with the caterpillars. Vermilion forecaster Willis ``Goodnews'' Gebheart predicted chilly weather for Ohio after examining the bugs, called woollybears up North. ``The thick overcoats on the Ohio woollybears are as dark as a tax collector's heart - the sign of an unusual snowy and cold winter,'' he wrote in a Beattyville weekly paper. Mrs. Kilduff turns the Woolly Worm survey over to the National Weather Service station in nearby Jackson to aid in their forecasting. Gil Russell, official in charge of the station, promised to take Mrs. Kilduff's forecast into consideration. Last year, the woolly worm forecast accurately predicted an early cold winter in Kentucky, followed by a warming trend. But the worms' prediction of a harsh ending to winter didn't occur. ``There are some things I hear in folklore that I can make some kind of scientific reason for, but woolly worms is not one of them,'' Russell said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It Will Sell Oil for $21 a Barrel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throut with quote, stated reason, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today that it is willing to sell its oil to all sides in the Persian Gulf conflict, including the United States, for $21 per barrel, OPEC's benchmark price before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The announcement appeared a sign that Iraq was feeling the pinch of the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade, which is being enforced by a naval blockade, and seeking to entice nations into abandoning the alliance arrayed against it. Iraq already has offered to give oil free of charge to Third World countries, but there have been no reports of any takers. Oil had been Iraq's only significant source of export earnings and Baghdad is not now able to sell its crude on the open market. Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Chalabi proposed that payments for Iraqi oil be placed in an escrow fund because of the U.N. sanctions. ``We accept that the price of sold oil is not to be transfered to Iraq but to deposit according to a special arrangement, and Iraq will not deal with it normally until we get over this crisis, and when the problems settle down on the bases of relations empty from any crisis,'' Chalabi said. Chalabi said the offer was made to stem the rise of world oil prices. He said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein approved the measure to fulfill Iraq's ``humanitarian role.'' Oil has nearly doubled in price to about $40 per barrel since Iraq touched off the crisis by seizing oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Iraqi announcement appeared aimed at trying to get countries that are feeling the economic pinch of high oil prices to losing their resolve and abandon the embargo on trade with Iraq. A prominent Kuwaiti economist, Jassem al-Saadoun of the al-Shall financial house, estimated Wednesday that the U.N. embargo is costing the Iraqis $54 million a day. Prior to the invasion, Iraq's OPEC production quota was 3.1 million barrels of crude oil a day. Much of that, and Kuwait's production of 1.5 million barrels a day, has been replaced on the world market by production increases by Saudi Arabia and other OPEC countries. With the invasion, Iraq increased its share of world oil reserves to about 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Additional Allegations as Grunseth Releases Affidavits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS St. Paul, Minn.,-dated 3rd item pvs to UPDATE with Grunseth releasing affidavits denying impropriety at 1981 party
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Jon Grunseth has released affidavits from 16 people who attended a 1981 party to counter allegations that he swam nude with four teen-age girls. ``To the best of my recollection, the allegations of improprieties involving Jon Grunseth simply did not occur,'' Richard Chant said, a senior vice president of People Management,in an affidavit. Liane Nelson, 23, of Boston, and her cousin, Elizabeth Dwyer Mulay, 22, of San Jose, Calif., have alleged in sworn statements that Grunseth encouraged them, his daughter Nina, now 23, and Lisa Hare, now 25, to join him for a nude swim. Nelson was 14 at the time; Mulay was 13. Hare has confirmed most of the allegations raised by Nelson and Mulay, while Nina Grunseth has signed an affidavit denying them. According to all the affidavits prepared on Grunseth's behalf, the party was a wholesome, family event, with the focal point being the swimming pool. They said they observed none of the activities alleged by the women, although about half of them said they left the party by midnight. William and Ingrid Emstad said they stayed overnight at the Grunseth home in a room overlooking the pool. ``From approximately midnight until the morning, I did not observe or hear anyone in the pool,'' Emstad said. Grunseth and his campaign officials consistently have blamed Gov. Rudy Perpich for the accusations, saying they are part of a ``win-at-any-costs'' strategy. Nelson and Mulay have denied any contact with the Perpich campaign, and Perpich and his campaign officials have denied any connection to the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.N. Chief Says Military Action Against Iraq May Be Necessary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts first two grafs to CLARIFY that Perez de Cuellar saying use of military power is legal, rather than justified. Pickup 3rd, ``He said...''
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. secretary general was quoted today as saying the Security Council can authorize the use of military power in the Persian Gulf if the trade embargo fails to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``The U.N. Charter's Article 42 permits military action. Should the Security Council come to that decision, that would be completely legal,'' the weekly news magazine Stern quoted Javier Perez de Cuellar as saying. He said it's up to the Security Council to decide whether military action is needed or to wait and see whether the embargo against Iraq eventually forces it to leave Kuwait, Stern reported. ``It (the Security Council) can't strengthen the embargo and sanctions against Iraq, because everything possible has already been done,'' he was quoted as saying in an interview in New York. The U.N. chief reportedly said, ``At the moment I see little movement in the direction of a peaceful solution.'' He added, however, ``I will never be the first one to say there remains only a military solution of the conflict,'' Stern reported.

DOC.HEAD: Bembenek's Run After Prison Escape Ends With Capture in Canada
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14-17th grafs, bgng Ms. Bembenek was...', with 5 grafs to CORRECT last name of victim to Schultz sted Shultz; DELETE incorrect reference to TV movie about case; add detail. Picks up 18th graf pvs, `While on...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MI1 of Oct. 17, MI2
DOC.TEXT: The ``tabloid TV'' notoriety of a former Playboy waitress and policewoman convicted of murdering her husband's ex-wife helped lead to her capture three months after she escaped from prison. Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek, 31, was arrested at an apartment in Thunder Bay, Ontario, on Wednesday on a tip from a viewer of last week's episode of ``America's Most Wanted.'' Ms. Bembenek, who has steadfastly professed her innocence, was captured with her fiance, Dominic Gugliatto, 34. Her flight had thrilled supporters in Milwaukee - prompting sales of T-shirts that read, ``Run, Bambi, Run'' - and was covered on several ``tabloid TV'' shows, which played up her looks and the romantic elements of the escape. ``I think all the TV shows that have aired this thing in regard to Bembenek and Gugliatto have romanticized, and that concerned me a little bit early on - that people were getting so hung up on whether she was guilty or innocent that it kind of detracted from what we had to do, which was catch her,'' said Lt. Edwin Sheppard of the Fond du Lac Sheriff's Department. But ``obviously in this case, it's a success story for `America's Most Wanted,' '' he said. ``We're glad they chose to do it.'' Ms. Bembenek and Gugliatto, who had scheduled a prison chapel wedding before the escape, were being held without bail. Sheriff James Gilmore said extradition proceedings could begin next week. ``I wish she would have got away,'' said Deter Day, 32, of Milwaukee. ``She was dealt injustice by the Wisconsin judicial system, and I think the case should be looked into further.'' ``I hope she enjoyed her freedom while she had it,'' said Ann Martel, 31, also of Milwaukee. An anonymous tip from a California man the fugitive had served while working as a waitress led to the arrest, authorities said. Thunder Bay Detective Ron Arthurs, pursuing the tip, interviewed Ms. Bembenek on Wednesday at the restaurant where she had worked since July 23. When her only piece of identification, a birth certificate, didn't check out, officers went to her apartment and found the couple about to move on, Gilmore said. ``She obviously made a call: `Pack up let's go.' The car was packed. They think it was probably five minutes'' before they would have fled, the sheriff said. Once a waitress at the now-defunct Playboy Club in Lake Geneva, Ms. Bembenek became a police officer in Milwaukee in the late 1970s. She was fired in 1980 for lying. The following year, Ms. Bembenek was convicted of murder in the killing of Christine Schultz, the ex-wife of her then-husband, Elfred Schultz, a Milwaukee detective. They were divorced after her conviction. Prosecutors contended Ms. Schultz, who was bound, gagged and shot in the back, was murdered because Ms. Bembenek resented the $700-a-month alimony Schultz was ordered to pay his ex-wife. Supporters contend she may have been the victim of a frame-up because of her knowledge of questionable police activities. They noted that one of Ms. Schultz's young sons had testified that the person seen in the house the night of the killing was not Ms. Bembenek. Ms. Bembenek escaped July 15 from the Taycheedah Correctional Institute near Fond du Lac. While on the lam, Ms. Bembenek worked as a waitress at the Columbia Grill and Tavern and also worked as an aerobics instructor, said her landlord, Jenny Beck. She knew Ms. Bembenek as Jennifer Gazzana, someone who said she fled Chicago with her husband, Tony, to find a simpler life. ``They were disenchanted with the American way of life,'' Ms. Beck said. ``She certainly didn't like the violence in the states.'' She described her tenant as a friend, a hard worker and a smart, polite, beautiful woman. ``I felt safe having her in the house,'' Ms. Beck said. Gugliatto, a lawn mower factory worker from suburban Milwaukee, faces a charge of aiding Ms. Bembenek's escape and a possible five-year sentence, authorities said. Ms. Bembenek could have five years added to her life prison term. Ms. Bembenek was one of 122 fugitives apprehended after being profiled on ``America's Most Wanted'' since the show began in 1988, said Jack Breslin, spokesman for the Fox Broadcasting Co. show. ``It was a phenomenal amount of interest, not only in terms of local interest, but in national interest,'' said Jon Wendt, FBI agent in charge of the bureau's Milwaukee office. ``It was far beyond our normal interest in an unlawful flight.''

DOC.HEAD: Children's Proposal To Lawmakers: Make Everyone Laugh A Little
DOC.TEXT: There ought to be a law: Sisters can't open your birthday presents and everybody has to laugh once a day. Those were among the ideas for new legislation offered to Gov. Neil Goldschmidt by about 3,500 youngsters from throughout the state who gathered on the Capitol lawn Wednesday to celebrate Children's Day in Oregon. Some other suggestions read by children at the celebration: - Restaurants must have computers so patrons can order their food easily. - If you are in an airplane crash and survive, you should get your money back. - All official announcements must be written in Spanish, too. Goldschmidt wore a Groucho Marx nose and glasses - his ``Arthur Goldfish'' disguise - as he brandished the document proclaiming Oct. 17 as Children's Day in Oregon. Cake, ice cream, songs, face painting, magic displays and puppet shows were offered to the children.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Soviets From Stranded Soviet Circus Apply for Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen members of a bankrupt Soviet all-star circus have applied for political asylum, and hope to restart their troupe in the United States. The members of the Great Circus Bim Bom - nine performers and crew members and their families - applied for political asylum Wednesday, claiming they would be treated unfairly and blocked from pursuing their careers if they returned to the Soviet Union. Tom Fischer, regional director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said they were granted a one-year work permit as the INS began a 90-day evaluation. The circus members said they would take whatever jobs they could find to earn money to restart their troupe. ``The circus was our life. We will do anything to get it back,'' said Vadim Lomakin, whose act included chimpanzees who can ski. Last spring, 118 members of Bim Bom began a two-year tour of the United States. But they ran into problems with the tour promoter and went bankrupt after just two U.S. performances. Financial backers then pulled out and creditors seized the animals and equipment. Bankrupt, the circus came here in May, hoping to raise money and get the show back on the road. Three months later, they were rescued. The promoter of the rival Moscow Circus paid some of Bim Bom's debts and brought most of its performers and their families home. Last week, most of the animals and equipment were returned to Moscow, said Dale Schwartz, an immigration lawyer representing the remaining members. Circus director Yuri Turkin said the four Bim Bom families who remained are afraid to return because Soviet newspapers are blaming the circus' failure on the performers who refused to return home. ``The Ministry of Culture of the Soviet Union is blaming the situation on the circus members who stayed in the United States, even though the circus wasn't given one dollar or any help at all to get out of trouble by the government,'' Turkin said. ``If we went back, we would never be able to perform our art again.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Minister Sends Apology Letter to U.S. Black Caucus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Japanese legislators planning trip to U.S. Pickup 7th graf `After a...'
DOC.TEXT: A Cabinet minister whose racial remarks infuriated American blacks has sent a letter of apology to black U.S. lawmakers who demanded that he step down, Foreign Ministry officials said today. A group of Japanese legislators, meanwhile, said today they planned to visit the United States to explain the remarks made by Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, who compared blacks to prostitutes. Kajiyama's letter of apology was delivered Wednesday in Washington by Japanese Ambassador Ryohei Murata to Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., officials said. Dellums chairs the 24-member U.S. Congresional Black Caucus. Murata asked Dellums to reconsider the caucus' resolution urging President Bush to demand Kajiyama's resignation and an official apology from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, a ministry official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Murata had not yet received a reply. Kaifu has expressed regret and rebuked Kajiyama but refused to fire him. The caucus resolution was presented to the House of Representatives shortly after Kajiyama's racial slur on Sept. 21. Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, told a news conference today that the party will send a group of lawmakers to the United States on Sunday. Ozawa said the delegation will meet with congressional leaders, including the Black Caucus, in hope of heading off the resolution demanding Kajiyama's resignation. He said passage of the resolution ``could damage the relations between Japan and the United States.'' After a police roundup of foreign prostitutes in Tokyo, Kajiyama compared the prostitutes to blacks in the United States. ``The area is becoming mixed just like in America where blacks move in and whites are forced out,'' he told reporters. In his letter, Kajiyama said there was no intent of racial discrimination behind his comment, but ``I learned again how deeply I have hurt the feelings of the American people, particular of the African-Americans. ``What I thoughtlessly said on Sept. 21 was wrong and grossly improper,'' he added. ``Although I am acutely aware how difficult it is to heal the wounds that my remarks inflicted, I will personally do whatever I can to strengthen Japan's relationship with the African-American community.'' Ambassadors from six African countries sent a letter of protest to Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. Black residents' groups in Japan demonstrated in front of the Justice Ministry. In the United States, civil rights groups launched a boycott of Japanese products, and the mayor of Trenton, N.J., Douglas Palmer, said a planned visit by a delegation of the Tokyo metropolitan government was not welcome. The Japanese officials had been scheduled to visit the city to study garbage-disposal methods. Kajiyama is the latest Japanese politician to offend minorities with public racial remarks. In 1986, then Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said Americans have a lower intelligence level than Japanese because the population includes a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans. In 1988, former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said American blacks have few qualms about going bankrupt and implied that tey walk away from debts.

DOC.HEAD: 477-Year-Old Manuscript Taken During War Returned to Germany
DOC.TEXT: A 477-year-old manuscript taken from Germany by an American soldier at the end of World War II has been returned to its homeland. The law firm Andrews & Kurth said Wednesday the Evangelister manuscript, noted for its silver cover containing the figure of Jesus Christ, was returned earlier this month and is being restored in Munich. American soldier Joe T. Meador, who died in 1980, brought the manuscript and several other items to America in 1945 from Quedlinburg. They eventually wound up in the hands of First National Bank of Whitewright. This is the second piece of Quedlinburg treasure recovered by the German Cultural Foundation of the States. The Samuhel Gospels, made in the 10th century, was recovered in Switzerland for a $3 million finder's fee, according to reports from the New York Times. The Lutheran Church is suing for the return of the other works, which are being held in a Dallas museum.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Benefits to Increase 5.4 percent in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs. Minor editing througout
DOC.TEXT: The nation's 40 million Social Security recipients will see their benefit checks increase by 5.4 percent starting in January, the biggest advance in 8{ years, the government said today. That increase will translate into an extra $31 per month for the average retired worker, whose monthly check will increase from $571 to $602. The maximum monthly benefit for a worker retiring in 1991 at age 65 will rise by $47, to $1,022. Since 1975, benefits have risen automatically each year, keeping pace with the annual inflation rate with the exception of six months in 1983 that were skipped to help bail the Social Security system out of a crisis. The exact size of the 1991 increase became official today when the Labor Department announced September's 0.8 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index, the inflation measure used to determine cost-of-living increases for the Social Security program. The 5.4 percent increase, which will show up in the Jan. 3 benefit checks, followed a 4.7 percent increase that took effect last January and a 4 percent increase in 1989. It was the largest increase since a 7.4 percent jump in July 1982, when high inflation rates translated into bigger cost-of-living increases. The 5.4 percent increase in 1991 also applies to the nation's 4.5 million recipients of Supplemental Security Income, which provides a minimum income floor for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled. The maximum federal SSI payment will rise by $21, to $407 per month, for an individual and by $31, to $610, for a couple. The government also said today that the maximum amount of wages subject to the payroll tax that finances Social Security benefits will climb from $51,300 to $53,400 next year. That change will boost taxes for about 10 million higher-income workers who earn above the current wage cap. The tax rate of 7.65 percent, which finances both the Social Security and Medicare programs, would remain unchanged next year. But higher-income workers may still see a bigger bite taken out of their paychecks, depending on what type of deficit-reduction bill finally emerges from Congress. Both the House and Senate are considering proposals to boost the amount of wages subject to the Medicare portion of the payroll tax. The House measure would increase the wage cap to $100,000. However, neither chamber is considering trimming Social Security benefit checks as a way of reducing the huge federal deficit. Even though Social Security is the government's biggest spending program after national defense, efforts to cut benefits in the past have triggered a heavy backlash from retirees. The Social Security Administration gave these examples of how the 5.4 percent increase will affect average monthly benefits: -Aged couple, both getting benefits: up $52, to $1,022. -Widowed mother and two children: up $62, to $1,203. -Disabled worker, spouse and children: up $52, to $1,022. -All disabled workers: up $30, to $587. ``For the 42 million people who receive Social Security and Supplemental Security Income checks each month, this cost-of-living adjustment will be their assurance that those checks will continue to allow them to pay for needed goods and services,'' said Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn S. King. At the start of this year, Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., attracted attention with a proposal to reduce the Social Security payroll tax to reflect the fact that the system is producing more revenue for the federal government than Social Security is paying out in benefits - an estimated $74 billion more for the 1991 fiscal year. However, with lawmakers trying to bridge a yawning budget gap, Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes never advanced in Congress. The payroll tax was 1 percent of income up to $3,000 when Social Security started in 1937. It stayed at that rate until 1950 but has been boosted since that time with the current rate set by a 1983 rescue plan passed by Congress to bail the system out of recurrent financing problems.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Part of Beirut's Green Line Being Dismantled
DOC.TEXT: Government bulldozers today began dismantling the oldest section of the so-called Green Line that has divided Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors for more than 15 years. Police said government troops were removing mines along the heavily fortified 1.2-mile strip that has separated the Christian district of Ein Rummaneh and the Moslem quarter of Shiyah since the civil war broke out. Government bulldozers were also dismantling other parts of the Green Line and reopening roads linking the Christian and Moslem sectors of the capital and the central mountains to the east and northeast, police said. The demarcation line began taking shape April 13, 1975, when Moslems in Shiyah opened fire at Christians in Ein Rummaneh, in retaliation for an attack by Christian militiamen of the Phlange party that had killed 27 Palestinians and wounded 19. President Elias Hrawi's government decided to reunify Beirut after crushing rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's mutiny in an air and ground assault Saturday that police said left 160 dead and about 800 wounded. Most of Aoun's 15,000 troops declared allegiance to Hrawi's army under Gen. Emile Lahoud. At least six of the defeated general's intelligence officers were known to have been arrested by Syrian troops. Meanwhile, Aoun was spending a sixth day holed up in the French Embassy in Beirut's Christian suburb of Hazmiyeh. Hrawi's government continued to ask foreign banks to freeze Aoun's accounts in preparation to bring him to trial. France on Saturday granted Aoun asylum, but Lebanon said it will not allow him to leave and that he has to face a court of law for war crimes and the alleged theft of $75 million from the ailing state treasury. Voice of the Nation, the Moslem radio station, said today that Aoun's stay in the embassy was ``expected to be long.'' ``No settlement is in the offing to the diplomatic differences between Lebanon and France over Aoun,'' the radio said. In Paris today, riot police removed about 50 Lebanese demonstrators from the Lebanese Embassy, which they had occupied for five days in a show of support for Aoun. Police said there was no violence. Hrawi's government plans to create a militia-free zone covering the capital's Moslem and Christian sectors and their immediate suburbs as the first step toward disbanding militias in the country and ending the civil war. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said contacts were under way with commanders of leftist militias to withdraw them from the 80-square-mile area formerly controlled by Aoun. The leftist newspaper As-Safir said Hrawi will visit the Syrian capital, Damascus, ``in the coming few days'' for talks with President Hafez Assad on the plan. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon with 40,000 troops deployed mainly in predominantly Moslem sectors under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 21-nation Arab League. Hrawi's plan would be in line with an Arab League-brokered peace pact to disband all the warring militias and end the war, which has killed more than 150,000 people. The peace pact, ratified by Parliament in August 1989, divides power equally between Moslems and Christians. The nation has a population of 4 million, belonging to 17 sects. Aoun had rejected the peace plan and refused to recognize Hrawi as head of state, saying the president was a ``Syrian puppet.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Suggests Curfew, National Guard Help, To Combat Crime
DOC.TEXT: Washington Mayor Marion Barry, saying that ``something drastically different'' must be done to combat murder on the capital's streets, has suggested invoking neighborhood curfews and calling out the National Guard. The recent rash of homicides is ``getting out of hand,'' Barry said Wednesday night after a forum for candidates competing for at-large seats on the District of Columbia Council. ``We have got to do something drastically different,'' ``The police chief is as frustrated about this as I am. We can't let this keep up,'' he said. A total of 373 homicides have been reported so far this year. Last year a record 434 deaths were reported. On Monday, after a weekend during which nine slayings were recorded, Police Chief Isaac Fulwood Jr. announced that he had created a unit of 100 officers to fight the problem. That squad is scheduled to begin operation on Sunday. But Barry said that if there was no sign the unit has slowed the homicide rate after about a month, he would establish a nightly curfew in neighborhoods where crime and violence are high. If that plan doesn't work, the National Guard would be called in, he added. Barry is one of seven candidates running for two at-large positions on the council. During his drug and perjury trial this summer when he was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession, he announced he would not seek a fourth, four-year term. Council attempts to impose a curfew for anyone under 18 have been rejected twice this year in the courts. Barry's plan, however, is broader than the voided laws. He suggested the curfew apply not only to juveniles but to all residents in neighborhoods ``where people are killing each other.'' Barry has previously rejected calls for National Guard help, saying in 1988, ``The city is not out of control.'' Wednesday night, however, he said Guard help may be needed ``if all else fails.''

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Head Says Diplomatic Progress Slow, Military Action Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with U.S. economic reports, U.N. agreement on seeking war damages from Iraq, protests in Japan against troop deployment, Japanese captives freed. Edits to TRIM. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM1
DOC.TEXT: U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar was quoted today as saying he sees little progress toward peacefully ending the Persian Gulf crisis. He raised the possibility the Security Council could authorize military action against Iraq. At the United Nations, the five permanent Security Council members have reached general agreement on a draft resolution that would require Iraq to pay for damages stemming from its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, diplomats said today. Countries that have suffered serious economic losses stemming from the invasion - such as Jordan, India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh - could apply for compensation out of Iraq's foreign assets, which have been frozen, or from future oil earnings, the diplomats said. No date has been set for the full Security Council to consider the matter. In an interview with the German news magazine Stern, the secretary general said the U.N. Security Council ``can't strengthen the embargo and sanctions against Iraq, because everything possible has already been done.'' But Perez de Cuellar added he would ``never be the first one to say there remains only a military solution of the conflict,'' the magazine said. In Washington, the 12-week-old gulf crisis was blamed for some bad economic news in the United States. The jump in energy prices brought on by the crisis sent Americans' cost of living up 0.8 percent in September, matching the increase the month before, the government said. It was also announced today that the U.S. merchandise trade deficit had jumped 2.4 percent in August, spurred by the high price of oil imports. Iraq, meanwhile, said it was willing to sell oil for $21 a barrel, about half the market price. The announcement appeared aimed at trying to undermine the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq, imposed to try to force an end to the occupation of Kuwait. Iraq already has offered free oil to the Third World, but there have been no reports of any takers willing to get around a naval blockade. On the diplomatic front, Soviet envoy and Middle East expert Yevgeny Primakov headed to Washington today for talks with President Bush. ``I remain a prudent optimist,'' Primakov said after talks with French President Francois Mitterrand in Paris on Wednesday. ``I think the Iraqi position could still become more flexible.'' Primakov met in Baghdad with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last month and has been quoted as saying Iraq might withdraw from most of Kuwait as part of a settlement. Also today, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze arrived in Vienna for consultations with his French counterpart, Roland Dumas, about European security and the gulf crisis. Asked by reporters if he was bringing any new ideas to his meeting with Dumas, Shevardnadze said: ``It's difficult to talk about new ideas. I have not brought any ready made concept with me. Nobody has one.'' In other gulf-related developments: -About 250 Japanese police entered the Kyoto University campus in western Japan and arrested two students occupying the dean's office. The students were protesting a plan to send Japanese troops to the gulf region in non-combat roles. Police also said about 80 people rallied outside the Foreign Ministry in Tokyo to protest the plan, which was introduced this week in Parliament. -Three Japanese nationals who had been held in Baghdad but were given exit visas by the Iraqis arrived in Amman, Jordan, today and then left for London. A fourth Japanese was scheduled to arrive later in the day. The Japanese Embassy said 140 Japanese remained in Kuwait and 185 in Iraq. Perez de Cuellar, in his magazine interview, pointed out that the United Nations legally has the power to authorize military action against Iraq. ``The U.N. Charter's Article 42 permits military action. Should the Security Council come to that decision, that would be completely legal,'' Stern quoted the U.N. secretary general as saying. ``At the moment I see little movement in the direction of a peaceful solution,'' he told the weekly. Baghdad seized Kuwait in a dispute over oil, land and money and now has an estimated 430,000 troops on Kuwaiti soil. Combined with its own oilfields, Iraq now controls about 20 percent of the world's crude. About 200,000 U.S. soldiers have been sent to region to stand up to Saddam. They lead a multinational land, air and naval force that has dug in in the Saudi desert and is enforcing a U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Ice Across Parts of Dakotas, Minnesota; Rain in Lower Midwest, South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to update with snow today in Mich. and across Upper Midwest on Wednesday, recast and tighten, picking up at the 9th graf, `-East: Albany...'.
DOC.TEXT: Michigan got its first snow of the season today from a storm that spread snow and ice across the Dakotas and parts ofMinnesota, and rain fell across much of the rest of the Midwest. Rain also fell in parts of the South early today, and in the Pacific Northwest. The first snow of the season fell in much of Michigan's western Upper Peninsula early today while cold rain and falling temperatures hit lower Michigan. The National Weather Service said 3 to 5 inches of snow fell in Houghton and Calumet by 7:45 a.m. State Police Sgt. Bob Johnson in Calumet said several vehicles slid off the road as heavy, wet snow coated roads and hampered visibility. ``It's really treacherous driving out there,'' he said. ``The first one always catches them by surprise.'' Elsewhere in Michigan, high wind knocked out power for some Detroit Edison Co. and Consumers Power Co. customers early this morning. Consumers Power spokesman Paul Knopick said about 7,800 customers lost service. On Wednesday, snow blanketed much of North and South Dakota and Minnesota, and even northwestern Iowa got about an inch. Up to 5 inches fell in parts of South Dakota, where one traffic death was blamed on the snow and ice, and an inch remained on the ground today in Aberdeen, Huron and Sioux Falls. Elsewhere today, rain was forecast along the Pacific Coast from northern California to British Columbia, with snow expected in the mountains of Washington state. Rain was forecast ahead of a cold front pushing into the East, with a possibility of tornadoes developing along the front from Virginia to New York. Pockets of rain were expected in the Rockies. The nation's high Wednesday was 96 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., and McAllen, Texas.
