DOC.HEAD: Freighter Sinks; Crew Rescued
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with small diesel spill; CORRECTS ship name to Raychel, sted Rachel; CORRECTS ship length to 164 sted 150 feet. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran-registered freighter sank two miles offshore early today after its load of construction material shifted, and all nine crew members were rescued from life rafts unharmed, the Coast Guard said. The 164-foot freighter Raychel went down in 43 feet of water shortly after midnight after stopping at Miami, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Jennifer Hogg. ``The freighter was carrying a load of construction material - cinder blocks, wood, nails - that nature,'' Hogg said. ``The report we received is that the load shifted and the vessel capsized.'' A small amount of the ship's 5,500 gallons of diesel fuel had leaked by daylight, said Petty Officer Buddy Dye. ``What has come out so far is not really a concern,'' Dye said. ``There is a sheen visible from the air, but they believe it will dissipate on its own. There are choppy seas out there, and it's very light and easily dissipated.'' A Florida Marine Patrol diver was assigned to plug fuel vents to keep any more fuel from spilling, and Coast Guard crews planned to check nearby beaches for any signs of the oil, Dye said. The ship went down by the approach channel for the port of Miami but was not blocking the waterway, which is heavily traveled by freighters and cruise ships, Hogg said. The crew included three Americans, she said. She said the Coast Guard will decide whether the freighter will have to be raised to keep the area clear.

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Legislative Leader Presses Demands on Kremlin
DOC.TEXT: The deputy chairman of the Ukrainian legislature pressed the republic's sovereignty demands on the Kremlin today, one day after student-led protests forced the Ukrainian prime minister to quit. In the Ukraine's boldest separatist action yet, two weeks of mass demonstrations, hunger strikes and classroom boycotts culminated Wednesday in the resignation Prime Minister Vitaly Masol. The Ukrainian legislature also passed a resolution embracing the students' demands, including the transfer of ownership of Communist Party property to the government and refusal to sign a new treaty of union proposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Tass reported. The unrest in the nation's second most populous republic - combined with sharp criticism by Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin of Gorbachev's latest economic reform plan - could hurt Gorbachev's efforts to forge a new treaty of union with the 15 diverse republics. The proposed treaty would link the republics in a loose confederation and redefine their political and economic links with the central government. The economic reform plan would give them more control over property and some prices. Republic leaders and liberal national lawmakers have criticized both initiatives as insufficient. ``Interestingly, the right and the left have the same demand about refusing to sign the union treaty,'' Vladimir Grinev, deputy chairman of the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet, said in an interview published today. ``The center sometimes looks on our declarations as adults' games. But it is from such declarations that the new state order will merge - an association of free states,'' Grinev told Komsomolskaya Pravda, the youth newspaper. ``Union law can only become law if ratified by the republics. We came to Moscow to get that across to the president and Defense Ministry.'' The protesters insist Ukranian conscripts be allowed to serve within the republic, a demand echoed by other republics but rejected by the ministry. Most of the 15 republics and many smaller provinces within them have declared some form of independence or sovereignty from central authorities. Most say they want independence first, and will then decide whether to voluntarily join any new confederation with the Kremlin.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Former Providence Mayor Cianci Missed Tax Filing Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Mayoral candidate Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. missed the deadline to file his 1989 tax returns, a newspaper reported today. Cianci's accountant, Daniel Kieliszak, said he has asked for a 30-day extension, until Nov. 15, to file the federal and state returns. But Internal Revenue Service spokesmen in Rhode Island and Washington told The Providence Journal-Bulletin that there is no provision in the federal tax code that allows for extensions more than six months beyond the April 15 filing date. The state Division of Taxation has the same rules, the newspaper said. Kieliszak said Cianci has not received some bank statements that he needs to file complete returns. Cianci, a former mayor who is running as an independent, has made public his 1987 and 1988 filings and promised to disclose his 1989 return as soon as it was ready. His opponents have already released their returns for the three years. ``It is not finished and I am not going to release an incomplete return,'' Cianci said Wednesday. A late income tax filing is a civil infraction if the government is owed money, said IRS spokesman Frank Keith. Penalties of at least 5 percent a month, plus interest on the amount due, could be assessed. There is no penalty if the taxpayer is due a refund. Elected mayor as a Republican in 1974, Cianci was forced out of office 10 years later after he attacked his estranged wife's lover with a fireplace log, an ashtray and a lit cigarette. He pleaded no contest to two assault charges, and in April 1984 he received a five-year suspended sentence and probation.

DOC.HEAD: City Police Said to Link Border Police Presence to Temple Mount Riot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with 35 Arabs wounded in Gaza. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Israel-Infighting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: City police commanders say the deployment of border policemen without their knowledge on the Temple Mount was a main factor behind last week's riots in which 19 Arabs were killed, Israel radio said. The disclosure was the first Israeli suggestion that police could have provoked the violence at the Jerusalem holy site. Arab witnesses have said police set off the violence, the worst in the 34-month Palestinian uprraeli occupation. In the occupied Gaza Strip today, at least 35 Palestinians were shot and wounded with bullets and rubber-coated steel balls in a seven-hour clash with soldiers in the Rafah refugee camp, Arab reports said. Witising against Isnesses told Palestinian reporters stoning started after soldiers raised an Israeli flag on a building in the camp, apparently in an effort to make it a headquarters. They said the clash ended when soldiers withdrew to just outside the camp. The army said it was checking the report. The radio report did not identify the police commanders who made the statements on the Temple Mount riots. But it said it was quoting testimony they gave before a three-member committee deployment of troops, there was no force mentioned that was supposed to be stationed on the Temple Mount,'' the radio said, quoting the testimony. It said the force was only discovered once another group of police stormed the Mount when stones came down on worshipers at the Wall, injuring 28 people. A separate probe of the killings has also been opened by a magistrates court judge. Jerusalem police spokesman Elhayan said it was a routine inquiry mandated by law into any violent incident. The Hadashot daily said the investigating judge may request autopsies on the 19 victims. The riot raised tensions in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where more than a million Palestinians were kept under curfew for a week to prevent unrest. Most restrictions were lifted by Tuesday. In the West Bank city of Nablus, merchants shuttered their shops for a second day in mourning for Temple Mount victims.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Reforms Will Cause Inflation, Job Losses, Economists Say
DOC.TEXT: Two leading economic advisers to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that the Soviet leader's plan for introducing a market economy would cause severe inflation and unemployment. Abel Aganbegyan told Soviet lawmakers in a one-hour report that preliminary steps toward a market system had already created an ``inflationary spiral,'' particularly for prices of meat and dairy products. He warned that hyperinflation was likely despite measures in the Gorbachev plan designed to combat runaway prices, such as restricting the nation's money supply and retaining state price controls on some items. Aganbegyan and another economist, Oleg Bogomolov, spoke to a meeting of several committees of the Supreme Soviet legislature before a full legislative session Friday, when Gorbachev is to formally present and defend his plan. Bogomolov said the Gorbachev plan for fails to identify potential victims of the transformation. He also said it should have established that no Soviet citizen's standard of living would be allowed to drop more than 25 percent. Bogomolov predicted the reforms were likely to halve the value of the ruble and force people to dip into their savings. Soviets have an estimated 500 billion rubles in savings because many necessities are subsidized by the state and few consumer goods are available. Both economists said the success of the Gorbachev plan hinged on cooperation from the 15 Soviet republics. The largest, Russia, has already rejected it and renewed threats to implement its own more radical program. Gorbachev's main political rival, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, has called the plan a ``catastrophe'' and said it would fail within months. But Aganbegyan said during a question-and-answer session with lawmakers that Yeltsin was criticizing Gorbachev's politics rather than his economics. ``He made a political speech and would have spoken this way regardless of what we had proposed,'' said Aganbegyan, who headed a 24-member commission that drafted one of the many economic reform plans considered by Gorbachev. The commission was appointed after the government's first proposals caused panic buying last spring and had to be scrapped. Aganbegyan also said Yeltsin's predictions could cause political instability resulting in millions of rubles of losses. He did not specify how that might happen. Gorbachev's four-stage blueprint begins by reducing the approximately $100 billion budget deficit and cutting the money supply. Efforts would also be made in the first stage to increase production of consumer goods and boost agricultural output through land reform. In the second stage, prices on roughly 70 percent of all goods and services would be freed to respond to market forces and small private businesses would be encouraged. The third stage would emphasize establishing a free market for housing, a modern banking system and entrepreneurship. The final stage would end government monopolies in many industries and allow the ruble to be freely traded against other world currencies. Gorbachev has set no timetable for his reforms but states other countries have achieved similar goals within 18 months to two years.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Member of Cambodian Dance Troupe Elects to Stay In U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The star of a Cambodian dance troupe that recently completed a U.S. tour has joined four fellow dancers in deciding to stay in the United States, at least for now. After intense questioning by frederal officials, Yim Devi decided not to leave with the rest of the troupe when its plane departed New York at 9 a.m. Wednesday, said her attorney, Martin Garbus. Four other members of the troupe defected earlier. Garbus declined to describe Devi's action as a defection, however, noting she may eventually change her mind. Her passport allows her to stay in the United States as a visitor until December. ``She's going to explore her options,'' Garbus said. ``She might stay two days, she might stay a week, who knows. She may want to pursue her studies here.'' Devi told police a Cambodian man tried to abduct her at knifepoint in New York on Oct. 8 and told her he would kill her if she didn't defect. Other members of the troupe reported receiving similar threats during the tour. Federal officials questioned the dancers individually Tuesday to see if any wanted to seek asylum, said Arthur Helton, director of the Refugee project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. Helton, who was hired by a relative of one of the defectors, said officials were concerned that those wanting to seek asylum were being denied the opportunity by Cambodian officials. Tour organizers said the dancers were the target of an organized network of Cambodian-Americans who were urging them to defect. The troupe's tour marked the first artistic exchange between the United States and Cambodia since 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Breaks Out Against Leftist Guerrillas In San Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with city calm today, government saying street protests expected. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The attack..'
DOC.TEXT: The army today drove off leftist guerrillas who attacked air force headquarters with homemade mortars and automatic weapons, and authorities said several people were wounded. A military spokesman said he had an initial report that one military mechanic was wounded and one aircraft was damaged in the three hours of fighting at Ilopango air base on the east side of the capital. A Red Cross spokesman said several people were wounded, but he did not immediately know the precise number. The fighting began at 9:45 p.m. Wednesday and died down after midnight. Helicopters were patrolling today, but the city was calm and traffic moving normally in most of the capital. In the eastern sector, near the air force headquarters, military roadblocks were set up to search vehicles for arms. ``The situation is now under the control of the armed forces,'' said the military spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity shortly after midnight. However, the government indicated it expected more trouble. It broadcast a communique saying leftist labor and student organizations planned to launch ``a series of provocative actions of street violence.'' The attack came exactly a month after yet another round of unsuccessful peace talks between rebels and the rightist government. A fifth round of U.N.-mediated peace talks between the rebels and the government of President Alfredo Cristiani had ended in a stalemate Sept. 18. Rebel commanders have said for weeks that an eventual stalemate at the negotiating table could provoke a major offensive. The two sides have agreed to meet again in Mexico before Nov. 4. Witnesses said Wednesday's attack began with a string of about 20 loud explosions, presumably caused by homemade mortars hurled from rebel catapults. Heavy small-arms fire followed for about 90 minutes, most of it on the edges of Ilopango and in the adjacent working neighborhood of Soyapango, as government paratroopers moved into the areas. At least four helicopters provided air support, dropping flares around the base and firing red tracer bullets and machine guns. As many as 100 rebels appeared to have been involved in the attack on the air force headquarters, located inside the base, a paratroop sergeant at the scene said. As soon as the fighting began, the eastern half of the city turned into a ghost town, with virtually everyone taking refuge in their homes. When the shooting died down, radio stations opened their air waves to residents wishing to inform relatives that they were unharmed and would spend the night in workplaces or at friends' rather than venture into the streets. Guerrilla leaders and government representatives have been negotiating unsuccessfully for more than a year to end the decade-old civil war. The guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front insist the military should be drastically reduced in numbers, and officers who violated human rights be prosecuted. The Cristiani government has balked at these requests, saying it would be tantamount to doing away with the armed forces. The killings caused an uproar in Washington and calls to scale back U.S. aid. Since 1980, the United States has provided more than $4 billion in economic and military aid to bolster a succession of Salvadoran governments. Human rights groups estimate more than 73,000 people have been killed since the war began in late 1979 in this country of 5 million people. Death squads linked to the military and right-wing extremists are blamed for a large percentage of the deaths.

DOC.HEAD: FBI: Blow Struck Against Hells Angels Nationwide in Amphetamine Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: Authorities struck a blow to Hells Angels motorcycle clubs that traffic in methamphetamines when they arrested 15 people in the Omaha area and one in California, an FBI agent said. ``We're going to knock the socks off the Hells Angels here,'' said Dennis Aiken, assistant special agent for the FBI in Omaha. Surrounded by confiscated rifles, a .22-caliber automatic pistol, $800,000 worth of drugs, $200,000 in cash as well as Hells Angels jackets and posters, Aiken said a two-year investigation culminated in simultaneous raids Wednesday on 14 locations, including the motorcycle club's headquarters in Omaha. A Rottweiler guard dog was killed after it attacked an officer at the clubhouse and one man at the clubhouse resisted arrest, but the other searches and arrests were conducted without incident, Aiken said. ``We consider this group to be a major center in the trafficking of methamphetamines,'' Aiken said at a news conference. Hells Angels clubs have played a major role in methamphetamine traffic in the country, he said. Many of the fewer than 50 club members in the Omaha area are now in jail, Aiken said. Everyone arrested in the Omaha area Wednesday was a Hells Angel club member or an associate of the club, Aiken said. The investigation continued and it wasn't known how much contraband and money would eventually be confiscated, Aiken said. Charges included interstate and foreign travel in support of racketeering enterprises, money laundering, manufacturing and distribution of a controlled substance and felony possession of a firearm, an FBI news release said. Eleven of the 16 people arrested Wednesday in or near Omaha and in Long Beach, Calif., had been named in a federal grand jury indictment handed up Monday, Aiken said. The five others were arrested on charges of drug possession based on evidence obtained during the raids, he said. Larry Holmquist, an FBI spokesman, would not comment on the connection between the arrest in California and the others here. Douglas County Sheriff Dick Roth said the suspects had been investigated as far back as 1978. ``We have had tons of intelligence on these people's actions over the years,'' Roth said. A cooperative effort that included the FBI, Nebraska State Patrol and the federal Drug Enforcement Administration used electronic surveillance such as wire intercepts, Aiken said. He refused to say whether undercover agents played a role. Homes and businesses were searched in Omaha; in Valley, a town west of here; and in Council Bluffs, across the Missouri River in Iowa, the FBI said.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Experts Denounce New Madrid Quake Prediction
With PM-Earthquake Anniversary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A projection of a major earthquake in the Midwest in early December is as about as reliable as a random guess, a group of scientists said today. ``Such a projection, especially at the predicted 50-50 chance level, implies a level of detailed knowledge ... that simply does not exist for the New Madrid or any other fault zone in the world,'' the group said in its report. The group released its findings, prepared for the National Earthquake Prediction Evaluation Council, today at a news conference in St. Louis. The 11 scientists were brought together from universities and governmental agencies to evaluate the scientific validity of Iben Browning's projection of a 50 percent chance of a big quake hitting the New Madrid Fault on or about Dec. 3. Browning, a climatologist based in Sandia Park, N.M, bases his prediction on the cyclical forces of tides and gravity. He has said that for 48 hours before and after Dec. 3, tidal forces will be particularly strong. Earlier this week, Browning said that conditions will again be ripe for a major quake in the region on New Year's Eve. Browning told Cape Girardeau television station KFVS that tidal forces on that date will not be as high as on Dec. 3, ``but they will still be dangerously high.'' In 1811-1812, a series of quakes estimated at up to 8 on the Richter scale struck the New Madrid region, causing the Mississippi River to appear to flow backward and forming Reelfoot Lake in Tennessee. The tremors rang church bells in Washington, D.C., more than 850 miles away. Browning's Dec. 3 claim has been widely reported, causing public anxiety throughout the region. At least nine school districts in three states have canceled classes, insurance agents have been swamped with requests for earthquake insurance and attendance at earthquake preparedness meetings has been high. The New Madrid fault runs from Marked Tree, Ark., across southeastern Missouri to southern Illinois and produces hundreds of small quakes every year, most hardly felt. It's named for the Missouri Bootheel town of New Madrid, about 140 miles south of St. Louis. In today's report, the scientists' agreed with other findings that ``the long-term potential for a large earthquake does, indeed, exist for New Madrid.'' But it said that ``Browning's correlations of earthquake activity with danger periods at times of highs in tidal forces does no better at predicting earthquakes of magnitudes greater than 6.5 than does random guessing.'' The scientific group also said it found no evidence to support the claim that Browning had predicted the Oct. 17, 1989, earthquake in northern California. ``We can only infer that successes claimed before that time were retrospective - that he found after the fact that certain earthquakes occurred during times of his `danger periods.''' A quake measuring 4.6 on the Richter scale hit the New Madrid region Sept. 26. The quake, the second strongest in the region this century, caused no injuries and no significant damage, but it added significantly to what has been called the ``earthquake hysteria.''

DOC.HEAD: Dolphins Try to Keep One of Their Own From Beaching Itself
DOC.TEXT: A family of dolphins has circled an ailing young dolphin inside the surf line off Pacific Palisades for 10 days, trying to keep the sick mammal from beaching itself. Nicknamed ``Bonnie,'' the Pacific bottlenose dolphin was kept in the water off Will Rogers State Beach today by six companions, marine conservationists said. Bonnie has a limp dorsal fin, possibly a birth defect, said Peter Wallerstein, director of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society. ``She could have been deformed at birth or possibly have been born with a weakened immune system,'' he said Wednesday. Would-be rescuers could do nothing because of the fear their efforts would further traumatize the 3-foot-long dolphin, Wallerstein said. ``As long as the family is with her, there's no need for human intervention,'' he said. ``At this point, they're keeping her afloat, kind of pushing her back and forth. But she's in bad shape. ``They'll keep shepherding her along as long as she needs help,'' he added. ``This is a great example of how these intelligent animals care for each other.'' Wallerstein said rescuers would intervene only if any of the dolphins beaches itself.

DOC.HEAD: China Uncovers 2,216 Drug Smuggling Cases In First Six Months
DOC.TEXT: The number of drug-smuggling cases in the first half of 1990 was almost four times higher than in all of last year, according to an official report Thursday. Police and customs officials uncovered 2,216 drug trafficking incidents in the first six months, confiscating 814 pounds of opium and 1,700 pounds of heroin, the overseas edition of the People's Daily reported. That compares with a total for 1989 of 563 cases, involving 635 pounds of opium and 1,234 pounds of heroin. The dispatch said most of the narcotics originated in southwest China's Yunnan province and were being shipped across southern China to Hong Kong and elsewhere. Yunnan province borders the so-called Golden Triangle, which produces much of the world's heroin and opium. China has set up a 1,300-man anti-drug force to combat a growing narcotics problem, which had been virtually eliminated soon after the Communists came to power in 1949.

DOC.HEAD: Motorist Drowned, Scores of Homes Damaged in Southern France
DOC.TEXT: A motorist drowned in floodwaters and scores of homes were damaged after torrential rains hit southern France, authorities said Thursday. About six inches of rain fell in less than an hour Wednesday night in parts of the Var region near Toulon, and another four inches fell in the Alpes-Maritimes. The downpour quickly overflowed stream beds hardened by a prolonged drought and spilled onto highways and into homes. Officials said Geneviere Glasner, 60, was swept away by the current and drowned when she tried to escape from her stranded car near the town of Vence. Rescue crews helped evacuate dozens of people from their houses and also from a home for retired people.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Universities Closed Because of Anti-government Unrest
DOC.TEXT: The government has closed two more universities following violent demonstrations calling for the resignation of the president. Rajshahi University and Mymensingh's Agriculture University were ordered shut late Wednesday. The two universities, both in northern Bangladesh, were to stay closed for one month. Earlier this week, Dhaka University and two other universities near the capital were ordered closed indefinitely because of recurring anti-government protests. Only two universities in the country are still open. Police and stone-throwing students have clashed repeatedly since Oct. 10 when the country's main opposition parties began a campaign of general strikes to demand resignation of President Hussain Muhammad Ershad. Protesters accuse the president of inefficiency and say his administration is corrupt. Three general strikes have been held since October. At least 50 people were injured Tuesday during a half-day strike in Rajshahi, 120 miles northwest of Dhaka, in clashes between students and police. In Mymensingh, 70 miles north of Dhaka, university students set fire to the train station and two trains during the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Claude Arpels, Member Of Jewelry Dynasty, Dies At 79
DOC.TEXT: Claude Arpels, who headed the U.S. operations of the Van Cleef and Arpels jewelry firm, died earlier this week in Switzerland, his family said Thursday. He was 79. No details were disclosed about the cause of death Monday. Arpels and his two brothers, Pierre and Jacques, were the heirs of the business founded in Paris by their parents and in-laws. Pierre died 10 years ago, while Jacques is the chief executive. Claude Arpels spent virtually his entire career with the firm in the United States. He opened the New York store on Fifth Avenue in 1939, opened a second in Palm Beach, Fla. the next year, and in 1969 added a branch in Beverly Hills, Ca. There was no immediate word on Arpels' survivors or funeral plans.

DOC.HEAD: Race Pits Experience Against `New Leadership'
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Bruce King's involvement in New Mexico politics goes back 36 years - a fact that both he and his opponent are trying to use to their advantage in the governor's race. King already has served longer than anyone as governor of New Mexico, two four-year terms starting in 1970 and 1978. ``I won't need any on-the-job training,'' the 66-year-old King tells audiences as he bids for a comeback. ``I have the experience I need to carry out the needs of the state.'' His rival is Republican businessman Frank Bond, who says he offers voters ``a new generation of leadership.'' Bond, 47, reminds voters that since New Mexico governors now can seek consecutive four-year terms, the next governor could serve through 1998, when he would be 55 years old, and King 74. GOP Gov. Garrey Carruthers, the first Republican governor since 1968, was prevented from seeking re-election by a constitutional provision that now has been changed. Bond, who trailed King by some 12 percentage points in recent polls, is turning up the heat on the campaign trail as he tries to boost his name identification. He has attacked what he calls an excessive number of executive pardons issued to ex-convicts by King and has accused King of cronyism. Two high-ranking officials were convicted of federal crimes and two resigned under a cloud of suspicion during King's second administration. King responds that hundreds of people are appointed by the governor and that a few bad apples are a ``small percentage.'' Known for his friendly ways, King talks often about his experience and ability to work well with the Legislature and diverse groups. ``I have the political maturity to carry out the needs of the people,'' he says. The state GOP chairman casts King's experience in a different light. ``Yes, he's back, like those tired, old vaudevillian jokes,'' John Lattauzio wrote of King in a recent fund-raising letter. ``But time has wrung the humor out of Bruce King as well.'' Bond disavowed the letter and said it was not his style. Both candidates come from ranching families with deep New Mexico ties and each has established himself in modern business. They first met as adolescents. ``There are all these connections and coincidences, but they don't bring us politically at all close together,'' says Bond. King and his two brothers built the family homestead into a farming, ranching and business empire covering nearly 500,000 acres and including a propane and butane company, feedlots and land development. His political outlook was influenced by the New Deal of President Roosevelt. At the same time, King emphasizes that ``the big thing I'm interested in is reducing big bureaucratic government.'' Bond, a lawyer and former state legislator, studied photography under Ansel Adams and stopped just short of a doctorate in Spanish literature. His grandfather and great-grandfather migrated from Canada to northern New Mexico in 1883. Bond's Republican roots also run deep. His father helped stat candidates and his maternal grandmother was a GOP national committeewoman for 18 years, hosting President Eisenhower in her Albuquerque home. ``I grew up basically with probably a much more conservative philosophy, particularly fiscally, with respect to taxes, with respect to the size of government and the like,'' he says. Bond hopes to exploit the state's political shift since King's last election. In 1978, Democrats outnumbered Republicans 2.3-to-1, and King won the election by just 1 percent of the vote. Republicans have narrowed the ratio to about 1.7-to-1 this year.

DOC.HEAD: Cycle Crash Kills Ex-Convict-Turned Acclaimed Author
DOC.TEXT: Former convict Seth Morgan, whose first novel ``Homeboy'' won national acclaim last spring, was killed with a companion when their motorcycle crashed into a bridge abutment, police said. Investigators said Morgan, 41, and Diane Levin, 37, both of New Orleans, were thrown from the motorcycle and died at the scene Wednesday. Neither victim was wearing a helmet, as required by state law, police said. Police said Morgan had been arrested Tuesday on charges of driving his motorcycle while intoxicated, but it was uncertain whether he was drunk at the time of his death. Morgan had drifted into New Orleans in 1986 after three years in a California prison for armed robbery. He had started writing in prison, where he won an award for his story of the last days of Janis Joplin, the singer who had been his lover when she died of a drug overdose in 1970. He resumed writing in New Orleans. In a few months, Morgan produced a 1,100-page manuscript that became ``Homeboy,'' a thickly plotted crime novel set in San Francisco. The first novel drew on his experiences with the seamier side of life and was greeted with strong praise when it was published last spring, including a complimentary front-page critique in The New York Times Book Review. ``Homeboy'' sold about 25,000 copies, which Jason Epstein, his editor at Random House, described as ``a lot for an unknown writer.'' At his death, Morgan was working on a second novel, ``Mambo Mephiste,'' set in New Orleans. He once said in an interview that he kept writing in New Orleans because it was the only way he could get control of his life. ``You can really stay messed up here in New Orleans very anonymously. But this is where I regained sobriety, sanity,'' he said. ``The city's inherent tolerance, I know, was very helpful.'' Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Worried About a Shutdown? Let Your Fingers Do the Touring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Spokesman Chris ...', to CORRECT makeup of asociation
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Help for tourists will be just a toll-free phone call away if President Bush again shuts down parts of the federal government. The National Tour Association said today travelers may call for information on which tourists sites - including the Statue of Liberty, Washington museums and national parks - are affected. Such facilities could be closed this weekend if Congress and the Bush administration fail to agree on a deficit-reduction plan. Spokesman Chris Dever said the association, which includes hotels, airlines and bus tours, will pool information from federal, state and local sources to benefit travelers. The phone number is 1-800-755-TOUR.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Refugee Sees Kids for First Time in 40 Years
DOC.TEXT: A frail, gray-haired woman who spent most of the last four decades in an Albanian prison camp kissed and hugged some middle-aged strangers who met her at John F. Kennedy International Airport. They were her children. ``Which one are you?'' 78-year-old Haxhire Bushka asked each of her children, the youngest of whom are in their early 40s, after she stepped off the plane Wednesday. ``You're not my son,'' Mrs. Bushka joked with Eddie Bushka, 60, of Waterbury, Conn., her oldest. ``You're too old.'' ``I'm Joan, Mommy - Joan, Joan,'' said Joan Ali, 46, of Waterbury, Conn., as she hugged her mother for the first time since she was a small girl. Mrs. Bushka was imprisoned in 1950 a few days after her husband fled Albania for Greece, taking Eddie with him. Halil Bushka feared he would be killed if he stayed in Albania after the Communist regime confiscated their farm. Eddie Bushka returned to Albania in 1951 and led six of his brothers and sisters seven miles across the border to freedom in Greece. Halil Bushka refused to let Eddie go back for his mother, fearing for her life as well as Eddie's. Bushka took his children to the United States in 1952 and settled in Connecticut, where the children still live and the brothers run a construction company, Bushka Lumber. Halil Buskha died in 1971. Mrs. Bushka was imprisoned on and off for nearly 40 years with her youngest child, Skender, who was 6 months old when she was first arrested. He accompanied her to the United States. The children have tried for years to get their mother and brother out of Albania, keeping in touch through a trickle of letters Mrs. Bushka was permitted to receive. They said she kept her hopes alive with the help of a few tattered photographs of them as young children. Six months ago, as reforms began infiltrating the hardline Communist government, she was let out of prison. ``She had no belongings, nothing,'' said Eddie Bushka. He said she went to live with friends and wrote to the family in Connecticut. Three of her children went to Rome last week to meet her and arrange for her visa to the United States. ``We are going to give her the very best we know how,'' said Mrs. Ali. ``Right now there is so much catching up to do.'' And Mrs. Bushka has to meet her 26 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. ``This is all so overwhelming for her,'' said Mrs. Ali. ``She is the very best present in the whole wide world.'' A reunion at Eddie Bushka's is planned for this weekend, with an Albanian feast featuring specialties like baklava pastry and byrek, a vegetable pie. ``This is the most wonderful day of my life,'' said Eddie Bushka.

DOC.HEAD: No Buyers for Fifth Avenue Tower in Marcos Case
DOC.TEXT: No one placed the minimum $100 million bid at a court-ordered auction of the Crown Building, one of four Manhattan properties tied to the late Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos and his wife, Imelda. A second auction of the 26-story retail and office building will be held, probably before the end of the year, auctioneer Stephen Estroff said at the close of the unsuccessful sale Wednesday in U.S. District Court. The auction came in a foreclosure action by Security Pacific Mortgage and Real Estate Services. Proceeds were to have gone into an escrow account until the resolution of civil lawsuits in which the Philippine government and others claim ownership of the four properties. Mrs. Marcos was acquitted in July of criminal charges that she and her husband used embezzled government funds to buy the buildings. Estroff said one reason for the lack of bidders was concern about the shaky economy. Two of the other Marcos properties already have been auctioned. The Herald Center, a retail building near Macy's, brought $25 million and an office tower on Wall Street was sold for $77 million. The fourth property at Madison Avenue has not come up for auction.

DOC.HEAD: Government Lifts State of Emergency in Natal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th pvs, `The ANC...' to UPDATE with White House comment. Pickup 5th pvs, `De Klerk lifted...'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk today lifted the state of emergency in violence-torn Natal Province, meeting a key demand that had slowed peace talks with the African National Congress. ``The state of emergency has now been completely lifted,'' de Klerk told a news conference. ``There is only one route to peace and reconciliation - that is through peaceful negotiation.'' He said the door to negotiations ``is now fully open and I am appealing to all leaders and all South Africans to accept the challenge.'' The ANC issued a statement welcoming the move. It has long demanded that the emergency be lifted as a precondition for full-scale negotiations on black-white power sharing and ending apartheid. President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, welcomed de Klerk's action as ``yet another important landmark on the road toward full normalization of political activity in South Africa.'' Fitzwater said, ``We believe that President de Klerk deserves credit for his political courage and leadership.'' De Klerk lifted a 4-year-old nationwide state of emergency in June, but kept the restrictive measures in Natal Province, where a power struggle between the ANC and the conservative Inkatha movement has claimed 5,000 lives since 1986. The president said the violence, though still sporadic, was receding and that law and order could be maintained through normal police powers. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said the decision to lift the emergency was ``a step which should bring South Africa nearer to the negotiating table.'' The state of emergency gave police and the army widespread powers, including detention without trial and the authority to break up political rallies and meetings. But police will retain the right under security laws to impose stringent restrictions in what they deem to be emergency situations. More than 30,000 activists, mostly black, were detained for varying lengths of time during the four years of the nationwide state of emergency. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told the news conference the number of police and soldiers would remain the same in Natal but that they would operate under normal procedures. Police still have some special powers in townships around Johannesburg that have been declared ``unrest areas,'' but the measures are far short of powers under the state of emergency. About 800 blacks have died in factional fighting around Johannesburg in the last two months. With de Klerk's latest announcement, he has addressed all of the ANC's demands, including the release of political prisoners and the return of some 20,000 exiles. However, the exiles have yet to begin returning in large numbers, and only a few dozen of the more than 1,500 political prisoners claimed by the ANC have been released. De Klerk said there was ``basic agreement'' on any remaining obstacles to negotiations but that ``there have been some hiccups.'' The fighting around Johannesburg had strained government-ANC relations, with the ANC accusing security forces of instigating the unrest. The government denied the charge and challenged the ANC to provide proof. De Klerk reiterated that all political parties, including right-wing conservative and militant black groups, are welcome at constitutional negotiations he hopes to launch early next year. Only the ANC, Inkatha and the white anti-apartheid Democratic Party have expressed a desire to attend. De Klerk said he wants to eliminate apartheid measures and give all South Africans a ``vote of equal value.'' He again promised that whites would have a chance to vote on any new constitutional agreement before it would be implemented. The president said he wants such an agreement by 1994, when the next national election is due.

DOC.HEAD: Game 4 of Chess Match Adjourned After 40 Moves; Draw Announced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with draw announced; CORRECT spelling of Lyons. Picks up penultimate graf.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Chess-Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: The fourth chess game in the world title match between champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov ended in a draw today when the players agreed not to continue after an adjournment. The game was adjourned Wednesday at shortly after 10:30 p.m. when Kasparov, playing the white pieces, wrote down his 41st move and sealed it in an envelope. The game had been scheduled to resume at 5:30 p.m. today, but the players this morning decided on a draw instead, officials for match said. Karpov's offer of the draw was made in a written note about 12:30 a.m. today, and was accepted by Kasparov shortly before 11 a.m. The sealed move was knight to g6, checking the black king, and came two hours and 34 minutes into the match. The draw had been predicted by experts watching the game Wednesday. ``It's definitely a draw,'' said grand master Stefan Djuric of Yugoslavia after the game was adjourned. ``There's no question about it,'' said international master Vitaly Zaltsman of Brooklyn. ``Kasparov has a perpetual check.'' That meant Kasparov could make endless checks to Karpov's king, a draw according to chess rules. Games 1 and 3 also ended in a draw, while Kasparov won Game 2. A win is worth one point and a draw is worth one-half point for each player. With today's announcement of a draw, Kasparov now leads 2{-1{. Kasparov, 27, the highest-rated player in the history of chess, and Karpov, 39, the former world champion he unseated in 1985, are playing a best-of-24-game, $3 million match. The first player to get 12{ points wins. The first 12 games are to be played in New York and the rest in Lyons, France. Spectators in the press room at Game 4 included Boris Spassky, who held the title from 1969 until he was defeated by Bobby Fischer in 1972, and Viktor Korchnoi, who lost two championship matches against Karpov in 1978 and 1981. Officials running the match removed Karpov's miniature flag of the Soviet Union and Kasparov's flag of the Russian Republic from the playing table after Karpov's delegation asked that Kasparov's be taken away.

DOC.HEAD: Government Distributes $60 Million in Drug Treatment Grants
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials on Thursday awarded $60 million in drug treatment grants to eight large cities and to almost 100 programs aimed at youth, minorities, public housing residents and criminals. The grants are intended not just to increase services where they are most needed, but to develop more effective treatment methods, officials said. ``It's not just having enough (treatment) slots, but the quality'' of the services available to keep addicts in treatment, said James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services. The eight cities will receive a total of $28.5 million to improve city-wide drug treatment systems to eliminate waiting lists and ensure that drug abusers receive better treatment more quickly. The cities will use the money for such things as developing a central referral service, improving patient monitoring, hiring more staff and improving outreach services, officials said. The Department of Health and Human Services also is giving $24.2 million to 80 drug treatment programs in 35 states and territories to improve services for three population groups that have a high prevalence of drug problems - adolescents, minorities and public housing residents. Officials hope these programs can become national prototypes of comprehensive services that will better serve others, such as the homeless, people with AIDS and people with mental illness who also have drug or alcohol problems, or both. Also, $8 million will be used to fund 19 demonstration projects designed to improve drug treatment in the criminal justice system, including people who are in jail and others who are on probation or parole. The eight target cities and their awards are: Boston, $4.5 million; Baltimore, $4.5 million; Los Angeles, $4.1 million; Atlanta, $3.9 million; San Juan, Puerto Rico, $3.8; New York, $3.7 million; Albuquerque, N.M., $2.5 million; and Milwaukee, $1.5 million. Officials said they expect to fund each city's program for three year, but said money for the following two years will depend on the department's budget. The funds for all of the cities and programs winning grants come from the budget for the fiscal year that just ended. They are the first projects funded by the Office for Treatment Improvement, which opened last January in the department's Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, Two Wounded In Oakland Shooting Rampage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with quotes from police spokesman that suspect had weapon with him; description of suspect as transient, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A shooting rampage in a fast-food restaurant, a nearby grocery store and a taxi left two people dead and two others seriously wounded, police said today. Authorities arrested Delaney G. Marks, 34, in nearby Alameda at about 12:30 a.m. today based on a description of the gunman by witnesses, said Oakland police Sgt. Dan Mercado. ``He had the weapon with him and through some admissions we believe he is the shooter in all four cases,'' Mercado said. Mercado would not comment on a possible motive. Marks was held for investigation of two charges of murder, two counts of attempted murder, and possession of a firearm by an ex-felon, police said. The shooting spree started about 7:40 p.m. Wednesday when a gunman walked into a Taco Bell restaurant and shot a cashier in the face, Mercado said. Mui Loung, 20, was in critical condition today at Eden Hospital Medical Center, a spokesman said. A few minutes later, a man believed to be the same gunman entered the Gourmet Market about two blocks away, where he shot and killed the owner and critically wounded an employee, Mercado said. Peter Bazea, 60, of San Leandro was pronounced dead on arrival at an Oakland hospital, police said. His employee John Myers, 30, of Oakland was in critical condition at Eden Hospital with a gunshot wound to the chest, officials said. Shortly after the shootings in Oakland, a Yellow Cab driver who had been shot in the face stopped at a fast-food restaurant in nearby Alameda, where employees called for help. The driver, a 47-year-old man whose name was not released, died about half an hour later, police said. Records showed the last fare the driver picked up was near the Oakland market, police said. Marks' girlfriend was with him at the time of arrest and also was in the vicinity during the four shootings, but she was released after questioning, Mercado said. Mercado said Marks, a transient, was on parole but would not release any details of his criminal history.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters Raise $30,000 To Send Radios to Mideast Troops
DOC.TEXT: U.S. radio stations have rcceived pledges of $30,000 and are seeking more donations to buy radios and batteries for use by American troops in the Persian Gulf region, the National Association of Broadcasters said Thursday. The first shipment of radios already has arrived in the gulf, thanks to the AIR-LIFT listener donation campaign that NAB launched last month in conjunction with Westinghouse Electric's Group W Radio. Another 6,000 batteries and receivers, including 5,000 sets from Sony, will be en route to the Middle East by next week, NAB said. The Armed Forces Radio and Television Service has begun broadcasting to U.S. troops in the region. Other manufacturer contributions are expected, NAB said, but the public is urged to send cash donations to buy more military-approved receivers. Radio donations are not needed. Contributions should be made by check or money order, payable to: AIR-LIFT, Rockefeller Center, Box 5493, New York, N.Y., 10185.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Gulf Expert Calls On Baker
Desk: Top 6 grafs new with US-Soviet consultations; pickup 6th graf pvs: ``Baker suggested:
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is weighing prospects for a settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis with a senior Soviet expert who is reporting on his recent talks in Iraq. The unannounced visit Thursday of Evgeny Primakov to the State Department is a warmup to the session the Soviet official will have at the White House on Friday with President Bush. The two superpowers are cooperating in efforts to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, its smaller, oil-rich neighbor in the Persian Gulf. However, an embargo on trade and other steps taken by the U.N. Security Council so far have failed to persuade President Saddam Hussein to pull out his troops. A report from Moscow in today's editions of The Washington Times quoted unnamed U.S. officials as saying Primakov is carrying a peace plan from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that calls on Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, possibly in exchange for free elections in the emirate and cash compensation to Iraq from an oil claims dispute. Baker earlier this week ruled out any ``partial solution'' short of total Iraqi withdrawal or anything that would enable Saddam to claim benefits from the Aug. 2 invasion. However, Baker also stressed the U.S. quest for a political settlement. On Wednesday, Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee a worldwide arms embargo might be maintained against Iraq even if it withdrew from Kuwait. Baker suggested the Security Council also consider calling for Iraqi reparations to Kuwait and an international war crimes trial of Iraq's leaders. Baker's latest proposal reflected concern within the administration and Congress that even if Iraq withdrew its troops, its large army and nuclear and chemical weapons technology would pose a danger in the Middle East and Persian Gulf. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., suggested, meanwhile, that companies providing military technology to Iraq be held liable for war crimes, as well. Baker did not respond to the suggestion, which Helms supported with a chart showing that firms in 19 countries, including the United States, had assisted Iraq before the invasion. West Germany headed the list, with 87 companies. Austria was second with 18 and France was third with 17. The hearing was marked by demands by key senators that Congress participate in any decision to send U.S. troops into combat against Iraq. But Baker resisted. He promised only further consultations. ``We should not have a constitutional argument over whether or not the president as commander-in-chief has authority to commit forces,'' Baker said in an effort to end the debate. Besides, Baker said, a vote on Capitol Hill could tip off Saddam about a pending military operation or even cause the White House to abandon that option. Only two members of the committee, Sens. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., and Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., supported the administration in its insistence that consultation with congressional leaders was sufficient. Typical of the demand was an assertion by Sen. Paul S. Sarbanes, D-Md., that ``consultation is not enough.'' ``There is a difference between consultation and authorization,'' Sarbanes said. ``The notion that the president alone would be able to commit American forces in a military assault in effect without receiving a shared decision by the Congress is contrary to the Constitution.'' Besides, Sarbanes said, ``it is clearly contrary to what makes good sense'' so far as ensuring support of the American people. But Baker responded: ``If you want us to agree to do nothing unless we get the approval of 535 members of Congress, we can't agree to that right now.'' The disagreement, mostly under wraps until now, is rising to the surface as Congress prepares for a year-end adjournment, beginning possibly late next week.

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Over Infant Deaths as Clinics Demand Parents Pay
DOC.TEXT: Parents whose babies died after receiving contaminated intravenous solutions at two clinics may be taken to court if they continue to refuse to pay bills for the treatment, officials said Thursday. As many as 16 children, all white, may have died at the two clinics this year from a bacterial infection possibly caused by contaminated intravenous solution used in the neonatal wards. The parents met with an attorney Wednesday and mandated that he ask the government to order an inquiry into the deaths at the Morningside and Park Lane clinics in Johannesburg. The parents have said they should not have to pay the medical bills. The clinics have replied that they were not responsible for the deaths and should not be left with the bills. The managing director of the Morningside clinic, Johan van Reenen, said it is impossible to determine if the fatal infections were a direct result of contaminated solution. He said there are ``1,001-plus causes'' of the bacterial infection known as Klepsiella. In addition, of the many infants who received the same drip formula, some became ill and others did not, van Reenen said. ``If it was contaminated solution (that caused the deaths), it's not the hospital that was negligent,'' he said. He also said most of the affected parents were covered by medical insurance. Four babies died at Morningside after contracting the infection, and another three who died might have been infected, he said. The number of infant deaths at Park Lane was unclear. News reports mentioned nine. The hospital's managing director, Jeffrey Hurwitz, said Thursday he could not give a specific figure. At the parents' meeting Wednesday night, the mother of one dead child said Park Lane had threatened to take her to court if she did not pay a $12,000 bill within 10 days. Hurwitz denied any of the bills were that high. He said they ranged from about $2,000 to $6,000, and he indicated Park Lane would pursue legal action if parents did not pay. ``The point is, we bill patients as a normal procedure and we give them credit terms the same as any business. We expect payment within those terms. If we don't receive payment, we take the matter further,'' Hurwitz said.

DOC.HEAD: Zombies Lurk at `Living Dead' Premiere
DOC.TEXT: Zombie extras lurked among moviegoers at a shopping mall at the premiere of ``Night of the Living Dead,'' a remake faithful in plot but deviant in style to the 1968 original. ``What makes a good zombie? Dull-eyed savagery, an advanced state of decomposition and a taste for human flesh. Uncontrollable drooling helps, but it's not required,'' actor Craig Spector said at Wednesday's premiere in suburban Pittsburgh. The color remake was based on the same script as the black-and-white thriller - the tale of farmhouse-bound survivors who bicker among themselves as hordes of slow-moving flesh-eaters attac. Spector and 14 other zombie extras in their makeup joined about 500 moviegoers Wednesday at the Galleria mall. The film is scheduled to open nationwide Friday. Ed Evans, who wore overalls and glued-on bullet wounds as he staggered in circles around the mall, said he was looking forward to seeing himself crashing through a boarded-up window and ``getting blown away by a shotgun.'' Spector said he learned to ``fall down dead and get up deader'' for his big scene, a mob attack on insurance salesman-turned-zombie killer Ben. George Romero, who directed the original ``Dead'' and two sequels, was the remake's executive producer. Tom Savini moved up from special effects supervisor to director. ``This picture has to stand on its own merits,'' producer Russ Streiner said. ``It would be a disservice to keep bringing up the original.'' The two were filmed on opposite sides of Pittsburgh, Romero's hometown. In 1968, the dead walked in Evans City, Butler County. The 1990 crew picked an abandoned dairy farm in Wolfdale, Washington County. ``When I was 13 years old, I saw the original and it set off a circuit breaker in my head that changed my life,'' said horror buff and ``Living Dead'' zombie extra John Skipp. He and said he and Spector ``live for this kind of thing. It's a personality disorder. We can't help it.'' The $130,000 original was shot like a grainy newsreel, but the $4.2 million remake includes more humor and allusions to horror landmarks filmed since 1968. For example, a sweet little zombie in a nightgown named Sarah resembles another cinema darling, the little girl from 1973's ``The Exorcist.'' ``As a moviegoer, I think fans will be interested in this picture because there are enough twists and turns in there,'' Streiner said. ``It's not just a carbon copy of the original.''

DOC.HEAD: Actor Ralph Waite Pushes `Waltons' Values on Campaign Trail
DOC.TEXT: Republican Al McCandless is a four-term congressman battling for name recognition against a first-time candidate - actor Ralph Waite. Waite, best known as television's ``Papa John Walton,'' has been campaigning non-stop for eight months. Wherever he goes, Waite is greeted by fans of ``The Waltons'' who ask him to autograph his campaign brochures. Both he and McCandless have lined up big-name support in the battle for the nation's fastest-growing congressional district. Democrat Waite draws on entertainment celebrities such as ``St. Elsewhere'' star Ed Begley Jr. and film ``Superman'' Christopher Reeve. McCandless has Bob Hope and Gerald Ford serving as his chief fund-raisers. Palm Springs Mayor Sonny Bono also is in his corner. McCandless, who stresses fiscal conservatism and a strong military, represents a district where Republicans outnumber Democrats 200,000 to 165,000. But his constituents include voters in half a dozen cities that didn't even exist a decade ago. ``People who have moved into this district don't know the name of the man who represents them,'' says Indian Wells Mayor Richard Oliphant, a McCandless supporter. ``He's the incumbent, but he needs to build name identification. It's a unique situation.'' The district includes Palm Springs, Rancho Mirage and Riverside, plus new communities on the Mojave Desert 70 miles inland from Los Angeles. ``In this district, it could be a close race,'' says former President Ford. ``Just because the registration is plus Republican, and because Al has been re-elected four times, you can never be sure.'' Waite says he has come from 28 percentage points behind McCandless in polls during the spring to a dead heat in the final weeks. Waite also leads in fund raising, with $450,000, including $156,000 of his own money. McCandless has raised $250,000. ``A lot of it has to do with Waite being a celebrity, and it's the first time Al has been seriously challenged,'' McCandless campaign spokesman James Moore says. ``When you get the Hollywood liberals in a race, it create tension.'' Republicans have brought in Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and have scheduled former President Reagan, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner to raise funds for McCandless. ``We're using the secretaries and former presidents to define what we represent - as opposed to sit-com actors,'' Moore said. Early in the campaign, McCandless ignored Waite and made few appearances. But McCandless switched tactics in August in response to the challenge from Waite and challenged his Democratic rival to debates that have yet to occur. McCandless, 63, labels Waite a typical big-spending Democrat. For the 62-year-old Waite, the district's heavily Republican registration is a problem. ``Being a Democrat's a tough job in these parts, but someone's got to do it,'' said a sign on a Waite booth at a community fair. Before becoming an actor, Waite was a social worker and a minister, giving him experience dealing with housing and drug rehabilitation issues. Waite also reminds voters of his Hollywood past. ``I guess I've been in almost every one of your homes for 10 years on The Waltons,'' he told a senior citizens group at a mobile home park. ``Being an actor, playing on The Waltons doesn't necessarily make a good leader or qualify you for Congress, but it might say something about the kind of values you have,'' Waite continued. Waite faults McCandless for failing to act to avert the savings and loan scandal. McCandless, who has spent five years on the House Banking Committee, calls that a meaningless ``pot shot.'' Waite endorses environmental regulations and more federal spending for seniors, education, health and social programs. He tells senior citizens McCandless ``does not seem to have your interests very high on his agenda.'' McCandless received ``Taxpayers' Friend'' and ``Watchdog of the Treasury'' awards from conservative groups. He says he won't vote for increased taxes while Democrats promise ``vague spending cuts.'' Even his own campaign brochures acknowledge the low-profile McCandless ``isn't a smile and backslap politician.'' His campaign materials credit him with water and flood control projects, highway construction and housing grants for his district.

DOC.HEAD: ``Good Morning America'' Host Heading to Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: ``Good Morning America'' co-host Charles Gibson is going to Saudi Arabia for live Thanksgiving week broadcasts from U.S. military bases there and a Navy ship in the Persian Gulf, ABC said Thursday. The five-day trip starts Nov. 19. It will be the second time a network morning show star has broadcast from Saudi Arabia since the U.S. military buildup began there after Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. Bryant Gumble co-anchored NBC's ``Today'' show there for a week of broadcasts beginning Aug. 17. ABC's expedition is more ambitious, partly because its show will be freer to travel to U.S. military bases due to a loosening of restrictions that were in force when Gumbel went there in the early days of the U.S. buildup. Gibson, accompanied by a 16-member crew to include reporter Steve Fox, will broadcast from two Army camps, an Air Force base, and a Marine encampment, in addition to the as-yet unidentified Navy ship. No specific locations can be announced yet because of security regulations, ABC said. Co-host Joan Lunden will remain in New York, doing other segments of each day's show. The show also will broadcast reunions - via satellite - of members of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia with their families in the United States. Since mid-August, NBC's ``Today'' each day has shown what its staff has nicknamed ``Hi, Moms'' - tape-recorded greetings of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia to their families and friends. ABC's announcement came as last week's Nielsens showed ``Good Morning America'' first in ratings for network morning shows for the 41st consecutive week, easily beating once-dominant ``Today.'' ABC's show averaged a 4.7 rating, ``Today'' a 3.3 and ``CBS This Morning'' a 2.6. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Blasts Colleagues on Capital Punishment
DOC.TEXT: Justice Thurgood Marshall, now a Supreme Court minority of one on the death penalty, still has an abolitionist's fervor. He blistered his fellow justices for their ``indifferent shrug of the shoulders'' in allowing a Virginia execution Wednesday. Marshall, indisputably the court's most liberal member, fired off a strongly worded dissent as the court, voting 8-1, rejected a death row inmate's last-gasp legal gambit. Wilbert Lee Evans was electrocuted in Richmond hours later. Marshall said the execution, the nation's 141st since the high court allowed states to reinstate the death penalty in 1976, ``highlights the inherently cruel and unusual character of capital punishment.'' Since Justice William J. Brennan's retirement in July, Marshall, 82, is the only court member who opposes the death penalty in all cases. ``We hope our movement will help Justice Marshall feel less isolated,'' said Leigh Dingerson of the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty. ``Even though the ... polls say 70 percent of Americans favor the death penalty, those polls mean 65 million people agree with him.'' Michael McConnell, a University of Chicago law professor, said Marshall's persistent refusal to condone capital punishment does not weaken the court's authority. ``I can see no principled objection to a justice refusing to follow a precedent if he feels it sufficiently important to register continued disapproval,'' McConnell said. ``But he who does so must not object when others similarly depart from precedent regarding some other issue.'' In the Virginia case, Evans was convicted of murdering a deputy sheriff in 1981. He was sentenced to death because jurors found one aggravating factor - the likelihood that Evans would be a future danger to society. While on death row, Evans was credited with saving the lives of prison guards taken hostage during a 1984 riot and with preventing the rape of a nurse. Marshall said such action ``casts grave doubt on the jury's prediction of Evans' future dangerousness.'' Virginia prosecutors did not argue that Evans still must be considered a future danger. But they said letting him attack his death sentence based on his actions in prison would lead to every well-behaved death row inmate challenging a past finding of future dangerousness. Marshall accused Virginia officials - and his eight fellow justices - of ignoring ``late-arriving evidence'' that should have been taken into account. ``The indifferent shrug of the shoulders with which the court answers the failure of its procedures in this case reveals the utter bankruptcy of its notion that a system of capital punishment can coexist with the (Constitution's) Eighth Amendment,'' Marshall said. The amendment bans cruel and unusual punishment. ``A death sentence that is dead wrong is no less so simply because its deficiency is not uncovered until the eleventh hour,'' Marshall said. ``A system of capital punishment that would permit Wilbert Evans' execution notwithstanding as-to-now unrefuted evidence showing that death is an improper sentence is a system that cannot stand.''

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Taking on the Duke From N.H. to Nebraska
DOC.TEXT: Republicans can't stop talking about Michael Dukakis. Nothing flattering, mind you. They just find the Massachusetts governor an irresistible campaign issue. Oklahoma Republicans offered Dukakis first-class air fare to come to their state and campaign for David Walters, the Democratic candidate for governor. The offer was not accepted. Democratic candidate David Worley's vote for Dukakis in the 1988 presidential election is an issue in a Georgia congressional race. Can Nebraska gubernatorial candidate Ben Nelson overcome the fact he has dark hair, bushy eyebrows and a prominent nose, giving him a superficial resemblance to the Massachusetts governor? Nowhere, of course, is Dukakis more of an issue than in his home state, where John Silber, the Democratic nominee for governor, relishes telling people he voted for George Bush in 1988. Dukakis can take some small comfort in the fact he's far from the first defeated presidential candidate to remain a political target. Republicans ran against Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale long after their names no longer appeared on any ballot. A whole generation of Democrats ran against Herbert Hoover, and with considerable success. Sheffield Nelson once raised money for Edward M. Kennedy and for Jimmy Carter. That was before he became a Republican in 1989. Now he's running for governor of Arkansas against Democratic incumbent Bill Clinton. During a recent debate, Nelson said Clinton ``wants to run for president. He wants to do like Michael Dukakis, and if you give him four more years, he'll bring the Massachusetts Miracle down South.'' The souring of the booming economy that Dukakis liked to call the Massachusetts Miracle triggered a voter revolt that gave the gubernatorial nomination to outsider Silber. Also worried is Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., who is being challenged by Republican Jim Rappaport. Once thought safe, Kerry now is looking at polls showing him in a very close contest. The GOP candidate is running an ad in which a picture of Dukakis gradually transforms into one of Kerry. ``He's back,'' says the voice. ``Oh, not Mike Dukakis. He's gone. But the man who was Dukakis' lieutenant governor, he's back. He and Dukakis were a team. They think like a team.'' In neighboring New Hampshire, Republican Gov. Judd Gregg likes to point out that his Democratic opponent, Joseph Grandmaison, ran Dukakis' first campaign for governor. During a debate with Gregg, Grandmaison tried to laugh off any such comparison by pointing out that he looked nothing like the Massachusetts governor. ``I'm the one with the double chin,'' he said. That's not so easy for Democrat Ben Nelson, running against Republican Gov. Kay Orr of Nebraska. ``The Michael Dukakis of the Midwest,'' is how the Orr camp refers to Nelson. So far, at least, Nelson leads Orr in opinion polls - despite his hair and eyebrows and nose. David Worley is running against Rep. Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican who is House minority whip. Gingrich repeatedly characterizes Worley as a liberal. The proof? He voted for Mondale in 1984 and Dukakis in 1988. David Walters did more than just vote for Dukakis. He ran the Democratic nominee's Oklahoma campaign. Or as Republican gubernatorial candidate Bill Price puts it, Walters tried to ``ram Michael Dukakis down the throats'' of Oklahomans.

DOC.HEAD: Better Crash Position, Rear-Facing Seats Could Cut Air Casualties
DOC.TEXT: Airline cabin crews could save lives by telling passengers before takeoff how to brace themselves for a crash, medical investigators said Thursday in a report on an accident that killed 47 people. A separate report released Thursday by the Department of Transport's Air Accidents Investigation Branch blamed pilot error for the crash of a British Midland Airways 737-400 jet on Jan. 8, 1989. The jet developed trouble in its left engine but the pilots mistakenly shut off the right engine before attempting an emergency landing at East Midlands airport near Kegworth, 20 miles northwest of Leicester. Thirty-nine passengers died on impact as the plane crashed short of the runway. Another eight died later and of 79 who survived, 74 suffered serious injury. The Air Accidents Investigation Branch report concluded the pilots reacted prematurely to initial engine trouble and ``in a way that was contrary to their training.'' Both reports called for study of turning airline seats around so that passengers face the rear, as in some military aircraft. The investigators also recommended research to strengthen floors, improved designs for seats and seat belts, engine modifications and improved cockpit displays and pilot training. The Civil Aviation Authority, the government agency responsible for airline operations and safety, said research would continue into the best position to brace for a crash as well as the possible introduction of rear-facing seats. ``The preliminary results of this research indicate that even a small change in the passenger brace position might improve survivability or reduce the degree of injury,'' the authority said in a statement later. The Aviation Authority said shoulder harnesses and air bags were also possible areas for research. The medical report by the University of Nottingham Medical School, commissioned by the Aviation Authority recommended that the braced crash position be demonstrated before every flight. It said that was more important than the routine demonstration of life jackets. The report said many leg injuries suffered by 57 passengers were caused by floors disintegrating and seats collapsing in the forward cabin. Seventy-seven survivors had head and face injuries, it said. Few of the passengers were in the correct position when the plan crashed, the report said. The doctors said their new recommended crash brace position offered ``significant protection against head injury and concussion.'' The researchers recommended that passengers bend forward with their heads resting against the seat ahead. Hands should be clasped behind heads, with elbows tucked outside the knees. Feet should be together on the floor, resting slightly behind the knees. John Wolfe, managing director of British Midland's parent company, Airlines of Britain, said the airline would change its flight safety cards to reflect the new position. The British Midland jet was flying from London's Heathrow Airport to Belfast, Northern Ireland when fan blades failed in the left engine. The government report said the combination of heavy engine vibration, noise, shuddering and smell of fire was ``outside the training and experience'' of the pilots.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Between Menotti, Festival
DOC.TEXT: CHARLESTON, S.C. (AP). - A tentative agreement has been reached to ensure composer Gian Carlo Menotti's lifelong involvement with the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., the arts festival he created, the festival chairman said. Spoleto board Chairman Ross Markwardt told The News and Courier the exact nature of that involvement has not been defined. He said Tuesday talks may continue several days while specifics are worked out. But Menotti will continue as festival artistic director at least through next year. Last week Menotti said he wanted to resign, but he has changed his mind for now. ``I promised that I want the festival to go on and will collaborate, will make peace with anybody,'' Menotti said. ``I started the program (for 1991) and I will go through with it. Then, if it is felt that my services are no longer necessary, I will retire in good graces without any bitterness,'' the composer added. He and board members have said they had a dispute centering on the authority and responsibility of artistic director. The 79-year-old Menotti started the Charleston festival in 1977. It is patterned on the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary Teaches Youngsters About Potatoes
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter on Thursday gave Brenda Maxwell's 6th grade class a lesson in the virtues of potatoes, and found ``a smart bunch of kids'' who already had a paper spud in his name. ``We'd like to present you with a `Yeutter'o potato' name tag,'' 11-year-old Crystal Ford told a surprised Yeutter. All 25 youngsters in the Van Ness Elementary School classroom donned similar handmade tags in honor of the secretary's visit that marked National School Lunch Week and World Food Week. Yeutter and seven other top officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture discussed the potato in second through six-grade classes at Van Ness, which has been a ``partner'' of the USDA for about six years. ``Most people don't realize how important a food potatoes are,'' Yeutter said, after distributing white potatoes to each of the students. ``They are the most important vegetable in the whole world. ``Of course there's broccoli. The president says you shouldn't eat broccoli but don't pay attention to him,'' he said smiling. Yeutter rhapsodized on the merits of the spud, using a lesson plan developed by John S. Niederhauser, the winner of this year's World Food Prize for advancing the production and consumption of potatoes. Reneya Gaston, 11, eagerly told Yeutter that water is stored in potatoes, while two other students traded guesses of 100 pounds and 125 pounds as the amount of potatoes most Americans eat per year. Joking with teacher Maxwell, Yeutter said, ``You got a smart bunch of kids here. They don't really need a teacher.'' Bernadette Goatley, 11, presented to Yeutter a green school cap, key chain and a framed copy of the school's vision, ``on behalf of all potato lovers here at Van Ness.'' Yeutter left the students a potted leafy green potato plant. What did she learn in class? ``We eat a lot of potatoes over a year. My favorite is french fries,'' said Bernadette. After class, Yeutter and the officials put on large white aprons and served the students a lunch of barbecued chicken, macaroni and cheese, mixed vegetables, oatmeal roll, fresh fruit and pear cobbler - but no potatoes. The National School Lunch program, established in 1946 and administered nationally by the USDA, is a federally assisted meal program that provides balanced, low-cost or free lunches to about 24 million children each school day at 91,500 schools. At Van Ness, Principal Cassandra Butler said about 90 percent of the 280 pre-school through sixth grade youngsters receive free lunch, while a small percent pay either the reduced fee of 10 cents or the full price of 40 cents.
