DOC.SECOND: 25 More Films Added to Registry of Best Movies
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five American movies, as old as ``The Great Train Robbery'' of 1903 and as recent as ``Raging Bull'' in 1980, were named Thursday to the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress as outstanding films worthy of historic preservation. The list was announced by James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, under terms of a 1988 statute that established the registry to honor 25 films a year deemed ``culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.'' ``This is not Academy Awards night,'' Billington told a news conference. ``These are not annual lists of the `best' American films.'' Rather, he said, they were chosen because they ``impressively display the depth and variety of the American creative spirit'' in filmmaking. This year's selections join the first 25 films chosen last year for the registry. Listed alphabetically, the 1990 choices are: ``All About Eve,'' made in 1950 by director Joseph L. Mankiewicz; ``All Quiet on the Western Front,'' 1930, directed by Lewis Milestone; ``Bringing Up Baby,'' 1938, produced and directed by Howard Hawks; ``Dodsworth,'' 1936, directed by William Wyler; ``Duck Soup,'' the Marx brothers classic made in 1933, Walt Disney's ``Fantasia,'' made in 1940. Also, Harold Lloyd's ``The Freshman,'' made in 1925; Francis Coppola's ``The Godfather,'' 1972; Edwin S. Porter's ``The Great Train Robbery,'' a 12-minute classic made in 1903; ``Harlan County, U.S.A.,'' 1973, directed by Barbara Kopple; John Ford's ``How Green Was My Valley,'' 1941; Frank Capra's ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' 1946. Also, Charles Burnett's ``Killer of Sheep,'' 1977; ``Love Me Tonight,'' produced and directed by Rouben Mamoulian, 1932; ``Meshes of the Afternoon,'' an 18-minute film directed by Maya Deren in 1943; ``Ninotchka,'' a 1939 Greta Garbo film directed by Ernst Lubitsch; ``Primary,'' a Time Inc. film made in 1960. Also, ``Raging Bull,'' directed by Martin Scorsese, 1980; ``Rebel Without a Cause,'' the James Dean movie of 1955; ``Red River,'' made by Howard Hawks, 1948; ``The River,'' a 32-minute Farm Security Administration film made in 1937; ``Sullivan's Travels,'' a Preston Sturges film made in 1941. Also, ``Top Hat,'' a 1935 musical starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers; ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' directed by John Huston, 1948, and ``A Woman Under the Influence,'' directed by John Cassavetes, 1974. The list was based on 1,500 nominations made by the public, and narrowed by a 14-member National Film Preservation Board representing the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the American Film Institute, movie and television producers, directors, broadcasters, screen writers, the Screen Actors Guild of America, film critics and scholars. The final choices were made by Billington, a cultural historian and movie buff, based on consultations with advisers including the staff of the library's division of motion picture, broadcasting and recorded sound. Films are eligible for the registry 10 years after their first theatrical release. They need not necessarily be American films, the library said, but the first 50 movies in the registry all were made in the United States. The Library of Congress contains the nation's largest film archive, and accounts for more than half the number of films preserved in the United States. Even so, Billington said, half of all movies made before 1950 - and 80 percent of those made before 1930 - are lost forever. ``The cold, hard fact is that, for all their popularity in America today, films are an endangered species for the America of tomorrow,'' he said. Billington estimated it would cost a minimum of $600 million to preserve all remaining American movies on nitrate film, a highly flammable film that eventually deteriorates into gunpowder. Other library officials said the cost of restoring those movies and transferring them to safety film is probably closer to $1 billion or more. The library's annual budget for film preservation is about $300,000, officials said. Billington said the library is still trying to obtain archival quality originals of two films selected last year for deposit in its national film collection. They are ``Some Like It Hot,'' the Billy Wilder movie of 1959, and ``The Best Years of Our Lives'' of 1946. So far, library officials said, six of the 50 listed in the National Film Registry have been released in colorized versions on videotape cassettes. Under the 1988 law, those taped copies must carry a label noting that they are colorized versions of black and white films that were ``altered without the participation of the principal director, screenwriter and other creators of the original film.'' The six are ``The Maltese Falcon,'' ``Casablanca,'' ``Bringing Up Baby,'' ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ``Top Hat'' and ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Robot Moves from Auto Plant to Pizza Parlor
DOC.TEXT: A robotic arm once used in an auto assembly plant has been programmed to spread tomato sauce, sprinkle cheese and toss pepperoni onto pizzas in a plan to help handicapped people work in restaurants. Carnegie Mellon University's Pizzabot, which takes orders verbally and warbles back the command in a computer-generated voice, was unveiled Wednesday at a Pittsburgh pizzeria. The robot's developers say it should open up the food service job market, which needs workers, to the handicapped by performing tasks they cannot. The technology already is used in the auto and electronics industries. ``This is an effort to bring humans very intimately into the loop of robot technology,'' said K.G. Englehardt, director of the university's Center for Human Service Robotics. ``We'd like to level the playing field in business for the handicapped.'' Developers say applications extend beyond helping the handicapped, citing the increase in repetitive strain injuries to the wrists and hands and potential dangers in restaurant kitchens. ``Humans are thinkers. By nature, we're not good at repetitive tasks,'' said Roger Edwards, president of Intervention Technologies Inc., which built the arm. ``Just as we created forklifts when it became inhuman to lift with our backs, we're learning of the injuries caused by repetitive, menial work.'' The Pizzabot, which formerly twiddled knobs on dashboards in General Motors Corp. cars, stands in the center of a semicircle of nine bins. Its dimensions match those of a human arm, with elbow and wrist joints and two pinchers for fingers. The arm drops up to nine toppings on pizza dough placed on a spinning, stainless steel disc. Fluidly and silently, it levels the toppings with a ladle, passing less than an inch over the surface of the pizza. Ms. Englehardt, proud of the robot's smooth movements, said the arm is a descendant of robots she programmed to dance ballet. ``Psychologically, it's important it move like a human moves,'' she said. ``No one likes to see these jerky motions. That's scary.'' Ms. Englehardt said the robot and a handicapped worker together would be able to do the work of one non-handicapped employee. Human hands still must shape the dough and place the pie in an oven. The arm was displayed at Fox's Pizza Den on Pittsburgh's North Side and will be used to help train the handicapped for jobs in the food industry. James Fox, chairman of a chain of 130 stores in six states with headquarters in nearby Monroeville, said he hopes a handicapped franchisee will be able to open a shop, complete with a robot, within two years. With the meat and potatoes of pizza making in the robot's hands, a handicapped owner should have more time to manage his business affairs, said Tom Poppa, who owns Fox's stores in Irwin and Monroeville. ``It's still the American dream to own your own business,'' Poppa said. Fox's, CMU and Pittsburgh human services industries and charities founded Robotic Assisted Employment, a partnership trying to place robots in the region's restaurants, cafeterias and airline kitchens. Fox, whose father was a disabled war veteran, said he was motivated to help handicapped people because of frustration he saw while ``growing up by spending my weekends in veterans' hospitals.''

DOC.HEAD: Kim Offers to Meet South Korean Counterpart
DOC.TEXT: North Korean Communist dictator Kim Il Sung on Thursday offered to meet South Korea's president for the first time since the Korean peninsula was divided four decades ago. His offer was contingent on progress in high-level talks between the enemy neighbors, but it was seen as a positive step toward easing tension. The 78-year-old Kim, head of one of the world's most closed societies and the longest-ruling Communist dictator, told South Korea's premier he hoped for progress in a third round of North-South premiers talks. The second round of talks finished Thursday in North Korea's capital of Pyongyang with no tangible results. Both sides claimed their differences had narrowed and they agreed to meet again in Seoul Dec. 11-14. If the December talks come off as scheduled, it will mean the rival Koreas will have met three times in roughly three months to discuss face-to-face issues at the senior levels of government. ``The issues being discussed at the premiers' talks would also be discussed at the summit talks,'' Kim told South Korean Premier Kang Young-hoon. ``I want the prime ministers to do a lot of work so that summit talks can be held ... and bring about good results.'' He said the talks between Kang and North Korean Premier Yon Hyong Muk must show ``visible results'' before a summit can be planned. The premiers' contacts are the highest level talks between the two sides since the peninsula was divided in 1945 and they hold great symbolic value as a meeting of two enemy nations. The two Koreas fought a three-year war in the early 1950s; a peace treaty was never signed. The border between them is tightly sealed and remains one of the most heavily fortified in the world, with 1.5 million troops on either side. The next and most significant step toward easing decades of confrontation and beginning efforts toward unification would be a summit between the Communist leader of North Korea and the capitalist leader of South Korea. South Korean President Roh Tae-woo has called repeatedly for a summit meeting, but North Korea has not responded. Kim's willingness to even consider a summit is surprising to many South Koreans who for years have assumed change can only occur when the North Korean leader is dead. Partially for that reason, South Korea is obsessed with Kim Il Sung's health. Television reports of Thursday's meetings talked excessively about Kim's apparently robust health, his erect stature, his lack of a reported limp, and his voice, which was slightly hoarse. There was no immediate official South Korean response to Kim's comments, but officials said privately they viewed them as a step forward in efforts to improve relations. The South Korean delegation returns to Seoul on Friday. Reports of the two days of talks in Pyongyang said the differences narrowed on two different proposals calling for, among other things, mutual recognition, non-aggression and arms reductions. South Korea proposed a joint statement requiring both sides to recognize each other's government and cooperate through multilateral exchanges. North Korea insisted on a declaration of non-aggression. In another development Thursday, South Korean opposition leader Kim Dae-jung said he would end his 11-day-old hunger strike and call off a three-month boycott of Parliament if the governing party agrees to laws for prompt local elections. Kim said he had instructed his party's floor leader to complete negotiations with the governing party by midnight Friday. If there is no agreement, he warned, the turmoil in domestic politics would worsen. And in downtown Seoul, 11 radical students wielding steel pipes and firebombs tried to attack the U.S. Embassy but were overpowered by police, police officials said. ``Drive out yankees!'' the students shouted as they were taken away by police, witnesses said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Amendment Shifting Burden to Rich
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Moves up references to more than 2 dozen amendments and hopes of having bill on Bush's desk by Friday. Edits throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: throughout

The Senate today voted 55-45 to defeat an effort to raise taxes on the rich and moderate a Medicare premium increase as it struggled to complete work on a deficit-reduction plan. The vote killed an amendment by Sens. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., that would have scaled back increases in gasoline taxes and Medicare premiums and substituted a House-approved, three-pronged attack on those with higher incomes. The amendment was one of more than two dozen ready for Senate consideration, many of which have been designed to move the Senate bill closer to the soak-the-rich package that won House approval Tuesday. ``Do we want to ask senior citizens in the hospital to pay more so the wealthiest in our society can pay less?'' Gore asked before the vote on his amendment. ``The middle class has no more to give,'' Ms. Mikulski said. Democratic leaders praised the aim of the amendment but said it would have killed the deficit-reduction package because President Bush has promised to veto any plan raising the top tax rate on the wealthiest Americans to 33 percent. The proposal would have raised that rate from 28 percent. ``What we have tried to do is put together a package the president will sign,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee. ``There is substantial divergence with what came out of the House. ... We will end up with something that is in between.'' The budget bill is on a fast track that congressional leaders hope could place it on Bush's desk for his signature Friday night. Without final action, or at least considerable progress on such a package, Bush has said he'll shut down the government Saturday morning, when federal spending authority is due to expire. A key element of the Senate's deficit plan is a 9{-cent increase in the gasoline tax. The Senate voted Wednesday to leave that provision intact. The Gore-Mikulski amendment would have provided a 6-cent increase. The amendment would have been attached to a measure raising taxes and reducing benefit programs by $250 billion over the next five years. In addition to increasing the tax rate for the wealthiest Americans, the Gore-Mikulski plan proposed imposing a 10 percent surtax on those with taxable incomes over $1 million and raising to 25 percent the alternative minimum tax designed to snare well-to-do investors who have so many deductions that they might otherwise escape any tax. The Senate package appeared to be in considerable trouble Wednesday after Sen. Steven Symms, R-Idaho, proposed stripping the 9{-cent increase in the gasoline tax. The issue wasn't settled until almost 14 hours later, just before midnight, when the Senate heeded pleas from Democratic and Republican leaders and used a procedural vote to dispose of Symms' amendment. ``Once again the American people are going to have their pockets picked,'' Symms protested. ``A vote for this amendment is a vote to destroy this effort at deficit reduction,'' countered Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine. ``No senator who votes for the Symms amendment should have the temerity to go anywhere and say they are trying to reduce the deficit.'' Symms' amendment, which was put aside on a 59-40 vote, probably was the biggest challenge facing the bipartisan proposal. In addition to raising the 9-cent gasoline tax and the 15-cent tax on diesel by 9{ cents a gallon, the bill would boost taxes on alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and such luxuries as expensive cars, boats, furs and jewelry. It would require retirees to pay slightly more for Medicare coverage of doctors' bills; limit itemized deductions of people making more than $100,000 a year and raise to $89,000 the $51,300 maximum wage against which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is applied. A bigger package was shot down by the Senate on a 67-32 vote. Sponsored by Sens. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., and Max Baucus, D-Mont., it would have included those three tax increases on the wealthy, moderated the gas tax increase and Medicare charges, restored half of $15 billion in farm-program cuts that would be required for deficit reduction, and eliminated the proposed limitation on itemized deductions claimed by higher-income people. Raising the gasoline tax in the name of deficit reduction is one of the less popular ideas in Congress. The House would not accept a package that included such an increase, and senators were told Wednesday that drivers would rebel. The $250 billion in tax increases and tightening of Medicare and other benefits represents about half a promised $500 billion deficit-reduction plan. The remainder, still working its way through Congress, would come from reductions in appropriations and in interest the government pays for borrowing.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister `Clarifies' Commitment To US On Loan Guarantees
DOC.TEXT: Under pressure from Cabinet hard-liners, the foreign minister on Thursday backed off a promise he made to the United States that Israel would not settle more Soviet immigrants in Arab east Jerusalem. The change could affect $400 million in loan guarantees the Bush administration approved last week after receiving the minister's promise. The change of position by Foreign Minister David Levy came in a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The letter was sent Thursday and read aloud on Israel radio. A Foreign Minstry official confirmed its contents. Levy said in the letter that he wanted to clarify ``differing interpretations'' of a letter he signed Oct. 2 while visiting the United States to secure the loan guarantees to help finance housing for Soviet Jews. In the Oct. 2 letter, Levy wrote that Israel's policy ``is not to direct or settle Soviet Jews beyond the green line.'' The green line divides Arab territories captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 war - the West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem - from Israel proper. But in his new letter Levy said he ``made no commitment, directly or indirectly'' not to house Soviet Jews in east Jerusalem, or even in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He said, however, that U.S. funds would not be used to build such settlements. The Bush administration considers east Jerusalem occupied land, along with the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It has opposed settlement of Jews on such land as an obstacle to ending the Arab-Israeli conflict under the U.S. policy calling for trading occupied land for peace. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir also sought Thursday to reverse any U.S. conditions that Levy agreed to in his first letter. ``Whomever accepts these conditions doesn't mean he agrees to all these limitations always and under all circumstances,'' Shamir said on the radio without elaborating. The issue of the loan guarantees has become entangled with Israel's anger over last week's U.N. Security Council resolution condemning the Jewish state for the police killings of 19 Palestinians in a riot on the Temple Mount. On Sunday, Israel's Cabinet rejected the resolution and said it would not accept a U.N. investigation of the killings, which occurred in east Jerusalem on what Israel considers sovereign territory. That same day, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon announced that he planned to build up to 17,000 new housing units for Soviet immigrants in Jerusalem in the next three years, most in the Arab eastern sector. In announcing the plans, Sharon said: ``We never obligated ourselves not to build in Jerusalem, never.'' Levy made the promise to Baker before the Oct. 8 Temple Mount riots and has been called to task since by Shamir and Sharon. At the same time, the issue has arisen in Washington, and Baker has said he considers Levy's commitment on housing to apply to east Jerusalem. Baker told reporters Tuesday, ``We think the United States is and should be entitled to rely upon assurances received from the foreign minister of Israel.'' But Levy said in his latest letter that was not the case. He wrote: ``I want to make sure that you are aware that it (the earlier letter) made no commitment, either directly or indirectly, to refrain from building in east Jerusalem, or restricting it, or in any other place, including Judea, Samaria and Gaza.'' Judea and Samaria are the biblical names for the West Bank. The United States took months to negotiate the loan guarantees with Israel, at a time when it was trying to bring together Israeli and Palestinian delegates in the first preliminary peace talks between the two sides. It was also when Palestinian leaders and Arab states were complaining that the housing of Soviet Jews in the occupied territories could push out the 1.7 million Palestinians who live there. Only several hundred Soviet families are believed to have settled in the West Bank or Gaza, but more than 3,000 Soviets have moved to east Jerusalem where Israel has built a ring of Jewish suburbs around the Arab city. About 140,000 Palestinians live in east Jerusalem, along with about 120,000 Jews. Israel receives $1.2 billion in U.S. economic aid annually and is the largest recipient of U.S. assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Issues Christmas Stamps
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service on Thursday issued this year's 25-cent Christmas stamps featuring traditional and contemporary themes. The traditional stamp featuring a religious painting and a contemporary stamp showing a brightly decorated cut-paper tree were released at a ceremony at the National Gallery of Art, with Richard J. Strasser, senior assistant postmaster general, speaking. The design on the first incorporates a portion of 15th-century Sicilian painter Antonella da Messina's Madonna and Child, which is part of the museum's collection. The contemporary stamp, designed by Libby Thiel of Bryan's Road, Md., was presented in a ceremony in Evergreen, Colo. attended by Kenneth J. Hunter, associate postmaster general. The stamps will be available in sheets of 50 and in booklets of 20.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Said To Be Undecided About Advice on 1991 Defense Bill
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon on Thursday criticized major parts of the 1991 military budget approved by congressional negotiators, but a spokesman said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had not decided whether to recommend a presidential veto. Cheney is on an official visit to the Soviet Union. He has been apprised by his Pentagon office of Wednesday's outcome of House and Senate negotiations on defense spending for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, said spokesman Bob Hall. The bill sets military spending at $288 billion, or $19 billion less than the Bush administration requested last January. The bill, which must be approved by the full House and Senate, sharply reduces spending on major strategic weapons programs and imposes larger troops cuts than Bush had sought. Hall said he could not say whether Cheney will recommend that Bush veto the bill and that the defense secretary won't know all the measure's details until it is filed formally in the House and Senate, probably on Friday. Hall said that while he could not speak for Cheney on specific aspects of the spending bill, others in the Pentagon have raised numerous objections. For example, he said, the $2.9 billion budgeted for the Strategic Defense Initiative is nearly $2 billion less than Bush requested and $900 million less than Congress provided last year for the antimissile research program. Hall also cited a provision in the bill requiring a cut of 100,000 troops from the 2.1 million now in uniform. Cheney had urged Congress to hold the cuts to 80,000. The Pentagon also is unhappy with a provision that establishes new procedures for closing military bases. Hall said this would set up a ``cumbersome process that appears to be designed to delay and deter and prevent management decisions.'' Although the bill makes deeper cuts in military spending and troop levels than Bush had proposed, Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said he believed the president would not veto the measure. ``I'm optimistic that the president will sign this bill - the best that could be achieved in this conference, given the circumstances fiscally,'' Warner said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake Jolts Orange County In Southern California; No Injuries
With PM-Earthquake Anniversary, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake jolted Orange County in Southern California today, breaking glass but causing no injuries or serious damage. The 10:21 a.m. quake, a year and a day after the major quake in Northern California, measured 4.0 on the Richter scale and was centered one mile north of Costa Mesa, said Dorothy Jennings of the California Institute of Technology. ``It was a pretty good jolt,'' said Susan Maples, spokeswoman for South Coast Plaza, one of the nation's largest shopping malls, which is located close to the epicenter. ``We all got up in the doorway.'' She said the only damage discovered immediately was a single fallen ceiling tile. At the May Co., crystal department sales clerk Ursula Yang said a few things fell off the shelves and broke. Costa Mesa is about 50 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. At Disneyland in nearby Anaheim, ``we certainly felt it,'' said spokesman Bob Roth. ``I don't think the people in the park felt it, though. There was no response. There was no damage. ``Everybody looked a little peaked for a minute there, but nothing fell down or anything,'' he said. Dan Carpenter, service manager at a Von's supermarket about four miles southwest of the epicenter, said the store's only loss was about six bottles of wine that fell from a shelf. Canned goods also were knocked off shelves. Gary Gray, owner of Orange Coast Jeep-Eagle Inc. in Costa Mesa, said: ``It was a severe jolt. The showroom is covered with glass and we lost about four panes of 4 foot by 12 foot each.'' No one was hurt, he said. Police reported no injuries. ``It hit home real hard, just boom, you could feel the rattle and roll coming, like that wave effect,'' said Officer Bob Crogan of the Costa Mesa Police Department. A magnitude 4.0 to 4.9 quake on the Richter scale of ground motion is considered small to moderate and is capable of producing some local damage. The quake of Oct. 17, 1989, which measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people and caused an estimated $7 billion in damage in the San Francisco-Oakland area of Northern California.

DOC.HEAD: Top 10 Cities at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a look at the fiscal condition of the nation's 10 largest cities, along with Standard & Poors' rating of each city's ability to repay its bond investors. The highest possible rating is AAA, then AA, then A plus, and so forth. The lowest possible rating is D. The cities are listed by population size, beginning with the largest.
New York: Standard & Poors bond rating: A- New York City is facing its worst fiscal crisis since it nearly went bankrupt in the mid-1970s. Mayor David Dinkins is trying to plug a $1.8 billion budget deficit in this fiscal year's budget. He announced plans Tuesday for $1.3 billion in cuts, including layoffs of least 15,000 city workers. The city also has a major crime problem and on Oct. 2, Dinkins announced plans to hire nearly 8,000 more police officers as part of a four-year, $1.9 billion effort. But its proposed financing remains in doubt.
Los Angeles Bond rating: AA A relatively healthy economy coupled with stringent legislative spending caps have prevented serious fiscal woes from besetting Los Angeles. However, the $3.6 billion budget approved by the City Council in June provided for 6 percent cuts in all city departments except police, emergency medical services and sanitation. Mayor Tom Bradley said the cuts in the 1990-91 spending plan were intended to ``maneuver a soft landing in order to prevent a crash later.'' Bradley also declared a municipal hiring freeze that began in March and lasted through June 30.
Chicago Bond rating: A- Mayor Richard M. Daley has proposed a $3.1 billion 1991 budget based on the assumption the city will keep collecting revenues from what is now a temporary income tax surcharge. But if the Illinois General Assembly doesn't extend the surcharge beyond June 1991, the budget would be $75 million short. Daley indicated he would propose a supplemental budget in that likelihood and cautioned that ``essential services'' may have to be cut. The budget includes funds for an additional 600 police officer and for pay raises worth $71 million to the city's unionized workers, as required by contract.
Houston Bond rating: AA After struggling through economic hard times brought on by the collapse in oil prices in the 1980s, the nation's energy capital has enjoyed a modest recovery the last several years. There have been no budget cuts for the 1990 fiscal year that began July 1 and no layoffs. For the first time in several years, the city has seen an increase in property tax values.
Philadelphia Bond rating: CCC Philadelphia faces a $206 million deficit in the fiscal year that ends next June 30. Mayor W. Wilson Goode has frozen hiring and delayed pension fund payments and tax refunds, but the city expects to go broke by Dec. 1. Few taxes can be raised or added without state approval. The wage tax already is among the nation's highest. A proposal to impose a half-cent sales tax on top of the state's 6 percent tax was passed by the City Council but awaits action in the Legislature. The increase would only raise $45 million a year. Further budget cuts are difficult, because many expenses are locked in by long-term labor contracts.
Detroit Bond rating: BBB Longstanding fiscal problems could worsen because of a fluke of Michigan law. The law allows cities with a population of 1 million or more to impose special taxes on utilities and paychecks. Detroit had been the only city to qualify, but preliminary 1990 Census figures put Detroit's population at 970,000. The utility tax generates more than $50 million annually, while the income tax brings in $190 million. Detroit's budget is about $1.9 billion. Mayor Coleman A. Young has threatened vast layoffs if the state doesn't extend the utility tax.
San Diego Bond rating: AA plus The 1990-91 budget is $956 million. Although it was San Diego's largest ever, mayoral spokesman Paul Downy said the city had to freeze some services at the 1989-90 level. ``There's been a slight decline in city services but we had no option, short of raising taxes, and that's something we didn't want to do,'' Downey said. Still, Downey added that the city is in good financial shape overall. He said officials are continuing efforts to ``recession-proof'' the city.
Dallas Bond rating: AAA Fiscal analysts nationwide point to Dallas as an example of a city that has weathered tough times by hewing to fiscal conservatism. The 1990-91 budget included some staff cuts to pay for an increase in police staffing. Overall, spending was cut by slightly more than $8 million to $1.006 billion. Cynthia Marietta, director of budget research, said the city tried to make cuts without hurting essential services.
San Antonio Bond rating: AA San Antonio has faced financial problems the past two fiscal years. In September the City Council adopted a $774.2 million budget that required the elimination of 225 jobs and an 8 percent tax rate increase. The services cut include public works, parks and recreation, and libraries. There was much public debate about paying for school crossing guards until a restaurant chain agreed to help pay for the service.
Phoenix Bond rating: AA plus City officials announced delays last month for about 200 capital-improvement projects, which now will take eight years instead of five. The Phoenix real estate market remains in a slump, and city officials said the timetable revision was needed because of slow growth in assessed valuations for property taxes. Delayed projects include sewers, parks, low-income housing, fire stations, improvements to a theater and art museum, and construction of a science museum and a library.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Wound 35 Palestinians in Gaza Strip
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops shot and wounded 35 Palestinians with live ammunition and rubber bullets on Thursday in seven hours of clashes fueled by army efforts to set up a new lookout post in a Gaza Strip refugee camp. The incident reflected the continuing tension in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip over the Temple Mount killings on Oct. 8 in Jerusalem. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealed again Thursday to the United States and other nations to put the Temple Mount incident behind them and refocus their attention on the Persian Gulf crisis. He defended Israel's rejection of a U.N. fact-finding team, saying it challenged Israel's control of Jerusalem. Israel seized east Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the 1967 Middle East war. ``Israel can, in no way, sign with its own hands a verdict abandoning its sovereignty over Jerusalem,'' Shamir told army radio. ``We call on our friends to turn the poor page, to wipe it off and to concentrate again on the main mission - curbing the terrible threat to peace and stability in this part of the world,'' Shamir said. Residents of the Gaza Strip's Rafah camp said the incident began when soldiers raised an Israeli flag on a rooftop in the center of the camp. Scores of teen-agers began throwing stones, and at least eight military jeeps full of soldiers were sent to try to restore order, the residents told Arab reporters. ``The entire camp was in turmoil for seven hours,'' one said. The army said in a statement that ``an army unit in Rafah was attacked massively by stones.'' It said soldiers responded by ``firing plastic bullets in a controlled fashion.'' An army official confirmed on condition of anonymity that the soldiers were setting up a lookout post and said the camp reaction ``was not expected.'' Arab hospitals said 35 Palestinians were treated for bullet wounds, most from live ammunition. The army put the toll at 26 and said most had light wounds. On Oct. 8, Israeli police opened fire on Palestinian rioters on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, killing at least 19 Arabs and wounding 140 others. The shooting came after the rioters threw stones on Jewish worshipers at the Wailing Wall below. The Wall is also known as the Western Wall. It was the worst violence in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Some 761 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the uprising, and an additional 281 were slain by other Arabs as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Forty-eight Israelis also have died. The Temple Mount, located in east Jerusalem, is the most sensitive spot in the Arab-Israeli conflict. Jews revere it as the site of their ancient temple. To Moslems, it is the place where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven. Israel has launched its own investigation into the shooting deaths, and the three-man commission headed by a former Mossad spy chief, Zvi Zamir, is expected to conclude its probe next week. In Jerusalem on Thursday, city police commanders were quoted as saying that a force of paramilitary border policemen reportedly deployed without police knowledge on the Temple Mount may have fueled last week's riot. The disclosure on Israel radio was the first Israeli suggestion that police might have provoked the violence at the holy site, not Palestinian demonstrators. Arab witnesses have claimed police set off the violence by firing tear gas, then rubber bullets and live ammunition at Arabs on the Mount. The radio report did not identify the police commanders but said they made the statement to the Zamir commission, which has kept its findings private. Jerusalem police spokesman Aharon Elhayani declined comment. Border police commanders rejected the claims, saying they had documents proving there had been advance notification of the paramilitary posting, the radio reported.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0671 to restore keyword line
25 More Films Added to Registry of Best Movies
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five American movies, as old as ``The Great Train Robbery'' of 1903 and as recent as ``Raging Bull'' in 1980, were named Thursday to the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress as outstanding films worthy of historic preservation. The list was announced by James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, under terms of a 1988 statute that established the registry to honor 25 films a year deemed ``culturally, historically or aesthetically significant.'' ``This is not Academy Awards night,'' Billington told a news conference. ``These are not annual lists of the `best' American films.'' Rather, he said, they were chosen because they ``impressively display the depth and variety of the American creative spirit'' in filmmaking. This year's selections join the first 25 films chosen last year for the registry. Listed alphabetically, the 1990 choices are: ``All About Eve,'' made in 1950 by director Joseph L. Mankiewicz; ``All Quiet on the Western Front,'' 1930, directed by Lewis Milestone; ``Bringing Up Baby,'' 1938, produced and directed by Howard Hawks; ``Dodsworth,'' 1936, directed by William Wyler; ``Duck Soup,'' the Marx brothers classic made in 1933, Walt Disney's ``Fantasia,'' made in 1940. Also, Harold Lloyd's ``The Freshman,'' made in 1925; Francis Coppola's ``The Godfather,'' 1972; Edwin S. Porter's ``The Great Train Robbery,'' a 12-minute classic made in 1903; ``Harlan County, U.S.A.,'' 1973, directed by Barbara Kopple; John Ford's ``How Green Was My Valley,'' 1941; Frank Capra's ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' 1946. Also, Charles Burnett's ``Killer of Sheep,'' 1977; ``Love Me Tonight,'' produced and directed by Rouben Mamoulian, 1932; ``Meshes of the Afternoon,'' an 18-minute film directed by Maya Deren in 1943; ``Ninotchka,'' a 1939 Greta Garbo film directed by Ernst Lubitsch; ``Primary,'' a Time Inc. film made in 1960. Also, ``Raging Bull,'' directed by Martin Scorsese, 1980; ``Rebel Without a Cause,'' the James Dean movie of 1955; ``Red River,'' made by Howard Hawks, 1948; ``The River,'' a 32-minute Farm Security Administration film made in 1937; ``Sullivan's Travels,'' a Preston Sturges film made in 1941. Also, ``Top Hat,'' a 1935 musical starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers; ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' directed by John Huston, 1948, and ``A Woman Under te Influence,'' directed by John Cassavetes, 1974. The list was based on 1,500 nominations made by the public, and narrowed by a 14-member National Film Preservation Board representing the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the American Film Institute, movie and television producers, directors, broadcasters, screen writers, the Screen Actors Guild of America, film critics and scholars. The final choices were made by Billington, a cultural historian and movie buff, based on consultations with advisers including the staff of the library's division of motion picture, broadcasting and recorded sound. Films are eligible for the registry 10 years after their first theatrical release. They need not necessarily be American films, the library said, but the first 50 movies in the registry all were made in the United States. The Library of Congress contains the nation's largest film archive, and accounts for more than half the number of films preserved in the United States. Even so, Billington said, half of all movies made before 1950 - and 80 percent of those made before 1930 - are lost forever. ``The cold, hard fact is that, for all their popularity in America today, films are an endangered species for the America of tomorrow,'' he said. Billington estimated it would cost a minimum of $600 million to preserve all remaining American movies on nitrate film, a highly flammable film that eventually deteriorates into gunpowder. Other library officials said the cost of restoring those movies and transferring them to safety film is probably closer to $1 billion or more. The library's annual budget for film preservation is about $300,000, officials said. Billington said the library is still trying to obtain archival quality originals of two films selected last year for deposit in its national film collection. They are ``Some Like It Hot,'' the Billy Wilder movie of 1959, and ``The Best Years of Our Lives'' of 1946. So far, library officials said, six of the 50 listed in the National Film Registry have been released in colorized versions on videotape cassettes. Under the 1988 law, those taped copies must carry a label noting that they are colorized versions of black and white films that were ``altered without the participation of the principal director, screenwriter and other creators of the original film.'' The six are ``The Maltese Falcon,'' ``Casablanca,'' ``Bringing Up Baby,'' ``The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,'' ``Top Hat'' and ``It's a Wonderful Life,'' officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Stallone Gets 3-Year Court Order to Keep Female Fan Away
DOC.TEXT: An obsessed fan who has harassed Sylvester Stallone for years was ordered by a judge Thursday to stay away from the macho ``Rambo'' and ``Rocky'' movie star. Superior Court Judge Irving Shimer granted Stallone's request for a three-year injunction ordering Elsie Wade to stay at least 200 yards away from the actor's Malibu beach house and his White Eagle Enterprises. Stallone and Ms. Wade didn't attend the brief court session. The Santa Monica woman also was prohibited from following or telephoning Stallone or writing and personally delivering any letters. Gary Compton, the actor's security chief, told the court earlier that Ms. Wade arrives at the Stallone home between 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. to hand deliver notes. One note included a photograph of slain singer John Lennon and a statement reading, ``Now that's frightening,'' Compton told the court. Over two years, the woman has delivered more than 200 cards and letters to Stallone's home, placing up to 10 letters or cards a day in his mailbox. Stallone said in a court statement earlier: ``I am extremely concerned that Ms. Wade may be a great danger and threat to me.'' Many Hollywood celebrities have been plagued by obsessive fans, including Johnny Carson, David Letterman, Michael J. Fox, Olivia Newton-John and Sharon Gless.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian-British Ties Taking Center Stage in Fate of Lebanon Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to make minor change in wording of quote. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `When the..'
DOC.TEXT: Freedom for British hostages in Lebanon may take time if the restoration of diplomatic ties between Syria and Britain is made a condition for their release, a Western diplomatic source said Thursday. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said he saw no linkage between British and U.S. hostages. He said there was ``nothing special'' to indicate any U.S. hostages would be freed soon. The Western source responded to comments made by Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa on Wednesday to the NBC television network. In the interview, al-Shaara said the pro-Iranian extremists holding most of the 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon would take the hostage issue more seriously if ties were restored between Syria and Britain. ``I can say securing the release of the British hostages would be easier if there's a diplomatic relationship between Syria and Britain,'' al-Sharaa said. When the hostage-takers know that Syria and Britain have restored ties, ``certainly they'll take more seriously our pressure and our efforts,'' he said. The missing Westerners are six Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. On Thursday, Sharaa told British journalists that Syria would keep working to win the release of British hostages, backtracking from his comments to NBC. Syria is the main power-broker in Lebanon, and previous hostage releases have depended on Syrian help. Britain broke relations with Syria in October 1986 after claiming it had evidence Syrian Air Force intelligence was involved inan abortive attempt to put a bomb aboard an Israeli airliner at London's Heathrow Airport. Syria has denied involvement. The Western source said both Iran and Syria have concluded that continued captivity for the hostages is in neither nation's interest. He said the recent Syrian-led removal of rebel Lebanese Gen. Michel Aoun in east Beirut will have a ``positive effect'' on the hostages because of the diminished role of militias that will follow. Beirut newspapers have reported that one of the British hostages, Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, would be freed soon. But informed sources, with some knowledge of the negotiations to free the captives, said another Briton, journalist John McCarthy, would be released before Waite. Waite disappeared Jan.20, 1987, in Beirut. McCarthy was kidnapped in Beirut on April 17, 1986. No group has claimed to hold either man, but they are believed to be the captives of pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem groups.

DOC.HEAD: From Harvard to Honolulu, Opponents to Gulf Intervention Mobilize
DOC.TEXT: A diverse coalition is taking to the airwaves, handing out leaflets and holding teach-ins in an effort to awaken opposition to U.S. intervention in the Middle East. A round of protests began Thursday at Harvard University, where students and faculty held teach-ins reminiscent of the Vietnam era. The events continue through Saturday, when rallies are planned in at least 15 cities. Television ads opposing U.S. intervention and starring Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic aired for the first time Thursday, and support was widening for a Marine corporal facing court-martial in Honolulu after he refused to go to Saudi Arabia with his unit. ``The response we've been getting is tremendous, versus how long it took to build up opposition to the Vietnam War,'' said Charles Twist, spokesman for the New York Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. This time, though, the coalition members range from veterans groups and labor unions to disabled people and environmentalists. Groups representing the homeless and the elderly also are involved. A protest march on Saturday in New York City will begin in Harlem. ``It's a big step forward from the '60s when the majority of the anti-war movement was mostly white and mostly students,'' Twist said. Organizers credit this apparent broad appeal not only to concerns about the morality of sending soldiers to the Middle East, but also to the cost. ``The front pages are full of the budget crisis,'' Twist said. ``It doesn't take much to make the connection that we're spending billions to keep our troops there at the same time we're cutting Social Security.'' Anti-intervention leaders, who complain they have been virtually ignored by mainstream media, said the word is being spread. ``There's been very little negative response and not a lot of leaflets end up on the ground,'' said Phebe Eckfeldt, spokeswoman for the New England Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. Veterans group have been particularly active in the opposition. ``The days of U.S. veterans blindly supporting their government are over since Vietnam,'' said Winston Warfield, president of the 400-member Smedley D. Butler Brigade of Veterans for Peace. ``U.S. soldiers are being asked to pay the ultimate price in a war for oil and to protect the grotesque profits of multinational oil interests.'' Kovic, author of ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' stars in a 30-second television spot, funded by money raised from veteran and peace groups, and airing in 50 U.S. cities. In it, he says American troops are risking their lives ``not to defend democracy, but to protect the big oil companies.'' Kovic is scheduled to address a Los Angeles rally Saturday. Labor unions also have been drawn to the protests. ``You've got inflation, budget cuts, joblessness, and now the war,'' said Nan Genger, an organizer for a United Auto Workers local that is co-sponsoring the rally scheduled for Boston. ``Working people are under attack.'' Besides Los Angeles, New York and Boston, protests are planned on Saturday for Albuquerque, N.M., Birmingham, Ala., Chicago, Cleveland, Honolulu, Houston, Minneapolis, Olympia, Wash., Portland, Ore., San Diego, San Francisco and Seattle. They follow rallies held on Tuesday in Honolulu, Washington, Houston, Seattle and San Francisco in support of Jeffrey Paterson, a 22-year-old Marine corporal who refused to go to the Middle East with his unit. There also are events planned Saturday supporting U.S. forces in the Middle East. In Atlanta, where protesters plan to gather at a downtown induction center Saturday, families of soldiers stationed in the gulf have scheduled a counterdemonstration. And in Savannah, Ga., residents will bake and airlift 120,000 brownies to the 24th Infantry Division now in Saudi Arabia. President Bush, who has been heckled along the campaign trail this week, has defended the U.S. involvement amid signs of decreasing public support. ``The bottom line for us is Iraqi aggression will not be allowed to stand, Saddam Hussein will be held accountable and the legitimate government of Kuwait will be restored,'' Bush said Tuesday. A recent Washington Post-ABC News Poll showed 60 percent of people questioned believe the United States should keep troops in the region until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait. Five weeks ago, the figure had been 75 percent.

DOC.HEAD: University To Return Rare Music to Austrian Monastery
DOC.TEXT: A university will return rare copies of works by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and other composers apparently stolen from an Austrian monastery at the end of World War II, officials said Thursday. ``We are sad to see them go,'' said John Roberts, chief music librarian for the University of California at Berkeley. The 18 manuscripts include religious works by Mozart and Michael Haydn transcribed by monks in the 18th century and s- an evening mass - and liturgical works by lesser-known composers, Roberts said. An Austrian music expert noticed this year that there were several references to the missing works in a catalogue published by UC-Berkeley in 1988. ``They inquired and we investigated,'' Roberts said. ``It became clear to us that they had been unlawfully removed during the war and it seemed appropriate that they be returned.'' The manuscripts are ``important but not priceless'' parts of the Berkeley music library, Roberts said. They include 13 copies of Austrian church music and five Schubert songs, many of which are unpublished, Roberts said. UC-Berkeley has one of the world's foremost music collections.

DOC.HEAD: WPPSS To Try To Keep Options Open To Finish Nuclear Plants
DOC.TEXT: Washington state public power officials said Thursday they will ask the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to extend a construction permit for a nuclear power plant now in mothballs. An extension for the No. 1 plant at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation would give the Washington Public Power Supply System the option of completing the plant that was 63 percent finished when construction came to a halt in 1982. This appears to be the first time any operator has indicated interest in resuming construction of a commercial nuclear power plant that was put on hold over the last decade, said Frank Miraglia, deputy director of the NRC's Office of Nuclear Reactor Regulation. WPPSS officials told NRC staff members during a meeting at commission headquarters that they have not decided whether they want to complete the system's No. 1 plant at Hanford or another mothballed facility, the No. 3 plant at Satsop, Wash. The No. 3 plant was 76 percent done when work stopped in 1983. Construction at the plants was halted due to the default of municipal bonds and a sharp downturn in energy demand. The No. 3 plant's federal construction permit is good until 1999, but the NRC permit issued for the No. 1 plant in 1975 will expire in June. Gerry Sorensen, WPPSS's manager of regulatory programs, said the supply system will ask the NRC ``probably in February or Marc to extend the construction permit for the Hanford plant. ``But we have no direction at this time to pick up the hammer and start building again,'' he said. During Thursday's meeting, WPPSS officials sought the NRC's cooperation in identifying potential roadblocks to licensing the plants and reviewing proposed solutions to such concerns. ``We would like to enhance the licensability of the plants,'' said Don Bouchey, the supply system's director of licensing and assurance. Sorensen said he could foresee no problems that would be ``show stoppers ... issues that would stop us dead in our tracks.'' Miraglia said the NRC will be happy to cooperate, but regulators will need more specific plans before they can review the licensing potential. Energy demands in the Pacific Northwest are expected to increase over the next 20 years due to economic growth and the potential for reduced hydroelectric power as a result of anticipated environmental protection in rivers where salmon spawn, Sorensen said.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU and National Guard Criticize Mayor's Plan for Capital's Drug Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf pvs bgng, `Barry, who,' to UPDATE with council member noting that Barry previously opposed calling in the Guard
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union and a National Guard official on Thursday criticized Mayor Marion Barry's suggestion that curfews be imposed and troops called out to help slow the number of drug-related homicides in the nation's capital. Barry said Wednesday night that the city's drug wars and homicide rate are ``out of control.'' He said he may impose a curfewto keep drug dealers off city streets and may ask President Bush to send National Guard troops to conduct traffic patrols and help man roadblocks in drug-ravaged areas. But the ACLU and the Guard were cool to the proposals Thursday. ``We don't like the idea of curfews in general, and we certainly look upon any curfew with suspicion,'' said Arthur Spitzer, legal director of the national capital chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. ``One of the elements of a constitutional curfew would be that it would be a short-term response to an emergency, not an ongoing response to an enduring problem.'' Said District of Columbia National guard spokesman Harry Dorsey: ``The military is not permit Before soldiers could patrol the streets, the president would have to declare an emergency, Dorsey added. ``Typically, the Guard is called out after earthquakes, other natural disasters, riots, or other short-term things,'' Dorsey said. Declaring an emergency for an enduring problem ``could be done, but it would be unusual,'' he said. The mayor's remarks came as the city grappled to control a sharp increase in homicides, which are already on pace to set a new record - for the third year in a row. Nine homicides were reported last weekend. As of Thursday, 373 slayings were recorded so far this year. Police blame more than 60 percent of the killings on drugs. Barry, who is awaiting sentencing on one misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, made his comments at a candidates' forum. He is not seeking re-election but is running for a seat on the D.C. Council. City council member John Ray noted that Barry opposed involving the Guard in the city's drug war two years ago but is considering that option just three weeks before the election. ``It's real interesting that the mayor has gotten religion on the National Guard,'' said Ray, who opposes calling in the Guard. ``I think this is the mayor's new platform.'' Ray unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination for mayor this year but will keep his seat on the council. Two attempts by the D.C. Council to institute a curfew in the past two years were struck down in federal court on constitutional grounds. ``There may be a curfew law, somewhere, that has withstood constitutional scrutiny, but if there is, I am unaware of it,'' U.S. District Judge Charles R. Richey ruled in striking down a city law barring youths under the age of 18 from congregating on city streets at night. The ACLU had complained that the law violated teenagers' right of assembly and also prohibited them from traveling to and from legitimate activities like band practice and athletic events. The National Guard already assists the city police department's drug war by providing sophisticated surveillance equipment and helicopters for monitoring drug activity, Dorsey said. ``If we are asked to do more than that, the city in effect would be turning their powers over to us,'' Dorsey said. Barry said that before deciding on his next step, he will assess whether a new, 100-officer homicide task force reduces the killings.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Arrests Snaky Character
DOC.TEXT: A police officer stretched the truth when he reported having a prisoner in custody. Officer Will Platts did take a prisoner Tuesday. But the guilty party was a 7-foot-plus, 25-pound boa constrictor. And for a while it was Platts' arm that was in custody. Platts made the arrest after answering a call from Alton Ray Kelly about 10:15 p.m. A reluctant bystander held a flashlight to the snake's head while Platts picked it up. ``The snake got a little irritated when I picked him up. He hissed a little bit,'' Platts said. ``I thought, well, I've got him. Now what am I going to do with him?'' Nobody in the neighborhood acknowledged ownership, or even knowledge, of the snake. ``So, much to my wife's dismay, I brought him home until we can find out what to do,'' Platts said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Celebrates 107th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Blanche Maphis celebrated her 107th birthday Thursday but had little advice for others hoping to survive more than a century. ``I don't know why I have lived this long,'' she said. ``I worked very hard all my life.'' Mrs. Maphis loves playing bingo at the Sunnyview Home, the retirement home where she lives. ``I win a nickel once in a while, and it's good exercise for my eyes,'' she said. Mrs. Maphis reads the newspaper daily and attends church every Sunday. She was born Oct. 18, 1883, in New Martinsville, W.Va., and worked as a bookkeeper in Butler until retiring at age 70. Mrs. Maphis said she's grateful she got an education. She tried to drop out of school in seventh grade. ``My uncle made me go back,'' she said. ``I cried pretty hard, but I studied good and hard.'' Mrs. Maphis has an 81-year-old son, Edward, and two grandsons, six great-grandchildren and five great-great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Philanthropist Wants $250,000 Donation Back
DOC.TEXT: Drug-store magnate Jack Eckerd said he was misled into donating $250,000 to the University of South Florida Eye Institute - a week before its financial collapse. Now he wants his money back. In a Sept. 14 letter to university President Francis Borkowski, Eckerd said he was shocked to read a newspaper story about the private institute closing in September. Its building was paid off in a $14 million bailout from the Legislature and transferred to the university. ``I can't help but feel grossly misled,'' Eckerd wrote. ``I feel our good faith and trust has been ... maligned.'' University spokesman Mark Lono said Borkowski would agree to return Eckerd's money, but the institute foundation's entire board of directors will make the final decision. Steve Pankau, an institute foundation attorney, said the board probably would review Eckerd's request at its November board meeting. ``No one has indicated an interest in going against his wishes,'' Pankau said.

DOC.HEAD: County Residents Get Their Say on Times Beach Dioxin Incinerator
DOC.TEXT: St. Louis County voters may oppose a government plan to build a dioxin incinerator at Times Beach when they go to the polls Nov. 6. But a ``no'' vote isn't likely to halt the project aimed at cleaning up this community turned toxic ghost-town 20 miles from downtown St. Louis - not with the Environmental Protection Agency and Missouri's governor John Ashcroft solidly behind the plan. ``We don't have many vestiges of hope left,'' said Jerome Wallach, attorney for the neighboring town of Eureka and a spokesman against the incinerator. ``We fought the thing as hard as we could.'' For months, Wallach and fellow members of the citizen-based Times Beach Task Force have been fighting the plan to build a huge incinerator to burn dioxin-tainted soil from Times Beach and 27 other sites in eastern Missouri. Despite assurances from federal and state environmental officials, they doubt the incinerator's safety. They say it shouldn't be built in heavily populated St. Louis County, or in the Meramec River flood plain. They're also concerned that - state and federal pledges to the contrary - Times Beach will become a permanent hazardous waste site. Times Beach has sat empty and fenced-off since 1983, when the government bought out the town because of the discovery of dioxin in the soil on the town's streets. The toxic chemical was in the waste oil sprayed on the streets in the 1970s to keep the dust down. This summer, federal and state environmental officials reached a cleanup agreement with Syntex Agribusiness Inc. The plan calls for Syntex to provide about $100 million in cleanup services, including building and operating the incinerator, building a levee to protect the incinerator from Meramec River flooding, and demolishing abandoned buildings at Times Beach. Syntex didn't produce the dioxin, but the government considered the Palo Alto, Calif.-based firm a responsible party because the chemical was produced by a tenant in a Verona, Mo., plant owned by a company Syntex later acquired. Martha Steinkamp, regional counsel for the EPA, said the plan adequately addresses all safety concerns. She said the agency would go ahead with what it had determined to be the best alternative, despite public opposition. All that's left now is for the settlement with Syntex to be approved by U.S. District Judge John Nangle. Steinkamp said that could come before the end of the year. ``We're interested in getting this process through so we can hurry up and get the dioxin dug up and incinerated, so we can dismantle the incinerator, get out of there and return Times Beach to beneficial use,'' Steinkamp said. Ashcroft agrees, said his spokeswoman, Yolanda Murphy. ``He would like to see the proposed cleanup proceed,'' she said. ``The governor feels the EPA plan is the best viable alternative in dealing with the dioxin in a way that would protect both the health of the people and environment as well.'' Wallach said task force members had proposed the non-binding referendum, hoping a resounding ``no'' vote would sway state leaders, particularly Gov. Ashcroft. ``We're not going to change the EPA's mind,'' Wallach said. ``We're hoping that perhaps our elected officials will recognize that this is an absurd idea.'' Since the issue reached the November ballot, Ashcroft has made his support of the cleanup plan clear and hopes for the governor's intervention have been all but died. ``But hope springs eternal, doesn't it?'' Wallach said.

DOC.HEAD: United Way Charities Face Greater Competition
DOC.TEXT: Charities outside of United Way campaigns are gaining an increasing share of the millions of dollars that American workers give through workplace campaigns, a report said Thursday. The report was issued by the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, which has campaigned for giving workers access to newer and smaller charities that are not usually part of United Way campaigns. The committee, representing more than 300 fund-raising organizations, was established in 1976 to monitor developments in philanthropy. Alternative organizations are getting 10.1 percent of the money raised in workplace campaigns, the report said. Ten years ago, it said, alternative groups got 3.5 percent of the total. Among the alternative organizations are some health agencies such as the Muscular Dystrophy Association; international agencies such as CARE and Oxfam America; arts funds; the United Negro College Fund; and agencies which raise money for social action causes and women's and environmental groups. All told, United Way campaigns are expected to raise $3.2 billion in contributions this year, two-thirds of it through payroll deductions and other employee contribution programs. Organizations not under the United Way umbrella are expected to raise $205 million from employee contribution programs. ``We have already witnessed the dismantlement of the United Way's monopoly of workplace fund raising,'' said Robert Bothwell, executive director of NCRP. ``Our figures indicate that the 1990s will produce a 20 to 25 percent market share for alternatives to United Ways.'' Clark LaMendola, senior vice president of the United Way of America said the report failed to make clear that United Way acts as the campaign manager for raising most of the money collected by the alternative organizations. ``We get the volunteers together, we raise the money, we print the pledge cards, we count the money and we make sure the organizations get it,'' he said. He said the report gives the erroneous impression ``that these funds are somehow raised independently.'' Two-thirds of the $205 million expected to be raised this year on behalf of the alternative organizations will be solicited by campaigns managed by United Way, LaMendola said. The NCRP report said alternative charities made their most significant gain in the huge Combined Federal Campaign, which collects contributions from federal employees. CFC is the world's largest workplace charity drive. It solicits contributions from almost five million workers. In 1987, it collected $187 million. In 1980, United Way organizations got 71 percent of all money collected by the federal drive. By 1989, their share had fallen to 37 percent, the report said. ``CFC donors have sent out a message that has been picked up by workplace giving campaign decision makers across the country, in both the public and private sectors,'' said Don Sodo, who champions broader workplace fund drives. ``They have demonstrated that they are interested in a wide variety of charities, including those that provide services not within the somewhat limited United Way umbrella.'' Sodo is executive director of National-United Services Agencies, which represents 87 widely divergent organizations, including the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, National Organization for Women Legal Education and Defense Fund, Phyllis Schlafly's Eagle Forum, Ralph Nader's Public Citizen and the National Right to Life Educational Trust. The NCRP fought successfully in court and in Congress during the 1980s to broaden CFC drives to include alternative charities, including some lobbying and advocacy groups. The federal campaign now collects for United Way, seven other national federations, 220 unaffiliated agencies and thousands of local unaffiliated charities and federations, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Arrest Students Protesting Gulf Deployment Plan
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 250 riot police entered the Kyoto University campus on Thursday and arrested two students occupying an office to protest a government plan to send troops to the Persian Gulf, officials said. In Tokyo, police said 80 people, most of them women from a peace group, rallied outside the Foreign Ministry to protest the plan, which would allow deployment of Japanese soldiers abroad for the first time since World War II. The two students at Kyoto University had barricaded themselves inside the dean's office since early Wednesday, in one of the first public protests against the measure, which was introduced in Parliament on Tuesday. There has been a surge of criticism from Japanese media and politicians over the plan. Opinion polls have shown significant public opposition to sending Japanese soldiers overseas. Opponents say the bill violates the country's pacifist constitution, which bars the use of force to settle international disputes. Government officials say the bill is constitutional because the military would be deployed only for non-combat duty under the auspices of the United Nations. Soldiers would be allowed to carry small arms for self-defense only. The two students arrested in Kyoto were charged with trespassing, said Kyoto police spokesman Kenichi Yoshino. Police believe the students belong to a leftist radical group, Chukaku-ha. Yoshino said about two dozen radicals demonstrated at the campus when the riot police arrived, but there were no major incidents.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Couple Detained by Iraq Marry in Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: A Sicilian man held hostage by the Iraqi government was married Thursday after the government gave his fiancee a visa to come to Baghdad. ``This is fantastic,'' the groom, Paolo Carpino, 32, told reporters after his wedding at a luxury hotel here. Government officials and friends from Italy clapped and threw rice at the newlywed couple. Carpino is one of 325 Italians detained in Iraq by the government of Saddam Hussein since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Like many, he is being held as a human shield to deter attack by the U.S.-led multinational force. ``We were in love for the past 16 years but I could never imagine I would get married here,'' said the former Maria Colosa, 30, also from Sicily. Miss Colosa flew Thursday into Baghdad after the Iraqis gave her a visa and said they had no objection to their being married in Baghdad. Carpino has worked as an electrical engineer in the Iraqi city of Basra the past 18 months.

DOC.HEAD: Tens of Thousands Throng to See Mandela
DOC.TEXT: More than 80,000 wildly cheering people crowded a sports stadium Thursday to hear South African leader Nelson Mandela, who said the welcome made him ``feel like a man with his batteries recharged.'' ``I am full of strength and hope after visiting Calcutta,'' Mandela said at the Eden Garden stadium where he was given a mass reception by the government of West Bengal state. The crowd held up portraits of Mandela as he stepped to the podium, his dark blue suit speckled with petals showered by a hovering helicopter. Thousands waved flags of the anti-apartheid African National Congress, of which Mandela is deputy director. Thousands of men, women and children stood along the road from the airport to the Eden Garden stadium, which was decorated with welcome arches and buntings. ``We are overwhelmed by the kindness and honor shown by the people. ... I feel like a man with his batteries recharged,'' Mandela said. He arrived in the city of 12 million residents Thursday on the last leg of a five-day visit to India. After being released last year after 27 years in prison, Mandela has traveled widely to speak with leaders and garner international support for his anti-apartheid movement. Prime Minister V.P. Singh presented Mandela with a $5 million check for the ANC on Monday, and President Ramaswamy Venkataraman presented him with India's highest civilian honor, the Bharat Ratna, or ``India's Jewel.'' Later Mandela took in the sights at the Taj Mahal in Agra and in the holy Hindu city of Varanasi. He was to leave Friday for Indonesia and will later visit Brunei, Australia, Japan and Malaysia. He returns home Nov. 4. Mandela earlier noted the worldwide movement against apartheid began in India, which in 1954 became the first country to sever diplomatic relations with South Africa. Mandela paid tribute to Mohandas K. Gandhi, who began developing his strategy of nonviolent resistance during the 21 years he lived in South Africa. Gandhi returned to India in 1914 and led the struggle for indpendence from Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Memorial to Pogo Creator Walt Kelly to Be Dedicated Saturday
DOC.TEXT: Relatives and fans of the late Walt Kelly, creator of the Pogo comic strip, will travel to the edge of the Okefenokee Swamp this weekend to open a memorial to the cartoonist. The Okefenokee, located just south of Waycross in southeastern Georgia, is the home of the fictional Pogo Possum and his critter friends. Among those expected at Saturday's dedication of the Walt Kelly Room at the Okefenokee Heritage Center in Waycross are Selby Kelly, the cartoonist's widow, and writer Larry Doyle and artist Neal Sternecky, the team selected by Mrs. Kelly to revive the strip. The current version of the strip is distributed by the Los Angeles Times Syndicate. In addition to the dedication, Waycross' annual PogoFest will include a screening of a film on the life of Kelly, the auction of six original Kelly Pogo strips and a question-and-answer session by Mrs. Kelly, Doyle and Sternecky. The Kelly estate has donated to the memorial all the things the artist used to create his menagerie of Albert Alligator, Pogo Possum, Howland Owl, Churchy Lafemme, Beauregard Bugleboy, Porkypine and other swamp critters. The room, made to resemble Kelly's New York apartment, will display the portable typewriter, easel, ink bottles, pens and brushes Kelly used to draw the original Pogo from the 1940s through the early '70s. On permanent display will be Kelly's hat rack with his everyday coat and hat, as well as his more formal coat and top hat, his walking cane, his dark-rimmed spectacles, pipes and ashtrays. The room also will contain Mrs. Kelly's baby grand piano with the out-of-print ``Pogo Songbook,'' for which Kelly wrote both music and lyrics. Worldwide interest in Kelly and the Pogo characters runs high. The Pogo Fan Club has grown 300 percent since 1988, said Steve Thompson, who runs the international club from Richfield, Minn. Thompson said he hears monthly from fans in Canada, Germany, Denmark, Italy, England and Scotland. Recently, an Australian chapter was added. ``I knew the baby boomers would welcome the rejuvenation of the Pogo strip,'' he said, ``but I've been pleasantly surprised by the interest shown by the younger generation. ``It's a strip that makes you think. It takes some effort. But it rewards that effort. That's why I think it's been popular on college campuses since day one.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used Today In History for Sept. 18 are asked to use the following story:
DOC.TEXT: In its Today In History daily news feature on Sept. 18, The Associated Press erroneously reported that United Nations Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold died in a plane crash in northern Rhodesia in 1971. The correct year was 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Education Department Rule Comes Under Attack
DOC.TEXT: Officers of several degree-granting trade schools on Thursday attacked as ``cruel'' and ``discriminatory'' a proposed Education Department rule that changes the way they would measure a student's academic progress. The rule - among a host of regulations proposed to curb abuses, waste and mismanagement in the embattled federal student loan program - would redefine the academic year. Trade and vocational schools would be required to offer courses in ``clock hours,'' rather than credit hours. For the half million students attending ``career-specific'' schools, the rule would result in excessively long hours in the classroom and several extra years to earn a degree, officers of The Art Institutes International, DeVry Inc., The Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising, and ITT Educational Services Inc said at a news briefing. Colleges, universities and most community college programs would be excluded from the proposed rule, they say. The deadline for commenting on the rule ends this month and officials are lobbying the Education Department and Congress for an extension so trade school officials can submit alternative ideas. The Education Department, under pressure from Congress, has taken a number of actions to stem student loan defaults that have spiralled to $7.8 billion. A large percentage of the money is owed by students who attended trade or vocational schools. Robert Knutson, chairman of the Arts Institute, said, ``The department is trying to get at abuse and we support the department's goal to do that. It needs to happen. But our students already are in school more hours than other collegiate institutions and counterparts. ``It's cruel to have our kids ... go to school 40 hours per week, in the classroom, in order to receive the same credits and the same amount of financial aid'' as college students, Knutson said. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos testified last week before a Senate committee that the clock hour-credit hour conversions are ``highly questionable.'' He said unscrupulous institutions either compress or expand what they say is classwork time just to ``circumvent the minimum course length requirements'' and ``dramatically increase the amount of student aid funds they receive for the same course.'' The department's inspector general learned of a school where a 13-month, 1,300-clock hour X-ray technician program was reported as converted to 78 credit hours, Cavazos said. The proposed rule, published in the Federal Register Oct. 1, requires that a semester or trimester hour include at least 37.5 clock hours of instruction, while a quarter hour include at least 25 clock hours of instruction. Sharon Thomas-Parrott of DeVry Inc. described the rule as ``discriminatory'' and said, ``Our students receive three-fifths of what regular college students receive'' in financial aid and now would have to work much harder for the disproportionate share of student loan dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Voting Enters The Fax Age For Persian Gulf Soldiers
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of voters will be in Saudi Arabia on Election Day, but a Raleigh company is helping some of them obtain absentee ballots from home via facsimile machines. ``This is an emergency ballot process that's been developed to make sure the troops get to vote,'' said W. Edward Weems Jr., president of Election Technology Co., which is handling fax voting for U.S. personnel taking part in Operation Desert Shield. Weems said elections officials can use the system to fax ballots through a communications system established with AT&T and the ballots are delivered to the troops. In almost all cases, soldiers will mail their ballots back to their local elections board. Weems said they have transmitted ballots from 20 states. Some states have not yet determined if they can send ballots over telephone lines, Weems said. He said elections officials in Connecticut told him Thursday that their laws prohibit the transmission of ballots. ``It's a whole new approach to ensuring that people get to vote who are out of the country,'' Weems said. ``They're scratching their heads, some of them are.'' Some states are allowing troops to apply for absentee ballots through the system, Weems said. North Carolina is one of the states using the service. State Board of Elections director Alex Brock said he is convinced that adequate safeguards are in place to prevent fraud. ``We think the safeguards are sufficient,'' Brock said. ``I won't go into all of them. Many of these individuals are and were registered voters before they left our state. Therefore their registration can be checked and it can be determined right away if that person has or has not voted previously.'' Election Technology Co. won a Department of Defense contract to provide the service. Election Technology is a joint venture between Independent Election Corporation of America and Office Technology Corp. of Raleigh, Weems said. Independent Election Corporation of Lake Success, N.Y., is the nation's largest processor of corporate proxy ballots and Office Technology designs voting systems, Weems said.
