DOC.HEAD: Washington Pushing For Swift Passage Of Anti-Iraq Resolution
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Thursday pushed for the swift passage of a new Security Council resolution condemning Iraq's human rights violations in Kuwait and demanding the release of all hostages held by Baghdad. ``It's one we hope will pass quickly,'' a State Department official said on condition of anonymity. However, no formal council meeting, or even private consultations of the whole council, have been scheduled. Officials were told the council might act on the resolution over the weekend. The five permanent Security Council members have reached broad agreement on the resolution, which also lays the groundwork for a system of compensation. Under the measure Iraq would pay for damages stemming from its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, diplomats said. The British, French, Soviet, Chinese and U.S. ambassadors continued meeting Thursday to refine the language of the resolution, while their capitals studied its legal ramifications. The other 10 council members may receive the text later, they said. Since the five permanent members hold veto power, they customarily reach agreement on a draft text before presenting it to the other 10 council members. According to the draft resolution, Baghdad would be liable only for compensation, not for punitive reparations, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. Countries that have suffered serious economic losses stemming from the invasion - such as Jordan, India, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh - could apply for compensation out of Iraq's foreign assets, which have been frozen. They could also apply for compensation from future oil earnings, the diplomats said. The draft would address the mistreatment of Kuwaitis by Iraqi soldiers, and would also urge Iraq to let all foreign hostages go, reiterating a resolution the council passed on Aug. 18. It would urge Iraq to permit the sending of supplies to Western embassies in Kuwait City. Foreign missions in Kuwait have had their water, electricity, and supplies cut off by the Iraqis. Iraq says Kuwait is now a province of Iraq and that the diplomats must move their operations to Baghdad. During their private talks, the five permanent Security Council members dropped a proposal for a war-crimes tribunal for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, the diplomats said. They said the ambassadors wanted to focus on humanitarian issues in this resolution and avoid specifically targeting Saddam. The Americans, in particular, do not want a text on war crimes. They fear it could spur Arab appeals for similar resolutions holding Israeli leaders individually responsible for the deaths of Palestinians in the uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied territories. The United States would veto any such resolution, thus endangering its fragile anti-Iraq coalition with Arab states.

DOC.HEAD: Dole's Voice Lesson Earns Movie Credit
DOC.TEXT: Add another credit to the resume of Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole: Voice coach to movie stars. The Kansas Republican provided a little vocal assistance to Paul Newman for a movie to be released next month, ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge.'' For his help, Dole will be listed in the credits as, ``Shakespearean Tutor to Mr. Newman.'' Newman sent a letter to Dole last year asking for guidance in perfecting his accent for the film in which he portrays a Kansas lawyer. In one scene, he helps his daughter learn lines for a school production of ``Romeo and Juliet.'' Newman provided a script, a blank audio cassette and asked Dole, ``Would you do a little Romeo for me on tape? Kansas style?'' Dole obliged, starting with the line, ``What light through yonder window breaks?'' Newman sent a personal letter of thanks to the senator in August 1989, and a movie representative later called to work out the film credit, Dole spokesman Walt Riker said Thursday. The movie will open No. 21 in New York and Los Angeles. A nationwide release is scheduled during the Christmas holiday period, according to a spokesman for the distributor, Miramax Films.

DOC.HEAD: Put Honecker in Nursing Home, Says Former East German Dissident
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker fell from power in East Germany one year ago Thursday, and a dissident who helped topple him said it's time to put the aging Communist in a nursing home. Baerbel Bohley, one of the most heralded dissidents in East German history, said she disagrees with widespread demands that the 78-year-old Honecker be prosecuted. ``I would find it absurd to put him before a court,'' she said. Authorities are trying to decide whether to prosecute Honecker on charges of corruption, harboring leftist terrorists and ordering authorities to shoot people who tried to flee the country. Bohley, however, said she believes he should be put in a home for the aged. He is suffering from kidney cancer and is staying at a Soviet military hospital near Berlin. Bohley led the activist group New Forum, which helped direct the peaceful street protests that toppled the Communists and opened the door to unification of the two German states. Her group, comprised of intellectuals, artists and veteran dissidents, found little political success after East Germany's brief stint as a sovereign democracy. The group remains an opposition force in the united Germany, frequently opposing what it says are heavy handed attempts by western Germany to impose its will on the former Communist nation. Bohley, a painter, is widely respected throughout Germany, however, as the mother of the revolt and a dedicated activist who endured years of harassment by the old regime's secret police. She met with reporters on Thursday to mark the first anniversary of the day when Honecker was forced out of power by members of his party, who were trying to placate the growing masses of protesters. A German magazine reported Thursday that Honecker himself blames Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for his downfall. The Hamburg-published Stern magazine said in its latest issue that Honecker made the statement to Heinz Junge, an old friend who recently visited the former East German leader at the two-room apartment where he lives on the Soviet military hospital compound. ``From the beginning, I was in Gorbachev's way because my political experience made me see glasnost and perestroika differently,'' Honecker told Junge, according to Stern. Junge, a former member of the Communist anti-Nazi resistance, and Werner Cieslak, a former member of the leadership of the (West) German Communist Party, have both visited Honecker, Stern said. The magazine printed a photograph of Honecker and his wife Margot, a former education minister in his government, sitting at a table with Cieslak in the sparsely furnished apartment. Honecker, 78, was deposed at a stormy Communist party meeting on Oct. 18, 1989, as the ruling party was trying to hang onto power with thousands of East Germans demonstrating on the streets for democracy. A little more than a week before Honecker's removal, Gorbachev visited East Berlin and said in a television interview that life punishes those who are late, an indirect referrence to Honecker's refusal to accept reforms. Junge told Stern that Honecker's condition appears to have improved in recent weeks and that he had regained some weight. Honecker underwent surgery for kidney cancer in January, and was briefly detained after leaving the hospital. German prosecutors have opened a criminal investigation against the former Communist boss, but there is not arrest warrant against him. Stern quoted his friends as saying Honecker did not plan to leave Germany. It said the former Communist leader has been receiving a monthly pension of $340.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Dispute Earthquake Prediction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 16th graf, `The scientific ...' to ADD third goal of scientists' news conference. Pick up 17th graf, `Four quakes ...'
DOC.TEXT: Predictions of a major earthquake in the Midwest in early December are without scientific basis and could even be dad the Bush administration has been trying to come up with a way to protect the bird while limiting the loss of 20,000 jobs in the timber industry considered to be in jeopardy. The owls are rapidly dying off because of intense cutting in the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan prompted an uproar among environmentalists when he suggested the endangered species law be made more flexible to better take into account economic considerations in some circumstances. The report concluded that the Fish and Wildlife Service ``has neither developed nor implemented a basic management system for effective administration of the (endangered species) program.'' It said investigators found that in addition to the huge backlog of petitions to list species for protection, the agency also has failed to develop recovery plans for plants and animals already are under the law's protection. The investigators acknowledged that lack of money is a major problem. The report said the cost of protecting all of the presently known endangered species is more than $4.6 billion, while the Fish and Wildlife Service is provided only about $33 million a year to administer the program. It estimated that the cost of simply listing the 601 species that are current candidates for protection would cost $36 million, but that the agency has a listing budget of only about $3.5 million a year. The cost of programs designed to ensure the recovery of protected species could be $4.6 billion, while currently the agency has only about $8.4 million a year for recovery programs, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Mission Coming to U.S. after Minister's Racial Slur
DOC.TEXT: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party said Thursday it will send a group of lawmakers to Washington to follow up new apologies by a Cabinet minister for racial remarks that infuriated black Americans. In his remarks on Sept. 21, following a police raid on a Tokyo red-light district, Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama compared the arrival of foreign prostitutes in Japan to blacks moving into neighborhoods in the United States and forcing whites out. Foreign Ministry officials said Kajiyama apologized in a letter to the U.S. Congressional Black Caucus, which demanded his resignation. They said Japanese Ambassador Ryohei Murata delivered Kajiyama's letter of apology in Washington on Wednesday to Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., chairman of the 24-member caucus. Murata also asked the caucus to reconsider its proposed resolution demanding the resignation, but received no immediate response, an official said. The resolution, to be presented to the U.S. House of Representatives, urges President Bush to demand Kajiyama resign; asks that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu officially apologize; and suggests programs to improve Japanese officials' understanding of racial issues. Murata later delivered a letter from Kaifu to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in which the prime minister apologized for Kajiyama's remarks and pledged to work for more awareness among the Japanese of American minority problems, said a Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Kajiyama retracted his comments four days after making them after civil rights groups in the United States protested. He also apologized to U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost. Kaifu expressed regret and rebuked Kajiyama. But protests have continued, and demands for Kajiyama's resignation have grown. On Thursday, Ichiro Ozawa, secretary-general of the Liberal Democrats, said the party decided to send a group of legislators to the United States on Sunday to make further explanations. He said the delegates would meet with congressional leaders, particularly the Black Caucus, in hopes of heading off the resolution. He said passage of the resolution ``could damage the relations between Japan and the United States.'' In his latest letter, Kajiyama said he did not intend any racial discrimination in his comments. ``I learned again how deeply I have hurt the feelings of the American people, particularly African-Americans,'' he said. ``What I thoughtlessly said on Sept. 21 was wrong and grossly improper. Although I am acutely aware how difficult it is to heal the wounds that my remarks inflicted, I will personally do whatever I can to strengthen Japan's relationship with the African-American community.'' Six African ambassadors also condemned Kajiyama's remarks and delivered a letter of protest to Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama. U.S. civil rights groups asked a boycott of Japanese products, and Mayor Douglas Palmer of Trenton, N.J., called off a planned visit by a delegation of the Tokyo metropolitan government. On Wednesday, Kaifu rejected an opposition demand to dismiss Kajiyama, saying, ``He deeply regrets the comment and has apologized to those concerned. I trust that he will be speaking with more discretion in the future.'' Other Japanese politicians have offended minorities with public racial remarks. In 1986, Yasuhiro Nakasone, then prime minister, said Americans have a lower intelligence level than Japanese because the population includes a considerable number of blacks, Puerto Ricans and Mexicans. In 1988, former Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said American blacks have few qualms about going bankrupt and implied they walk away from debts.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Pay Agreement Will Help Boost Morale, Unions Say
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal workers' pay would be increased by as much as 5 percent a year through 1994 and employees living in high-cost cities would receive extra compensation under an agreement by House and Senate negotiators. the compromise on Thursday, saying it would provide a much-needed morale boost to the 2.4 million federal employees who have faced furloughs and government shutdowns in recent weeks because of the budget stalemate. ``These are people who've been demoralized and beat about the head and shoulders,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents 700,000 federal workers. ``This is a breakthrough that will allow us to keep those people and attract bright new recruits as well. The taxpayers win on this one,'' Sturdivant said of the tentative agreement, reached late Wednesday. Studies have indicated that federal workers are paid an average of 30 percent less than their private-business counterparts. The new plan is aimed at closing the pay gap within 13 years, said George King, a spokesman for the 140,000-member National Treasury Employees Union. Under the plan, civil service salaries would be raised as much as 5 percent each year from 1992 through 1994. For 1991, federal pay would increase 4.1 percent, a bigger boost than the 3.5 percent recommended by President Bush. The administration has pledged to commit $3.6 billion for the federal pay plan over the next five years, King said. Starting in 1994, federal workers in high-cost cities, such as Washington, New York, Boston, Los Angeles and San Francisco, would receive even bigger pay raises. Federal workers now are paid the same no matter where they live.

DOC.NOTE: For release 5 p.m. EDT, Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Carbon Monoxide Reaches `Potential Hazard' Levels in Tractor Pulls
DOC.TEXT: Tractor pulls, those rev-`em-up spectacles where giant machines test metal and mettle in hauling competitions, can produce potentially hazardous levels of carbon monoxide, U.S. health officials warned Thursday. Carbon monoxide levels at two tractor pulls in 1988 in Canada ``represented a potential health hazard to both participants and observers,'' the Centers for Disease Control said. Carbon monoxide is a colorless, odorless gas in exhaust and smoke that can cause headache, dizziness, cardiac problems and death. Health officials urged officials of the Winnipeg, Manitoba, arena not to allow future tractor pulls. The management of Winnipeg Arena agreed, said Rod Thiessen, the arena's director of operations. ``They've never come back and made them safe enough.'' Federal health officials aren't sure whether the problem is peculiar to the Winnipeg arena. ``I wish I knew,''said Dr. Ruth Etzel, a researcher with the Environmental Health Center of the Atlanta-based CDC. ``We would certainly like to see some data so we would know if this is a problem. ``We were quite surprised at the levels of carbon monoxide that can build up in these things.'' The hazard at the Winnipeg arena prompted cancellation of a February 1989 tractor pull and no future pulls will be held there, the CDC said. Tractor pulls typically feature a dozen or so truck rigs outfitted with super-powerful engines made of anything from supercharged car engines to aircraft turbines. The tractor drivers are professionals who compete by pulling 50-ton sleds across a dirt floor. A 2{-hour event can feature 25 competitive pulls. In a February 1988 pull at Winnipeg, health inspectors measured airborne carbon monoxide levels averaging 62 parts per million at the start, or nearly twice the Winnipeg Health Department's recommended indoor guideline of 33 parts per million in one hour. By the event's end, the level had risen to 262 parts per million. During a November 1988 pull at the arena, roof louvers were opened, the duration of the event was extended and one fewer pull was run. Even then, carbon monoxide levels rose more than five times, from 78 parts per million to 436 parts per million. ``The control measures were not effective,'' the CDC said. Adverse effects have been reported in people breathing a constant 15 parts per million, the CDC said. Health officials reported no incidents of carbon monoxide poisoning during either Winnipeg event, although members of the ambulance crew reported severe headaches, Etzel said. Louisville, Ky.-based TNT calls itself the world's largest promotor of indoor motor sports, attracting 2.5 million fans a year. It has never had problems like those cited at the Winnipeg arena, TNT spokesman Mike Weber said from his office in Lombard, Ill. TNT was not involved in the Winnipeg events. ``We present motor sports events in all the major arenas across the country and we take every precaution. We do constantly monitor our emitted fumes. ... It's worked very well for us,'' Weber said. Weber is also director of public relations for the United States Hot Rod Association. The organization sanctions TNT events. Weber said some giant trucks that might perform in outdoor stadium shows shouldn't be run indoors. ``There are so many different classifications of vehicles ... some are appropriate for indoors, and there are some which are not,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rwandan President Offers to Hold Talks With Rebels
DOC.TEXT: President Juvenal Habyarimana of Rwanda said Thursday he was ready to open peace talks with leaders of the three-week rebellion against his government. After talks here with French President Francois Mitterrand, Habyarimana pledged to hold a referendum on a new Rwandan constitution by 1992. But he said negotiations could only begin with a cease-fire in effect. Habyarimana also said he asked Mitterrand's help in convening a session of the U.N. Security Council, so that ``those who are attacking us will cease their aggression.'' On Wednesday, Habyarimana met with the leaders of Uganda and Tanzania and agreed to a cease-fire monitored by neutral troops. The three leaders said they would later call a regional conference to discuss the future of Rwandan refugees. About 1 million Rwandans live in exile, many in the neighboring countries - Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi and Zaire. The refugees are mostl members of the Tutsi tribe, as are the members of the rebel army that invaded from Uganda on Sept. 30. Habyarimana is a Hutu, the majority tribe in Rwanda. Habyarimana said his government ``solemnly declares that it is ready to receive all the refugees,'' but said international aid will be needed to accommodate them. Habyarimana previously said Rwanda, the most densely populated country in Africa, had no room for the exiles. The rebels said Thursday they would be willing to negotiate if government soldiers stopped killing civilians and if foreign troops withdrew. Zaire has sent as many as 1,000 troops to help Rwanda's army. France and Belgium, Rwanda's former colonial ruler, also have sent troops but say they are there only to protect their citizens and embassies. The rebels, enlisted from a 250,000-strong population of Rwandan refugees in Uganda, accuse Habyarimana's government of corruption, human rights abuses and failing to repatriate the refugees. As many as 10,000 Tutsis were massacred and hundreds of thousands driven into exile from Rwanda in the 1960s. The current conflict has sparked a new wave of refugees. Several thousand Rwandans have crossed into Uganda since the invasion. Many say they fled massacres by Rwandan soldiers and zealous Hutu youth armed with machetes. A photographer for The Associated Press on Wednesdsay saw the aftermath of an apparent massacre when he visited a small village 12 miles north of Rwanda's capital, Kigali. The village had been burned to the ground and the bodies of 20 inhabitants hacked to pieces and burned, the photographer said. The army appeared to be responsible, he said, citing indications the village was a Tutsi settlement. Many of the Tutsi rebels are former Ugandan army soldiers. They are led by the former Ugandan deputy army commander, Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a Tutsi of Rwandan origin. Belgium's foreign minister, Mark Eyskens, said Thursday a solution to the conflict must be found by African nations, but said the European Community might help with aid. Returning home from a peace mission, Eyskens said he and Belgian Prime Minister Wilfried Martens had told African leaders the Organization of African Unity should be responsible for monitoring a cease-fire. Habyarimana and the Ugandan and Tanzanian chiefs said Wednesday the cease-fire should be supervised by an EC peacekeeping force. The EC at present has no formal mechanism for deploying such forces.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Says State Department Withheld Info On El Salvador Murders
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House task force on El Salvador said Thursday the State Department withheld from Salvadoran investigators important information about the slaying last year of six Jesuit priests and two others. Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass., said he had learned of an affidavit given by an American Army major to the FBI in January detailing a threat against the Jesuits by a Salvadoran officer some 10 days before the Nov. 16 killings. The American officer later recanted his statement, but the FBI believed it important to inform Salvadoran authorities and forwarded it to the U.S. Embassy in San Salvador. U.S. officials never passed the information along, Moakley said. ``At best, I consider this to be an unbelievable and inexcusable error in judgment,'' he said in a statement, which also made clear he did not know whether the affidavit was true. The State Department had no immediate response to Moakley's charge. A congressional source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the document told of an incident in which Col. Guillermo Benavides had been angrily ranting against the Jesuits and making threats prior to the murders.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Says It Uncovers Plot against Government
DOC.TEXT: Panamanian authorities said Thursday they broke up a military ring plotting against the government and named as a coup leader the man picked as security chief following last year's U.S. invasion of Panama. Attorney General Rogelio Cruz accused the band of terrorist activities and of conspiring to seize military installations. He said former Col. Eduardo Herrera and a brother, Capt. Francisco Herrera, were implicated. Eduardo Hererra, who took charge of the newly formed Public Forces after U.S. troops invaded Panama on Dec. 20, 1989, and ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, was reported out of the country. His brother apparently is not in custody. Col. Hererra retired last August after 23 years of service. Noriega, who as chief of Panama's heavy-handed Defense Forces was de facto ruler of Panama, now is held on federal drug trafficking charges in Miami. The civilian-directed Public Forces were formed to replace the Defense Forces in a move to demilitarize Panama. Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon said Thursday that members of the Public Forces ``could be connected to the explosion of bombs in the province of Chiriqui and possibly to some bombs that went off in the capital. ``There are three military men under arrest and being investigated by prosecutors.'' Calderon, who also serves as Interior Minister overseeing the new police force, said no bombs had gone off since the start of the investigation. The explosions damaged electrical facilities and homes of government officials, but caused no injuries. Cruz said the group had plans to take over military bases in western Chiriqui province. He said Capt. Ivan Moreno, subdirector of Public Forces in Chiriqui, divulged the conspiracy after he was detained. Cruz said a corporal and a private also were in custody. Cruz said plot leaders deceived other members of the Public Forces, and told them their plan had American support. A communique from the presidency said explosions in Chiriqui ``took place on orders coming from Col. Eduardo Hererra.'' It said Moreno told authorities that last Tuesday ``he was to receive a signal to put all the military detachments in the Chiriqui police zone on alert.'' The communique called the conspiracy part of a national movement and said Francisco Hererra was a go-between for his brother. It said the goal was to take over the province after a demonstration of public employees that took place on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Say Judge Should Reject Barry Retrial Request
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Thursday that Mayor Marion Barry should not be granted a retrial on his cocaine possession conviction, arguing there was no evidence jurors were unfairly influenced in making their decision. Barry's attorney has said he should receive a new trial because some of the jurors in his case witnessed a drug sting operation at the hotel where they were sequestered and because deputy U.S. marshals told at least one juror that an alternate would have voted to convict Barry of all 14 charges against him. Barry's jury convicted him of one misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, acquitted him of another, and was deadlocked on a dozen other charges, including a possession charge resulting from his Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation at a Washington hotel. Lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy asked for the retrial in court papers filed last week. Prosecutors responded in papers submitted Thursday. ``The defendant has not offered any affidavits in support of his claim, but instead has referred to post-verdict ... interviews with some of the jurors,'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens argued. ``Generally, in order to make a colorable showing of extraneous influence to justify further inquiry ... the defendant must submit affidavits or other sworn statements.'' Stephens also argued that even if Barry were able to prove the two ``improprieties'' he alleged in his request for a retrial, he might not be entitled to another trial. ``Not every extraneous influence on the jury warrants a new trial,'' Stephens said, citing a Supreme Court ruling which indicates that ``due process does not require a new trial every time a juror has been placed in a potentially compromising situation.'' Stephens also insisted that the deputy marshal's alleged statements could not have influenced the jury, since it voted to acquit the mayor on one of the two charges it decided. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has set sentencing for Oct. 26. A pre-sentencing hearing is set for Friday, and Jackson could rule on Mundy's retrial request at that time.

DOC.HEAD: Coleman Requests Meeting with Bush on Civil Rights
DOC.TEXT: Former Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman pleaded Thursday for permission to make one last face-to-face pitch before President Bush vetoes a major civil rights bill designed to combat job bias. ``If you veto it, whether such veto is sustained or overridden, you subject this country and the Republican Party to years of divisiveness over these issues,'' Coleman said in a letter to Bush. The prominent black Republican recounted how Bush called him in August and ``asked me to get involved in the civil rights bill. ... You indicated that I could come to see you if there were any problems. I herewith request such a meeting before you do other than sign the bill.'' The House approved the bill Wednesday and sent it to Bush, one day after the president promised to veto it on grounds that it would prompt employers to adopt hiring quotas. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages in the most extreme discrimination cases. The fiercest disputes, however, have come over proposed changes in complex rules under which courts decide job discrimination cases. The changes would make it easier for those filing discrimination suits to win and harder for employers to defend themselves. Bush said in a letter Tuesday to Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., that he would veto the bill because these provisions would force employers to turn to hiring quotas. The idea is that the use of quotas would provide employers with a ready-made defense. ``All reliable criteria of reason demonstrate that the bill, as finally passed, is not a quota bill,'' Coleman said. ``First, there is not a word in the bill that would require quotas; in fact, the bill actually provides that a statistical shortage of minorities or women in the employer's workforce is not by itself sufficient to hold the employer liable under this act,'' he said. ``It further provides that nothing in the bill shall construed to require or encourage quotas,'' Coleman added. Coleman said his meeting also should be attended by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, White House counsel C. Boyden Gray, Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and U.S. Civil Rights Commission Chairman Arthur Fletcher as well as Sens. Arlen Specter, R-Pa.; Warren Rudman, R-N.H.; John Danforth, R-Mo., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts Orange County, No Serious Damage, Injuries
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake that struck a day after the anniversary of the San Francisco quake shattered a store's windows and knocked cans from shelves Thursday. No injuries were reported. The quake, centered one mile north of Costa Mesa, hit at 10:21 a.m. and measured 4.0 on the Richter scale, said Robert Finn of the California Institute of Technology. ``It felt like the building was bouncing up and down,'' said Susan Wood, who was in a fifth-floor City Hall office when the quake hit. The quake's epicenter appeared to be under the South Coast Plaza shopping mall. ``It was a big jolt,'' said Ursula Yang, a clerk in the crystal department of the mall's May Co. store. ``Everything is back to normal five minutes after the shock. A few things fell off the shelves and broke, just a little bit of stuff though.'' Mall spokeswoman Susan Maple said some customers and employees crouched under doorways to wait out the quake, but none appeared seriously alarmed. She said there was no apparent structural damage to the mall building. The quake shattered four plate-glass windows at Orange Coast Jeep-Eagle Inc. and frightened customers from the glass-strewn showroom, said owner Gary Gray. ``It was a severe jolt,'' Gray said. ``We are going to have an open air showroom for a couple of days.'' Dan Carpenter, service manager at a Von's supermarket four miles southwest of the epicenter, said canned goods were knocked from shelves and six bottles of wine shattered, but customers took the quake in stride. ``I guess we get enough small tremors and aftershocks, so the customers all remained calm. They just got startled for a second and then went on shopping,'' Carpenter said. Thequake came one year and a day after a 7.1 temblor killed 67 people in the San Francisco-Oakland area. On Wednesday, Californians remembered the death and destruction that earthquake caused. Across the nation, television viewers watching the second game of this year's World Series on Wednesday were reminded of Oct. 17, 1989. The quake struck at 5:04 p.m. that day, as the third game of the World Series was about to begin in Candlestick Park. Wednesday's quake in Costa Mesa struck less than 15 minutes before Vice President Dan Quayle was scheduled to arrive at the Marine Corps Air Station at El Toro, about 15 miles southeast of the epicenter. The visit was not affected by the earthquake, said Quayle aide Craig Whitney.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Tornado And A Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms spun off a tornado that caused damage Thursday in Virginia, and a snowstorm created near-blizzard conditions in northern Michigan. During the afternoon, lines of showers and thunderstorms reached across central and western New York state, much of Pennsylvania, eastern West Virginia, western Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, northern and eastern Georgia and northern Florida. In northern Virginia, a tornado damaged several buildings in Fauquier County. No injuries were reported. State police spokeswoman Lucy Caldwell said several buildings in Remington, a town of 420 residents, were damaged ``and some people's cars were gone.'' ``It ran up and down Main Street and tore roofs off some buildings and tore down some power lines,'' said Dawn Driggers, a dispatcher at the Fauquier County Sheriff's office. Kay Billingsley, wife of Remington Mayor Gerald Billingsley, said she was at the Town Hall ``when I heard what I thought was a train coming down the street. ... At that point, I dove under the desk.'' In the Great Lakes region, snow fell over northwestern Upper Michigan and 8 inches of snow covered Calumet. Strong wind produced near-blizzard conditions plus wind chills that made it feel like between zero and 5 below zero over parts of Upper Michigan. An accumulation of 6 to 12 inches of snow was possible on the Keweenaw Peninsula. Snow also fell over northeastern Wisconsin. South of the snow, rain and rain mixed with snow fell over northwestern Indiana, western Lower Michigan, northeastern Illinois and southeastern Wisconsin. Advisories for frost and freezing temperatures during the night were posted for Illinois, Indiana, north-central Kentucky, western Ohio and extreme northern Arkansas. High wind warnings were posted for lakes Erie, Huron and Ontario, eastern New York state and southern New England. Wind gusted to 43 mph at midday at Albany, N.Y. In the West, rain, with snow at higher elevations, extended over northern California, western through south-central Oregon, Washington state and northern Idaho into northwest Montana. Up to 3 inches of snow was possible over the higher mountains of northern California. Showers were scattered over central and southern California. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.40 inches at Roanoke, Va.; 1.25 inches at Martinburg, W.Va.; 1.05 inches at Eugene, Ore.; and 1.03 inches at Crescent City, Calif. In the Atlantic, tropical storm Nana grew to hurricane strength, with a sustained wind speed of 75 mph. It was more than 400 miles south of Bermuda, moving toward the north-northwest. Bridgeport, Conn., warmed to a record high of 75, and Daytona Beach, Fla., tied its record of 89. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 11 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 41 at Yellowstone National Park to 92 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats Sign Letter in Support of Exon
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jim Exon's 54 Democratic colleagues in the U.S. Senate all signed a letter rejecting suggestions that the Nebraska Democrat has a reputation as a heavy drinker. ``I note with some unrestrained disbelief that John Tower continues to insist that `some Democratic senator' smeared Sen. Jim Exon,'' said Nebraska's other U.S. senator, Democrat Bob Kerrey. ``To bury this lie as deep as possible, 54 Democratic U.S. senators have signed a letter refuting Mr. Tower's words,'' said Kerrey, who wrote the letter. The letter was a response to remarks last week by former Sen. Tower, who visited Omaha to campaign for Exon's challenger, Republican Hal Daub. Tower said Exon had ``a reputation in Washington of being one of the two or three biggest boozers in the Senate.'' ``We have never observed, in public or private relationships, any hint whatsoever of alcohol abuse by our colleague from Nebraska,'' the Senate Democrats wrote.
DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Still Trailing Boschwitz In Polls
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz has a comfortable lead in the polls over Democratic challenger Paul Wellstone in Minnesota's U.S. Senate race, according to survey results released Thursday. Boschwitz was favored by 56 percent of the likely Minnesota voters surveyed, while 38 percent supported Wellstone, according to a Star Tribune-KSTP Minnesota Poll. The telephone survey of 1,003 randomly selected adults was conducted Oct. 8-14. It had a margin of error of 3.1 percentage points. Wellstone campaign director John Blackshaw said the race was ``much, much, much closer'' than the poll suggested. Boschwitz press secretary Jay Novak said the numbers ``give us some encouragement.''
DOC.HEAD: Avenson Returns to Airwaves With Assault on Branstad
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Don Avenson's final television blitz in the Iowa governor's race seeks to cast Republican Gov. Terry Branstad as a protector of the wealthy. A new 30-second Avenson commercial says Branstad ``gave millions of our tax dollars to the big meatpacking companies while he cut help for Iowa's children and seniors.'' The spot hits on several of Avenson's campaign themes. It says Avenson better represents the views of middle-class Iowans and that Branstad cares only for the wealthy. Branstad's campaign makes points by playing off Avenson's image as a bully and legislative insider for eight years. Avenson's new ad tries to turn that to his advantage. ``Don Avenson, tough enough to fight for you and me,'' the ad declares. Branstad, who has been widening his lead in the polls, has been running a mix of ads. One spot attacks Avenson for supporting tax increases. Others featuring Branstad and his family are designed to build a positive image.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Assassin of Bashir Gemayel Freed
DOC.TEXT: Habib Shartouni, the man accused of assassinating President-elect Bashir Gemayel in 1982, was freed after the Syrian military moved into Lebanon's Christian heartland, his party announced Thursday. A communique from the Syrian Social Nationalist Party said Shartouni was set free Monday, two days after Syrian troops and Lebanese government forces overran rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's enclave northeast of Beirut. ``Comrade Shartouni has been freed along with several other political prisoners,'' said the communique, without giving any further information. The party is a pro-Syrian leftist Lebanese group that advocates the merger of Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, Kuwait, Israel and Cyprus into a greater Syria. Shartouni was arrested Oct. 24, 1982, hours after a powerful bomb exploded at the right-wing Christian Phalange Party headquarters in East Beirut, killing Gemayel and 21 aides. Gemayel, then 34, was elected president by Parliament three weeks before his assassination. He was slated to take the oath of office a week later. The Syrian party considered Gemayel a collaborator with Israel for supporting its 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Israel invaded Lebanon to drive Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization from its main Middle East power base. Shartouni was held for four years by the Lebanese Forces, a coalition of rightist militias founded by Gemayel. He was turned over to the government after Amin Gemayel, Bashir's brother, was elected president. Shartouni, who like the Gemayels is a Maronite Catholic, was held at the state prison in Romieh in the Christian hinterland northeast of Beirut. He was not tried during Amin Gemayel's term nor during the subsequent reign of Aoun.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Restricts Flying in New Safety Precaution
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has imposed new restrictions on low-level flying in the Persian Gulf area in response to a recent rash of air crashes, the Pentagon said Thursday. Lt. Gen. Charles Horner, commander of the Central Command Air Force in Saudi Arabia, ordered pilots on training missions not to fly below 1,000 feet. They previously had flown as low as 150 feet. The Pentagon issued a statement quoting Horner as saying the new limit of 1,000 feet is ``not realistic for combat training, but it'll get the point across. Then we'll work our way back down to realistic training altitudes.'' The statement did not elaborate, and Maj. Margaret Sutter, an Air Force spokeswoman, said she had no further information. The action was taken after the Air Force last Wednesday grounded all warplanes on training missions in the gulf area for one day. Pilots were given special ``safety awareness'' briefings during the flight ban, which did not apply to operational missions such as reconnaissance, border patrols and air-to-air refueling. Twenty U.S. military aircraft have crashed in the gulf area during Operational Desert Shield since the defensive buildup began Aug. 7. Last week the Pentagon reported three separate air crashes in which 12 pilots and crew members were killed. Two of the crashes involved Air Force planes; the other involved two Marine Corps helicopters.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Condemns Israel, Splits Over Iraq, PLO Denouncements
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League issued a unanimous condemnation of Israel on Thursday, but split bitterly over an unsuccessful bid by Iraq and the PLO to include a denunciation of the United States. The league's 21 members had convened an emergency session Wednesday night to draft a statement on the Oct. 8 incident in which Jerusalem police shot dead 19 Palestinians during a riot on the Temple Mount. On Thursday, delegates from Iraq, the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yemen and Sudan walked out of the meeting, protesting the defeat of a resolution denouncing the United States. An 11-country bloc led by Iraq's adversaries in the Persian Gulf conflict blocked the PLO-backed statement, which condemned the United States for ``prorastination and maneuvering'' in response to the events in Jerusalem. The PLO, which withdrew its draft resolution, has criticized the United States for threatening to veto a harsh U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel for the violence. The milder resolution that past called for a U.N. inquiry into the shootings. Thursday evening the delegates unanimously agreed to adopt a statement condemning Israel and urging the United States to become more sensitive to Palestinian rights. The measure also deplored Washington's alignment with Israel. The final resolution also called for sanctions against Israel because of its rejection of the proposed U.N. inquiry into the killings. A member of the Iraqi delegation, Saad Kacem Hammoudi, told reporters the four delegations had walked out because they did not want to provide ``an Arab coverup for American policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Population of Pollution-Plagued City Threatens to Emigrate
DOC.TEXT: Residents of Ruse, on the Romanian border, told the government Thursday that the entire city of 250,000 may pack up and seek ``ecological asylym'' elsewhere unless pollution stops, the state news agency BTA said. Ruse has suffered health problems and ecological damage for nine years because of chlorine gas clouds drifting across the Danube River from a chemical works in Giurgiu, Romania. Protesters demanded quick official action and asked U.N. Secretary- General Javier Perez de Cuellar for help at a mass rally organized by the Ruse Salvation Committee. BTA said a declaration warned that the population would leave Ruse for a time to protest the ``chemical warfare'' from Giurgiu if the government fails to take effective measures to stop the ``chlorine gas attacks'' within a month. If that proved unavailing, people would give up Bulgarian citizenship en masse and ``seek ecological asylum for the entire city in another country or community of countries,'' BTA quoted the statement as saying. The move was seen as reflecting Ruse's despair over Bulgarian failure to get the Romanian factory closed down, and followed road blockades and other ineffectual protests. In the letter to Perez de Cuellar, read at the rally, residents said that in Ruse, ``the fundamental right to health and life is not granted.'' They lashed out at ``the diplomatic helplessness and . . . transparent demagoguery of those responsible on the Bulgarian and Romanian side.'' ``We ask you, please use all your political influence, take a diplomatic initiative so word will spread at the U.N. that Romania owes 250,000 Bulgarians the right to ecological security,'' the letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Whistleblowers: IRS `Sugarcoats' Black Discipline Rate
DOC.TEXT: A private group complained Thursday that the Internal Revenue Service is trying to ``sugarcoat'' evidence that the agency disciplines blacks at a larger rate than other workers. But the agency said it is making a good-faith effort to uncover the cause. The National Coalition of IRS Whistleblowers issued a copy of a memo it obtained in which Michael J. Murphy, a deputy commissioner for the IRS, acknowledged that blacks had been punished at a higher rate than other workers. ``Enclosed is a bar chart which reflects that black IRS employees are disciplined servicewide at a substantially higher rate than their percentage in the workforce,'' the memo said. The memo - written jointly with the president of the union that represents IRS workers - asked IRS executives and union officials to answer a questionnaire about the agency's disciplinary policy to uncover why the disparity had occurred. The memo noted that the IRS and the National Treasury Employees Union had formed a task force to review the agency's disciplinary practice and make recommendations on minority employees. ``The task force is trying to determine the causes of the higher rate and the most appropriate solutions to correct the imbalances,'' the memo said. IRS spokesman Henry Holmes said the joint effort by IRS management and union officials shows the agency is trying to uncover the causes for the disparity. ``We want to find out why. If it's attributable to anything unwarranted, such as discrimination, we're going to correct it,'' Holmes said. Figures show that both black male and female workers are disciplined at higher rates than their white counterparts, Holmes said. For instance, in 1989, the IRS took 700 disciplinary actions involving black females, while there should have only been around 400 if the actions were distributed evenly throughout the workforce, Holmes said. There were about 500 actions taken against white females, when there should have been around 750 under a statistical model figuring in the entire workforce, Holmes said. George King, a spokesman for the 140,000-member Treasury Employees Union, said the memo shows both sides are trying to uncover the cause of the imbalance and see if it needs correcting. ``Both the union and the agency are doing everything possible to begin to further identify these disparities and rectify the situation,'' King said. But Mike Lashaway, a spokesman for the whistleblowers group, said the IRS is trying to ``sugarcoat'' the evidence. ``They're trying to shuffle it under the carpet,'' he said. ``It's more or less a white man's world within the upper power structure (of the IRS). It's been going on for years. It's not like they were blind to it,'' Lashaway said. The group, formed in 1985 by the Church of Scientology's Freedom Magazine, said it had received ``numerous reports of harassment against minority IRS employees.'' The government has had numerous legal battles with the Church of Scientology, many of them concerning taxes and charges brought against the church by the IRS.

DOC.HEAD: Peru's Agriculture Minister Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Minister Carlos Amat y Leon resigned Thursday, days after stating that the country faces famine unless loans to farmers are quickly approved. Amat y Leon's resignation took effect immediately, the government news agency Andina reported. Neither the minister nor the government gave an explanation for his decision. No replacement was immediately named to the 14-member Cabinet. Amat y Leon was one of three members of the Marxist United Left coalition named to the Cabinet of President Alberto Fujimori, who took office July 28 under the banner of a tiny party with a populist ideology. Amat y Leon, a former economics professor, said this week that Peru faced a famine unless $300 million in agricultural loans were quickly approved for the October to December planting season. The government has been slow to approve the loans for fear they will heighten inflation, which has risen the past two weeks after declining to 13.8 percent in September, the lowest rate in many months. The country is suffering its worst drought in history and many of this year's crops have been almost entirely lost. Drought is one of many critical problems facing the Fujimori government, ranging from drug smuggling and inflation to a 10-year-old insurgency by left-wing extremists. The district attorney's office in Ayacucho, in the southern highlands, said Thursday that farmers had reported the discovery of a grave with at least 15 bodies they say are the remains of relatives who were detained by police. A spokesman for the office, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the farmers claimed their relatives were arrested in an anti-terrorist operation in September in Chilcahuayco, 9 miles northeast of Ayacucho. Police detectives left Thursday for Chilcahuayco to investigate the farmers' story, the official said. The armed forces refused to comment. Ayacucho, a departmental capital 230 miles southeast of Lima, is the birthplace of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement. The guerrilla war has claimed the lives of over 20,000 people, most of them civilians, human rights groups say.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Republics Challenge Gorbachev Decree on Holiday Parades
DOC.TEXT: The parliaments of Latvia and Armenia said Friday they would challenge President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's decree requiring all major cities to hold parades on Nov. 7, anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. The dispute threatens to turn Revolution Day, one of the top holidays on the Soviet calendar, into a day of protest for republics striving for independence. The chairman of the National Democratic Party of Georgia also urged his republic to prevent any parade in Tbilisi, its capital. ``The co-called socialist revolution of 1917 ... abolished democracy and stopped the people's drive for freedom with bayonets,'' said the party leader, Georgy Chanturiya. ``Any attempt to hold a military parade in Tbilisi on Nov. 7 may have unpredictable consequences,'' the independent Soviet news agency Interfax reported. Armenia's lawmakers declared the 73rd anniversary of the 1917 revolution ``will not be marked by a military parade'' in Yerevan, the republic's capital, according to the official Soviet news agency Tass. Latvia's parliament passed a resolution saying there was ``no legal basis'' for a parade in Riga, its capital, according to the independent Baltic News Service. ``A demonstration of Soviet military power will be in contradiction with Latvia's sovereignty, and it will sharpen the political situation,'' the Latvian parliament said. Latvia, Armenia, Georgia and most of the other 12 Soviet republics have been pushing for greater autonomy - or, in some cases, outright independence - from the central government in Moscow. Gorbachev issued his decree Oct. 10 in an attempt to prevent a boycott by radicals led by the mayors of Moscow and Leningrad. The mayors have called for abandoning the traditional Revolution Day festivities, saying deteriorating economic conditions give Soviets nothing to celebrate. November 7 is usually devoted to patriotic marching, flag-waving and praising the glories of communism. The parades usually include military equipment, such as tanks and rockets, followed by ``people's demonstrations'' involving thousands of residents in major cities. May Day, another leading Soviet holiday, was marked this year by counter-demonstrations involving tens of thousands of people in Moscow. As they passed through Red Square, many shouted ``Resign!'' and jeered at Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Declaration of War Against Iraq May Be Unwise
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday it would be self-defeating for the administration to promise Congress a role in deciding whether the United States should engage in armed conflict with Iraq. Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Baker raised the possibility that any such commitment would give a decided advantage to Iraq's military forces. Baker reaffirmed that the administration would be willing to consult the Congress but offered no commitment beyond that. Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., strongly urged that the administration call on Congress to declare war if the need arises, consistent with its constitutional responsibilities. Though the president is commander-in-chief of the armed forces, the Constitution says in Article I, Section 8 ``The Congress shall have power ... to declare war.'' Weiss suggested that the administration follow the example of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who won a declaration of war by Congress against Japan the day after the bombing of Pearl Harbor. The World War II declarations of war were the last in U.S. history. But Baker replied that a nightmarish situation would result if tensions in the Persian Gulf escalated during a period when Congress were not in session. ``I really think it would be self-defeating ... if Congress was called back into session and we had days of debate about what we should or should not do. ``What I can't do is make a general, across-the-board commitment,'' Baker said. Baker had faced similar questioning on Wednesday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Congress has become increasingly concerned about the situation as the stalemate in the gulf continues without solution and as the current session of Congress winds down. Congressional leaders hope to adjourn by next Friday, normally not to reconvene until January. Baker said repeatedly during his appearance that the administration is seeking a peaceful outcome to the conflict. He said he did not foresee an early solution because U.N. sanctions against Iraq will take a ``substantial period of time'' to cripple the country's economy. Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., opened the hearing by suggesting the formation of a new group of lawmakers to consult with the executive branch on a regular basis. Some senators have made similar suggestions. The group would consist of the House and Senate leadership and the chairmen and ranking members of the relevant House and Senate committees. It could be convened when the Congress is in recess or has adjourned and would avoid the need for the administration to consult with all 535 members, Fascell said. Rep. William S. Broomfield of Michigan, the ranking Republican on the committee, opposed Fascell's proposal. ``We should never be placed in a situation where a single American's life is risked in the Persian Gulf because a requirement to consult with Congress tipped the president's hand to our adversaries,'' Broomfield said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union Pledges Not to Deploy Nuclear Weapons in Baltic
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union announced Thursday it would stop deploying nuclear weapons on ships or aircraft operating on the Baltic Sea. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinski made the promise to the ambassadors of neighboring Baltic states - Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Poland and Germany, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. Tass said Kvitsinski handed the ambassadors a note saying the Soviet Union had given up ``the deployment in peace time of nuclear arms on Soviet ships and combat aircraft on the Baltic Sea and in the airspace above the Baltic.'' The Soviet diplomatic note proposed other countries also pledge not to deploy nuclear weapons in the Baltic. It said the Soviet Union was willing to begin negotiations toward that goal ``with nuclear powers and Baltic states.'' There was no immediate response from the Baltic countries.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says It is Ready to Fend Off Israeli, U.. Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Thursday said it expects war at any time and is ready to fend off a surprise attack from either the United States or Israel. ``Our people are mobilized. Their morale is very high. Our 8 million (strong) popular army and 1.5 million soldiers are absolutely ready,'' Information and Culture Minister Latif Nsayief Jassim told Western journalists summoned to his office. Western analysts have said Iraq's army totals about 1 million men, including reserves. ``We are ready for any surprise attack by either the United States or Israel,'' Jassim said. ``We will never start the war, but if we were attacked, we will retaliate with our full might.'' Iraq has repeatedly tried to link Israel with the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia. The force was dispatched following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Jassim also reiterated Iraq's stand that ``Kuwait is the 19th province of Iraq. We cannot leave an inch of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Warns Syria Against Trying to Spread Influence
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens warned Syria on Thursday against trying to spread its influence from Beirut to the Israeli-controlled security strip in south Lebanon. Syrian forces ousted Christian rebel leader Michel Aoun from Beirut on Saturday and control almost the entire city. ``There is a danger that the Syrians, after their success in Beirut, and their big influence on the Lebanese government of (President Elias) Hrawi ... will want to perhaps have influence in ... our security zone,'' Arens said, speaking on Israel radio. ``I hope they will not do this because this is something we cannot accept,'' he added. Foreign Minister David Levy, speaking on Israel television, said Israel ``has certain parameters which it sees as a red line. The Syrians are aware of this and every other element is aware of this too.'' A violation of such red lines, he warned, would trigger a serious response from Israel. Levy added, however, that Syrian involvement in Beirut does not constitute a serious threat to Israel. When asked if there were signs of a change in Syria's hostility toward Israel, Levy responded: ``I want to hope so. There are small, veiled signs. I want to encourage them.'' Syria, one of Israel's most heavily armed and hostile Arab foes, has long been a rival to Israel in Lebanon, where each country has carved out its sphere of influence. The two nations have avoided confrontation since June 1982 when Israel invaded Lebanon to rout Palestinian guerrillas from the south. The Israeli security zone was formed in 1985 when Israel ended a three-year occupation of south Lebanon. It runs about six to 10 miles north of Israel's border and is patrolled by Israeli soldiers and an Israeli-supported Lebanese militia. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon and controls most of Beirut and eastern Lebanon. Arens met Thursday morning with visiting British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd, who later left for Athens. The Israeli defense minister said on radio later that he doubted the Western standoff with Iraq could be solved without military action. Mentioning the goals of getting Iraqi forces out of Kuwait and stripping Iraq of its military capability, he said: ``They (Western countries) certainly would like to do this through diplomatic means. I cast a lot of doubt on whether this is possible.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, and President Saddam Hussein annexed his oil-wealthy neighbor four days later.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Ratification Documents for German Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Without fanfare, President Bush on Thursday signed ratification documents for the treaty formally ending the post-World War II division of Germany. The treaty had been signed in Moscow Sept. 12 by Britain, France, the Soviet Union, the United States and East and West Germany. It relinquishes all American rights and responsibilities over Germany and lifts remaining Soviet, French and British controls over the country as well. The Senate gave its consent to ratification 98-0. Bush's signature was disclosed in a brief White House announcement. The four allies suspended exercise of their rights over Germany Oct. 1 to allow the reunification of Germany to go forward. After the defeat of Nazi Germany, the four allies divided the country and its capital into four occupation zones. The zones of the three western powers became West Germany and the eastern zone occupied by the Soviet Union became East Germany; the four countries continued to retain formal authority over the city of Berlin. Aside from ending the division of the country, the treaty calls on the Soviet Union to complete the withdrawal of its estimated 370,000 troops from what was East Germany by 1994. U.S., British and French troops will remain in Berlin during the interim.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Mortar Attacks Rattle Capital; More Violence Feared
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with rebel comments, congressional complaint on Jesuit case, clarifies that army agreed to get rid of rights abusers, but on own terms. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this capital nervously went about their business Thursday after being rattled by a guerrilla attack overnight, the latest rebel offensive in El Salvador's decade-old civil war. Dozens of explosions from rebel mortars were heard from the city's eastern outskirts starting at 9:45 p.m. Wednesday and lasting until about midnight, when army troops said they drove rebels off. Small-arms fire, however, lasted into the early morning. As many as 100 rebels appeared to have been involved in the attack on the Ilopango air base, which is headquarters of the air force. The base is four miles east of downtown. Gen. Rafael Villamariona, commander of the air force, said at a news conference Thursday that five soldiers were wounded in the offensive. He said six helicopters and two trucks were also damaged. Reporters were shown the aircraft, but the damage appeared slight though only a small sector of the sprawling airfield was seen. The guerrillas, in a communique, claimed they damaged most of the government's helicopter fleet. They charged the government with covering up the damage. The attack came exactly a month after yet another round of unsuccessful peace talks between rebels and the rightist government. A fifth round of U.N.-mediated peace talks between the leftist rebels and the rightist government of President Alfredo Cristiani ended in a stalemate Sept. 18. The two sides have agreed to meet again for peace talks in Mexico before Nov. 4. Rebel commanders have said for weeks that a stalemate at the negotiating table could provoke a major offensive. Disabling the Air Force fleet would be key to blunting the military's effectiveness in rebuffing any guerrilla offensive. The rebels used an abandoned commercial building in the La Palma neighborhood adjacent to the airfield as the main staging area for the attack. About 30 empty packing tubes for 60mm mortar rounds, as well as tubes for launching homemade bombs were strewn about the building early Thursday. A dozen unfired rocket-like weapons that one officer said were Chinese-made were lined up on the floor. Also in the building were ingredients for explosives. The government indicated it expected more trouble. It broadcast a communique saying leftist labor and student organizations planned to launch ``a series of provocative actions of street violence.'' The insurgents last November launched the biggest offensive of the civil war. About 1,000 soldiers, guerrillas and civilians died in three weeks of intense, mostly urban, combat. Guerrilla leaders and government representatives have been negotiating unsuccessfully for more than a year to end the decade-old civil war. Each side accuses the other of intransigence. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler issued a statement Thursday noting U.S. and Soviet officials had met in Washington last week seeking ways to promote peace talks. The Soviet and American participants urged intensified negotiations toward a cease-fire, said the statement, issued jointly with the Soviet Union. It added: ``They also consider that both sides in the dialogue should refrain from military actions which would damage the prospects for peace.'' The statement appeared to be aimed at the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The FMLN maintains a cease-fire can only be put in effect after substantive agreements on reform of Salvadoran society are reached. FMLN spokesman Miguel Saenz, in an interview in Tegucigalpa, where rebel leaders met with Honduran President Rafel Callejas, said the Salvadoran army was negotiating in bad faith. The government says much the same of the rebels. The FMLN insists the military should be drastically reduced in numbers, and officers who violated human rights be prosecuted. The military has not rejected a clean-up of rights abusers but says it would conduct such a purge on its own. Soldiers are charged with murdering thousands of suspected leftists in cold blood during El Salvador's civil war. Last November's murder of six Jesuit priests who were out of favor with the military has led Congress to consider cutting military aid to El Salvador. Rep. Joseph Moakley, D-Mass., chairman of a House task force on El Salvador, charged Thursday that the State Department had withheld information about the slayings from Salvadoran investigators. Moakley said he had learned of an affidavit given by an U.S. Army major to the FBI in January detailing a threat against the Jesuits by a Salvadoran officer about 10 days before the Nov. 16 killings. The U.S. officer later recanted his statement, but the FBI believed it important to pass along to Salvadoran authorities and forwarded it to the U.S. Embassy in San Salvador. U.S. officials never passed the information along, Moakley said. The killings led to calls to scale back U.S. aid. Since 1980, the United States has provided $4 billion in economic and military aid to bolster a succession of Salvadoran governments. Rights groups estimate 73,000 people have been killed since the war began in 1979 in this country of 5 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Planes Back in Service After Hand-Soap Incident
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines said Thursday that two DC-9 jets whose hydraulic systems were accidentally filled with a mixture of hand soap and hydraulic fluid were repaired and back in service. Fifty flights were canceled around the country Wednesday and 12 DC-9s were grounded for inspections of hydraulic systems. Northwest spokesman Doug Miller said tests showed only two of the grounded planes contained the soap mixture. ``Those two systems were flushed last night and replaced and those planes are back on the flying line as well,'' he said. Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said Wednesday it was an honest mistake, not sabotage, that led ground workers in Atlanta to fill the hydraulic systems with the mixture. ``It was certainly inadvertent and nothing suspicious,'' Gibbons said Wednesday. He said an investigation was under way to determine how it happened. Gibbons said he knew of no problems associated with the mixture. He said there could have been danger if the problem had not been detected by a mechanic, who noticed the fluid was an unusual color. The planes had been flying with the contaminated fluid no longer than 10 days, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Miners Killed, 17 Missing in Moravian Coal Mine Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE toll. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An explosion Thursday in a Moravian coal mine left 13 miners dead and 17 missing, Czechoslovak state television reported. Three miners were reported badly hurt in the blast, which occurred during tunneling work at the May 1 mine in the Ostrava-Karvina district in northern Moravia. The state news agency CTK said a fire caused by the blast was extinguished, but no other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Salvation Army to Resume Work in Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, China
DOC.TEXT: The Salvation Army will resume charitable work in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and China in the next year, the organization's worldwide commander announced Thursday. The Christian organization, which has 1.5 million members worldwide, was banned from the Soviet Union in 1923 and Eastern Europe and China when communist regimes emerged in the late 1940s. General Eva Burrows, worldwide commander, said officials in those countries had invited back the army. ``We've been out of these areas too long and need to let the people of those countries know that they have our concern and support. We are moving quickly to respond to their needs, wherever we can,'' she said. Burrows, an Australian native based in London, made the announcement at Baltimore-Washington International Airport on her arrival from Bermuda, where she had toured army facilities. She was on her way to Washington for a one-day visit that will include a meeting with President Bush on Friday. Burrows said preparations for the army's return to Hungary, Czechoslovakia and what was East Germany began weeks ago. She said she hoped full-scale operations will get under way by next year. ``Under the communist regimes there were no charities allowed. The state was to provide all,'' Burrows said. ``But now they're realizing opportunities should be opened to charitable organizations. We've been welcomed everywhere we've been in Eastern Europe.'' Initially, the army will work to regain its confiscated properties, establish new charity centers and recruit members, Burrows said. Later, as it does in nearly 100 other countries, the army will provide food and shelter to the poor and homeless and will try to instill its Christian religious message as well. Burrows wouldn't attach a dollar figure on the cost, saying the figure has yet to be established. ``We're looking for funds. We're looking for personnel who have the language of these countries and who are prepared to identify themselves with these people who are emerging from years of being under what I call the cold compassionless hand of the Marxist-Communist philosophy.'' She revealed that, about a month ago, the army mounted its first aid effort in the Soviet Union in 70 years, in Leningrad. ``We've taken great lorry (truck) loads of foodstuffs and clothing for the poor because there are a lot of poor people in the Soviet Union, especially the elderly.'' Salvation Army ambassadors are in the Soviet Union this week to help re-establish its continuing work there, she said. Burrows said she will meet Friday in Washington with several eastern European ambassadors to help speed the army's entry into their countries.

DOC.HEAD: Spain Awards Top Cultural Prize to Sephardic Jewish Community
DOC.TEXT: Crown Prince Felipe presented Spain's top cultural prize to representatives of the world's Sephardic Jews on Thursday, symbolically opening the country to descendants of people forced into exile in 1492. Professor Solomon Gaon of New York's Yeshiva University accepted the Prince of Asturias prize for harmony on behalf of the international Sephardic community. The prize was one of eight awarded by the Spanish heir. ``In the spirit of harmony of today's Spain and as an heir of those who signed the expulsion decree 500 years ago, I welcome you with open arms and great emotion,'' the prince said. The 10th annual edition of the prize, named after the title held by the 22-year-old Felipe, carries a cash award of $50,000 and a statuette designed by the late Spanish artist Joan Miro. Gaon choked back tears as he read his acceptance speech in Ladino, a dialect of medieval Spanish that is still spoken by some Jews five centuries after they were expelled from Spain by a royal edict. ``In this world full of struggle and conflict, we hope this award brings a message of harmony,'' he said. Representatives of Sephardic communities in Spain, Latin America, Greece, Turkey, Israel and Morocco also received certificates from the prince. Felipe called the Sephardic Jews ``a beloved member of the great Hispanic family'' and praised them for preserving their Spanish language and culture over five centuries. German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher received the prize for international cooperation for his work to construct a united Europe, help slow the arms race and defend human rights. Genscher reiterated Germany's support of a European political and monetary unity that extends beyond the borders of the 12-member European Economic Community to the recently liberated countries to the east. ``Now that the political and ideological walls have come down, we need to eliminate the economic and social walls that still divide East from West,'' he said. Other recipients included Venezuelan novelist Arturo Uslar Pietri, who received the prize for letters; Central American University of El Salvador, for communication and humanities; and Honduran pharmacologist scientist Salvador Moncada for scientific research. The arts prize went to Spanish painter Antoni Tapies, while motorcycle racer Alfonso ``Sito'' Pons took home the sports prize. Spaniard Santiago Grisolia shared the research prize and Rodrigo Uria won in the social sciences category.

DOC.HEAD: France Asks U.N. Chief to Investigate Alleged Executions in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: France on Thursday demanded U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar immediately investigate allegations that Syrian forces have executed officers loyal to defeated rebel Gen. Michel Aoun. The Foreign Ministry in a communique said France is trying to obtain independent information concering reports that scores of Aoun's followers had been shot. The communique said the allegations of atrocities made by Lebanese Christians ``aroused extreme emotion.'' Aoun took refuge in the French Embassy in Beirut on Saturday in the face of an assault on his Christian enclave by Syrian and Lebanese government troops. He urged his followers to surrender and was granted political asylum by France. Lebanese authorities have refused to let Aoun depart, saying they want to put him on trial for taking money from the national treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Federation Wants Say in Kuril Islands Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Japan will be unable to reach any agreement over the disputed Kuril Islands without the involvement of the Russian Federation, the republic's new foreign minister said Thursday. Andrei Kozyrev told a news conference ``there is no such alternative'' to participation by Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, in any negotiations. The group of islands stretching north from Hokkaido were seized by Soviet troops in the final days of World War II. The dispute has kept Japan and the Soviet Union from signing a peace treaty to formally end the war. Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin visited the islands in August and said they should remain under Soviet control, but be demilitarized. The official Tass news agency said it was the first time in postwar years that such a high-ranking leader had visited the islands. Kozyrev, in his first news conference since being appointed last week, also said the Russian Federation planned to set up overseas embassies or consulates. He did not provide any details.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Rejects Call for Boost in Wheat Rates
DOC.TEXT: A group of farm-state Democrats appealed to Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter on Thursday to prop up slumping wheat prices by raising the government loan rate. Yeutter, however, believes boosting the loan price would have a ``devastating'' impact on U.S. grain exports, an Agriculture Department spokesman said Thursday. Wheat prices have fallen under $2.50 a bushel this fall, the lowest in five years, because of a bumper crops in the United States and around the world. A year ago, the price would have been about $3.50 a bushel. In a letter to Yeutter, the nine House members said he is using the loan price ``to manipulate the market and drive market prices down.'' ``We feel that the low-price strategy fails our farmers badly, because it does not allow them a loan price sufficient to pay off their own cash operating costs,'' the lawmakers said. They proposed raising the loan rate from the current $1.95 a bushel to about $2.65. The loan rate is the price at which farmers can take out government loans, using their grain as collateral. It effectively puts a floor under grain prices, since farmers usually forfeit their stocks to the government if market prices fall below the loan rate. Yeutter and others with a market-oriented philosophy say high loan rates allow foreign competitors to undercut U.S. exports and encourage farmers to dump grain on the government. ``We tried raising loan rates in 1981,'' said department spokesman Steve Censky, referring to the 1981 farm bill. ``We saw grain being produced and simply forfeited to the government instead of going to the market. ``It comes down to a fundamental disagreement on philosophy and policy. The folks who signed this letter are those who favor high loan rates and have advocated such policies for years.'' Signing the letter were Reps. Richard Gephardt of Missouri, who is the majority leader, Jim Oberstar and Tim Penny of Minnesota, Byron Dorgan of North Dakota, Tim Johnson of South Dakota, Richard Stallings of Idaho, David Obey of Wisconsin, Pat Williams of Montana and David Nagle of Iowa.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Die from Eating Poison Mushrooms in Istanbul
DOC.TEXT: Nine people have died in two days in the Istanbul area after eating poisonous mushrooms, the provincial Health Department said Thursday. Department head Temel Dagoglu said four of the 22 people hospitalized Wednesday died that day, and five more deaths were reported among those under treatment on Thursday. He said they had picked the mushrooms in meadows near Istanbul not realizing they were poisonous. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Health asked people to refrain from collecting and eating mushrooms that they were unfamiliar with and urged them to seek immediate medical help if they suspected they had been poisoned. It said the symptoms included heart palpitations, a rise in blood pressure, high fever and circulation problems.

DOC.HEAD: Government Upgrades Probe of Taurus, Sable
DOC.TEXT: Federal engineers are stepping up an investigation of reported brake disc corrosion in all Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models, the government reported Thursday. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had upgraded the probe from a preliminary evaluation - an examination of paperwork - to an engineering analysis, in which engineers will study the possibly defective parts. The investigation could result in a recall. In an unrelated matter, the agency said it was discontinuing an investigation of seat separation in the 1988 and 1989 Ford Festiva and 1985 Toyota vans and cargo vans because it could find no pattern to incident reports. On the brake issue, Ford Motor Co. said it was conducting its own investigation of all its models that have the same brake rotor and hub assembly as the Taurus and Sable.
