They include the Lincoln Continental, Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar, spokeswoman Joyce Stinson said. The investigation of the Taurus and Sable brake problem is the second this year. The government opened a preliminary investigation but closed it several months later, saying there was no evidence of a widespread defect, Ms. Stinson said. Agency spokesman Tim Hurd said there had been six complaints of front disc brake corrosion in the Taurus and Sable. An estimated 1.8 million of the vehicles are on the road. The complaints allege that the discs deteriorate and fail. The problem has been blamed for one accident and a minor injury. The problem appears to be centered in Northern climes where roads are heavily salted in the winter, Hurd said. Reports also have come in from maritime areas of Canada, Ms. Stinson said. The agency also announced the following new preliminary evaluations: -Ford Bronco and Bronco II, 1986 models, four complaints of fuel tank corrosion and leaks. An estimated 170,000 of the vehicles are on the road. -Chrysler Eagle Medallion, 1988-89 models, four complaints of electrical overload, possible cause of two fires. An estimated 33,130 are on the road. -Chrysler Jeep Cherokee, Wagoneer and Comanche, 1989-90 models with front wheel drive. Two complaints of broken left front brake hoses. An estimated 330,000 on the road. -Buick Reatta, 1989 model. Complaints of cars pulling to the right or left when pressure applied to brake, blamed for one accident and four injuries. An estimated 6,300 on the road. -Honda Accord, 1990 model. Two complaints of stuck locks on passenger side door, a safety problem in an emergency.

DOC.HEAD: So-Called `Killer' Bees Headed for Texas, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: It's certain now that infamous Africanized ``killer'' bees will invade southern Texas, officials said Thursday, touting a plan to slow down the bees if they can get the money to pay for it. Africanized bees are hybrid descendants of bees that escaped a breeding experiment in Brazil in 1957. They have been heading toward the United States ever since. To the untrained eye, the bees are indistinguishable from domestic varieties. They earned the nickname ``killer'' bees because of their tendency to sting in swarms when they perceive an intruder is threatening their hive. According to unofficial estimates, several hundred people probably have died from Africanized bee attacks since 1957 in South America, Central America and Mexico. The arrival of the bees in Texas seemed more imminent last November, when a swarm was trapped about 150 miles south of the U.S. border with Mexico. On Monday, U.S. Department of Agriculture scientists discovered the first swarm of the dreaded bees in a trap set just east of the border city of Hidalgo. A quarantine is already in place. It bans beekeepers or anyone else from moving bees from an area 100 miles north of the Rio Grande River. The emergency Texas Africanized Honey Bee Management Plan also includes search-and-destroy missions against the Africanized bees, enforcing quarantines, public education and research. Fowden G. Maxwell, head of the Entomology Department at Texas A&M University, estimated it would cost $800,000 to carry out. Last year the state Legislature denied a funding request for the plan, though it funneled $100,000 through other programs. ``We are worried that other states will decide that we are not doing our job to manage these bees and they will place a quarantine on all Texas bees,'' said Maxwell, who supervises the State Apiary Inspection Service, which regulates honey bees. State and federal officials are still hoping the Legislature will provide more money when it meets in January. Their main concern is to reduce economic damage to beekeepers and farmers. Africanized bees could cause havoc if they mate with the domestic variety. In the mean time, the federal Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service has stepped in. The agency of the USDA brought in 14 apiarists to search a 2-mile radius of the site where the Africanized swarm was caught Monday. It will take the bee experts about three weeks to take samples and test for Africanization in all managed bee hives and any wild swarms they find in that area, said Elba Quintero, program manager of the search. But the inspection service is committed to stopping only the first five swarms. It may be a year before people in the area notice an increase in wild bee swarms, said Anita Collins, resaarch leader at the Honey Bee Research Laboratory in Weslaco. Although bee attacks are unlikely, she said people should be aware that ``there's something out there besides rattlesnakes'' to watch out for.

DOC.HEAD: Vice Squad Detective Stumbles Through Tape
LaserPhoto MH3
DOC.TEXT: Jurors laughed Thursday as a flustered detective stumbled through her testimony in the obscenity trial of three members of 2 Live Crew, unable to understand a tape she made of the group's rap songs. The officer had recorded the allegedly obscene Hollywood concert that led to the arrest of the three, who were charged with violating community standards of obscenity by singing about oral and anal sex, among other things. The misdemeanor charges against Luther Campbell, Mark Ross and Chris Wongwon could bring yearlong prison terms and fines up to $1,000. Broward County sheriff's Detective Debbie Werder was one of eight undercover vice officers who taped the June 10th performance. Prosecutors asked her to play a few seconds of the cassette tape, then tell jurors the lyrics. She had trouble understanding the scratchy recording and repeatedly asked it to be played over. Jurors, who worked through lunch, were clearly irritated, shaking their heads and laughing. ``This isn't the type of music I listen to every day,'' Ms. Werder explained to the court. ``It's not the kind of music I want to memorize.'' One female juror nodded off. A young musician on the jury lightly tapped his feet during the music. Testimony was interrupted frequently by objections. And the jurors, who Wednesday had sought and received permission to laugh during the trial, loudly exercised that right in the jury room while the attorneys argued. Later the sequestered panel sent out for videotapes, including ``The Sound of Music,'' ``Fatal Attraction'' and ``West Side Story.'' The trial was scheduled to continue through the weekend. Two weeks ago, record store owner Charles Freeman of Fort Lauderdale was convicted of peddling obscenity for selling the rappers' album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Offers Aid in Drafting U.N. Report on Jerusalem Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Israel said Thursday it would try to help the U.N. chief write his report on the killing of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem, but stuck to its refusal to receive a visiting U.N. team of investigators. U.N. officials said Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar would have no immediate comment on what his course of action will be. He summoned Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein to discuss the extent of Israel's cooperation with a Security Council demand that Perez de Cuellar submit a report on the Oct. 8 killings on Temple Mount. Bein said later he had been called ``to convey some messages from the government of Israel, and we agreed that we'll cooperate in trying to find ways if means to facilitate the secretary-general to write his report, and present it.'' When asked if Israel would receive the secretary-general's emissaries, Bein smiled, said ``Thank you,'' and concluded the briefing. Officials said later, on condition of anonymity, that Israel would send Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to New York next week with a copy of Israel's official inquest into the shootings. At least 19 Palestinians were killed when Israeli security forces fired on protesters throwing rocks down on Jews praying at the Western Wall, more commonly known in the West as the Wailing Wall. Last Friday, the Security Council condemned Israel's security forces over the incident. The resolution also regretted that worshipers were injured, its only reference critical of the Palestinians. The council asked the secretary-general to send a team to investigate the killings and report back by the end of October. Perez de Cuellar told the council he needed clarification from Israel on its cooperation. He was adamant on Thursday that he would not prepare a report on the violence without firsthand information from a U.N. mission. He was asked if he might prepare a report based on news reports and other information. ``No. . . . That's not what the Security Council is asking us to do,'' he said. ``They want that I send a mission to the area. They are not asking me to prepare a report here in New York.'' Israel rejects an official U.N. mission as violating Israel's sovereignty. ``The mission goes, or it doesn't,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters who asked about a possible alternative. Israel has said that U.N. officials could enter as tourists, but the secretary-general has rejected travel on a less than official basis. Most members of the 15-nation Security Council, including the United States, are urging the secretary-general to press ahead and send a mission despite Israel's refusal to accept one.

DOC.HEAD: Rochester Police Chief Charged With Embezzling Cash From City
DOC.TEXT: The city police chief was arrested in the mayor's office Thursday on federal charges of embezzling at least $58,000 in police department funds, FBI officials said. Mayor Thomas P. Ryan was present during Police Chief Gordon F. Urlacher's arrest, the FBI said. Later in the day, Urlacher pleaded innocent to embezzling and misapplying public funds, a charge that carries a penalty of up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. U.S. District Judge Michael Telesca released Urlacher on $50,000 bail. Urlacher and five other department employees were suspended with pay in connection with the ongoing investigation. The investigation began Oct. 1 when the FBI was contacted by an employee in Urlacher's office who claimed to have helped the chief embezzle money from the department's special investigation funds, the criminal complaint filed against Urlacher said. Since July 1, 1989, the employee, who was not identified, helped Urlacher embezzle $58,000, said the complaint. ``A significant portion of said monies were in fact used by Gordon Urlacher to benefit himself personally,'' the complaint said. The special funds included money intended for drug buys during undercover drug investigations. FBI Special Agent Paul Moskal said the amount of money stolen may have been higher than $58,000. ``There are indications it's above that,'' he said. ``The exact figures at this point aren't known and may never be known.'' In setting bail, Telesca barred Urlacher from leaving the area and from carrying a firearm. Telesca granted Tyler's request to bar Urlacher from any police department contact during the continuing investigation by the FBI and the police department. Urlacher was ordered to return to federal court Friday for the setting of a preliminary hearing. After his arraignment, Urlacher would not comment on the charges. ``Obviously this comes as a shock to me,'' he said. Urlacher has been chief since 1985 and a member of the department since 1964. Ryan named Deputy Chief of Administration Roy A. Irving as acting police chief.

DOC.HEAD: Exit Poll: Tories Trail in Vote for Seat of Slain Parliamentarian
DOC.TEXT: An exit poll announced early Frida indicated the centrist Liberal Democrats may defeat the governing Conservatives in a special parliamentary election to replace a legislator killed by the IRA. A defeat in this coastal town in southern England, a Conservative stronghold, would come as a stunning setback to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Tories. The British Broadcasting Corp. exit poll of 2,000 voters here had the Liberal Democrats taking 47 percent of Thursday's vote and the Conservatives 45 percent. The Labor Party had just five percent and fringe candidates took three percent, according to the poll. The BBC said the margin of error was three percent and that the contest appeared a cliffhanger. Official results were expected later Friday. Ian Gow, the previous legislator, was killed July 30 when the Irish Republican Army blew up his car. His constituents are among the staunchest Conservatives in the country. But Conservative candidate Richard Hickmet, 42, a lawyer, was accused of overplaying the IRA card in his campaign to get a sympathy vote. A blacklash, combined with disillusion with the Thatcher government, was likely to slash the Tories' huge majority of nearly 17,000 votes, observers predicted. The Liberal Democratic Party ran an aggressive campaign and said its candidate, David Bellotti, 47, stood a good chance of snatching the 71,400-voter constituency to pull off a major special election upset. The main opposition Labor Party, which has led in national opinion poll ratings for more than a year, has no chance in Eastbourne. At the 1987 general election, Labor ran a distant third in Eastbourne behind the Liberal Democrats. The Liberal Democrats needed a strong showing to revive their waning fortunes before the next general election, which must be held by mid-1992. The latest national opinion poll, taken by ICM and published Thursday in The Guardian newspaper indicated Labor had 49 percent support, the Conservatives 36 and the Liberal Democrats 9. The Conservatives have a 97-seat majority in the 650-member House of Commons. Before voting, the Conservatives had 373 seats, Labor 226 and the Liberal Democrats 19. The rest were split among minority regional parties.

DOC.HEAD: British Mock Trial Acquits George Washington of Treason
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with court's reasoning, quotes, CORRECTS to make Sommerfield throughout. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON4
DOC.TEXT: George Washington was found not guilty on Thursday of treason against the British crown at a mock trial in which his lawyer argued that the American Revolution was a case of self-defense. ``I am delighted, elated,'' said Washington, played by Bill Sommerfield. ``Justice has been done. We've been vindicated and now I must go back and pursue the war with vigor and bring it to a just conclusion.'' Sommerfield and actors portraying Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin are members of the Royal Pickwickians of Philadelphia, a troupe that combines acting with historical research. Jefferson and Franklin testified at the trial, which pitted pin-striped American lawyers against British counsel in wigs and gowns. Harold Braff, a New Jersey trial lawyer and one of the team defending the commander-in-chief of the American Revolutionary Army, said the British were the ones who declared war on the colonists - hurting them economically and depriving them of liberties. ``If the British leadership had played their cards right, there would have been no revolution,'' he said. ``The colonialists weren't interested in severing the relationships. They felt a loyalty to the king but they were unwilling to have to accept laws from Parliament.'' The three judges - Lord Bridge of Harwich, a senior British Law Lord; Sir Patrick Neill, a British appellate judge; and U.S. Federal Judge A. Sherman Christensen of Utah - were unanimous in their ruling of innocent. They found that the way Britain governed the colonies forced the Americans to react. The colonists ``only as a last resort were driven to the Declaration of Independence,'' Bridge said. The judges agreed that Washington and all Americans were entitled to revolt against repression. ``The conduct of the Crown was in violation of the right of self-determination,'' Christensen said. Bill Barker, playing Jefferson, spoke softly in a southern accent and wore a blue ribbon to hold his ponytail. He told the court he was the governor of Virginia and an author of the Declaration of Independence. Franklin, played by Robert Gray, testified that he had traveled to England to try to reach a compromise with King George III and Parliament. Prosecuting Washington under the Treason Act of 1351 was Sydney Kentridge, the human rights lawyer who defended Steven Biko in South Africa. The lawyers agreed to limit the number of objections so the trial, filmed for screening on British and U.S. television, would ``make good drama,'' said Lanny Kurzweil, a member of the defense team. About 280 court spectators paid $34 each to attend, the money to go to the International Scholarships for Young Lawyers fund. The mock trial came about after Lord Goff, a member of the House of Lords made the treason charge at a June meeting of the American Inns of Court Foundation. Lawyers from Illinois and New Jersey took up the challenge and traveled to historic Lincoln's Inn for the trial. The Inn, an oasis of Georgian office buildings and tidy gardens in central London, was founded in the 14th century. It is the oldest of four Inns of Court that train and admit barristers, lawyers allowed to plead cases in court. Barristers-in-training must spend 18 months following senior barristers through the courts and the Inns, so-called because many barristers used to work and live there. The American Inns of Court Foundation, with 128 Inns in 38 states, works to bring the same tutorial methods to the U.S. legal system, matching young lawyers with senior advocates and jurists, said the foundation's president, Sherman Cohn.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises New Aid to Hungary
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs 4 grafs on dinner toasts
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Thursday promised drought-stricken Hungary $47.5 million in agricultural credits and loan guarantees and called for international lending concessions to help embryonic Eastern European democracies. President Bush also announced during an official visit of Hungary's Prime Minister Josef Antall that the United States is lifting travel restrictions on Hungary's diplomats and has agreed to permit a Hungarian consulate in Los Angeles. ``Hungary is no longer an emerging democracy. Hungary is a democracy,'' Bush said in a speech welcoming Antall to the White House. In keeping with administration support for the switchover from communism to democratic government and more free-market economies in Eastern Europe, Bush said he would push the International Monetary Fund to expand its lending to those countries by making 5 billion available. The president said that lending is needed to help compensate for the economic the new democracies are facing because they support U.N. sanctions against Iraq. ``We understand that the loss of export markets and rising energy costs complicate your historic effort to transform a centrally planned economic system to a free-market economy,'' Bush told Antall. The president also pledged to ask the World Bank to accelerate aid in the energy field, drawing on $9 billion already committed to Central and Eastern Europe. Hungary, suffering from what one U.S. official described as ``internal economic constriction,'' sought U.S. support to encourage foreign investment. ``They asked for American support in giving a strong signal to foreign investors that Hungary was a good place,'' for investment, said Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Curtis Kammen. Bush gave that signal in his speech, saying that U.S. companies already have invested more than $500 million in Hungarian enterprises. ``I encourage more American businesses to find out what Hungary has to offer,'' the president said. Bush announced $47.5 million in credits and loan guarantees to help Hungary cover its grain shortfall of 800,000 tons after its drought. The money will include $40 million in U.S. guarantees for 7-year commercial credits for U.S. commodities and $7.5 million in long-term credits on specific items. Hungary has the highest per capita debt in East Europe, standing at $20 billion for a population of 10 million. Antall, the first democratically elected Hungarian leader to visit the White House in more than 40 years, also met with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. Later, Antall and his wife Klara were feted at a state dinner at the White House, where guests included actors Kevin Costner and Tony Curtis, nuclear physicist Edward Teller and fashion designer Adrienne Vittadini. Entertainment was provided by classical pianist Van Cliburn. In a toast to the Hungarian leader, Bush applauded Hungary's struggle toward democracy. ``Especially during the past two years a your gallantry has evoked our admiration. Your example has been our inspiration,'' he said. For his part, the Hugarian prime minister joked that Bush was so popular in Hungary that he could find future employment there. Since the U.S. Constitution limits the president to two terms, Antall told Bush, ``I'm sure the Hungarian nation would surely elect you as president.''

DOC.HEAD: ABC Closing Bureaus In Three Cities
DOC.TEXT: Although it's still earning money, ABC News will close its bureaus in Chicago, Boston and Dallas because of lean times, but will maintain reporters in all three cities, an ABC spokesman said Thursday. The spokesman, Scott Richardson, said no further cuts were expected. The bureaus will be closed by Dec. 31. The move, which leaves ABC with nine U.S. bureaus, comes as ABC News is undergoing belt-tighting as a result of Persian Gulf coverage costs and lower-than-expected advertising revenues that affect all three networks. In Dallas, correspondent Charles Murphy will work from his home. In Boston, a two-man staff will be kept to work with ABC's medical correspondent, Dr. Tim Johnson, who reports for several ABC shows. In Chicago, correspondent Chris Bury will work out of ABC-owned WLS-TV. Twelve off-camera staff members are affected by the closings. Some will be reassigned or offered other jobs and others will be let go, Richardson said. He said it was not yet known how many would be let go. CBS, which has seven domestic bureaus, and NBC, which has nine, have no plans to close those offices, spokeswomen for those networks said. ABC's action was expected. The network earlier put on hold a planned 1 a.m. to 6 a.m. news feed to its affiliates that would have begun in January. That operation would have employed 40 people. ``I think domestically, this is it. ... This isn't like a `first-wave' (of layoffs) thing,'' Richardson said. ABC News officials have said the division still will earn money this year, despite the lean times, although it probably will earn about $25 million less than the $75 million that had been anticipated. NBC News recently said it would let go 25 staff members, but it isn't a cutback, said NBC spokeswoman Peggy Hubble. Their skills were just not needed for various projects being planned. Ms. Hubble said NBC is hiring an additional 100 staff members, the majority for the 24-hour NBC News Channel for affiliates it is starting next year. The remainder would work for the new ``Real Life With Jane Pauley'' series that NBC says it will add to its schedule as a midseason replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Police Announce Capture of Motorcycle Bandit
DOC.TEXT: Police with helicopter support captured Israel's ``Bikerbank'' bandit Thursday as he attempted to rob his 23rd bank. Police Minister Roni Milo announced the arrest on national radio. The suspect, an Israeli in his 30s, was spotted in the Tel Aviv suburb of Ramat Gan after parking his red and black motorcycle at a back entrance of a Bank Leumi branch. He reportedly fled without entering the bank when he spotted a police car. But a police team already had blocked off the area. Police on the goound and in a helicopter pursued him for 7{ minutes before he was captured. ``We were very close to the area, heard reports on the radio ... and noticed a bike rider who fled on a small road,'' police officer Shlomo Braunstein told a news conference in Tel Aviv. ``I was directed into the courtyard where the suspect was and stopped him. Afterwards we continued searches and found the suspect's bike and the pistol,'' Braunstein said. The bandit - nicknamed ``Ofnobank,'' Hebrew for ``Bikerbank'' - robbed 22 banks in a dozen towns the past 22 months. He became a local hero because of his ability to elude police. Israel Television had primetime reports on his exploits, and the daily Hadashot newspaper ran a series of articles trying to pierce his mysterious ways. There were even T-shirts that said ``Bikerbank.'' Before Thursday, police had no description of the man, who always wore a crash helmet during his robberies. The single fingerprint found had drawn a blank in police computers. His method was always the same - striking between 10 a.m. and noon, robbing the teller nearest the door, firing one shot in the air from his .38-caliber Smith and Wesson pistol and escaping on his high-powered motorcycle. News reports say Bikerbank's loot totaled $150,000. ``Every legend has its end,'' Israel radio said after the capture was announced. An unidentified Israeli told the army radio, ``The banks are harming us all the time, it's good that somebody harms them once.'' Milo made reference to such feelings in his statement: ``In the course of the various robberies, we have witnessed a certain feeling of public sympathy for the robber. I'm convinced that the public today will see the fact of police success ... as a great public success, too, that this issue at this stage comes to a positive ending.'' A Tel Aviv magistrates court issued an order banning publication of the suspect's photograph or any identifying details about him. But before the order was issued, media reports said the suspect was 37 years old, married, had no criminal past and came from a ``very wealthy'' Ramat Gan family of industrialists. According to radio reports, he was captured at the house of his parents.

DOC.HEAD: Remedy for a Space Cold: Stay Indoors and Plenty of Vitamin C
DOC.TEXT: Soviet space officials have ordered an old-fashioned remedy for a cosmonaut who caught a cold: take lots of vitamin C and stay indoors. That meant postponing a space walk Wednesday because Gennady Strekalov, 49, one of two cosmonauts on the orbiting Soviet space station Mir, caught a cold while working out on an on-board running track, the official news agency Tass said. The space walk was rescheduled for Oct. 30. ``A cosmonaut is, naturally, not a robot or automaton. He remains an ordinary human and, unfortunatey, is susceptible to ailments lurking in his path even in orbit,'' said Valery Polyakov, deputy director of the Health Ministry's Institute for Medical-Biological Problems. Tass said Strekalov was taking ascorbic acid, or vitamin C. Soviet physicians on Earth said no other medicine was necessary. Strekalov and Gennady Manakov were to take space walks to make final repairs on a hatch that failed to close this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Priest of Poor to Run for President in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Slum priest Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who has survived at least three assassination attempts and whose radical sermons led to his oster from the Salesian order, said Thursday he will run for president. ``If the people say run, I must run,'' Aristide said over the Catholic Radio Soleil. Aristide, 35, was nominated by the Democratic Convergence, a progressive political action group of about 300 public figures that has been seeking a unity candidate for weeks. Some grassroots organizations and small, left-wing parties also endorsed him for the Dec. 16 presidential election. His candidacy was unexpected. Reaction was not immediately available from the government, the military and mainstream parties. The outspoken priest has many enemies among the elite in this impoverished Caribbean island nation of 6 million. The last attempt on his life came in September 1988 as he was saying Mass at St. Jean Bosco Church. Hooligans with machetes, guns and spears burst into the church, killed 12 worshipers and wounded at least 70. Today, Aristide seldom sleeps at home and never takes the same routes. Jean-Claude Roy, president of the center-left Union of Haitian Constitutionals, said Thursday, ``Aristide's influence is essentially moral, not electoral. His candidacy will not win the support of conservatives nor even of moderates, who are afraid of violent confrontation.'' There are about 20 other presidential hopefuls but only seven have officially filed. The deadline is Sunday. Aristide runs a center for street children and is known as a spokesman for the poor and downtrodden. He has said in the past he was not interested in political power unless ``the people called me.'' Aristide was expelled from the conservative Salesian order in December 1988 after his superiors in Rome accused him of fomenting class warfare and being a ``protagonist of destabilization.'' A proponent of liberation theology, which advocates church involvement in the social struggles of the poor, Aristide preached ``active nonviolence'' and repeatedly denounced human rights abuses by Haiti's military. ``Aristide is the one and only candidate on the political scene who has wide appeal,'' said economist Paul Latourtue, a former senatorial candidate. His candidacy will not be popular with supporters of the Duvalier regime which ruled Haiti for 29 years, until the fall of Jean-Claude Duvalier in 1986. Duvalierist leaders and militants founded the Union for National Reconciliation last Sunday and chose Roger Lafontant for president.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Reformed Church in South Africa to Permit Women Ministers
DOC.TEXT: The 1.5-million-member Dutch Reformed Church voted Thursday to allow women to become ministers and elders. An all-male synod voted 242-137 for the proposal after two hours of debate, the independent South African Press Association reported. Previously, the highest office women could hold in the Protestant church was deacon. The Dutch Reformed Church is the main church of Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended whites who dominate the government.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors Recalling Big Cars
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Thursday recalled about 64,000 of its 1990 model Buick, Oldsmobile and Cadillac cars because of a possible transmission problem. The company said it was possible that a cable to the cars' floor-mounted shift levers could disconnect, freezing the transmission in the last gear selected. Cars affected by the recall include Buick Riviera and Reatta, Oldsmobile Toronado and Trofeo and Cadillac Eldorado and Seville models with floor-mounted shift levers. General Motors said it was unaware of accidents or injuries because of the problem. GM said it will install a retaining clip on the cable to ensure it remains in contact with the lever. Repairs will be performed for free.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed When Quake Hits South African Gold Mine
DOC.TEXT: An earth tremor caused a collapse at an Anglo American Corp. gold mine on Thursday, leaving six miners dead and six missing, the company said. It was the mine's second such tragedy in two days. On Wednesday, three miners died and two were injured when a tremor hit the same Western Deep Levels' West mine near Carletonville, about 40 miles west of Johannesburg. Five mine employees were injured in the Thursday incident, none seriously, the company statement said. The collapse took place about 1{ miles underground and rescue teams were searching for the six missing miners, it said.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Lifts State of Emergency in Natal Province
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Four grafs SUB for final 4 grafs, 22-25, to UPDATE with ANC said to ask corporations for money.
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk, meeting a key African National Congress demand, on Thursday lifted the 4-year-old state of emergency in violence-plagued Natal Province. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups welcomed the move, which de Klerk said removed all obstacles to negotiating power-sharing between the dominant white minority and the black majority. ``There is only one route to peace and reconciliation - that is through peaceful negotiation,'' the president said in Pretoria. ``The door to this is now fully open and I am appealing to all leaders and all South Africans to accept the challenge.'' The act officially ended a nationwide state of emergency declared in June 1986, when unrest spread throughout the country. In June, de Klerk lifted the emergency restrictions in the rest of the country but kept them in Natal, where a power struggle between the ANC and the conservative Inkatha movement has claimed 5,000 lives since 1986. Ending the state of emergency was an ANC condition for full-scale negotiations with the white-led government on ending apartheid and giving blacks a voice in national affairs. The United States and other nations that have imposed economic sanctions on South Africa to protest apartheid also have called for the emergency measures to be withdrawn. The ANC praised the move Thursday but urged de Klerk to release all political prisoners and repeal all security legislation. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi called the decision ``a step which should bring South Africa nearer to the negotiating table.'' A spokesman for the white anti-apartheid Democratic Party said ending the state of emergency forced ANC and Inkatha leaders to halt violence. Delegations from the two black opposition groups have been meeting in Natal to try to stop the fighting. But Buthelezi and ANC leader Nelson Mandela have refused to meet in what has become a political faceoff over control of the black opposition. De Klerk said the violence, though still sporadic, had receded and that order could be maintained through normal police powers. The state of emergency gave police and soldiers wide-ranging powers, including detention without trial and the authority to break up political rallies and meetings. Under security laws, police retain the right to impose stringent restrictions in what they deem emergency situations. More than 30,000 activists, almost all of them black, were detained for varying lengths of time during the four years of the nationwide state of emergency. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told the news conference the number of police and soldiers in Natal would not change. Police still have limited special powers in black townships around Johannesburg that have been declared ``unrest areas.'' About 800 blacks have died in factional fighting around Johannesburg in the last two months. De Klerk has now addressed all of the ANC's demands, including the release of political prisoners and the return of some 20,000 exiles. But exiles have yet to begin returning in large numbers and only a few dozen of the more than 1,500 political prisoners claimed by the ANC have been released. De Klerk reiterated that all political parties, including right-wing conservative and militant black groups, are welcome at constitutional negotiations he hopes to launch early next year. Only the ANC, Inkatha and the Democratic Party have expressed a desire to attend. De Klerk also said he wants to eliminate apartheid and give all South Africans a ``vote of equal value.'' The ANC, which for years has demanded nationalizing big business, is now asking corporations for financial help, Business Day newspaper reported Thursday. It said Mandela and other ANC leaders approached at least two major corporations in South Africa and were expected to approach a third soon. No financial commitments were made, it said, quoting unidentified business sources. An ANC statement acknowledged contacts between ANC leaders and businessmen, but said only that the ANC was developing a fundraising strategy which would likely target business organizations.

DOC.HEAD: FBI: Raids Struck Blow Against Hell's Angels Drug Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: The Hell's Angels motorcycle club was largely put out of the illicit business of methamphetamines trafficking with the arrests of 15 people in the Omaha area and another in California, an FBI agent says. ``We have made a significant impact on their ability to conduct illegal activity in this area,'' said Dennis Aiken, assistant special agent for the FBI in Omaha. Surrounded by confiscated rifles, a .22-caliber automatic pistol, $800,000 worth of drugs, $200,000 in cash as well as Hells Angel's jackets and posters, Aiken said a two-year investigation culminated in simultaneous raids Wednesday on 14 locations, including the club's headquarters in Omaha. A Rottweiler guard dog was killed after it attacked an officer at the clubhouse. One man at the clubhouse resisted arrest, but the other searches and arrests were conducted without incident, Aiken said. ``We consider this group to be a major center in the trafficking of methamphetamines,'' Aiken said at a news conference. Hell's Angels clubs have played a major role in methamphetamine traffic in the United States, he said. Many of the fewer than 50 club members in the Omaha area are now in jail, Aiken said. Everyone arrested in the Omaha area Wednesday was a Hell's Angel club member or a club associate, Aiken said. The investigation continued and it wasn't known how much contraband and money would eventually be confiscated, Aiken said. Charges included interstate and foreign travel in support of racketeering enterprises, money laundering, manufacturing and distribution of a controlled substance and felony possession of a firearm, an FBI press release said. Eleven of the 16 people arrested Wednesday in or near Omaha and in Long Beach, Calif., had been named in a federal grand jury indictment issued Monday, Aiken said. The five others were arrested on charges of drug possession based on evidence obtained during the raids, he said. Larry Holmquist, an FBI spokesman, would not comment on the connection between the arrest in California and the others here. Douglas County Sheriff Dick Roth said the suspects had been investigated as far back as 1978. ``We have had tons of intelligence on these people's actions over the years,'' Roth said. A cooperative effort that included the FBI, Nebraska State Patrol and the federal Drug Enforcement Administration used electronic surveillance such as wire intercepts, Aiken said. He refused to say whether undercover agents played a role. Homes and businesses were searched in Omaha, in Valley to the west and in Council Bluffs, across the Missouri River in Iowa, the FBI said.

DOC.HEAD: New York State Acts Against Major Barge Company
DOC.TEXT: The state on Thursday shut down one of the largest sludge and oil transport companies in New York Harbor, citing a pattern of abuse of environmental laws. Thomas C. Jorling, state commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, said the order was the first against an entire fleet of barges since the department was created in 1970. The order comes after one of the barges, operating illegally, sank Sept. 27 at the First Marine Shipyard on Staten Island, spilling 50,000 gallons of oil into the Kill Van Kull between the island and New Jersey. That was the latest in a series of unrelated spills that have dumped more than 1 million gallons of petroleum products into the harbor during the past year. ``Here we are going further because ... we have concluded that this corporation cannot operate safely,'' Jorling said Thursday. The barges cited in the civil order belong to the family of former city Ports and Terminals Commissioner Susan Frank. The order names three of about 45 family-owned businesses: Berman Enterprises Inc. of Manhattan and General Marine Transport Corp. and Standard Marine Services Inc., both of Bayonne, N.J. The companies control at least 19 barges, or 10 percent of all commercial barges operating in the harbor, Jorling said. They are also being investigated for possible criminal violations, he said. Also named in the civil order were Ms. Frank's mother, 72-year-old Evelyn Berman Frank, who heads General Marine; Peter Frank, president of General Marine and Susan Frank's brother; and Jane Frank Kresch, secretary of Berman Enterprises and Susan Frank's sister. Phone messages left at their offices and at First Marine Shipyard by The Associated Press were not returned Thursday. The order gives the companies seven days to dock the barges at First Marine Shipyard. A hearing was scheduled for Oct. 30 to decide whether the operating licenses should be revoked permanently. The companies hold contracts to dispose of sewage sludge fr Westchester County and several New Jersey cities, Jorling said, adding that the state was looking for alternative disposal companies. There should be no interruption in oil supplies, he said. Besides the spill last month, the state order blamed the companies for nine known oil spills, three groundings and two collisions since 1983. They have also received 21 Coast Guard citations in other cases since then. Fires and explosions involving the barges have killed two people and injured several others, it said. Eight of the 19 barges lack inspection certificates, five failed to complete required midterm inspections and five lack DEC licenses, the order said. Evelyn Frank and General Marine recently pleaded guilty in New Jersey Superior Court in a toxic-sludge dumping case and was fined $1 million. According to the criminal indictment, she ordered employees to dump toxic substances in the waters off Brooklyn and Newark, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Trafficker Surrenders Under Extradition Promise
DOC.TEXT: An alleged drug smuggler surrendered Thursday, becoming the first to accept the government's promise not to extradite traffickers to the United States who turn themselves in, a radio report said. Jesus Rincon, 24, took President Cesar Gaviria up on his offer last month not to extradite smugglers who surrender and to reduce their jail sentences by up to half, Radio Caracol reported. Neither police nor judicial offices were answering the phone late Thursday to confirm the report. Caracol said Rincon, who is sought in the States for drug crimes, turned himself in to a judge and was jailed in Pereira, a coffee-growing region of southwestern Colombia and hometown of President Gaviria. To be eligible for Gaviria's offer, surrendering drug traffickers must confess their crimes and cooperate with police. Rincon is the first to accept the offer. The notorious Medelli cocaine cartel has rejected Gaviria's offer. It kidnapped seven journalists and the sister of an ambassador to pressure the government to grant pardons instead.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Becomes Season's 8th Hurricane
DOC.TEXT: Nana grew from storm to a hurricane Thursday, heading north toward Bermuda, forecasters said Thursday. A hurricane watch was posted for Bermuda as the season's eighth hurricane generated top sustained winds of 75 mph, just 1 mph above the threshold for hurricanes, National Hurricane Center forecasters said. The storm was headed northwest at near 15 mph and a turn to the north or possibly northeast was expected during the next 24 hours, the center's advisory said. ``It probably will remain a minimal hurricane,'' said meteorologist Joel Cline. However, forecasters said Nana could strengthen during the next 24 hours. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, the center of Nana was located near 27.5 north latitude, 66.4 west longitude, or about 335 miles south of Bermuda. Formed Tuesday as a tropical depression northeast of Puerto Rico, Nana became the season's 14th named storm. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Associates Indicted For Alleged Money-Laundering
DOC.TEXT: One of Ferdinand Marcos' lawyers was indicted with her husband Thursday on charges of laundering about $2.9 million for the late Philippine president. Helen Rivilla, a member of Marcos' legal team in the United States, and her husband, Antonio C. M. Rivilla, were named in the 39-count federal indictment, U.S. Attorney Dan Bent said. The Rivillas caused eight Honolulu financial institutions to fail to file required currency transaction reports with the Internal Revenue Service or to file reports that did not identify Marcos and others, the indictment said. The alleged transactions occurred between June 1987 and September 1988, it said. If convicted, Helen Rivilla faces a maximum penalty of 390 years in prison and a fine of $19.5 million. Her husband faces a maximum 80-year prison term and a $4 million fine. Marcos died in exile in Honolulu last year, nearly four years after being ousted by a popular revolt in the Philippines. His widow, Imelda, was acquitted in July of federal fraud charges in New York. She was charged with looting more than $200 million from the Philippine treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Romania to Lift Most Price and Wage Controls
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Petre Roman on Thursday announced the lifting of most price and wage controls in conjunction with a devaluation of the currency. The new measures, which take effect Nov. 1, are ``a leap toward a market economy,'' but could cause inflation and unemployment, Roman said in a speech to both houses of Parliament. However, he said, ``This is the price we must pay to fill stores, combat speculation and correct the economy.'' Subsidies are to be maintained for the moment on energy, rent and some food items. It was not clear how much the uncontrolled prices actually would increase on Nov. 1. Items supplied by less than three producers will remain price-controlled because of insufficent competition to regulate prices on a market basis. Under the centralized economy inherited from the Communists, prices and salaries were set without connection to their real market value. Since the December revolution that ousted the Communist regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, both productivity and production have fallen by more than 20 percent. Wages, however, have increased 11 percent. At present, 50,000 of the country's workforce of 12 million people are registered as unemployed. But Roman warned that ``hidden unemployment'' is much higher. He estimated that to avoid massive unemployment about 700,000 ``inefficient'' workers and another 300,000 of next year's graduates would have to be retrained. According to the government's plan, Romanians should be partially compensated for expected price increases through a complex system of indexing. Roman said wages are to be ``liberalized'' according to market principles, ``with the highest wage-earners being those who produce the most profit.'' He said he hoped this would stimulate production enough to counter-act inflationary pressures of the reform program. Roman said the Romanian leu would be devalued to 35 to the dollar from its present, artificially low rate of 20. The move is an effort to halt the spiralling trade deficit and hasten convertibility.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Inmate's Arrest Rekindles Interest in Murder Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after lead and graf after 10th graf, `Ms. Bembenek ...' to UPDATE with quotes from her. Pick up 11th graf, `The escape ...'
DOC.TEXT: The capture of prison escapee Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek and her fiances rekindled public interest Thursday in the one-time police officer and former model who was convicted of murder. ``Minutes, just 10 more minutes and we could have gotten away,'' she said in a jail interview with the television show ``Inside Edition.'' Listeners jammed the switchboards of Milwaukee radio call-in shows eager to debate Ms. Bembenek's conviction nearly a decade ago for killing her former husband's ex-wife. ``As pretty as she is, people don't want to believe she did what she did,'' said Elfred Schultz, a former Milwaukee police detective who was briefly married to Ms. Bembenek. In her native Milwaukee, residents have long debated Ms. Bembenek's involvement in the 1981 killing of Christine Schultz, who was bound, gagged and shot. Ms. Bembenek was a university security guard at the time of the killing. Before that, she worked briefly as a Milwaukee police officer, a model and a waitress in a Playboy club. Royal Canadian Mounted police arrested Ms. Bembenek on Wednesday in the tourist city of Thunder Bay, Ontario. She fled there with her fiance after escaping from a Wisconsin prison three months ago. Ms. Bembenek was serving a life sentence for killing Mrs. Schultz, former wife of Elfred Schultz. Authorities allege Ms. Bembenek, 32, killed the first Mrs. Schultz because she was receiving $700-a-month alimony payments from Elfred Schultz. Ms. Bembenek continued to maintain her innocence after her sentencing. She was divorced from Schultz shortly after her conviction. Her appeals for a new trial have been rejected three times by state appeals courts and twice by the Wisconsin Supreme Court. Ms. Bembenek escaped July 15 from the Taycheedah Correctional Institute near Fond du Lac in northeastern Wisconsin and fled to Canada with Dominick Gugliatto, a suburban Milwaukee factory worker who courted her in prison. ``Dominick and I love each other,'' she said during the interview from a Thunder Bay jail. ``One of my biggest regrets is that we were never able to get legally married.'' The escape thrilled Ms. Bembenek's Milwaukee fans. Entrepreneurs sold T-shirts that read ``Run Bambi Run.'' A private investigator offered to research new evidence that would help reverse the conviction. Several tabloid TV shows also reported on the escape, playing up Ms. Bembenek's looks and the romantic elements of the prison break. Ms. Bembenek and Gugliatto were arrested after authorities were contacted by someone who recognized the pair in a Thunder Bay restaurant from the Oct. 12 episode of ``America's Most Wanted.'' The two were held in the Thunder Bay district jail pending an immigration hearing next week. Those who met the couple during their brief stay in Thunder Bay were shocked by their arrests. Ms. Bembenek worked as a $5-an-hour waitress and Gugliatto was short-order cook. They shared a small basement apartment and went by the names Jennifer Lee and Tony Gazzana. ``I found her a lovely woman. She was very kind, warm and outgoing,'' said Jenny Beck, their landlady. ``I can't believe it.'' Louis Kebezes, owner of the Columbia Grill & Tavern where Ms. Bembenek worked, called her ``a beautiful lady, a excellent waitress.'' ``I have policemen come here,'' said Kebezes. ``She serves them and she was terrific. Nobody expected her to have a thing on her record.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Once on This Island'' has blossomed on Broadway. The charming Caribbean musical that was a hit last spring at off-Broadway's Playwrights Horizons has danced into the Booth Theater with its sweet simplicity and heart-tugging emotions intact. Moving small off-Broadway shows to a much bigger Broadway theater is risky business. For every ``Chorus Line'' or ``Ain't Misbehavin' ,'' there's a ``Chu Chem'' or ``The Human Comedy.'' But Graciela Daniele has directed and choreographed ``Once on This Island'' with such a sure sense of style and unity that the leap to a larger space works. The 90-minute show, a seamless blend of narrative, song and dance, expands to fill the theater. The story spun by ``Once on This Island'' is a slight one. It unfolds as a fable told to a little girl on a storm-wracked island in the French Antilles. The storytellers, virtually the entire cast of 11 performers, become the characters in the tale. The musical celebrates the love of a dark-skinned peasant girl, Ti Moune, for Daniel, the mulatto son of a wealthy landowner. She saves him from an auto accident and nurses him back to life and love. Their relationship is helped and hindered by the gods - a quartet of deities who represent earth, water, love and death. Daniel eventually must marry a woman of his own class. The two have been promised to each other since childhood. But the ending is far from downbeat. In fact, it's cathartic and exhilarating. Part of the exhilaration comes from a radiant young actress with an exotic name - La Chanze - who plays Ti Moune. She sings and dances with a freshness that is captivating. She gets fine support from the rest of the cast, particularly Jerry Dixon as the young man and Kecia Lewis-Evan as the most boisterous of earth mothers. On a second hearing, the score remains as melodic as ever. Stephen Flaherty's atmospheric music is rich in Caribbean rhythms wedded to more traditional musical theater songs. Lynn Ahrens - who did the artful adaptation from a novel by Trinidadian writer Rosa Guy - has carefully matched Flaherty's music with simple but not simplistic lyrics. Designer Loy Arcenas has created a deceptively primitive background that immediately places the audience in a storybook frame of mind. He has come up with a bright blue background with a few painted palm trees, a style that suggests a tropical Chagall crossed with Matisse. It looks like a giant children's pop-up book come to life. But in the end, it is the show's emotional content that is its most appealing aspect. We root for the girl and her attempt to find happiness. But then, that's not too hard when we have such a sparkling heroine who lifts our spirits and the musical as well.

The army early today drove off leftist guerrillas who attacked air force headquarters with homemade mortars and automatic weapons, and authorities said several people were wounded. A military spokesman said he had an initial report that one military mechanic was wounded and one aircraft was damaged in the three hours of fighting at Ilopango air base on the east side of the capital. The fighting began at 9:45 p.m. Wednesday and died down after midnight, but helicopters continued patrolling the city early today. A Red Cross spokesman said several people were wounded but did not immediately know the number. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Senate is considering raising taxes on the rich and moderating a Medicare premium increase after refusing to strip a higher gasoline levy from its deficit-reduction bill. The measure, which would raise taxes and reduce benefit programs by $250 billion over the next five years, is on a fast track that congressional leaders hope could place it on President Bush's desk for his signatue Friday night. Without final action, or at least considerable progress on such a package, Bush has said he will shut down the government Saturday morning, when federal spending authority is due to expire. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Senate documents show Sens. Alan Cranston, Donald W. Riegle Jr. and Dennis DeConcini had more extensive dealings with the owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan than previously acknowledged. In one of the documents, Cranston thanks ex-Lincoln head Charles H. Keating Jr. for a $250,000 contribution to a pet political cause. In the same memo, the senator expresses pleasure that Keating's meeting with the chief thrift regulator ``had gone so well.'' The Senate Ethics Committee documents, obtained by The Associated Press, are expected to play a major role in the panel's deliberations, beginning today, on whether to intensify the investigation of the three senators - part of the so-called ``Keating five.'' Committee Counsel Robert S. Bennett has recommended advancing the investigation against Cranston, D-Calif., Riegle, D-Mich., and DeConcini, D-Ariz., while dropping the investigation of Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz. and John Glenn, D-Ohio. A committee decision was not expected today. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - U.S. officials are gaining important espionage information from newly available files of the disbanded East German secret police, CIA Director William Webster says. West German officials have shared with the United States information from voluminous files seized when the communist government of East Germany was toppled by popular discontent last fall, he said. ``We have pursued a number of important leads,'' the CIA director said in an interview with The Associated Press on Wednesday. ``That's not to say we've identified spies, but we've learned more about some notorious cases,'' he said, declining to elaborate. East Germany's notorious Stasi secret police had about 80,000 agents keeping tabs on its 11 million citizens, Webster said. The files have yielded a bonanza of secrets and identified some highly placed West German officials as East German spies, he said. ---= SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - A day of somber remembrance gave way to a night of celebration as survivors of the San Francisco Bay quake marked its anniversary at a restaurant that stayed open a year ago for those needing a good stiff one. ``To some people, it's like surviving the Titanic. They were panicky a year ago, but now they're just happy,'' Alexander Mortacavi, owner of L'Entrecote de Paris, said Wednesday night on the anniversary of the Oct. 17, 1989 earthquake. Earlier Wednesday, people throughout the Bay area fell silent or wept at 5:04 p.m., the moment the quake hit. Church bells tolled and mourners in Oakland heaped white carnations near where the Cypress Freeway collapsed and killed 42 people. The quake, which measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people throughout the Bay area and caused $7 billion in damage. ---= FOND DU LAC, Wis. (AP) - The ``tabloid TV'' notoriety of a former Playboy waitress and policewoman convicted of murdering her husband's ex-wife helped lead to her capture three months after she escaped from prison. Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek, 31, was arrested at an apartment in Thunder Bay, Ontario, on Wednesday on a tip from a viewer of last week's episode of ``America's Most Wanted.'' Ms. Bembenek, who has steadfastly professed her innocence, was captured with her fiance, Dominic Gugliatto, 34. Her flight had thrilled supporters in Milwaukee - prompting sales of T-shirts that read, ``Run, Bambi, Run'' - and was covered on several ``tabloid TV'' shows, whihh played up her looks and the romantic elements of the escape.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Mining Emeralds, Rubies to Finance War
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Dramatic events elsewhere are drying up the money pool for Afghan guerrillas, and one group has started mining gems to finance the 12-year-old war. The snow-covered mountains and rocky valleys of the Hindu Kush have been known for centuries as a rich source of emeralds and rubies, aquamarines and lapis, but mining has been primitive and irregular. Guerrilla chief Ahmed Shah Masood decided to exploit the mineral wealth of the Panjshir Valley, the largest area controlled by a single commander, to replace dwindling outside aid and pay the bills of his Islamic army. For help, he turned to Gary Bowersox, a gemologist based in Honolulu. Bowersox is making a survey of the valley's deposits, using a Soviet study made in 1977, the year before a coup installed a Communist government and the Moslem uprising began. He said preliminary findings point to a potential in billions of dollars. ``We're seeing crystals of a size and quality that equals or surpasses material from anywhere in the world,'' he said in an interview during a month-long visit to the Panjshir. ``What we've found justifies a closer look.'' According to Bowerox, the valley could rival Brazil, Zambia and Colombia, the world's leading producers, as a source of emeralds. The richest known emerald deposits are in the Colombian jungles, but gangs of drug traffickers and bandits have interfered with the supply. Even in the mid-1980s, during the fiercest fighting between guerrillas and the Soviet-backed Afghan army, precious stones trickled out of Afghanistan to northern Pakistan and on to other markets. Bowersox said he would like to bring in sophisticated drilling and sorting equipment to speed the mining process and save more of the gems. ``A lot of the Afghan miners are using explosives taken from bombs and shells to blast them up,'' he said. ``In the process, they're destroying a lot of valuable gemstones.'' During the nine-year Soviet military involvement in Afghanistan, the United States provided an estimated $300 million of military aid to the guerrillas. Since the Red Army withdrew in February 1989, Washington been trying to extricate itself from what has become a political and military stalemate. Many oil-rich Arab states that supported the Moslem guerrillas now are preoccupied with the Persian Gulf crisis that began Aug. 2, when Iraq occupied Kuwait. Guerrilla commanders say their flow of arms, ammunition and money has nearly stopped. Gem mining in the Panjshir is not done by Masood's guerrillas, but by prospectors who pay digging fees. Masood also either collects a 10 percent tax on gemstones or buys them to sell on the world market. Masood, whose success against the Soviet army made him a folk hero, said he hoped the gems eventually would finance his military operation. He would not be specific about profits, but said: ``We're well ahead of our expectations.'' Residents say the Panjshir Valley has been relatively free of attacks by government forces since the Soviets left. Admirers attribute that to Masood's military prowess, but critics claim he made a secret deal with President Najibullah. Taloqan, capital of Takhar province, has a population of about 50,000 and is the largest city outside government control. It is administered by an advisory council that collects taxes to run a police force, schools, clinics and a movie theater. ``If Masood can continue to supply the level of security he has so far, this place is a lot safer than Colombia,'' Bowersox said.

For Release Friday PMs Oct 26 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Oldest Emigrant, 100, Leaving for Canada
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Maria Venus Rozario has faced hunger and Japanese invaders during 100 years in Hong Kong. After her husband died when she was 33, she hacked a living for their eight children from this jungle of free enterprise. Now Mrs. Rozario is leaving, lonely for the children already gone and fearful of China's Communist government, which takes over the British colony in 1997. When she steps onto the plane for Vancouver, Canada, the frail but spry great-grandmother will become the oldest emigrant in a mass exodus from Hong Kong. The government says 62,000 of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people will leave this year, but other estimates put the number closer to 80,000. Most emigrants are professionals in their 30s and 40s, but growing numbers of old people are joining them. Hong Kong's elderly, left behind by their emigrating children, often have the bitter choice of dying alone or leaving home. ``It's not too much to ask to be with one's family, is it?'' Mrs. Rozario said, fingering a tattered family photograph. ``But I will also miss Hong Kong. My whole life is here with all my memories.'' Mrs. Rozario, who plans to leave in November, has a daughter in British Columbia and a son in San F section. Downstairs are the Steamy Steam Baths and the Chinese Happy Tattoo House. Upstairs, in Mrs. Rozario's apartment, are fresh cut flowers and a small collection of butterflies. Maria Venus Gomes da Silva was born into a family of sailors from the Portuguese colony of Macao, 45 miles south of Hong Kong on the southern Chinese coast. Her father moved to Hong Kong, where he married and started a family. Maria went to work at 14, teaching English grammar to the daughters of British soldiers stationed in the territory. She left the school in 1913 to marry a Portuguese businessman, and her first child was born in 1915. His death of a heart attack in 1923 left Mrs. Rozario alone with eight children. She never remarried and supported the children by working two jobs at once, sometimes three, as secretary, clerk and accountant. ``You don't know how hard hunger is to take, especially when it's your children who are hungry,'' she said. Then came Japan's brutal occupation during World War II. One day, Japanese troops lined up a group of young men on a boulevard by Hong Kong's harbor. A Japanese policeman moved along the rank, chopping off their heads with a sword. One of Mrs. Rozario's sons, Marcos, was last in line. He had been arrested for resisting the occupation. ``I ran through the crowd and pleaded with the man to save my boy,'' she said. ``He gave in.'' At the end of the war, Mrs. Rozario collected Marcos from jail. He was tortured and broken by the Japanese and still lives with his mother, unable to work. Mrs. Rozario said she hopes to take Marcos to Canada, ``but if we cannot get the visa, then he will stay here. This is what has become of my family.'' After the war, her other children left Hong Kong one by one, attracted by better job prospects or propelled by fear of the Communists in China. ``The family all wanted to stay,'' she said, ``but it was the insecurity about Hong Kong that made them leave. How can we live in peace here with the Chinese ready to grab us back?'' Soon after China's bloody crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Beijing last year, Mrs. Rozario also decided to go. ``Just like in the Bible, it's really an exodus,'' she said. ``I'm just a little drop of water in all this.''

DOC.HEAD: An Experiment in Independence: Bringing Battered Women Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note date in 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: Cindy's husband roused their sleeping 12-year-old son at midnight. ``You're the first one that's going to die,'' he said. That night, Cindy and her three kids left the beatings, the threats, the daily violence of her crazy-jealous husband forever. After 16 years of marriage, of control so complete she lost herself, Cindy found the courage to face freedom. ``I thank God I'm free,'' said Cindy, who didn't want her real name used for fear her husband will find her. ``I'm home, with my kids.'' The two-bedroom apartment they share is an experiment in independence for battered women, believed to be the first of its kind in the nation: permanent homes with social services downstairs. Thursday marks the official opening. Six women and their children have moved in, and eight more are coming. There are at least 4 million Cindys each year in America, according to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence. Every 15 seconds, a woman is beaten. Every six hours, a woman is murdered by her husband or boyfriend. Still, women stay with their abusers, because a violent home often seems better than no home at all. And that is the choice. The sad truth is that battering causes homelessness. A Victim Services Agency study showed that 35 percent of women living in city homeless shelters were there to escape men who beat them. ``In order to protect yourself and care for yourself, you have to let go of everything: friends, family, furniture, clothing,'' said social worker Olosunde Johnson, who is helping these women face the future. ``Things that you love, that have emotional value to you. And you have to walk out and leave that. And there's something wrong with that.'' Cindy left, and lived in a shelter for battered women, one of 1,700 serving 20,000 cities nationwide. The National Domestic Violence Hotline receives 108,000 calls a year, about one-third of which request shelter. But the need far outstrips the available space. A Los Angeles County grand jury found last year that 90 percent of the battered women and children who sought safety were turned away. In Washington, D.C., eight out of every 10 women are told there is no room. Advocates believe the situation is similar in New York, Chicago and other big cities. ``And then, after 90 days, you have to be uprooted again. This is victimization after victimization,'' Johnson said. ``It just keeps eating away at the women and the children. `Who am I?' is a question that comes up. `Who am I?''' The victimization stops at the glass doors on a residential street in Brooklyn, the ones that lead to these 16 apartments. Permanent homes, ones the women and their children leave of their own free will and return to, feeling safe. ``This man used to tell me when to go to bed, when to take a bath, when to get up, five minutes to go to the store, and after five minutes, there would have been a beating or a fight,'' Cindy, 33, said. ``Now it's just me and the kids. Nobody to say, `No, you can't go, or if you go, I'm going to hit you.' And it's wonderful.'' Advocates say this permanent housing, which cost $1.7 million over 18 months to develop, is the logical conclusion in the evolution of services for battered women. In the early '70s, people would open their private homes for abused women and their kids. Emergency shelters followed, where women could stay for up to three months. It soon became clear that it took more than 90 days to reorder a life. So transitional housing was born, which allowed stays of a year or 18 months. Even that was not enough. The economy was changing; living costs were soaring in big cities like New York, and the result was that during the 1980s, battered women were increasingly returning to the men who abused them simply because they couldn't afford not to. ``And the thing that was different was housing,'' said Lucy Friedman, executive director of Victim Services Agency, the independent, non-profit group that created the housing with the Urban Coalition. ``It got down to going back to an abusive partner or going to a welfare hotel.'' Now these women are home for good. The social services, provided by Johnson, will be here for 18 months. There is a support group for the women and another for their children. Johnson works on getting child care, enrolling the kids and the women in school, helping them achieve their career goals. Johnson's desk is in the basement, but her heart is with the women. She's been there, and that helps her maintain her faith that these women will come as far as she has. ``It also helps me in identifying what's going on with them, even when they're unable to identify it,'' she said. ``And it helps me to love them, even when they're unlovable.'' Sometimes Jennifer gets that way, comes downstairs acting like a fool. Leaves the tidy, three-bedroom apartment she shares with her two daughters and young son, and vents some of the anger and depression that comes of growing up abused with 10 brothers and sisters, then being abused for two years by a crack-addicted husband, and being a crack addict herself. Jennifer bounced from shelter to shelter for more than a year, her children in tow, fighting urges to smoke crack again, to drink herself into oblivion, to kill herself and be done with it all. She left her husband for her children's sake, but the injustice of having to walk out that door still galls her. ``I left my own apartment. Not his. Mine! He is the one who had my apartment when I was in the streets, including the nights he put me in the streets,'' the 26-year-old said. ``Cold, freezing outside with my children. Five or six in the morning.'' She left once and returned once. She left again, almost returned again but thought better of it. Not being involved with the batterer is one of the criteria for renting one of these heavily subsidized apartments. That, and being drug and alcohol-free, and being motivated to move ahead with life. Being willing to learn how to act independently without fear. Jennifer and Cindy are doing their best. ``When I finally felt safe, that I could sleep and walk the street without somebody yelling or doing something, then I started thinking, `I want a home for my children,'' Cindy said. ``I always told them, `I'm going to get you a better home.' ``Thank God I did. Now we have everything.'' ---

DOC.HEAD: Chamber's Lesher: The Economy Is Under Siege
DOC.TEXT: Richard Lesher knew that relations with the White House were less than cordial when, he says, John Sununu threatened to remove part of Lesher's anatomy with a chain saw. Sununu is chief of staff in President Bush's White House, while Lesher is president and chief executive officer of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, a strong supporter of free enterprise and economic growth. The communications gap opened several months ago, when the chamber expressed support for lower Social Security payments and took a stand against piling mandated benefit obligations on the back of industry. Now, although Lesher says the lines remain open, the rift is wide, as it is between the White House and other organizations that many people had assumed would be administration supporters. The chamber opposed the budget package. Lesher's lists the reasons why: 1. Raising taxes when the economy is in recession is dangerous. Eighty percent of the original package was in higher taxes, only 20 percent in cuts. 2. The notion of secret summit meetings for six months, followed by demands for approval within days and without open hearings, is wrong, especially since some of the agreements broke new ground. 3. Among proposals agreed to by the budget summitteers was a huge increase - to $50,000 from $10,000 - in fines for violations of the Occupational Safety and Health Act. ``It was carefully secluded in the package.'' 4. The assumptions that interest rates would decline, inflation tail off and the economy grow in spite of anti-growth recommendations were unsupported. After extensive talks with professional economists and with members around the country, Lesher says, ``I feel very strongly we are heading into a substantial recession, one made more so by the so-called solution.'' Popular forecasts generally refer to a mild recession, one lasting for two straight quarters, each of about 1 percent negative growth. Many forecasts assume that wise inventory management - Americans have learned to keep supplies to a minimum - and strong exports will prevent a more serious decline. Lesher doesn't believe it. He concedes that inventory management is good, but points out that exports already are slowing. He speculates about a world recession. Latin America ``already is in the tank,'' Asia is headed there and Europe is weakening, he says. Domestically, the recession would last six straight quarters, including all 1991. Vision and leadership in Congress would lessen the blow, he says, but he laments that it isn't forthcoming. Asked for an example, he refers to the nondebate on making the United States energy independent. He suggests the country's policy should be one of encouraging exploration and development of oil, in Alaska, offshore and elswhere, that distribution pipelines be built, that nuclear possibilities should be reinvestigated. ``These things alone might bring back the economy,'' he said, while, of course, making the country less dependent on supplies from abroad. But, he lamented, proponents too often become buried in blind, emotional reactions. It has reached the point, he said, where ``people of common sense have been shouted down by voices of emotionalism and distortion.'' He suggested that opponents of oil drilling, posing as environmentalists, prevent sensible debate on offshore developments, to wit: ``We have drilled thousands of wells on the coasts, and we've had one major oil spill.'' But, since further efforts often are thwarted, the United States must transport oil by ship, incurring vastly greater ecological risks. The economy is under siege, said Lesher. Not just from those whom he feels politicize and emotionalize energy issues, but from economic policy makers too.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Fri, Oct 19
