DOC.HEAD: Abortion Re-Emerging as Issue in Campaigns
DOC.TEXT: After taking a back seat to worries about taxes, the economy and the Middle East, abortion is re-emerging as a potentially decisive issue in the final days of the 1990 election season. ``It's one of the few issues that's still out there that distinguishes people,'' said Harrison Hickman, a pollster for abortion-rights causes. ``I would predict you'll see a lot of people using it at the last minute to try to push undecided voters.'' Conventional political wisdom has held that abortion-rights candidates had the upper hand this year and that opponents of abortion were on the defensive after a 1989 Supreme Court ruling revived the issue. Electoral losses for abortion foes in 1989 contributed to that view. Yet abortion hasn't proven to be the ``silver bullet'' for abortion-rights candidates, in the words of Democrat Donald Avenson, a pro-choice candidate for Iowa governor. And abortion opponents point to races where their candidates have stood firm and are leading - including governor's races in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and Iowa. ``It's not the issue some thought a year ago. On the other hand, it's more salient this year than it has been in the past in a lot of states,'' said Doug Johnson, legislative director for the National Right to Life Committee. As a result, some thought abortion was fizzling this year as an issue. But strategists for abortion-rights campaigns say there will be a flurry of last-minute advertising pushing the abortion issue. In some races it's already begun. Sometimes the push will be on television. But in other cases it will be more selectively targeted toward young women voters through direct-mail or telephone. ``People are thinking this is a dead issue. I think that's just a fundamental misunderstanding of this issue,'' said Celinda Lake, who has conducted polling for abortion-rights candidates around the country. ``It's a last-minute issue,'' she said. ``It's something you lay out in the last weeks of a campaign.'' Abortion-rights strategists say their target audience, younger voters, typically does not pay attention to campaigns until the final stages. Lake says polling shows that increasing economic worries and lack of trust of Democrats on the economy has caused a drop-off in support for Democrats among younger women, she said. Abortion may lure them back. ``It's a big drop off - 10 points,'' she said. ``Because of that you'll see more pro-choice direct-mail geared toward that audience at the end.'' In North Carolina's Senate race, both anti-abortion Sen. Jesse Helms and his Democratic challenger, Harvey Gantt, have been airing ads on the issue. But in most states, it's the abortion-rights candidates who have been using the issue in television ads. In Oregon, Democrat Harry Lonsdale has drawn even in his challenge to GOP Sen. Mark Hatfield, according to recent polls, after airing ads that attack Hatfield's opposition to abortion among other issues. One race where abortion hasn't been the factor that was expected is in Florida, where former Sen. Lawton Chiles is challenging GOP Gov. Robert Martinez, who opposes abortion. Chiles, who supports abortion rights, has found the issue uncomfortable for him and isn't airing ads despite Martinez' seeming vulnerability on the issue. The issue is important in Iowa's Senate race, where Democratic incumbent Tom Harkin has a double-digit lead over anti-abortion challenger Rep. Tom Tauke, according to recent polls. Harkin has been the abortion-rights point-man in the Senate, and he led the fight last week to oppose an amendment requiring teen-age girls to notify their parents before getting an abortion. Parental consent on abortion tends to gain strong support in most polls, but Harkin said the overall abortion issue helps him. ``The last thing my opponent wants to talk about is the choice issue,'' Harkin said. ``I'm watching my tracking polls ... and the number of people viewing his position as extreme is going like this,'' he added, pointing upward. The Senate adopted the parental consent provision on a 48-48 vote, but the amendment was expected to be deleted in later congressional action. Harkin's side was surprised it drew 48 votes. That vote has become an issue in California, where both candidates for governor are trying to appeal to abortion-rights supporters. Democratic candidate Dianne Feinstein blasted her GOP rival, Sen. Pete Wilson, for missing the vote while campaigning. Abortion opponents have the upper hand in several races. In Kansas, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Joan Finney has had difficulty explaining her anti-abortion position recently. But she still leads GOP Gov. Mike Hayden, an abortion-rights supporter, in the polls. Anti-abortion Republican George Voinovich has the lead in Ohio's governor race, where Democrat Anthony Celebrezze has been criticized for a startling flip-flop in which he dropped his long-standing opposition to abortion. A September poll by the University of Cincinnati found that the issue was helping Voinovich more than Celebrezze. Voinovich led among the 13 percent of respondents who said abortion was the single most important issue. In Iowa's governor's race, Democrat Avenson is running abortion-rights ads but has yet to catch up with anti-abortion GOP incumbent Terry Branstad. Abortion opponents in Idaho were angered by Gov. Cecil Andrus' veto of a restrictive abortion bill this year, but he is in strong shape in his re-election bid. It's become more of an issue in Idaho's Senate and House races, however. Idaho Republican Senate candidate Larry Craig surprised his anti-abortion supporters when he was asked in a debate what he would do if his wife became pregnant as a result of rape. He responded that it was her decision, which seemed at odds with his opposition to legal abortions. Democrat Ron Twilegar jumped on the response, saying he wanted all women to have that choice but Craig seemed to want it only for his wife. Craig says he was misinterpreted and hasn't strayed from his opposition to abortion. Abortion also is an issue in about a dozen congressional races. In northern Virginia, for example, Democrat James Moran is airing abortion-rights ads against GOP Rep. Stan Parris. Democrats see the issue helping Moran, the Alexandria mayor, since the district was won by Gov. Doug Wilder in an important abortion test last year.

DOC.HEAD: Post-Communist Irony: New Mayor Is Son of Old Lord ^With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the late 1940s, the Communist authorities chased Jan Zamoyski from the highlands of southern Poland, where his aristocratic family had ruled for nearly four centuries. Forty-five years later, another Zamoyski is in charge of Zamosc - invited back by townspeople who elected him mayor in the first democratic vote in decades. It is one of the many ironies in post-Communist Poland, a nation at once rushing forward and stepping backward. Jan Zamoyski's son, Marcin, walks the Renaissance cobblestones of Zamosc, greeted by the slight bows of a respectful populace and kissing hands in the genteel style of Old Poland. He is the first to say his name will get him only so far in today's Polish Republic, however, and that much must be done to repair ``respect for values, the main thing lost during those 45 years.'' The Communists nationalized private land and factories. Like all the vilified gentry, Jan Zamoyski lost everything and was barred from living within 30 miles of his former estates. That law remains on the books, but Parliament is working out ways to return confiscated property and businesses to former owners. As Poland plunges toward capitalism, it is welcoming back the exiled nobility and, in other ways, resurrecting the social fabric of a prouder past. When given a chance to vote, the people of Zamosc turned to the son of a man the Communists called one of the ``reactionary relics of feudalism.'' ``There is no doubt that my name decided it,'' Marcin Zamoyski said. ``Maybe they imagined that I would do here as much as my father used to.'' Zamoyski, born in 1947, was working in Warsaw as a cameraman for German television. He had little connection with Zamosc, and none with his family's prewar world of prestige, wealth and public responsibility. His father, nearing 80, turned down an invitation from Zamosc to run in the parliamentary elections of June 1989. When Marcin was asked to be a candidate for mayor, the son thought it was ``a nice joke.'' Marcin Zamoyski was persuaded to run by the ``great joy'' of the people he met in Zamosc, a provincial capital three hours' drive southeast of Warsaw. ``They thought I was the one who would assure them what they imagined the authorities should be: good and just,'' he said. His father hugged and kissed him, the son said, ``and it was only then that I understood how happy he was.'' It was in 1571 that his father's namesake, the secretary to King Zygmunt August, inherited ``three and a half villages,'' as the history books say, and began planning his ideal city. That Jan Zamoyski, educated in Paris and Padua, brought the vision of the Renaissance to Zamosc, building a university and library in a city underpinned by a geometric street plan and a sophisticated sewer system. Many ethnic groups settled in the city, each contributing its skills and trades. Zamosc became self-sufficient, a city-state that grew in prestige as its founder became Poland's chancellor and military chief. The Zamoyski family remained among Poland's most powerful, and the Zamosc properties were handed down through the generations. At the outbreak of World War II, Jan Zamoyski was the ``ordinat,'' or lord, controlling farmland and numerous industries in the region. In 1939, the Soviet army invaded Poland from the east. In three days, the soldiers carted off everything of value from the family palace at Klemensow, outside Zamosc. The family mansion in Warsaw was burned the same year. After the war, according to a recent magazine article, ``the time of `social justice' came. The Zamoyski name could be written only on graves.'' Jan Zamoyski and his wife fled to Krakow, where he was arrested by security forces as the Communists consolidated power. They moved to the Baltic Coast after his release. He was arrested again because his background made him suspect, and imprisoned from 1948 until 1956. The first return to Zamosc, in 1958, was painful for the elder Zamoyski, who was berated in the newspapers and tailed by security agents, but Marcin, then 11, remembers a warm reception by townspeople. Zamoyski's father stopped returning to Zamosc and the son came back rarely, ``mostly for funerals.'' Marcin Zamoyski's family lives in Warsaw and he stays with a friend in Zamosc, where housing is scarce. The Communists turned the family palace into a psychiatric hospital. Zamosc, like most Polish cities, is nearly broke because huge subsidies from the national treasury have ended. The once-admired sewer system is collapsing and there is no money to restore the fine architecture, which Zamoyski believes could be a valuable tourist attraction. ``It is not so easy to incite people to work,'' he said, in a voice tinged with frustration. ``I'm telling them they should start this work within themselves. . . . They should treat this town as something that is theirs. ``The people came up with the idea that I was the one,'' he said. ``Now it is hard work and nothing else.'' Residents of Zamosc appear charmed by their new mayor. ``Maybe I am romantic - I like history - but he is from a very good family that contributed a lot to Poland,'' said Marek Rzezniak, an artist. Rzezniak said the family name ``is money in the bank for him. . . . The future will tell whether he fulfills the requirements.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Cracks Down on Central Americans Trying To Flee North
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The government is getting tougher on Central Americans who migrate through its territory in hopes of trading poverty, war and repression at home for jobs in the United States. U.S. officials welcome the new policy in Mexico, which is forging closer economic ties with its powerful northern neighbor, but some Mexicans fear their government will turn next on its own citizens who sneak across the border. Smugglers and thieves prey on the Central Americans, most of whom are from El Salvador and Guatemala. Crooked immigration officials take their money and honest ones deport them, but still they come by the thousands. ``They know there is a risk. But it's nothing compared to the risks they run in their own countries,'' said Jose Luis Perez Canchola of the Center for Migrant Investigations and Studies in Tijuana. The number of Central Americans deported from Mexico has increased from 14,000 in 1988 to 80,000 in the first six months of 1990, which makes the long, dangerous trip north even more difficult. ``Mexico is not the easy springboard it once was into the United States,'' said Duke Austin of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. Between 300,000 and 400,000 Central Americans are estimated to be in Mexico at any one time, often working at menial jobs for money to complete the journey. For many, the departure point is Tecun Uman, Guatemala, just across the border from Tapachula in Chiapas, Mexico's southernmost state. In the town square of Tecun Uman, the migrants meet the ``coyotes'' (coyotes) who smuggle human beings. It is a place to change your money, your identity, maybe your luck. Sabino Gonzalez is a part-time preacher and full-time money changer who haunts the square, calculator in one hand and a fistful of cash in the other. He also is a go-between for the smugglers and their customers. ``This guy is good, one of the best,'' he said, introducing a coyote who gave his name as Jose Manuel Sanchez. Sanchez named his price: $1,000 from Tecun Uman to Tijuana, a journey of nearly 2,000 miles from the Suchiate River on Mexico's southern border and the Rio Grande on the north. ``You won't even get your feet wet,'' Sanchez assured a prospective client. The price includes bribes, hotels used by the coyote network and transportation by raft, taxi, bus, train and private car, he said. At dawn, on the river bank, the journey began. Why not cross at night? the client asked. ``Thieves,'' Sanchez replied. ``They will rob you, and maybe worse.'' Some people attribute the increase in the number of Central Americans apprehended to attempts by the 2-year-old administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to clean up a corrupt immigration service. Sergio Melendez, director of a 220-bed Roman Catholic Church shelter in Tijuana, is not among them. ``Those without money are the ones who are deported,'' he said. ``There is still corruption. We think about two out of five make it across.'' At the northern end of the pipeline, two Salvadoran and three Guatemalan women shared a cramped cell in the Tijuana city jail. They made it across both rivers, only to be caught by the U.S. Border Patrol near San Ysidro, Calif. Because they claimed to be Mexicans, they were deported to Tijuana, where unscrupulous Mexican immigration officers put them in touch with a coyote. Each paid $800 to cross again, but were caught and deported a second time. They have been in jail since Aug. 8, held as witnesses against the coyote and as illegal immigrants. They have no idea when the case will be heard. Judith Martinez Salmeron, 39, left three children with their grandmother in El Salvador to seek work in the United States. The journey cost everything the family could scrape together. ``I can't work,'' she said through the grating that separated her from a visitor. ``I am worried about my children.'' She looked down at her hands. ``I don't know what is going to happen to us.'' Mexico's 560-mile southern border with Guatemala is even more hostile to Central Americans than its northern frontier. The regional head of immigration in Tapachula, Baltazar Mejia, said 50,000 illegal immigrants had been deported from the area in nine months. ``It's a whole lot easier to hold the line'' there, and the south ``is out of the limelight,'' Bill Freylick of the U.S. Committee for Refugees in Washington said during a recent trip to Mexico and Central America. The crackdown has had a chilling effect on those who give sanctuary to the Central Americans. A church hostel in Tapachula, the only shelter in the south, closed recently. The director, Miguel Dominguez, said he feared a new law providing prison terms of two to 10 years for those who help illegal migrants. U.S. immigration agents have increased their intelligence activities in the south. ``Virtually all the information they are gathering, they are sharing with their Mexican counterparts,'' said a U.S. official familiar with immigration matters. Closer cooperation between U.S. and Mexican officials, which began last year, was an early sign that Mexico's tolerant attitude toward Central American migrants had changed. ``This is part of the price the United States is demanding for a free-trade agreement,'' said Monsignor Samuel Ruiz, the Catholic bishop of San Cristobal de las Casas in Chiapas. Freylick agreed: ``The U.S. pressure doesn't even have to be explicit. If Mexico wants a free-trade agreement, it has to seem simpatico.'' U.S. officials deny pressuring President Salinas to stem the flow of Central Americans. ``There is no substance to that at all,'' one said. ``Salinas has ordered this for the good of his own country.'' Immigration issues, particularly the flow of Central Americans, have been high on the two nations' agenda and they have established a high-level working group. ``We are asking Mexico to pay attention to the problem, but it is not a high-pressure situation,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mexico did not stop its own people from crossing the border until recently. Last year, Mexican police and U.S. Border Patrol agents carried out a joint operation at Tijuana-San Ysidro in which 500 people were arrested, most of them Mexicans. The Mexican government responded to the outcry by saying the objective was to protect the migrants from drug dealers and thieves.

DOC.HEAD: Western Artists' Organization Celebrates Silver Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: In the eye of the cowboy artist, the American West still rolls unfettered, unsullied and untamed toward a horizon rich with opportunity and bright with adventure. Some critics say the image never reflected reality, but it has turned the annual sale and art show of the Cowboy Artists of America into a happening for investors and collectors from more than 30 states and many foreign countries. The event, which started Friday, is the 25th since four hungry artists met in a tavern in Sedona and drew up plans to market a brand of realistic, action-based art that was scorned in avant-garde areas on both coasts but seemed as natural to them as breathing. They and a few others sold $49,000 worth of paintings and sculpture in 1965; last year's receipts from the offerings of 35 artists totaled more than $1 million. One oil by Howard Terpning of Tucson brought a record $135,000. ``I thought when I first came in contact with their work that it had no real economic value,'' said Sheldon Reich, a University of Arizona specialist in modern American and European art. ``I have since changed my mind. It has a rather broad audience, and the pictures do have rather substantial value.'' Reich said that he nevertheless is no fan of the genre, which association members call western American realism and which he calls representational. ``Yes, they depict the West, but it's a mythical West for the most part. They're not into, for example, revealing any accurate depictions of the American past. It's the West of the imagination. ... From my point of view, it's not much better than John Wayne movies,'' he said. CAA members have heard it all before, along with the jibes that they are illustrators, not artists. In the preface to the 1989 exhibition catalog, then-president William Moyers of Albuquerque, N.M., wrote that there is ``no strict demarcation ... between art and illustration.'' ``The only valid issue is whether our paintings, sculptures and drawings are the best we can produce,'' he added. Terpning, who worked in New York for 25 years as an illustrator for magazines and advertising campaigns, is equally unbowed by criticism. ``I'm sure some abstract artists probably look down their noses at what we do, and representational artists would prefer to look at other representational art,'' he said. ``I know a lot of great art is being done; I've seen some beautiful abstract art, and I say to each his own. I've certainly seen some that I thought was atrocious, but to somebody else it looks great.'' If the cowboy artists are creating art for the masses, the Phoenix show indicates the masses are responding. The event annually draws more than 1,000 customers at $125 per head for the Friday night show and some other events, or $200 for everything else and an awards banquet Saturday night. Each artist is allowed to display up to six works and set a price on each. Few pass up the chance to buy, whether for resale or collection. The bylaws of the invitation-only CAA stipulate that the organization exists ``to perpetuate the memory and culture of the Old West.'' They also require it to sponsor a trail ride and campout each year, in which the real horsemen of the group mingle with tenderfeet. Members such as Terpning and Harvey W. Johnson, another illustrator who had taught for 19 years at the Famous Artists School, form one end of the spectrum of the CAA - those who were born far from the areas they came to love and depict on canvas. At the other end is Bill Owen, a bona fide cowboy who grew up on a ranch near Gila Bend and owns another near Dewey. Yet regardless of origin, they share the feeling of the genre. To paint cowboy art, Owen said, each artist must know his subject intimately. ``You have to have that love for the subject matter before you can paint,'' he said. ``You have to know it inside and out. So many things you see where it's obvious the painter just doesn't know his subject matter. To me, it's like telling a lie.'' Johnson said he was illustrating pulp magazines when he became fascinated with mountain men and Indians, figures who recur again and gain in his work. Now a resident of Santa Fe, N.M., Johnson echoed Owen's feelings about authenticity depending on familiarity, and said his background was helpful in the intensive research he needed to do in the new field. ``Even though the pulps were inexpensive magazines, your things had to be accurate,'' he said. The accuracy required by representational art makes it valuable in preserving Western history, Johnson said. For example, he helped restore the memory of the second fort built at what is now Laramie, Wyo. The original was a stockade-style structure of wood. It was replaced by an adobe fort which had vanished from memory. Johnson said he was able to paint it from rude sketches done by an Army officer who had visited there. ``The other thing is that the landscape hasn't changed very much (in rural areas),'' he said. ``People say the Old West is done. That's baloney. First of all, there's the people. They're the old raw-boned people; you look in the old photographs ... that's the same face. And of course the animals are the same - coyotes, deer, eagles and everything else.''

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, Questions Persist in Stuart Story
DOC.TEXT: When Charles and Carol Stuart were found shot in their car on Oct. 23, 1989, they were depicted as a perfect suburban couple whose lives had been destroyed by a monster from the inner city. A year later, it is clear monsters were unleashed that night, but no one can say which ones or how many. A husband's murderous inclinations? Law enforcement ineptitude? A brother's complicity? Racism? The monsters haunt Boston a year after the shootings. The grand jury investigating the case has yet to issue any indictments. And though the crime was ``solved'' in a television dramatization broadcast nationwide, questions persist that may never be answered. On that night a year ago, Carol Stuart, a tax attorney who was seven months pregnant, was shot in the head in the city's Mission Hill area as she and her husband left a hospital birthing class. Mrs. Stuart, 30, died a few hours after her son, Christopher, was prematurely delivered. The baby died 17 days later. Charles Stuart, who was seriously wounded in the stomach, told police a black man had abducted them in their car, robbed them and shot them. The next morning, headlines delivered his story to the world. Police kicked in doors and randomly searched Mission Hill residents in the hunt for the black assailant, whom they eventually announced they had located. But that man was absolved Jan. 4, when Stuart jumped to his death in the icy waters of Boston Harbor. His death came the day after his younger brother, Matthew, told police he had been enlised by Charles to aid in what he thought was an insurance scam. Police say they had no reason to doubt Stuart, but blacks say the authorities were too quick to pursue a stereotypical suspect in a city racked by racism. ``I don't think the city's learned anything from this,'' Louis Elisa, head of the Boston chapter of the National Association for Advancement of Colored People, said recently. ``The issues are the same: Violence against people of color continues. People still complain they still don't get equal treatment under the law.'' It still is not known exactly how the shootings occurred or who fired the weapon. Though police believe Stuart killed his wife - the conclusion of the television movie - it's possible someone else fired one or both shots. If Stuart did fire the gun, what madness triggered him to kill his wife for the insurance money to start a restaurant, as reports have suggested, when the money was scarcely enough to cover the mortgage on their house? Two men apparently know the secrets of the case: Stuart's brother, Matthew, and his lawyer, John T. Dawley. But laws have shielded both. Stuart apparently told Dawley of his plot to kill his wife the day before he died. Prosecutors want the state's highest court to force Dawley to tell what he knows to the grand jury. But Dawley is protected by attorney-client privilege, and lawyers say it is unlikely the court will force him to testify. Matthew Stuart told police his brother tossed him a package from his car in Mission Hill as part of what he thought was an insurance scam. He allegedly disposed of the .38-caliber pistol used in the shooting, as well as other items he said he believed would later be reported stolen. He also said he did not recognize Mrs. Stuart in his brother's car, mistaking her body for a duffle bag or laundry sack. Matthew Stuart has been protected from arrest and the intense examination that would go with it by a state statute that immunizes blood relatives from prosecution as accessories after the fact. ``It's quite likely he would have been prosecuted as an accessory after the fact were it not for that exemption,'' said Phyllis Goldfarb, a criminal law professor at Boston College who has followed the case. His attorney, Nancy Gertner, said prosecutors were groping for Dawley's testimony because they didn't have much of a case. ``If the investigation is foundering because they can't get Dawley to testify, then they've done a bad job,'' she said. ``If they're waiting on that, then their prosecution is in trouble.'' Paul Leary, first assistant district attorney of Suffolk County, has refused comment on the importance of Dawley's testimony. But he conceded the grand jury probably would not reconvene until the court rules on whether Dawley must testify. ``Even if Stuart's attorney has to disclose what he was told, that may not clear up everything,'' Goldfarb said. ``The chance of finding out the answers to this case died when Charles Stuart did.'' In retrospect, police had at least several reasons to look more closely at Stuart, the 29-year-old manager of a fur store. Husbands always are considered suspects in such cases, and Stuart's failure in his call for help to distinguish any landmarks in a city he knew well seemed odd. He told the police dispatcher that when the shots were fired, he ducked and his wife was hit. But ducking would have little bearing on a bullet fired by an assailant in the back seat. When he viewed a lineup containing William Bennett, the black man police linked to the shootings, he could provide no stronger identification than to say Bennett most resembled the assailant. By then, Staart probably had seen Bennett's photo in Boston newspapers. Stuart's death prompted renewed cries of outrage from black leaders, who contended police ran roughshod over the rights of minorities in their search for a black suspect. ``Police had nothing on Bennett, but still they kicked in his mother's door, tried to cajole his family to give testimony,'' Elisa said. Still, some good has come from the tragedy. A foundation set up by Carol Stuart's family in her name has raised nearly $500,000 and funded 33 scholarships for students in Mission Hill. For her family, the pain of Carol's death has ebbed little in a year. ``It's painful to talk about. We try not to,'' said her brother, Carl DiMaiti. ``I'm surprised that it's already been a year. It's still very hard to think about.'' DiMaiti has taken over the family's pizza dough business from his father, who has retired. ``Dad comes down to the bakery to help,'' he said. ``I'd rather have him here with me than home by himself. The worst thing is for them to sit around the house.''

DOC.HEAD: New Farm Bill Makes Farmers Look Harder at Overseas Markets
DOC.TEXT: The new $40.8 billion farm bill cuts deeply into spending on federal programs, another indication that farmers will be linked even more firmly to overseas markets. Over the next five years, the Agriculture Department will have to trim projected outlays by $13.6 billion as its part in an overall $500 billion federal deficit reduction. The net result is that farmers will be looking less toward Washington for a large part of their incomes and more to Europe, the Soviet Union, Japan, China and scores of other countries that need U.S. commodities. By reducing the amount of land eligible for crop payments each year, the 1990 farm bill cuts costs. It also frees the extra land for use as a farmer chooses by not restricting it to a ``program'' crop base. ``It gives the American farmer a great deal of flexibility and freedom to plant,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee. Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas and the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said, ``You cross your fingers and hope that giving them flexibility will make up for the loss of support.'' The new farm bill is the latest in a long series of moves to bring more market-oriented features into U.S. farm policy and to provide an income safety net for producers. It was the Agriculture and Consumer Protection Act of 1973 that produced a fundamental change in farm programs by initiating the ``target price'' concept. Under it, farmers began to get ``deficiency payments'' or direct subsidies whenever market prices averaged less than the target levels. This introduced federal income supports as a way of life in American agriculture. Officially, the government said it was supporting the incomes of farmers, not simply their commodity prices. The concept survives in the 1990 farm bill - but in a reduced role because of the need to trim federal spending. Market-oriented economies have burst upon the world scene faster than anyone had dared speculate a short time ago, with new systems undergoing development pangs in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. A final push for the integration of the European Community, the 12-nation trading bloc, is set for 1992. Structural adjustments are being made throughout the Third World as nations try to respond to complex and awesome debt problems. These and other factors are being brought to bear on U.S. agriculture and its producers, says the Agriculture Department. Mathew Shane of the department's Economic Research Service says the multilateral talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade also bear watching. The GATT talks, also called the Uruguay Round of discussions, are scheduled to end by Dec. 31. The goal is to liberalize trading rules among the 97 GATT trading partners. Agriculture is but one of 15 trading areas being negotiated. However, it is seen as the key to the talks because Third World countries have balked at agreeing to U.S. proposals on removing barriers to trade in services and strengthening copyright enforcement unless they win expanded markets for their farm products. Last week the United States offered a compromise proposal aimed at breaking a deadlock on the GATT trade reform discussions. The Bush administration said it would seek agreement from the other countries to cut farm export subsidies by 90 percent and trade-distorting domestic supports by 75 percent over the next 10 years. Previously, the United States had sought total elimination of export and other trade-distorting subsidies and policies by the year 2000. The U.S. proposal in Geneva, where the GATT talks are being held, was endorsed by the American Farm Bureau Federation. The National Farmers Union, however, had reservations and still viewed the U.S. position as ``basically anti-family-farm'' in its general thrust. Economist Shane, writing in the October issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, described ``a growing consensus that domestic farm policies have global repercussions.'' ``A market-oriented outcome to the GATT talks would improve the environment in which commodity markets operate,'' he said. ``Competitiveness in these markets would then be related to real comparative advantages of the producing countries.'' Shane said that for farmers to remain major players in world markets, U.S. policies ``must be realigned to reflect the new international realities.'' He added, ``This would not mean giving up the objectives of supporting farm income and providing increased stability for farmers. But redesigning the policies to achieve these objectives without distorting the market signals would improve U.S. export performance and promote efficient use of global resources.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush on Campaign Trail: Filling Those GOP Coffers
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: His poll ratings have slumped, but it doesn't show at the Republican cash register as President Bush seeks money and votes for GOP candidates in a methodical, unmatched off-year election campaign. He's helped raise more campaign money than any president before. By White House count, Bush campaign events have produced about $56.5 million for Republican candidates this year. That compares with about $33 million raised at Ronald Reagan's appearances in the last off-year election campaign. So far, Bush has attended 67 campaign events, with more to come in the final two weeks. An extra push is likely just before the Nov. 6 elections, to help mobilize Republicans and turn out the vote. With the slip in Bush's popularity rating, Democrats have been saying that he's less of an asset, claiming that some Republican candidates are keeping their distance. ``Wishful thinking,'' said a White House official, adding that there has been no letup in the requests for campaign help. That held despite Republican differences about the politically costly stalemate on the swelling federal deficit, which led Bush to jettison his no-new-taxes pledge while Republican challengers for Congress were campaigning on that very theme. He's campaigned for dissenters, including a senator who called his budget settlement a turkey and a Senate challenger who likened the tax provisions to a mugging. Bush skirts their differences by saying that if there were more Republicans in Congress, the deficit and the budget wouldn't be such a mess. At one point, White House Chief of Staff John H. Sununu suggested that Republicans who broke with Bush on the budget might be taking a campaign risk. Sununu said he didn't threaten punishment. ``What I said was, `The president will go into your district and campaign for you. He wants your support on the budget... I hope that you supported him, because if he looks you in the eye and asks you to do it on the campaign, it might be a little embarrassing.' '' Even that hasn't happened. Bush said he is campaigning for broad principles, not item-by-item backing. His campaign effort concentrates on Senate seats and governors, first on defending threatened Republican incumbents, then on boosting promising challengers. The emphasis all along has been on fundraising, and it began early, even before the election year, with GOP appearances the White House said helped raise about $25 million in 1989. The rallies and the speeches are the visible side of the effort, but the vital campaign business is done at the $1,000-and-up receptions, where donors get a presidential greeting, a handshake or a photo. That's the most effective kind of campaign work for a president in an off-year, when he isn't on the ballot. For all his campaigning, Bush has avoided themes that would lend themselves to a reading of the off-year returns as a referendum on his presidency. The appraisal is inevitable, but he's done nothing to encourage it, the way Reagan did in his off-year campaigns. Reagan campaigned intensively in 1986 in an unsuccessful effort to keep Republican control of the Senate. He said he didn't want to be ``a six-year president,'' with programs blocked by a Democratic Senate. He urged voters to support Republican Senate candidates ``if you'd like to vote for me one last time.'' But Republicans lost the Senate that year. The Democrats gained eight seats, to the 55-vote majority they still hold. Bush asks support for Republican candidates and principles, without personalized appeals like Reagan's. Presidents who try that usually find their popularity is not transferable. And even when he topped the GOP ticket, Bush showed no coattails in winning the White House in 1988. So the circumstances fit a start-early strategy concentrated on fundraising, a strong suit for any president. ``The president is raising a lot of money for their candidates,'' said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, but beyond the help that provides, ``it doesn't really affect the politics of a state or a district.'' The chairman of the Democratic Governors Association, Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, said the Bush campaign won't deliver votes. ``It is a cash cow which the Republicans are milking every effectively,'' he said last month. ``It is not a raging bull aimed at Democratic candidates.'' Maybe not, but the Democrats do complain with some frequency that some of their candidates are at a disadvantage because they are being outspent. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Cranberry Growers Battle to Keep Environmental Exemption
DOC.TEXT: For a century, cranberry growers have planted and harvested in the wetlands, exempt from state environmental rules. Now, however, they are seeing red over proposals to change all that. The state Department of Natural Resources claims the exemption led growers to destroy thousands of acres of wetlands and rare wildlife habitat. The growers counter that environmentalists have misled the public about the quality of bogs converted from wetlands. ``I had a flock of a couple hundred geese that fed every day on a cranberry marsh,'' Ryan Walker said, peering over his fields as cranberries were harvested. ``I can't think of one cranberry marsh in Wisconsin that I would be ashamed to take anyone to.'' Cranberries grow on low, trailing, woody perennial vines in beds, usually 2 to 5 acres, which are surrounded by dikes. To harvest the crop each fall, beds are flooded, the bright red berries are gently knocked off the vines, and the fruit floats to the surface. Wisconsin produces 36 percent of the nation's cranberries - second only to Massachusetts. In 1989, Wisconsin produced 130 million pounds of cranberries, valued at $62.3 million. At least in part because consumers are eating more fruits and vegetables, the cranberry business grew in the 1980s, when most other farmers faced financial crises and drought. But environmentalists claim the bogs also have taken their toll: Wetlands teeming with plant life are being destroyed, and natural habitat for wildlife, sponges that prevent flooding and filters that clean water are disappearing. Destruction of wetlands by cranberry growers has increased flooding in some areas, decreased waterfowl production, and deteriorated the quality of water flowing into some lakes, environmentalists claim. ``I think there is a general consensus among the scientific community, the environmental community that we have lost as many wetlands as we can afford,'' said Duane Schuettpelz, a spokesman for the DNR's Bureau of Water Resources Management. A legislative proposal would modify or eliminate the 1867 law exempted cranberry growers from state regulations. A proposal by the DNR would impose new rules to restrict growers' activities in wetlands even if the law is not changed. The Massachusetts cranberry industry lives with regulations that forbid the loss of any more wetlands, said Dave Farrimond, general manager of the Federal Cranberry Marketing Committee, an agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. In fact, he said, the industry there expects to put 1,200 acres into production over the next three years, the bulk of it in uplands. Schuettpelz said new regulations are needed in Wisconsin because the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, which approves applications for expansion of cranberry operations under the Clean Water Act, has been too lax in enforcing wetland protection standards. Wisconsin has 150 growers with about 10,000 acres of mostly wetlands involved in direct production of cranberries, said Tom Lochner, executive director of the growers' association. An additional 100,000 acres - out of 5.3 million acres of wetlands left in the state - is used for small dams, reservoirs, channels and flowages needed for water for cranberry bogs. But it's the growth of the industry - 2,800 acres of new cranberry beds in mostly wetlands over the last 10 years - that sparked the dispute. When cranberry bogs are created from wetlands, the ground is scalped, vines are fertilized and chemically treated for bugs and wildlife and plants disappear, Schuettpelz said. Under current law, the state has no say in any expansion. State Rep. Spencer Black, chairman of the Assembly Natural Resources Committee, has formed a committee of environmentalists, lawmakers and growers to reach a compromise. Black believes the growers have abused their ``special privileges.'' ``I'm not out to hurt the industry and stop all expansion but I think reasonable control will make sure growth of the industry takes places in a positive manner,'' he said. But growers say they'll go to court, if necessary, to maintain the exemption. ``I think people are being misled on the destruction of wetlands,'' said Bob Duckart, president of the Wisconsin State Cranberry Growers Association and a grower with 100 acres of bogs. ``Our feeling is that we are not destroying it, we are preserving it. We feel we are doing a lot of the things the DNR is doing when they create a wildlife preserve,'' he said. Walker said proposed DNR regulations that would force growers to expand by building bogs in uplands, away from water, would cost too much. He also believes growers are not being credited for environmental improvements made in bogs. Wildlife flourishes in some bogs and growers store water with dams, reservoirs and flowages, fulfilling functions of a natural wetland, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Decades of Work Win Nobel for Seattle Doctor
With BC-EXP--Nobel-Murray
DOC.TEXT: Leukemia meant almost certain death when E. Donnall Thomas was in medical school more than 40 years ago. The fascination he developed then sustained him through a four-decade attack on the deadly disease, and he overcame skepticism and sometimes shaky financing to develop an effective treatment. Thomas' lifetime of work resulted in bone-marrow transplantation - a cure for thousands of patients worldwide - and earned him this year's Nobel Prize in medicine, along with Joseph E. Murray. ``Forty years is a long period of time, considering we thought this could be done in the middle 1950s. It's been slow,'' Thomas said, reflecting on his work at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle after being named a Nobel winner Oct. 8. Thomas didn't expect to work solid months at a time and be constantly on call when he chose to go into clinical research. He laughed when he recalled how he decided not to be a general-practice physician after watching his father, the lone doctor in Prairie Hill, Texas, on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week. ``Then my son looked at all the problems I had getting money for research, and now he's doing what my father did,'' Thomas said. Thomas, 70, became intrigued by leukemia and bone marrow transplantation while at Harvard Medical School in the mid-1940s. In leukemia, abnormal white blood cells prevent bone marrow from producing healthy red blood cells. Scientists knew bone marrow produced blood and was vital to the immune system, but did not know what controlled it or sometimes made it fail. In the early 1950s, while at hospitals and research centers in Boston, Thomas was one of several scientists searching for the factor that could stimulate the regeneration of bone marrow cells. It was discovered that transplanted marrow could replace damaged marrow in mice. Thomas extended the work to dogs, and in 1956 he performed the first human transplant at Cooperstown, N.Y. The transplant took, but the patient's leukemia later recurred. That pattern was repeated often. Through the 1960s transplants were performed mainly on twins, whose antigens, or ``cell identifiers,'' matched perfectly. It was in 1965 at the University of Washington that Thomas made a breakthrough that helped prove transplants could be widely applied. He transplanted bone marrow in canine siblings that were not identical but had matching antigens. The dogs survived. In 1968 Thomas assembled in Seattle a team of scientist-physicians from around the country. By the early 1970s he and his researchers were performing dozens of human transplants. Team member Alex Fefer recalled their first paper, which reported results from 100 transplant operations. Only 12 patients survived. ``There were a lot of people on the outside who said, `This is terrible, you shouldn't do it, I wouldn't give it to my dog,' and so on,'' he said. Many people felt that was a bad result, Thomas said. ``But we took just the opposite view, that if we could cure some of those patients with refractory in-stage leukemia we ought to do much better if we took the patients in an earlier stage of the disease.'' The team persevered. Thomas and his wife, Dottie, continued to take on what Fefer described as an enormous work load. Mrs. Thomas has worked with her husband as lab assistant, administrator and grant expert. ``I have met many workaholics in my day, but when I came here he and Dottie worked literally every single day,'' Fefer said. Joleen Kellehere, director of nursing at the Hutchinson Center, said: ``She struggled along with him, and when there were things to be done, she did them. She continues to this day to do it. It's an incredible relationship,'' Today, thousands of patients with leukemia and types of anemia have been treated by transplantation, and many have fully recovered. Survival rates for some forms of leukemia are as high as 90 percent, Thomas said. The 60-bed Hutchinson Centerperformed about 430 transplants in the last year. Ground-breaking is scheduled soon for a new site that will add 40 beds. Thomas' original handful of researchers has grown to a team of more than 50. It was the combined research talents of the team that made bone-marrow transplants possible, Thomas said. Thomas said government grants are getting harder to obtain, and the center has been forced to develop private financing sources. But he and his wife have no plans to quit. ``The work is so fascinating that we don't want to leave it,'' he said. ``There are so many new developments that offer solutions to some of the problems we have. We're looking at applying this kind of technology to other kinds of cancer and genetic diseases. It's an exciting time.''

DOC.HEAD: Boston Nobel Winner an Eternal Optimist
DOC.TEXT: In the early days of kidney transplants the Murray children weren't allowed to gab on the telephone for more than a few minutes at a time. Keeping the lines open for possible organ donors was frustrating for the houseful of teen-agers, but they knew it had to be important. It was. Their father, Joseph Murray, won this year's Nobel Prize for Medicine, along with E. Donnall Thomas of Seattle. The award announced Oct. 8 recognizes Murray's pioneering work in kidney transplants. The 71-year-old surgeon performed the world's first successful organ transplant - a kidney from one identical twin to another - at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital on Dec. 23, 1954. The household telephone regulations, explained his eldest daughter, illustrated Murray's lifelong commitment to two groups: his family and his patients. ``Our father was good about letting us know what he was doing and the courage of the patients,'' said Virginia Murray Boyle, who now lives down the street from her parents in Wellesley. ``He tried to make us appreciate the simple things in life.'' In fact, as Murray performed that first successful operation on Ronald and Richard Herrick, his family was gathered in prayer at home. ``My mother called us in to say a prayer for the courageous and new type of operation,'' Boyle said. ``Many people didn't think he should be doing it, but my mother said he was doing his best.'' At age 5, his second child, Meg Murray Dupont, hardly understood the significance. ``All I knew was my father wasn't around much that Christmas,'' she said from her home in California. ``We knew he was trying to make kidneys work, but we had no idea it would lead to livers and hearts and lungs.'' At times, Murray said it was more difficult convincing doctors of the promise of organ transplants than the public. ``They thought I was just pursuing pie in the sky,'' he said. Today, however, the significance is recognized. ``It was more than just a technical feat,'' said W. Hardy Hendren, chief of surgery at Children's Hospital. ``What Dr. Murray did was truly a shot heard 'round the world - once again from Massachusetts.'' His colleagues describe Murray as a determined, soft-spoken, eternal optimist. Nicholas Tilney, director of transplant services at the Brigham and Women's Hospital who was a resident when it was called the Peter Bent hospital, described Murray as a teacher and mentor. ``I learned mostly by his example, one-on-one'' Tilney said. ``I recall one time a patient of his died in the middle of the night and he took the trouble to come and talk to the family. Normally, residents would do that kind of thing.'' When one of Murray's kidney patients gave birth to her first baby, Murray was in the delivery room. Some patients have kept in touch with Murray for decades. Born in Milford in 1919, Murray attended Holy Cross College in Worcester and Harvard Medical School. He was an intern at the Peter Bent hospital before serving in the Army. His early work treating soldiers became a common thread throughout his medical career. ``Soldiers often died because they had no skin of their own to be grafted to the burned areas,'' Murray said in a medical journal in 1985. ``And therein lay the challenge; if only we could transplant skin from other persons to the burn victims, these soldiers might live.'' Skin grafting was impossible at the time because scientists hadn't discovered a way to counteract the body's inclination to reject someone else's skin. But Murray sensed that kidneys would be easier to transplant because they have larger blood vessels to connect. From his early successes, Murray went on to perform the first kidney transplant from a brain dead person and founded the International Kidney Transplant Registry. After 20 years in the transplant field, Murray returned to his first love: plastic surgery. He made a name for himself as a leading physician in reconstructing facial deformities, particularly in children. In 1983, the Nova television series featured Murray in its documentary called ``A Normal Face.'' Although a perfectionist devoted to medicine, friends and family said Murray has always found time for them and a variety of interests. Every year he took July off to spend with his wife, Virginia, and their six children, often camping out of their Country Squire station wagon, recalled Dupont. He climbed the Matterhorn for his 50th birthday and has trekked through the Himalayas with his wife several times. Even a stroke at 67 did not hinder the energetic Murray. When his friend Tilney visited him in the hospital a few days later, Murray was already at work on an article to inform doctors what it's like to be a patient.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbits Increasing to Plague Numbers - Again
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Austin got an award 130 years ago when he started raising rabbits for hunting in Australia. Today he might get a swift kick. Richard Downward, a senior adviser at South Australia state's Animal and Plant Control Commission, calls rabbits ``the most serious environmental pest we have today in temperate Australia,'' an area that encompasses the southern two-thirds of the country. Officials conservatively estimate rabbits cost the wool and cattle industries $79 million annually, not counting environmental damage. ``The cost is not just in lost agricultural production,'' said Ivan Nolan, who has spent 25 years at the Keith Turnbull Research Institute in Victoria state working to develop weapons against rabbits. ``Rabbits cause or contribute to oil erosion, increasing salinity, loss of top soil, poor water quality, silting of streams and dams, and the destruction of trees, as well as wildlife.'' John Burley, another Animal and Plant Control Commission adviser, said, ``They are a very efficient grazing animal and can destroy the quality of a pasture quickly.'' Many scientists believe it will be impossible to eradicate rabbits. But researchers like Nolan fervently hope that's not the case. He estimates his state alone has 25 million rabbits and 28 million sheep. Since eight rabbits eat as much as one sheep, Nolan figures the sheep population could be boosted by 2 million to 3 million if rabbits were wiped out. The first rabbits arrived in Australia in 1788 from Europe. But it wasn't until 1859, when Austin introduced them to the savannah woodland of Victoria state for game, that they found ideal surroundings and started to multiply in earnest. At first, trappers found the fur business lucrative. Then farmers began complaining about ravaged pastures. They built great walls of chicken wire, poisoned rabbits and fumigated their burrows. In the peak post-World War II years, hunters and trappers caught 100 million rabbits a year and produced up to 15.4 million pounds of rabbit skins for export annually. The problem was that even if 80 percent of the rabbits were killed in one area, the survivors could multiply fast enough to recover their numbers in a year. In theory, one pair could produce 2,000 descendants in 12 months. The first breakthrough came when myxomatosis was successfully introduced in 1950, initially killing 99.9 percent of the rabbits infected with the mosquito-spread virus. Within three years, the increase in annual wool production was estimated at 66 million pounds. But rabbits began developing greater resistance to the disease, which also was mutating into less-deadly strains, and the 1960s brought a new plague of bunnies. Scientists then introduced the European flea, which was more efficient than mosquitoes in transmitting the most virulent forms of myxomatosis. But the fleas were not effective in the arid outback, and the rabbits continued developing stronger resistance. As many as 75 percent living in moist areas now survive the disease. Still, the Animal and Plant Control Commission recently received approval to bring in the Spanish flea, which will be able to spread myxomatosis to rabbits in the outback, where resistance to the disease remains low. Scientists hope to begin releasing them by early 1992. Research also is continuing into viral hemorrhagic tracheopneumonia, known as VHD, an epidemic of which decimated Europe's domestic rabbit population last year. ``We don't know its origin or how specific to the rabbit it is,'' said Greg Mutze, research officer at the Animal and Plant Control Commission. In the meantime, farmers are once again digging up rabbit warrens, sometimes planting explosives, using poison gases, and leaving out carrots laced with poison.

DOC.HEAD: Motivation Makes Regular Exercisers Different
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version on sports wires as BC-Lifestyle Sports.
DOC.TEXT: Regular exercise is more than a state of activity - it's a state of mind. People who can stick with exercise apparently can focus how they feel and what they want, says one expert. ``People who come in for the first time need to be informed about the kind of experiences they are going through,'' said Lise Gauvin, an assistant professor in exercise science at Concordia University in Montreal. Her study of motivation was published in the Canadian Journal of Sport Sciences. Gauvin and her colleagues studied 78 people at a YMCA. Some exercised alone and others in a class. Still others were taking language or art classes. The report classed them as autonomous exercisers, fitness program enrollees, dropouts and non-exercisers. Researchers conducted interviews to draw out motivations and perceptions. The report concedes this does not generate standardized answers. Autonomous exercisers and fitness program enrollees highly valued fitness and looks. But the dropouts and sedentary individuals didn't seem to have well-focused goals. Some reported liking fun and competition. But the report said, ``Answers were so diverse that other categorizations were virtually impossible.'' Autonomous exercisers also tended not to be concerned with motivating themselves to exercise - they already had made it a habit. The researchers found similar force of habit among the fitness class enrollees. Dropouts, however, had planned extensively before they exercised, and made sure their other jobs had been done beforehand. Regular exercisers generally liked the activity itself, the researchers said, but dropouts and non-exercisers tended not to. Dropouts tended to value the social interaction or competition, while non-exercisers liked fresh air and sunshine. The report also says regular exercisers perceived their level of intensity at 75 percent to 80 percent - a good workout. Recent fitness enrollees gave estimates of 85 percent to 90 percent; dropouts claimed 95 percent to 100 percent. And the reaction to exercise was different. The self-motivated autonomous exercisers reported feeling energized afterward. Some of the fitness program enrollees reported being tired. And the dropouts tended to feel glad it was over. This might be a sign that those new to exercise or those who never developed a taste for it have not had a proper introduction to the stress of exercise, and are confusing exertion with pain, Gauvin said. Instruction in how to gear themselves mentally might help them become regular exercisers, she said. That approach also is favored by another researcher, Rod K. Dishman, an associate professor in the physical education department at the University of Georgia in Athens. ``Removing the barriers is as or more effective than increasing the motivation,'' he said. And, he said, barriers - such as scheduling and family obligations - are best addressed individually.

DOC.HEAD: With BC-EXP--Right Bites-Fish, b0995
Tips for Buying Fish
DOC.TEXT: Here are some tips to help make sure the fish you buy is safe and fresh: - Buy from a reputable, popular dealer to be assured of good turnover of stock. - Buy fish that is well-chilled, on ice at about 33 degrees. - The eyes of whole fish should be bulging and bright and shiny, not watery. - Skin should be moist, scales shiny. Gills should be red or pink. - The flesh should be firm to the touch. Filets should be firm and glistening. - Fish that smells ``fishy'' probably has gone bad. Fresh fish smells mild. - Eat the fish within 24 hours. Do not freeze fish unless you are absolutely certain it has not been previously frozen. - Shellfish should be alive and lively. In her new book, ``Fish: The Basics,'' Shirley King suggests shoppers go to the market willing to buy whatever fish is freshest. ``The depressing fact is that most of our fish reach us after many days out of water, but if fish are properly handled they can still be excellent,'' she writes.

DOC.HEAD: New Drug Eases Side Effects for Colitis Sufferers
DOC.TEXT: A new drug can ease the headaches, nausea and temporary infertility that afflict about 40 percent of the 1 million Americans with ulcerative colitis, doctors say. Those side effects are the result of the sulfa drug sulfasalazine, the standard treatment for ulcerative colitis. The new drug, olsalazine, is equally effective against colitis but is not a sulfa drug. That means it doesn't have the side effects of sulfasalazine, said Dr. Stephan Targan of the University of California Los Angeles. He is scientific adviser to the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis. Ulcerative colitis, a severe inflammation of the colon, is characterized by diarrhea, rectal bleeding, weight loss and pain. It can occur at any age but often strikes people in their 20s. The new treatment also has side effects, but they are milder than the side effects of sulfasalazine, doctors say. Olsalazine's side effects include abdominal pain and diarrhea in a small number of patients, researchers say. Olsalazine wa recently approved for commercial use by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. ---
DOC.HEAD: Purdue Developing Self-Supporting Space Colonies
DOC.TEXT: Purdue University scientists are trying to create an enclosed system that relies on four crops to provide oxygen, water and food. They are working under a $5 million grant from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which hopes to have small, self-supporting colonies of astronauts living on the moon by 2010 and on Mars by 2020. Cary Mitchell, a plant physiology professor and director of the research, said the work initially will focus on three plants that will comprise a complete diet for the astronauts: cowpeas, a relative of black-eyed peas; brassica, a mustard-like plant; and two strains of rice. The hydroponic crops also would give the astronauts oxygen, Mitchell said. The astronauts shouldn't expect gourmet cuisine, he said. ``The species that were chosen are just the bare minimum that will give a balance of protein and carbohydrates and fat. That doesn't mean the diet will be interesting,'' he said. A fourth crop, blue-green algae, will help produce oxygen and consume carbon dioxide. Unlike the bubble colonies of science fiction, astronauts and plants on the moon would live underground to protect them from the sun. Its damaging rays would be unshielded because the moon has no atmosphere. ``On Mars it's a different story. It would be interesting to use some natural sunlight there,'' Mitchell said.
