DOC.HEAD: Eating Fish a Growing Fancy in United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `In 1943...' to CORRECT total pounds for U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Unlike programs for meat and poultry, there is no mandatory inspection of the fish eaten in this country, so as Americans eat more fish, they should be aware of how to buy and prepare it safely. The U.S. Senate last month passed legislation that would charge the Agriculture Department with inspecting fish. Action was pending in the House. The legislation, called the Fish Safety Act, is based on a program in which the USDA already tests meat products for 200 harmful chemicals and other substances. The Food and Drug Administration and the Commerce Department conduct voluntary fish inspections, but less than 12 percent of U.S. seafood is inspected, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., says. Inspection is ``random, it's not enforced,'' said Jodie Silverman of the Washington-based public interest group Public Voice for Food and Health Policy. In his book, ``Diet for a Poisoned Planet,'' David Steinman says he found more than 2,000 advisory warnings against eating certain fish have been issued over the years by coastal and Great Lakes states. In addition to naturally occurring bacteria or parasites, water can be polluted by industrial and sewage discharge or by blooms of poisonous algae known as red or brown tide. Consumers should check for environmental warnings before going fishing, eat a variety of fish species, and avoid the viscera, skin and fatty sections of a fish. ``If you and others like you buy seafood from retailers who post the origin of their seafood, other retailers will follow suit,'' Steinman says. ``Remember, the way you spend your food dollars has an effect on retailers and ultimately on the environment.'' Americans are eating more fish each year because of health concerns and increased availability, but still lag behind many countries, says Roddy Moscoso, a spokesman for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration-Fisheries. Last year, Americans ate an average of 40.8 pounds of whole fish, or 15.9 pounds of edible fish, compared with 7.9 pounds of edible fish in 1943. But the average over the last four years was 152.8 pounds of whole fish in Japan, 46.3 pounds in Denmark, and 56.9 pounds in France. By comparison, Americans are expected to eat 64 pounds of beef apiece in 1990, down from 77 to 78 pounds in the early 1980s, according to the National Cattlemen's Association. Fish generally are low in calories and are a good source of protein. They contain a range of vitamins and minerals, and their omega 3 fatty acids have been linked to a lowered risk of heart disease. On the low end of fat content is Atlantic cod, which has 82 calories in a 3.5-ounce portion, about six of them from fat, according to the book ``Eat Fish, Live Longer'' by Anne M. Fletcher. At the other end is Pacific herring, 195 calories in 3.5 ounces, 125 of them from fat, and black or red caviar, with 252 calories in 3.5 ounces, 161 of them from fat, Fletcher says. The tastes of different kinds of fish vary as much, chef Shirley King says in her new book, ``Fish: The Basics.'' The book provides drawings, nutritional information, common and scientific names, cleaning and cooking instructions, and recipes for dozens of kinds of fish. ``Fish taste best when simply prepared - broiled, grilled, roasted, or baked in the oven, poached or steamed,'' King writes. Cooking fish to an internal temperature of 140 degrees will destroy parasites, she says. ``When you eat any type of meat, poultry, fish or shellfish that's not thoroughly cooked, there's always the possibility of contracting certain types of food poisoning,'' Fletcher writes, adding that the exact risks remain uncertain. Steinman says, ``By far the greatest immediate toxic risk in eating seafood lies in raw shellfish.'' The FDA has determined that the risk from raw oysters, clams and mussels from water considered clean is too small to warrant a warning. However, it recommends susceptible people, such as those with cancer, liver disease or chronic gastrointestinal illnesses, avoid them. Steinman warns that some toxic chemicals that are fat-soluble will leach out of fish during cooking. Those liquids should be discarded, he says.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 22

DOC.TEXT: Housing starts skidded 0.6 percent in September, continuing an eight-month slide that has become the longest decline on record. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that starts of new homes and apartments fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.14 million units on top of a 1 percent drop in August. Analysts said they foresee no improvement before next year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Industrial production rose 0.2 percent in September, with a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masking an underlying manufacturing weakness. Excluding autos, production dropped 0.1 percent, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday. At the same time, the Fed revised output figures for July and August to show the industrial economy stronger than first reported last summer. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Warren H. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of Dow Jones & Co. Inc., announced he would relinquish his chief executive duties on Jan. 1 and retire as chairman next July 1. Phillips, 64, has been chief executive of the media and financial information company since 1975 and chairman since 1978. He will be 65 by the time of his retirement as chairman. Dow Jones said Phillips' decision, announced Wednesday, was based on the customary retirement age of 65 and was not connected with recent financial troubles at the company. --- DETROIT (AP) - The nation's Big Three automakers are expected to report drastically lower third-quarter earnings, walloped by a slowing economy, foreign competition and rising fuel costs, industry analysts say. Chrysler Corp. likely will report an especially hard quarter, more than wiping out the profits it made in the first six months of the year, analysts said Wednesday. Their financial statements are to be released at the end of the month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Three auto consumer groups asked Americans to refuse to buy any car not equipped with air bags and chastised some Japanese automakers for lagging behind Western counterparts in installing the crash-protection devices. Motor Voters, the Center for Auto Safety and the U.S. Public Interest Research Group staged news conferences and demonstrations Wednesday in 12 cities to propose the boycott. --- FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) - The parent of American Airlines Inc. reported lower third-quarter earnings, blaming higher fuel prices for the 52 percent drop. AMR Corp. is the first of the major domestic airline companies to report third-quarter earnings amid predictions of a coming $1 billion loss in the last three months of the year. AMR said Wednesday it earned $65.6 million, or $1.05 per share, down from 1989's $137 million, or $2.15 per share. Revenue increased from $2.73 billion last year to $3.05 billion this year. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A federal judge ruled that witnesses testifying at Michael Milken's pre-sentencing hearing could publicly name parties connected to but not charged with wrongdoing. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood on Wednesday refused a request by attorneys for eight individuals or companies the government has linked to Milken to have witnesses to use code names while on the stand to protect their clients' privacy rights. Wood is presiding over the hearing on government charges against the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond financier. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A second Eastern Airlines foreman at Kennedy Airport has pleaded guilty to falsifying aircraft safety and maintenance records and has agreed to cooperate with authorities, according to court records. Michael Hennessey, Eastern's general foreman at the airport, admitted to conspiring with other airline employees to falsify log books, work cards and computer records in a scheme that allegedly allowed unsafe aircraft to carry passengers. He was not charged in a 60-count criminal indictment that was unsealed in July and accuses the airline and several top managers of routinely ignoring vital repairs. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Congressional negotiators reached a tentative accord on controlling emissions of toxic industrial chemicals, leaving them only one big step away from agreement on a costly new clean air law. The agreement Wednesday represents the first time the government would require businesses to make dramatic reductions in the more than 2.4 billion pounds of 189 hazardous chemicals. Still on the table was the question of how to deal with acid rain. ---

The stock market showed little change Wednesday, bogged down near its lowest levels in a year and a half. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 6.68 to 2,387.87. The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen. Bond prices were little changed. Orange juice futures prices dropped to new four-year lows; petroleum prices fell sharply; precious metals rose; grains and soybeans were higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait: Financial Engines Still Humming Despite Iraqi Conquest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait has a bustling economy, a loyal population, a functioning government - but no territory. The emirate's government-in-exile is using Kuwait's huge global financial resources to keep its national identity alive despite the Aug. 2 takeover by Iraq. But how long can Kuwait - with its dispersed population and scattered assets - continue to function financially as a sovereign nation? Indefinitely, according to some Middle East analysts. The oil revenues that made Kuwait so rich have dried up with the oilfields in Iraqi hands. And there is a worldwide embargo on the oil itself. But long before the invasion, the Kuwaitis had plowed their oil earnings into a variety of investments, which are now serving them well. ``They're earning money on their money,'' said Katya Maddison, an economic analyst with the London-based Middle East Economic Digest. ``They're pretty stable for a considerable amount of time.'' After the invasion, an asset freeze was clamped on Kuwaiti holdings by world governments to protect the assets from Iraqi seizure. But within three weeks after the invasion, Kuwait's finance minister, Sheik Ali Said, said the government-in-exile had ``plenty of cash'' and was in full management control of its assets. ``The Kuwaitis have virtually an economy offshore now,'' said Stephanie Cooke, a financial specialist in the London office of Institutional Investor magazine. ``But in another sense their hands are tied because they're having to cope with this assets freeze. Although they appreciate it, it's making the day-to-day operations very difficult. ``Every time they have to move assets around, they need the permission of several governments in terms of where the (financial) instrument is,'' she said. Iraq has looted and ravaged Kuwait itself since the invasion. But many of Kuwait's most valuable properties are beyond Iraqi reach. Kuwait Airways, which lost most of its planes to Iraq, planned to restart its operations Thursday from Cairo. The Kuwait Petroleum Co.'s Q8 service stations are still pumping gas in Western Europe. The Kuwait Investment Office in London is gradually regaining control of its monumental portfolio, estimated to total $100 billion, and the Kuwaiti government has pledged to stand behind the obligations of Kuwaiti banks. ``The very fact that they're able to operate Kuwait Air and Kuwait Petroleum Co. continues the country's identity,'' said Maddison. ``The very fact that the name Kuwait is still there, I'm sure, is a major irritant to the Iraqis.'' Unlike other conquered nations - for example, the European countries overrun by Adolf Hitler in the 1930s and 1940s - Kuwait has reconstituted itself outside its own borders with its governmental hierarchy and its assets largely intact. The investment income from Kuwaiti assets abroad is generally estimated to exceed the oil revenue from what its leaders say are the world's fifth-largest oil reserves. Kuwait's rulers without a realm, the al-Sabah family, run their government-in-exile from the Saudi resort town of Taif, and its international business empire operates mainly out of London. Policy-making is concentrated in the hands of the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, and a few advisers. A bureaucracy under the prime minister and crown prince, Sheik Saad, handles day-to-day decision-making. Both Kuwait Petroleum and the Kuwait Investment Office are controlled by the nation's top leadership. Kuwait Petroleum, which operates its own refineries in Rotterdam, Skaelskoer, Denmark and Naples, has offset the loss of its own crude oil supplies with Saudi oil and purchases on the open market, according to the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey in Nicosia. For a nation of only 640,000 citizens, with a territory smaller than New Jersey, pre-invasion Kuwait had enormous economic clout. The Kuwaiti investment portfolio, originally put together as a hedge against the time when the oil ran out, has given post-invasion Kuwait a financial infrastructure that can be effectively operated from exile, said Rosemary Hollis, a financial analyst with the Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies in London. But she noted many Kuwaiti banks are still unable to operate because of the destruction of records in the occupied emirate.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Brings Hope to Lonesome Dakota Prairie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thrusday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: Farmers who live in this nearly deserted prairie town, depressed by years of drought and low wheat prices, are starting to dream again thanks to a conflict halfway around the world. The sound of their tractors is accompanied by a new sound - oil rigs - suddenly more profitable because Iraq's invasion of Kuwait more than two months ago has nearly doubled crude prices. Balcron Oil of Billings, Mont., has found oil in two wells and is drilling a third. They call it the Lucky Mound field, the first in McLean County. ``It's very likely going to be a year or more, possibly two years, before outer limits of the field are defined,'' said Bob Graveline, associate director of the North Dakota Petroleum Council. The first oil well was found in early August on land belonging to Ed Wahner and his wife Bette, both 64-year-old retired farmers from Parshall. Company officials say it's giving out about 120 barrels a day so far. ``It all happened so fast,'' said Ed Wahner, who leased his land to Balcron about two years ago. ``We farmed it for many years and we had no inkling whatsoever.'' Owners of the minerals get royalty payments, or about one-eighth of the production, Graveline said. The Wahners don't know how much their first check will be, nor have they made grand plans - except for a reclining chair they bought for the Rev. Thomas Sullivan at St. Bridge's Catholic Church in Parshall. That's what the priest had mentioned when Bette Wahner asked him jokingly about a year ago what he wanted if she ever got an oil well. Now Sullivan has offered to ``help'' others in the community strike oil - except he wants a Cadillac as payment this time. ``I haven't got any takers on that,'' he said. North Dakota, the country's ninth largest oil producer, has given out 1 billion barrels since oil was discovered in the state in 1951. State wells currently average 100,000 barrels a day. The McLean County wells are part of the Williston Basin, a geological formation that covers roughly two-thirds of North Dakota. The Balcron drilling is within the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation, on land owned by Indians and non-Indians alike. The Indians own mineral rights to one of the wells, said Rich Schilf, natural resources department administrator for the Three Affiliated Tribes on the reservation. Hope about the new wells comes as the Persian Gulf crisis continues to push oil prices into the $40-a-barrel range, compared with $20 a barrel in midsummer. If that trend persists, exploration will become more profitable in the state, although Balcron officials said their McLean County operation was planned long before the price jump. Graveline said the Williston Basin will continue to be probed because it is one of the least explored parts in the continental United States. That's good news to the county's economy. Annie Hendrickson remembers the time when she and her husband ran a bar in Raub. The town died when the railroad passed it by, and the farm economy slipped. Folks come by these days to sit at her kitchen counter, have a cup of coffee and talk about oil. Jim Odeman, 26, who lives about a mile away, was welcoming an oil exploration crew late last week. ``There's some hope,'' he said. ``Farming hasn't been too good.'' Balcron officials held meeting with area residents to explain the oil development process, filling the Raub Town Hall for the first time in years. ``It's nice to have some faces behind an oil company name,'' Schilf said. Hope has also sprung in the form of jobs. Hendrickson's son Neal found one to supplement his farm income when he heard about the drilling. He didn't know what an oil pumper was or even what the job would pay. Now, he goes out every day to check the Wahner well and make certain it is pumping smoothly. ``It's something else to think about, instead of trying to think about farm prices,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Oil Surge, Few West Texans See Return to `Good Old Days'
DOC.TEXT: Once the epitome of the 1980s oil boom, this West Texas oil town is now plagued with closed businesses, for-sale signs and ever-shortening store hours. As thousands of oil industry officials gathered here Wednesday for the 1990 Permian Basin Oil Show, crude prices were at a decade high. Still, no one was talking about a return to the good old days. Industry officials here for the nation's largest inland oil show appeared to be doing more window shopping than buying. ``This quick rise in prices will not be the answer,'' Steve Todt, general manager of Midland-based Cactus Drilling Co., said of crude's current price. ``This industry was decimated during the mid-1980s. It will take yearstto get it back on its feet again.'' The price of a 42-gallon barrel of sweet crude oil, known here as West Texas Intermediate, closed down $2.17 at $36.72 in Wednesday's trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prospective buyers shuffled from booth to booth, inspecting skyscraper-like rigs and pumpjacks. But wallets stayed tucked away. ``They are not quite in the spending mood,'' said Rad Cagle, an oil show director, sporting a Stetson hat and snake-skin boots. ``I think people are upbeat, and as soon as those oil prices stabilize at around $20 to $25 a barrel, the folks will get real excited. But until then, they are not going to get crazy with the checkbook.'' ``Nobody is making plans for next year based on $40-a-barrel oil,'' said Gary Johnson, a Phillips Petroleum Co. representative at the oil show. ``We would like to think prices will stabilize around $25 a barrel soon. But if a war breaks out in the Mideast, the prices we are seeing now would seem cheap.'' Towns like Odessa and nearby Midland are hoping for a comeback - albeit a gradual one. Pointing to a graph indicating the number of rigs drilling in the Permian Basin over the past 50 years, Todt points to a line drawn nearly off the chart in 1981. ``There were 663 rigs pumping in the Permian Basin that year,'' he said. ``Today we have 150 working. Nobody feels like we could get back to that level again. And I don't think anyone wants to go back to that. It was excessive.'' The end of an eight-year war between Iraq and Iran in the mid-1980s uncovered a huge surplus of oil in the Middle East. Prices dropped and the bottom fell out. Locals watched the demise of nearly every oil-related business that had lined up for miles on Highway 80, connecting Midland and Odessa. ``It's tough to see Odessa like this,'' Billy Burcham said. ``This town is oil. And when times were good, you would have thought this was downtown New York. But when the market dropped, people couldn't get out of here fast enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Chairman Phillips To Retire
DOC.TEXT: The chairman and chief executive at Dow Jones & Co. announced his retirement, but company officials say the move is not connected to The Wall Street Journal parent's recent financial troubles. Warren H. Phillips, 64, has been chief executive of the media and financial information company since 1975 and chairman since 1978. He will relinquish his chief executive duties at the first of the year and retire as chairman next July 1. Phillips will stay on as a director. He will be 65 by the time of his retirement as chairman. Phillips' decision was based on the customary retirement age of 65, said Dow Jones spokesman Roger May. Eric Philo, a media analyst at Goldman Sachs & Co., said Phillips' announcement was not a great surprise. He agreed it probably was not connected with the company's financial problems. ``He has been operating in a very difficult environment in the past several years,'' Philo said, citing the cutbacks on Wall Street and the softness in the advertising market. ``You can't lay it at his doorstep,'' he said. Journal newsroom speculation differed. ``This could be Phillips saying these problems are going to be tough to solve and take a long time,'' a reporter, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said. Peter R. Kann, the company's president and chief operating officer, will succeed Phillips as chief executive. Kann, 47, also is publisher of the Journal. No date has been set for the board to elect a successor to Phillips as chairman, said Dana Jennings, another company spokesman. ``These actions will provide an orderly transition of executive responsibility,'' Phillips said in a statement. ``After an immensely satisfying 43-year career at Dow Jones and more than 15 years as CEO, it is time for me to step down and allow a new CEO and his colleagues to provide fresh energy and continuity of leadership in the years ahead.'' In addition to the Journal, Dow Jones publishes the weekly financial newspaper Barron's, produces a weekly financial television show and provides financial information electronically. Dow Jones announced in an internal memo last Thursday that it was freezing budgets for capital spending and salaries and imposing other news and business spending cuts to cope with weak financial results and the sluggish economy. The memo did not rule out layoffs. The memo followed an announced 17.5 percent slide in third-quarter profits, attributed principally to the company's acquisition of the financial information service Telerate Inc. Dow Jones also has been hurt by the recession plaguing Wall Street since the 1987 stock market crash. Operating income at Dow Jones' business publications dropped 80 percent in the third quarter. Advertising linage at the Journal dropped 16 percent in the period. At a regular monthly meeting Wednesday, the company's directors approved Kann's new duties and elected Kenneth L. Burenga executive vice president and successor to Kahn as chief operating officer. Burenga, 46, currently is senior vice president and general manager. The board also elected Burenga and Carl M. Valenti as members of the board. Valenti, 52, is president and publisher of Dow Jones' Information Services Group and president and chief operating officer of Telerate. Phillips' career with Dow Jones began in 1947, when he joined the Journal as a copy reader. He was named news editor in 1953, managing editor in 1957, executive editor of Dow Jones publications in 1965 and editorial director in 1971, a post he held for 17 years. Thereafter he held a variety of executive posts, leading to his appointments as CEO and chairman. Dow Jones annual revenue has risen from $238 million when Phillips became chief executive to $1.69 billion. Under Phillips' leadership, the Journal has expanded to three sections, adding coverage beyond financial news. The paper added a European edition and Dow Jones completed the purchase of Telerate Inc., an electronic financial information service in the past decade. The Dow board gave Phillips a $1 million bonus last year for his long service to the company. Last year, the company earned $317 million, compared with a profit of $228.2 million on revenue of $1.6 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Approves Doubling Grain Futures Investors Can Hold
DOC.TEXT: Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have approved a plan to double the number of grain and soybean futures contracts that speculators can control at any one time. The directors acted under pressure from large commodity fund managers. Critics said the move could make prices more volatile as huge commodity fund trades stir up the market. Commissions paid to many exchange members, both brokers and brokerage firms, likely would increase if the plan is adopted by the exchange membership and approved by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Approval is expected, and expanded limits could be in place within a few months, The Wall Street Journal reported in today's editions. ``Focusing on more business overlooks the fact that these funds already exacerbate price movements,'' Benjamin Raskin, a futures trader and honorary CBOT member told the newspaper. Acting en masse with holdings twice as large as previously allowed could make price fluctuations even more dramatic than they currently are, Raskin said. Earlier this year, the National Grain and Feed Association said they thought such a move ``could cause market distortions that would undermine price discovery.'' The board approved doubling the total number of contracts speculators can control to 4,800 for corn and soybeans and 3,600 for wheat. But it voted to limit holdings in any one contract month, excluding the front month, which retains its current limit, to no more than one-third of the total position allowed.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Prices Soar 0.8 Percent in September
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `In addition ...' with stock market and real earnings report; minor editing throughout. Trims last 5 grafs for length. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Soaring energy prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait pushed Americans' cost of living up 0.8 percent in September, the second consecutive monthly dose of bad inflation, the government said today. The September rise matched the August increase in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index. If prices continued increasing at the two-month pace for a year, it would produce an annual inflation rate of 9.5 percent. The pickup in inflation this year translated into the biggest boost in Social Security benefits in 8{ years. Based on today's report, the government announced a 5.4 percent raise in benefits beginning in January for the 40 million Social Security recipients. In addition to boosting inflation, the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion hurt the nation's merchandise trade deficit, which jumped 2.4 percent in August. Rising oil prices pushed imports to a record high. The gap between imports and exports climbed to $9.3 billion, the largest since January. The stock market shrugged off the news, with the Dow Jones average of industrial stocks rising 13.37, to 2,401.24 in the first half hour of trading. Analysts said traders were doing some cautious buying on the belief that worries about the economy had gone to unjustified extremes. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, increased 0.4 percent in September. Before adjusting for inflation, they totaled to $353.92. In the inflation report, energy prices in September jumped 5.6 percent, the worst rise on record since the department began tracking the sector in 1957. Gasoline soared 9.5 percent, the worst increase in 17 months, and fuel oil rose 15.9 percent. For August and September together, gasoline rose 17.9 percent and fuel oil was up 33.7 percent. Electricity and natural gas charges also rose, but less steeply. For the first nine months of the year, consumer prices advanced at an annual rate of 6.6 percent, well above the 4.6 percent increase for all of 1989. Analysts expect the bad news to continue through November or December, even if oil prices stabilize near $40 a barrel, double the July price. They anticipate a 1990 consumer price rise near 7 percent, the highest in nearly a decade. Prices increased 8.9 percent in 1981. The oil shock will begin feeding through to chemicals, airline tickets and other energy-related products and services. The big bite out of consumers' wallets is expected to slow an already sluggish economy. ``We're going into a recession, very clearly,'' said economist David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill. Prices excluding energy rose a more moderate 0.4 percent in September, the same as the previous month. But the Labor Department noted several sectors of above-average inflation. ``While prices in most components of the index accelerated, the run-up for petroleum-based energy prices has had the largest effect,'' it said in its release. Medical care was up 0.7 percent, bringing prices 9.3 percent higher than a year earlier. Clothing costs were also up 0.7 percent in September. Men's and boys' clothing prices fell, but women's, girls' and infants' clothing costs rose, as did the price of shoes. On a positive note for consumers, food and beverage prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent last month, the same as August. New car prices edged up only 0.1 percent after remaining unchanged in August. Car dealers beset with lagging sales have been unable to wean the public from rebate programs and discounted financing. Housing costs were up 0.4 percent, held back by a decline in hotel and motel costs, which had been rising steeply earlier in the year. The various changes put the index for all consumer items at 132.7 in September. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period, cost $132.70 last month, up $7.70 from a year earlier. As bad as the short-term inflation outlook seems, analysts expect inflation to return to normal next year, unless a shooting war breaks out in the Persian Gulf and sends oil prices up further. ``It's important to draw a distinction between a one-time rise in price level ... and whether or not that works itself permanently into a higher rate of inflation,'' said Michael Boskin, President Bush's chief economic adviser. ``Thus far, it appears that the most likely outcome will be similar to its mirror image: The collapse of energy prices in 1986 when consumer prices fell ... but then, the following year inflation went back more or less to its long-run historical level,'' Boskin told an American Stock Exchange conference earlier this week.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Auction Postponed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT congressional to Congress. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury is postponing today's auction of 52-week bills because Congress has failed to extend the federal debt limit, the agency said in a statement. The Treasury said Oct. 12 it would auction $10.75 billion in bills today, to be issued on Oct. 25. However, the government's current $3.195 billion-debt ceiling reverts to $3.12 billion at midnight Friday leaving the Treasury no authority to issue the bills next week.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 3rd Quarter Profits Down 52 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Dow Chemical Co. said Thursday its third-quarter profit dropped 52 percent despite increased sales, citing higher costs for petroleum - used as a raw material for its chemical products and as fuel to run its plants. Dow said its net income dropped to $282 million, or $1.04 a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, from $589 million, or $2.19 a share, for the third quarter of 1989. The decline came although sales for the period rose to $4.92 billion from $4.25 billion a year earlier. For the first nine months of the year, the company reported net income fell 46 percent to $1.11 billion, or $4.09 a share, from $2.06 billion, or $7.61 a share, a year earlier. Nine-month sales rose 9.7 percent to $14.63 billion from $13.34 billion a year earlier. To delay the fuel cost impact, Dow increased prices for products such as polystyrene plastic used for video cassette cases and electronics cabinets, and polyethylene used for packaging and other applications, spokeswoman Sarah R. Opperman said. Most prices were raised by 10 percent to 15 percent. Financial vice president Enrique C. Falla said the company had raised prices enough to offset higher materials costs by the end of the third quarter. He said Dow's global purchasing capability and manufacturing flexibility let it delay most of the cost impact until the fourth quarter when price increases were implemented worldwide. Dow, a maker of chemicals, plastics, specialty products, pharmaceuticals and household products, employs about 55,500 people.

DOC.HEAD: Colgate-Palmolive Reports Strong Growth in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Colate-Palmolive Co., a leading maker of consumer products, reported strong gains in third-quarter sales and earnings Thursday, attributing the improvement to new markets and the impact of a weak dollar. The company's earnings report contrasted sharply with the disappointing third-quarter results reported by many major U.S. companies, which have been adversely affected by a broad economic downturn in the United States and a large jump in energy costs due to the Persian Gulf crisis. Colgate said earnings for the three months ended Sept. 30 totaled $84.44 million or $1.20 a share, up 10 percent from $76.72 million or $1.06 a share reported a year earlier. Third-quarter sales totaled $1.46 billion vs. $1.26 billion, a 16 percent increase. Colgate said its household and personal-care operations did particularly well, with notable earnings advances in Europe and Latin America. Colgate also said its expansion into Eastern Europe, notably the former East Germany, also helped accelerate sales. Like some other large U.S.-based companies with significant business abroad, Colgate said it was helped by the higher value of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar vs. a year ago. That translates into higher sales and earnings figures when calculated in dollars. For the first nine months of the year, Colgate said it earned $247.59 million or $3.53 a share, up 14 percent from $217.52 million or $3.09 a share in the year-earlier period. Sales totaled $4.21 billion vs. $3.75 billion, up 12 percent. Based in New York, Colgate is a major consumer product company focusing on oral care, body care, household products and animal dietary care, best known for brand-names that include Colgate toothpaste, Ajax cleanser and Hill's pet foods.

DOC.HEAD: Will Announce Losses More Than Tripled in Fiscal Year
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., which reports fiscal year results later this month, will announce losses more than tripled from the previous year, a source familiar with the large national retailer said today. Macy, still paying down debt from a 1986 management-led, debt-financed takeover known as a leveraged buyout, will report losses of $215.3 million for the year that ended July 28, compared with a loss of $63 million the previous year, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The retailer's earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation - a key figure for a company paying down leveraged-buyout debt - totaled $721 million in fiscal 1990, down from $926.1 million the year before. The 1990 figure, which was lower than projections made by Macy last spring, reflected a $30 million accounting adjustment, the source said. Although worse than expected, the numbers were not a major surprise. Macy announced earlier this year it had a disastrous Christmas 1989 season and suffered a $39 million loss instead of turning a profit during its second quarter. However, the full-year results also reflected disappointing sales during the fourth quarter. Macy's August sales fell 5 percent from a year earlier, the source said. Macy reported sales of $7.27 billion for the year, up from $6.97 billion a year earlier. The upcoming Christmas season is expected to be sluggish for the entire retail industry, and Macy's poor showing during the summer has raised concerns among investors about how the company will fare during the holidays. Macy said it has responded to the poor business forecast by reducing its costs and planning conservatively for Christmas. James Fingeroth, a Macy spokesman, noted that the retailer is carrying $560 million less in inventory than it had a year ago and is ``planning for a very sluggish environment going forward for the forseeable future.'' Last week, Macy announced it was selling its credit operations to GE Capital Corp. Macy said the move would reduce its $4.8 billion debt load by $1.5 billion. The company has also said it is buying back some of its junk bonds as another means of lowering its debt and a $595 million annual interest bill. Macy has sold equity stakes to help finance the buybacks. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club and Aeropostale, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Third-Quarter Earnings Up Nearly 12 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Textron Inc. reported Thursday its third-quarter earnings increased nearly 12 percent, largely on improvements in its aerospace business. The Providence-based conglomerate, whose products range from Speidel watches to Bell helicopters, earned $66.6 million, or 75 cents per share, compared with $59.5 million, 66 cents per share, in the July-September period in 1989. The earnings were based on revenue of nearly $1.9 billion, an increase of 11.7 percent from 1989's $1.74 billion. Textron said it was pleased with the results because they were achieved ``despite unfavorable foreign exchange (rates) included in corporate expenses, higher interest expense reflecting increased borrowings and a higher income tax rate.'' B.F. Dolan, chairman and chief executive officer, said Textron had improved its performance on contracts in the aerospace technology sector, where earnings rose 25 percent to $82.1 million. Commercial products also were fairly strong, with profits rising 17.3 percent to $31.9 million. Textron's financial services division did not perform quite as well, although its income rose 8.3 percent to $74.7 million. For the first nine months of the year, Textron earned $204.9 million, or $2.28 per share, on revenue of $5.8 billion. That compared with 1989's earnings of $182.1 million, or $2.06 per share, out of $5.4 billion in revenue.
