DOC.HEAD: Sixteen Companies Qualify to Bid For Mexican Telephone System
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen companies, including a dozen foreign concerns, qualified to bid for the government-owned Telefonos de Mexico in a sale that could bring the government more than $4 billion, the Finance Ministry said. The telephone company, known as Telmex, is one of a number of state-owned enterprises to go on the block in recent months. Interested investors had to deposit $10 million or demonstrate more than $1 billion in assets to qualify. Telmex announced the planned auction on Aug. 13. Bidding will be Nov. 15. Preident Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration plans to divest itself of the company by Jan. 31, in line with a policy of selling off state enterprises, reducing budget deficits and trimming bureaucracy. Telmex stock is estimated to be worth more than $8 billion, and about half of it is held by the government. Mexican firms qualifying were Casa de Bolsa Inverlat, Acciones y Valores, Gentor and Grupo Carso, the ministry said late Wednesday. Foreign qualifiers are Southwestern Bell, GTE, Citibank, US Sprint, Bell Canada, Telefonica de Espana, France Cable and Radio, STET, Nippon Telephone and Telegraf, Singapore Telcom, Nynex International and Cable and Wireless PLC. To make the company more attractive, the government has launched a three-year project to modernize the nation's long-distance network with optic fibers. In March, the government allowed private companies to compete with Telmex in the newly inaugurated cellular telephone market. Mexico has sold or is selling its nationalized bank holdings, an airline, a hotel chain, mines and other interests.

DOC.HEAD: BP Says It Has Agreed To Sell Certain New Zealand Interests
DOC.TEXT: British Petroleum Co. PLC said Thursday it has agreed to sell the companies holding its exploration and production interests in New Zealand to Fletcher Challenge Ltd. for about $217 million. It said these interests include an 18.75 percent interest in the offshore Maui field, and a 37.5 percent interest in the onshore Kapuni field, both of which produce natural gas and condensate for the local New Zealand market. Fletcher Challenge is a New Zealand energy company which holds a 50 percent interest in the Maui field. BP said ``the sale is in line with BP Exploration's previously stated goal to focus on its core assets and dispose of those which are non-strategic.'' BP said its oil refining and marketing interests in New Zealand were not affected by the sale and would continue as an important element of BP's refining business worldwide. BP said its interest in forestry and chemicals in New Zealand also were unaffected.

DOC.HEAD: Pizza Hut Contract Starts Push for Expansion in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Pizza Hut plans to open at least 100 new restaurants in Brazil as a result of an agreement signed with a South American investor, a spokesman said. The financial terms of the agreement signed Wednesday with Ricardo Mansur, a prominent Sao Paulo businessman, were not announced. But the spokesman for Pepsico Food Service International, Pizza Hut's overseas arm, said it was one of the biggest expansions abroad for Pizza Hut. Mansur started the talks with Pizza Hut and will operate as a franchise, the spokesman said. The favorite pizza in Brazil is called the ``Brazilian.'' It is made with ham, eggs and cheese. In a separate franchise territory near Sao Paulo, another Brazilian franchise is completing its second Pizza Hut, the spokesman said. Pizza Hut has more than 6,800 locations in the United States and more than 1,100 in 60 countries overseas. A Soviet Union agreement calls for construction of 20 restaurants. Long-range agreements envision 250 Pizza Huts in the United Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Earnings Rose 32 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Medical supply giant Baxter International Inc. on Thursday reported a 32 percent increase in third-quarter profits, citing strong overseas markets. Baxter's net income rose to $135 million, or 46 cents per share, for the three months ending Sept. 30, compared with $102 million, or 34 cents per share in the third quarter of 1989. Third-quarter sales were $2 billion, up 12 percent from $1.8 billion a year ago, the company said. Domestic sales for the third quarter were about $1.5 billion while international sales were about $492 million, the company said. ``These results are excellent, consistent with the program we laid out earlier this year to improve operating income,'' said Vernon Loucks, chairman of the health-care manufacturer and marketer. ``They also reflect continuing strength in our overseas markets and in our alternate-site businesses.'' For the first nine months of the year, Baxter reported a net loss of $138 million, or 74 cents per common share, in cointrast to a profit of $307 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. Nine-month sales rose 9.3 percent to $5.9 billion from $5.4 billion in 1989. The company said the loss resulted from a pre-tax provision of $566 million to cover the cost of a restructuring program. Baxter in April announced plans to pare its workforce of 64,300 by 10 percent and close or sell 21 of its 100 manufacturing plants in 24 countries.

DOC.HEAD: House Raises Tariffs On Goods From China To Protest Tiananmen Crackdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 new grafs. No pickup. Moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted today to raise tariffs on Chinese clothing, toys and shoes by hundreds of millions of dollars to protest the military suppression of China's pro-democracy movement last year. In anticipation of a certain veto from President Bush, it also prepared a backup, if contradictory, measure that would condition continued open trade with improvement in China's human rights records. Bush, a former envoy to China, has indicated he is prepared to veto both, particularly if the milder version is amended later today to require the release of all protesters arrested after Chinese authorities ordered the military to crush the student-led Tiananmen Square democracy movement in June 1989. The United States suspended high-level political contacts and cut off international loans to China to protest the killings of hundreds, and possibly thousands, of unarmed students and others in the military crackdown. But Bush decided in May to continue for another year the lower, ``most favored nation'' tariffs that China has enjoyed since 1980. Raising them, he said, ``would only hurt the Chinese people themselves.'' The resolution disapproving Bush's continuation of the lower tariffs was approved on a 247-174 vote. It now goes to the Senate, where Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, has introduced a similar measure. Under a new trade law enacted in August, overturning Bush's decision requires a majority vote of both the House and Senate before Saturday. The resolution's author, Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., acknowledged that supporters lack the votes to override a presidential veto, but said just passing it ``will sent a hell of a message to the People's Republic of China.'' The administration estimates that the higher tariffs from suspending China's most-favored status would raise the price of its exports to the United States an average 40 percent. For example, a Chinese-made sweater with an import price of $20 now carries a tariff of $1.20. Without most-favored status, its import price would be $32. The United States imported about $12 billion in Chinese products last year while sending China some $5.8 billion in U.S. exports. The Bush administration and others supporting the continuation of most-favored-nation status say higher tariffs would hurt reform-minded Chinese seeking to keep China open to the rest of the world. They argue that increased tariffs would also deal a severe blow to Hong Kong, through which a large portion of China's exports pass, lead to Chinese retaliation against American exporters and mean higher prices for American consumers.

DOC.HEAD: Shares End Higher As Wall Street Rallies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed higher Thursday on London's Stock Exchange after a steady climb throughout the afternoon. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 14.6 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,082.6. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 17.3 points at 1,618.1. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 8.76 points to close at 1,112.27. Volume was 359.6 million shares, compared with 545.9 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: IBM, Motorola End Talks On Sharing Advanced Chip Technology
DOC.TEXT: IBM and Motorola Inc. have ended talks on sharing IBM's technology for making advanced computer memory chips, The New York Times reported Thursday. The companies had been discussing the possibility of Motorola using IBM's technology for making 4-million-bit chips, the highest-capacity memory chips now in production. International Business Machines Corp. entered into the talks earlier this year with the hope of establishing a stronger domestic semiconductor industry, the Times said. IBM is the only domestic maker of 4-million-bit chips. The Times, which based its report on anonymous industry and government sources, did not say why the talks broke off. Motorola has an agreement with Toshiba Corp. of Japan to make 1-million-bit chips and plans to use Toshiba designs to produce 4-million-bit chips in the future, the Times reported. IBM spokesman Mike King said Thursday the company never acknowledged such talks and so it had no comment on the Times report. A Motorola spokeswoman said her company also had no comment. IBM currently licenses its memory chip technology to Micron Technologies Inc., a chip maker in Boise, Idaho. IBM does not sell computer chips on the open market; it uses its entire chip production in its own products. A bit is the smallest piece of information used by a computer. Because of the way memory chips are designed, new generations of chips increase in capacity fourfold.

DOC.HEAD: Michelin Says It Expects Big Loss for 1990
DOC.TEXT: The price of Michelin shares fell sharply Thursday on the Paris stock exchange as the world's biggest tire manufacturer announced it expected a huge loss for 1990. Company officials told financial analysts that Michelin expects to post a consolidated net loss of more than 2.31 billion francs, or $440 million, this year. Last year, Michelin had a net profit of 2.449 billion francs. Eric Bourdais de Charbonniere, Michelin's finance director, attributed the sharp erosion to the company's $1.5 billion takeover of Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co. last year, weaker car and tire markets, and the appreciation of the franc against the dollar and other currencies. Michelin shares were temporarily suspended from trading on the Paris exchange after disclosure of the anticipated losses sparked a decline of nearly 10 percent in the share price. The stock closed at 68.4 francs, down from 74.5 francs at Wednesday's close. The dollar has been trading at about 5.06 francs. Michelin's share price has been rising sharply over the past week on speculation that the company would make a favorable announcement at the analysts' meeting. The company said the exact amount of the 1990 loss will depend on the scope of yet-undetermined restructuring charges it will take for the second half of this year. The 1990 forecast is much worse than previous projections by market analysts, who calculated that this year's loss would reach between 1 billion and 1.5 billion francs. Company officials said Michelin will remain in the red in the first half of 1991, but should return to the break-even point later next year. De Charbonniere, said it was too early to assess whether the tire and rubber group will break even for all of 1991. Company officials said that in order to be able to break even by the end of next year, Michelin will have to increase its cash flow by 2.5 billion francs. They said the return to profitability will require cuts in oprrating costs that may involve steps leading to job cuts affecting production, commercial and administrative employees. Carlos Ghosn, director of Michelin's North American operations, said Uniroyal Goodrich is expected to report cash flow of about $55 million but the unit will not make any positive or negative contribution to Michelin's consolidated 1990 earnings. He said Michelin intends to proceed with sales of certain of Uniroyal Goodrich's textile assets, but didn't elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Primerica, PaineWebber Report Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Positive returns from its insurance unit helped Primerica's profits jump 20 percent in the third quarter, but diminished investment banking revenue hurt PaineWebber's profits, the companies said Thursday.
DOC.HEAD: Primerica
DOC.TEXT: Primerica Corp., parent of the Smith Barney, Harris, Upham & Co. brokerage, reported earnings of $94 million, or 82 cents a share, up from $78.3 million, or 80 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue totaled $1.5 billion, up 2 percent from $1.47 billion. Primerica Chairman Sanford I. Weill said the company's consumer finance and insurance unit is expected to ``continue delivering sizable and growing earnings contributions, which cushion the impact . . . of the cyclical results in Smith Barney's businesses.'' The company's insurance services operations, which include A.L. Williams, saw earnings rise 20 percent to $64.8 million on revenues of $545.1 million. But earnings slumped 43 percent to $15.5 million on $413.2 million in revenue in the investment services unit, which includes Smith Barney. Primerica cited a decline in commissions amid weak volume on world stock exchanges and lower investment banking revenues. Weill said Primerica will ``continue evaluating all our businesses in the difficult environment ahead and will make whatever adjustments become necessary to sustain profitabilty.'' For the first nine months, Primerica earned $274.1 million, or $2.38 a share, up 42 percent from $193.1 million, or $1.98 a share a year ago when fewer shares were outstanding. Revenue for the period totaled $4.5 billion, up 9 percent from $4.11 billion in the first nine months of 1989.
DOC.HEAD: PaineWebber
DOC.TEXT: PaineWebber Group Inc. said earnings plummeted 43 percent to $9.57 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $16.83 million, or 41 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue was marginally higher at $720.65 million, compared with $719.39 million in the third quarter of 1989. Chairman Donald B. Marron said earnings were adversely affected by risk arbitrage trading results and ``the industrywide softness in investment banking.'' Still, the firm has managed to expand its retail customer base, which saw assets in PaineWebber accounts rise 10 percent to $69 billion. For the nine-month period, earnings fell 15 percent to $35 million, or 70 cents a share, from $41.1 million, or 85 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue advanced 8 percent to $2.28 billion from $2.12 billion in the first nine months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Board Takes Step Toward Far-Reaching Rule Change
DOC.TEXT: The board that makes the nation's accounting rules has taken a major step toward changing the way retiree health benefits are reported by businesses, which if approved could slash billions of dollars from corporate earnings. Diana Scott, a project manager of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, said Thursday that members voted 4-3 Wednesday to order the board's technical staff to prepare a draft version of the rule change. Scott said the board expects to vote on the draft by Thanksgiving, and if approved the rule change would be promulgated by the end of the year and take effect starting in 1993. The board, based in Norwalk, Conn., is a federally sanctioned body that sets the standards for how companies report their financial condition in quarterly earnings statements and other documents. Since February 1989 it has been considering a retiree-benefit rule change that would more accurately state a company's long-term liability in its financial reporting. Under the current rule, most companies account for benefits to retirees on what is known as a pay-as-you-go basis. But under the change, they would not be able to wait until the costs are incurred. Instead, they would have to subtract from each year's earnings a portion of the expected costs. Most companies have accepted the logic behind the change, although they have said it could result in drastic reductions in their bottom lines. Over the past 20 months, many lobbied successfully to soften some provisions of the proposal, such as gradually implementing it over a few years. Some retiree benefits analysts have estimated the cost of the rule change to businesses could be at least $200 billion, just for the largest U.S. companies. Others have estimated the cost as high as $400 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Imports Hit New Record Following Oil Price Surge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Surging oil prices drove imports to a new record in August and helped propel the U.S. merchandise trade deficit to its highest level in seven months, the government reported Thursday. Analysts said that excluding the oil factor, the trade picture actually improved as exports continued to grow moderately. Nevertheless, soaring energy costs were adversely affecting the economy and driving up inflation. In its first report on America's trade gap since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and disrupted international oil markets, the Commerce Department said imports rose 1.8 percent, to $42.0 billion, while exports gained 1.6 percent, to $32.6 billion. The difference meant a $9.3 billion imbalance, up 2.4 percent from July and the largest since a $10.2 billion gap last January. The non-oil deficit, on the other hand, fell from $5.4 billion in July to $5.0 billion the following month. The previous record for imports was $41.6 billion in March this year. ``If you throw out energy, the trade picture shows gradual continuing improvement,'' said Donald Ratajczak, economist at Georgia State University. Nevertheless, ``the deficit is going to be plagued at least through the end of the year by increasing oil imports,'' said economist Mark M. Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. The volume of imported oil actually declined in August, down 10.3 percent to 7.95 million barrels a day. But a hefty 34.8 percent price gain, to $19.54 a barrel, pushed overall petroleum costs up 20.9 percent to $4.8 billion. And the price of oil has since doubled to nearly $40 a barrel. Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, said despite the boost in the deficit, the trade gap still could end the year under $100 billion for the first time since 1983. For the first eight months of 1990, the deficit was running at an annual rate of $96.8 billion, compared to $110.7 billion during the same period last year. Zandi said the nation's trade problems could benefit from a weakening U.S. economy. ``What we may see is that imports of automobiles and industrial goods will fall and offset the oil import bill,'' he said. However, imports of foreign-made cars rose 2.1 percent, to $3.39 billion, in August. Exports, on the other hand, rebounded from a 6.1 percent decline in July. ``The good news is that the lower dollar is still helping on the export side and we saw at least a modest further increase,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a New York securities dealer. ``The hope is that modest growth in the export sector will help offset the weakness we see in all the other major sectors of the economy.'' J. Antonio Villamil, Commerce Department chief economist, noted that ``export growth has been the major contributor to the increases in overall economic activity during the year,'' and said, ``We expect this trend to continue.'' Indeed, fully one-third of overall U.S. economic growth for the last three years has been supplied by export sales. They had become even more important recently as consumer spending has slowed. But economists believe the oil-price shock is likely to further weaken the economy and drive it into a recession - if it isn't there already. As usual, the biggest deficit was with Japan - a $3.8 billion imbalance, up from $3.0 billion in July. Other deficits included Taiwan, $1.2 billion; China, $1.1 billion; Canada, $509 million; South Korea, $518 million; Hong Kong, $397 million; Western Europe, $374 million, and Brazil, $178 million.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Soars Again, Fueled by Gulf Oil Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Americans' spendin power sank again in September as the Persian Gulf crisis pushed prices up a sharp 0.8 percent for the second straight month, the government said Thursday. Still, inflation not tied to oil prices remained relatively mild. If the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index continued increasing at the September pace for a year, it would produce an annual inflation rate of 9.5 percent. Most economists believe price increases - absent the outbreak of a shooting war - will return to a more normal level by the end of the year. The oil shock nevertheless has added a new burden for an economy that was already on the brink of recession. ``You take out energy and the numbers aren't that bad. But on the other hand, people have to buy the energy and it gives you an annual inflation rate roughly double the rate of wage growth,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. ``It means that people won't have a lot of money to spend on Christmas,'' he said. The ``core'' inflation rate - prices excluding food and energy - was 0.3 percent in September, down from 0.5 percent in August. For the first nine months of 1990, prices increased at an annual rate of 6.6 percent, well above the 4.6 percent increase for all of last year. The rate for all of 1990, if it comes in close to 7 percent as now expected, will be the worst since 1981, when prices shot up 8.9 percent. The pickup in inflation so far this year helped bring about the biggest boost in Social Security benefits in 8{ years. Based on Thursday's report, the government announced a 5.4 percent rise in benefits beginning in January for the 40 million Social Security recipients. In addition to boosting consumer inflation based on oil and various energy products, the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion and its aftermath hurt the U.S. merchandise trade deficit. It rose 2.4 percent to a seven-month high of $9.3 billion in August. Increasing oil prices pushed imports to a record high, more than offsetting a modest rise in exports. The stock market shrugged off the news, with the Dow Jones average of industrial stocks advancing. Analysts said traders were doing some cautious buying in the belief that worries about the economy had gone to unjustified extremes. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, increased 0.4 percent in September. Still, they were down 1.5 percent from a year ago. In the inflation report, energy prices in September jumped 5.6 percent, the worst rise on record since the department began tracking the sector in 1957. Gasoline soared 9.5 percent, the largest increase in 17 months, and fuel oil rose 15.9 percent. For August and September together, gasoline rose 17.9 percent and fuel oil was up 33.7 percent. Electricity and natural gas charges also rose, but less steeply. Analysts expect the bad news to continue through November or December, even if oil prices stabilize near where they are now - around $40 a barrel, double the July price. In the next few months, the oil shock probably will begin feeding through to chemicals, airline tickets and other energy-related products and services. But it probably will not produce a permanent increase in the inflation rate, said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York. ``We simply don't suffer this time around from the same kind of inflationary psychology as we did during earlier oil shocks in 1973 and 1979. In the `70s, consumers were buying in anticipation of price increases. Now, consumers are waiting for a bargain,'' he said. Jones said recent increases in consumer prices are great enough to cause the Federal Reserve to be cautious about stimulating the economy with lower interest rates but not so great as to prevent a quarter-point cut in short-term rates if Congress and President Bush agree on a plan to cut the federal budget deficit. In other details, the Labor Department said: -Food and beverage prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent last month, the same as August. -Medical care was up 0.7 percent, bringing prices 9.3 percent higher than a year earlier. -Clothing costs also were up 0.7 percent in September. Men's and boys' clothing prices fell, but women's, girls' and infants' clothing costs rose, as did the price of shoes. -New car prices edged up only 0.1 percent after remaining unchanged in August. Car dealers beset with lagging sales have been unable to wean the public from rebate programs and discounted financing. -Housing costs were up 0.4 percent, held back by a decline in hotel and motel costs, which had been rising steeply earlier in the year. The various changes put the index for all consumer items at 132.7 in September. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services costing $100 in the 1982-84 base period, cost $132.70 last month, up $7.70 from a year earlier.

The stock market chalked up a broad gain today, rallying from close to its lowest levels of the year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 43.07 to 2,430.94 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 2 to 1 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 1,062 up, 445 down and 412 unchanged. Analysts said traders were doing some buying on the belief that worries about the economy had gone to unjustified extremes. For example, they said expectations about corporate earnings seemed to have been lowered so sharply that some individual stocks were starting to rise in response even to lackluster reports for the third quarter. American Telephone & Telegraph, which posted flat earnings per share for the third quarter, rose 1 to 31~. The market's advance got a big boost from falling oil prices. Crude oil for November delivery traded briefly below $35 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange before rebounding at midafternoon. In the economic news, the Labor Department reported that the consumer price index rose 0.8 percent in September, just about matching its rise in August. Brokers said the latest figure, though hardly cheerful news, was actually a shade better than Wall Street had been expecting. Elsewhere among the blue chips, International Business Machines climbed 3 to 103}; Philip Morris 1{ to 46{; American Express | to 18[, and General Electric } to 53]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.43 to 166.02. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.01 at 290.14. Volume on the Big Board came to 149.96 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Richest Man Supports Income Tax Hike with Capital Gains Tax Cut
With AM-Budget-Taxes Bjt
DOC.TEXT: John W. Kluge, a Virginia billionaire listed by Forbes magazine as the richest man in America, said Thursday he favors an increase in the nation's top income tax rate if the capital gains tax is reduced. ``I recognize that the budget deficit must be reduced and that issues of tax fairness are prominent in the minds of many Americans,'' Kluge, 76, said in a telephone interview with AP Network News, a broadcasting operation of The Associated Press. ``To address both of those concerns, I personally would favor raising the top income tax rate to 33 percent as a part of a package that included a meaningful reduction in capital gains tax,'' Kluge said. For some time, Kluge said, U.S. businesses have been hampered by the high cost of capital, ``especially when compared to businesses in Japan and many European countries.'' ``I believe that the most effective way to bring down the cost of capital would be to reduce the rate at which capital gains are taxed,'' he said. ``The president and many members of the Senate and the House of Reresentatives share that view.'' Kluge said tax laws should be written ``to foster and encourage the American genius for creating new businesses and new jobs. I firmly believe that the best way to further that goal would be a lowered tax on capital gains for small and large businesses.'' Kluge said most people reinvest money from capital gains. ``Money just doesn't stay at the sidelines,'' he said. ``It seems to me that if one is to risk capital, there has to be an incentive. If there is no incentive to risk capital, why even try to make an investment? You might as well live off interest on money.'' Kluge (pronounced kloogy), owns a 10,000-acre farm near Charlottesville, Va. and is worth about $5.6 billion, Forbes estimated in its 1990 ranking of richest Americans released earlier this month. He was speaking from his office at Metromedia Co., the business he founded and the basis for his fortune. Years ago he sold the company's radio and television properties for $4.65 billion and netted more than $1.6 billion. Since then, Kluge has invested his profits into other interests, including cellular telephones and restaurants. He owns the Ponderosa Steak House, Bonanza and Steak & Ale chains. He recently sold his New York cellular operations for more than $1 billion in cash and $850 million in stock.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Up, Corn, Soybeans Off
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices were mostly higher, but corn and soybean prices were off at the close Thursday at the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures were supported by an increase in export business this week, traders said. Analysts said severe weather moving into the Midwest growing regions helped rally prices Wednesday, but now that the wintry weather was here, there was nothing else to keep prices going much higher. Traders were unimpressed with the U.S. Agriculture Department announcement overnight that the Soviet Union had purchased 350,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. ``They're saying `Who cares,''' said grain analyst Mickey Luth of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. He said the purchase was a drop in the bucket compared with the 16 million tons the Soviets had bought a year ago. Luth also said that demand for soybeans are below what they were a year ago. At the close, wheat was unchanged to 2{ cents higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $2.64} cents a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower, with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower, with December at $1.23 a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent to 3{ cents lower, with November at $6.11 bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 207,259 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 225,434, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 212,637 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 131,154 cars this week, compared with 143,150 a week ago and 143,497 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 76,105, compared with last week's 82,284 and last year's 69,140. Canadian automakers were to build 21,212 cars this week, down from 21,489 a week ago and from last year's 23,436. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 18,636, compared with 13,880 a week ago and 20,903 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bowater Reports 33 Percent Drop in Earnings for Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: A glut of newsprint and wood pulp contributed to a 33 percent drop in third-quarter earnings at Bowater Inc., the paper manufacturer announced Thursday. Bowater reported earnings of $23.7 million, or 63 cents per share, on sales of $346.6 million. That compared with earnings of $35.5 million, or 95 cents per share, on sales of $360.1 million in the same 1989 period. A June newsprint price increase was not enough to offset operating problems at Bowater's Calhoun, Tenn., and Nova Scotia, Canada mills, said A.P. Gammie, chairman and chief executive officer. Gammie said pulp prices continued to weaken on world markets during the third quarter. Bowater manufactures newsprint, bleached pulp and specialty papers. For the first nine months of 1990, Bowater reported earnings of $60.1 million, or $1.82 per share, on sales of $1.03 billion. That included an extraordinary charge of $9 million in the second quarter. Earnings totaled $112.4 million, or $3 per share, on sales of $1.08 billion, in the first nine months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Executive Officer Of Mobil Corp. Testifies
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Corp.'s chief executive officer, tesifying in a wrongful firing suit, said Thursday that he knew nothing about an employee who said he was fired for not going along with an alleged coverup of environmental problems at a company plant. ``We have too much to lose to defeat the law,'' Allen E. Murray told U.S. District Judge Harold Ackerman. ``We're not a fly-by-night business. We've been around for 100 years.'' The judge had ordered Murray to testify in the case of an employee of Mobil Chemical Co., a division of Mobil Corp. The employee, Valcar Bowman, contends he was fired in 1986 as the No. 2 environmental officer in that division because he blew the whistle on a cover-up at a plant in Bakersfield, Calif. Mobil says it fired the Princeton, N.J.-based manager as part of a cost-cutting campaign. The company later added that Bowman was fired for insubordination and disobedience. In a hearing last year, Judge Ackerman noted that in 1986 - the year Bowman was fired - Mobil Chemical had its best year ever, with net earnings rising to a record $140 million, a 164 percent increase from 1985. During testimony, Murray touched directly on several of Bowman's charges. Bowman insists that following a government search of Mobil's oil refinery in Torrance, Calif., the company ordered his staff to deliver all records that it could legally move from the Bakersfield, Calif., plant to the company's outside counsel. Bowman says the theory behind moving documents was that attorney-client privilege would keep the documents confidential and out of the hands of investigators. But Murray said such moves are not unusual for a company the size of Mobil, the country's second largest oil company behind Exxon Corp. with about 150,000 employees and hundreds of plants around the world. ``Records are moved around all the time,'' he said. And the company is not ready to tarnish its image for such a ``two-bit item.'' Murray stressed that, as Mobil's top officer, he did not know about Bowman's firing or operational details in the Bakersfield plant. Murray noted that he is not the president of Mobil Chemical Co., the division Bowman worked for, and so was not concerned with such matters. ``I wasn't aware of Mr. Bowman at all,'' Murray said. But Bowman's attorney, Stephen B. Wiley, showed Murray a copy of a letter to Murray that was marked with the chief executive officer's ``received'' stamp. And he asked if Murray could still say he had never heard of Bowman. Murray explained that he has two secretaries who handle the 100 or so pieces of mail that enter his office each day. The initials of another Mobil executive at the top of the paper showed that his secretary had forwarded it to someone else, Murray said. Regardless of who eventually received the letter, Murray said, he interpreted the document differently than Wiley did. Instead of withholding information from top officials to protect them from knowing the facts, Murray said the letter indicated that results of a plant audit would be sent to those who needed the information. ``I guess we just interpret this differently,'' Murray said. ``The important thing to me is that nothing is being covered up.''

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Earnings Drop 50 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. reported Thursday a 50 percent drop in third-quarter profits, blaming the decline on higher material costs and rising wage and benefit increases. Quarterly earnings totaled $54 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $108 million, or $1.07 per share in the third quarter of 1989. It was the sixth consecutive quarter in which profits at the world's leading manufacturer of earth-moving equipment were less than the comparable period in the previous year. However, sales and revenue climbed 6 percent to $2.79 billion for the three-month period ended Sept. 30, compared with $2.64 billion a year earlier. Len Kuchan, Caterpillar treasurer, called the profit outlook for the remainder of 1990 gloomy despite the possibility that the 75-year-old company could eclipse its sales and revenue record of $11.13 billion achieved last year. ``Our general expectation is that we would always expect to earn a profit,'' Kuchan said. ``Based on what we see now, we will make a profit in the fourth quarter. ``We're certainly not happy. With record sales we'd like to see record profits go right along with it.'' Kuchan blamed numerous factors for the depressed profits, including higher material costs and wage and benefit increases for its employees. The Persian Gulf crisis, which sent oil prices soaring, has also hurt Caterpillar, Kuchan said. ``Higher oil prices have an impact on inflation and hold interest rates higher than they might be otherwise,'' Kuchan said. ``We see a rough road ahead for the United States economy and the world economy and recognize the possibility of a recession.'' The company announced plans in August to lay off 650 workers at its Gosselies, Belgium, facility by the end of 1991. But no domestic plant furloughs or layoffs are anticipated at this time, he said. For the first nine months of the year, Caterpillar's profits totaled $199 million, down from $390 million last year. Profit per share was $1.97, compared to $3.85 for the first nine months of 1989. Sales and revenue for the first nine months of year totaled $8.7 billion, up from $8.4 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Waste Management Profits Up 26 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Waste Management Inc. on Thursday reported profits up 26 percent for the third quarter, as its recycling and trash-to-energy services continue to expand. The waste disposal firm said its net income for the three months, before an extraordinary charge, climbed to $190.7 million, or 40 cents per share, compared with $151.7 million or 33 cents a share in the same period last year. Sales for the three months ended Sept. 30 were up 34 percent to $1.59 billion from $1.19 billion in the year-earlier period. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, revenues were up 29 percent to $4.22 billion from $3.26 billion. Net income grew 26 percent to $514 million or $1.09 a share from $409 million or 89 cents a share a year earlier. ``Waste Management is enjoying an outstanding year, with each of our primary business units expanding their operations and improving their performance,'' said chairman Dean Buntrock. The company said it had restated its per share results for 1989 to reflect a two-for-one stock split. It also recorded an extraordinary charge representing the company's share of a writedown by Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. of Wheelabrator's investment in the stock of The Henley Group Inc. and Henley Properties Inc. to market value. The extraordinary charge was $24.5 million or 5 cents per share. The company said its stake in Wheelabrator adds to its abilities in trash-to-energy conversion and other environmental services. It also said its North American recycling services continue to expand, holding recycling contracts with more than 250 communities.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Advance After Selloff
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices swung wildly Thursday before settling slightly higher as tensions rose following a report that Israeli soldiers wounded dozens of Palestinians in clashes in the occupied West Bank. Crude prices were sharply lower in the early going as the market reacted to Wednesday's Energy Department report showing shortages created by the Persian Gulf crisis have been largely alleviated. The near-term contract for light-sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil, initially plunged more than $2.25 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. That extended Wednesday's $2.17-a-barrel decline and was well off the record-high level of $41 a barrel registered earlier this month. But prices reversed course following a mid-afternoon report that an attempt by the Israeli army to establish a new post in a Gaza strip refugee camp sparked hours of skirmishes and saw 35 Palestinians wounded by live ammunition and rubber bullets. The the price of light-sweet crude for November delivery settled at $36.80 a barrel, up 8 cents on the Mercantile Exchange.The contract had traded as high as $37.20 a barrel. Other contract months settled lower. ``This just adds to the tension in the Middle East,'' Jim Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.F. & Man International Inc., said of the Israeli report. ``The market reacted immediately to it.'' Fiedler said the market was concerned over the Palestinians' ability to drive a wedge into the unified front against Iraq. Non-Arab as well as some Arab nations have harshly condemned Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and have been supporting a U.S.-led embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude oil. Israel's killing of Palestinians at the Temple Mount holy site earlier this month met with sharp criticism, and Fiedler suggested any further moves by the Israelis against the Palestinians could weaken the United States' position as a leader against the Iraqi invasion. Several traders said they were exasperated with the wide swings in crude futures prices. Since the Persian Gulf crisis erupted, the band in which energy prices trade has widened considerably. As long as the crisis remains unresolved, many analysts predict crude prices will continue to swing between $34 and $41 a barrel. Higher oil prices were behind an 0.8 percent hike in the cost of living last month, according to a Labor Department report released Thursday. It was the second-consecutive month of bad U.S. inflation and translates to a 9.5 percent annual rate. Crude prices have nearly doubled since the invasion largely on speculation that a war would disrupt critical supplies from the Western world's most important source of petroleum. The market has been influenced by war jitters for weeks on little more than rumors, but to date there have been no hostilities between Iraq and a U.S.-led force deployed in the Gulf. Some analysts also said an Iraqi offer Thursday to sell oil to anyone for $21 a barrel may have had a minor effect on depressing prices intially. But others dismissed the gesture as propaganda posturing by Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to gain world sympathy and undercut the U.S.-led embargo. Prices for oil products declined. Home heating oil for November delivery lost 1.74 cents to 96.51 a gallon. Several later months posted greater losses. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for delivery in November lost .44 cent to 92.96 cents a gallon, with subsequent months dropping more than 2 cents a gallon. In natural gas trading, the November contract closed at $1.890 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.900 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T's Profit Rises 2 Percent in Quarter, But Credit Card Drags Earnings
DOC.TEXT: AT&T said Thursday its third-quarter profit rose almost 2 percent despite the sluggish economy, but earnings continued to be dragged down by processing costs for the phone company's highly popular new credit card. For the three months ended Sept. 30, AT&T said it earned $712 million, or 65 cents a share, compared with $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Per-share earnings remained stable due to a higher number of outstanding shares in the most-recent quarter. Revenue advanced about 5 percent to $9.36 billion from $8.9 billion in the year-ago quarter. American Telephone and Telegraph Co. Chairman Robert E. Allen called the results by the nation's largest long-distance phone company ``solid in the face of a softening economy.'' Industry analysts generally agreed. Richard Toole of Merrill Lynch & Co. called the earnings ``flat but good.'' Despite the economic downturn and drag from the AT&T Universal card, ``they were able to overcome that and have an all-time record operating (profit) margin,'' he said. Toole credited the company's cost controls and strong international sales of telephone equipment for the profit increase. Shares in AT&T, the nation's most widely held stock, rose $1.12{ cents to close at $32 on the New York Stock Exchange. Demand for the Universal card, a combination credit and calling card introduced in March, has exceeded AT&T's projections, causing greater-than-expected processing costs, the company said. Toole estimated the credit card processing costs cut earnings by 5 cents a share in the quarter. AT&T's total expenses rose 4.3 percent during the quarter, reflecting increased marketing and advertising costs, the company said. In addition, AT&T said, earnings were reduced by 4 cents a share due to higher income taxes resulting primarily from reduced tax credits. But product sales, including telephone network products, computers, microelectronic components and consumer products, jumped almost 13 percent during the quarter to $3.08 billion. Service revenues, which include long-distance service, installation and maintenance of equipment, and finance services, rose 3 percent to $5.72 billion. Long-distance revenue itself grew 1.5 percent as calling volume advanced 7 percent. Charles Nichols, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the 7 percent increase in calling volume ``shows that AT&T has become more effective in stemming market-share erosion'' to MCI Communications Corp. and U.S. Sprint. Toole said AT&T apparently continues to lose long-distance customers in the residential and international markets, but in the highly profitable business market ``they're holding their own or maybe even winning back a little.'' AT&T has about 65 percent of the overall long-distance market. Nichols said he was pleased by the company's earnings growth and agreed that it was doing well in light of the economic decline. He called the continued earnings drag from the Universal card ``a short-term negative, long-term positive'' since the card should increase earnings in the future. But Pat Jurczak, another Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst, projected the card would continue to lose money for two years. ``The real concern is that we are moving into a slowing economy,'' he said. ``They have to keep the bad debt low. They have to make sure they have the right customers.'' While international equipment sales were strong, AT&T said sales of communications systems to large business customers were flat and sales to smaller businesses declined slightly. For the first nine months of the year AT&T earned $2.04 billion, or $1.87 a share, up 2.5 percent from $1.99 billion, or $1.85 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue totaled $27.27 billion, up almost 2 percent from $26.81 billion in the year-ago period.

DOC.HEAD: Bonneau Co. Makes Offer for Foster Grant
DOC.TEXT: If Dallas-based Bonneau Co. has its way, it soon will provide the answer to the question: ``Who's that behind those Foster Grants?'' Bonneau, a leader in the sunglasses business, has offered to pay $9 million for the assets of Foster Grant, including its name and trademark. Foster Grant, which rode to prominence with ads asking what star was behind its sunglasses, sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors in August. The company, with sales of more than $50 million worth of sunglasses, reading glasses and technical products last year, blamed the bankruptcy court filing on cash flow problems and competition from Asian imports. Court papers showed the company had total assets of about $25 million and liabilities of about $36 million, including nearly $19.3 million in unsecured debt. Foster Grant, founded in 1919 by Sam Foster, was the first company to use abrasion-resistant lens coatings that blocked the sun's ultra-violet rays, but is best known for its advertisements. Bonneau's offer must be approved by a Tucson, Ariz., bankruptcy court. A hearing is set for Oct. 25 on the proposed sale. ``Assuming the court accepts the deal, we will close on it a short time later,'' said Foster Grant president William Mahoney. Bonneau officials said they would continue manufacturing operations in the two Foster Grant plants in Nogales, Mexico, and one in Leominster, Mass., and maintain its Tucson packing division.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Profit Up 21 Pct
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. said Thursday its third-quarter profit rose 20.8 percent, paced by gains in music, entertainment and broadcasting earnings. MCA, the entertainment conglomerate that is the parent of Universal Studios, has been in the news recently because Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. of Japan has offered to buy all or part of the firm. Revenues rose 18.7 percent, from $894.4 million to $1.061 billion. Sales in the music entertainment division climbed 64.9 percent to $347.9 million, reflecting fees earned by MCA from an agreement to form a new record company in Japan. Quarterly profit was $61.4 million, or 71 cents per share, compared with $50.8 million, or 69 cents per share, during the third quarter of 1989. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, net income rose 14.7 percent, from $120.1 million, or $1.64 per share, to $137.8 million, or $1.70 per share. Revenue rose 21 percent, from $2.4 billion to $2.9 billion. Per-share earnings were affected because MCA had the equivalent of about 92 million shares of common stock outstanding during the third quarter of 1990, compared with about 73 million during the same period of 1989. New shares were issued to purchase Geffen Entertainment and for the $500 million conversion of convertible subordinated debentures. Third-quarter operating profits in the theatrical film entertainment division fell 6.7 percent to $81 million. Book publishing earnings fell 54.5 percent. But operating earnings in the music entertainment unit soared 120.8 percent to nearly $43 million. And profits from broadcasting and cable operations rose 152.6 percent to $12.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer's Losses More Than Tripled in Fiscal Year
DOC.TEXT: Losses at R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. more than tripled in the company's 1990 fiscal year, a source familiar with the national retailer said Thursday. The company's losses totaled $215.3 million for the year that ended July 28, compared with a loss of $63 million the previous year, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Sales rose 4.2 percent to $7.27 billion from $6.97 billion a year earlier. The closely held company is still paying down big debts rolled up in a 1986 management-led buyout and faces grim predictions for the Christmas shopping season. Macy's earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation - the key figure for a company trying to reduce debt from a so-called leveraged buyout - totaled $721 million in fiscal 1990, down from $926.1 million the year before. The 1990 figure fell short of the $743.2 million projection made by Macy last spring, but the source attributed the gap to a $30 million accounting adjustment. Macy had been expected to post disappointing results since it announced earlier this year that it had a disastrous 1989 Christmas season. The results were expected to be released publicly later this month. The upcoming Christmas season is expected to be sluggish for the entire retail industry, and Macy's showing during the summer has raised concerns among its bondholers and suppliers about how the company will fare during the holidays. Macy's August sales fell 5 percent from a year earlier, the source said. But Macy said it is prepared for a poor Christmas. James Fingeroth, a Macy spokesman, noted that the retailer is carrying $560 million less in inventory than it had a year ago, has controlled other expenses and is ``planning for a very sluggish environment going forward for the forseeable future.'' Tom Razukas, an analyst with Fitch Investors Service Inc., said the company's results do not change his assessment of the retailer or its prospects. Macy's extremely conservative approach to this Christmas ``is a good way to be,'' he said. Last week, Macy announced it was selling its credit operations to GE Capital Corp. Macy said the move would reduce its $4.8 billion debt load by $1.5 billion. The company has also said it is buying back some of its bonds - including some of its $1.6 billion in junk bonds - as another means of lowering its debt and a $595 million annual interest bill. Macy has sold equity stakes to help finance the buybacks. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club, Morgan Taylor and Aeropostale, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Weaker, Gold Prices Inch Upward
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished sharply weaker against most key currencies Thursday, reflecting what money dealers called a loss of confidence in the U.S. government's ability to adopt a deficit-reduction package. Gold prices rose while silver prices were mostly unchanged. The dollar's decline was particularly acute against the German mark, falling through a psychological barrier of 1.50 marks to 1.4970 in New York, down from 1.5125 Wednesday. ``The dollar is weakening,'' said William Sterling, an international economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. ``Foreigners are increasingly coming to believe that the U.S. government is incapable of delivering a competent fiscal policy.'' Traders said Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's comment earlier this week that he wasn't ``overly concerned'' about the dollar's decline also was considered a green light to sell dollars. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 124.40 Japanese yen from 125.80 yen at Wednesday's close and its lowest close since it finished at 124.05 yen on Jan. 4, 1989. Later, in London, it rose to 125.25 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at $124.40 yen, down from $125.43 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9540 from $1.9650 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9710 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9615. Lamakers were working late again Thursday, mindful of President Bush's promise to let the government shut down again Saturday - when its authority to spend money expires - unless Congress seems near a budget he likes. But traders said the prolonged political stalemate in Washington over the deficit, considered a major drag on the U.S. economy, was causing foreign investors to lose confidence in the dollar and in the federal government's ability to function effectively. Sterling predicted the dollar would weaken further if Congress misses the latest deadline. ``They ought to meet the deadline,'' Sterling said. ``If a budget is delayed and the government has to shut down again, all of that would leave the dollar twisting in the wind.'' Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday included: 1.2590 Swiss francs, down from 1.2720; 1.1698 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1683; 5.0165 French francs, down from 5.0680; and 1,122.00 Italian lire, down from 1,132.50. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday included: 1.5115 German marks, up from 1.5105; 1.2735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2725; 5.0630 French francs, up from 5.0588; 1.7035 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7015; 1,132.75 Italian lire, up from 1,130.75; and 1.1750 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1646. Gold closed at $370.10 per troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange, up $3.40 from Wednesday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for bullion of $391, up $4.90. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $367.75 a troy ounce, up from $366.50 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $366.50, up from $366.20 bid late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.77 to $369.58. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.198 a troy ounce, unchanged from Wednesday. In London, silver bullion fell to a late bid of $4.18 a troy ounce, down from $4.24 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Plans To Sell Off Smallest Properties Soon
DOC.TEXT: The federal agency disposing of failed savings and loans is selling its smallest properties in the next few months in order to free employees to concentrate on the largest properties. ``We're much better off administratively if we can sell them (smaller properties) off fast and reduce the bookkeeping and number of people needed to manage them,'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``We want to use our people to move on big assets,'' he said. The RTC was created by last year's S&L bailout law. By early this month, it had taken over 492 failed thrifts with assets of $258 billion. It has disposed of 286 of those S&Ls but has had less success in selling the assets owned by the institutions. In early August, Seidman announced a ``great fall inventory clearance sale'' to move more than $50 billion in assets by the end of the year. He said Thursday that effort had been set back by the cancellation of an auction via international satellite, scheduled for November, but that the agency still might reach its goal. Seidman first disclosed the RTC's strategy shift toward disposing smaller assets in a speech Wednesday to the Washington Analysis Corp., a subsidiary of National Westminster Bank. He said more than 76 percent of the 40,000 real estate parcels in his agency's possession had values of less than $100,000. It also has a large number of delinquent loans wih book values of less than $50,000 each. Most of the loans will be packaged and sold to the highest bidder at auctions, he said. In the January-March quarter, the agency will conduct a series of auctions and accept sealed bids for almost all real estate properties valued at less than $100,000, he said. Sealed bids will be used in a program aimed at providing homes to poor people. ``The faster disposition of these small assets will maximize returns by freeing up our staff to concentrate on large sales where the real dollars are recovered,'' Seidman said.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Up
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Oct. 8, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,325.5 billion from $3,322.2 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,092.0 billion from $4,085.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $821.9 billion from $828.8 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,304.4 billion, a 3.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,085.8 billion, up 1.6 percent, while M1 rose 4.5 percent to an average of $816.9 billion. In other reports: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $377 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $399 million the previous week. - The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.4 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, up from $317.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast News Affects Oil Futures
DOC.TEXT: News from the Middle East incited a rebound in the oil market Thursday, while increased export business pushed wheat prices higher and consumer demand for beef raised cattle prices. November crude oil slid in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $34.40, down $2.30 a barrel, in a follow-through from Wednesday's concern over high supplies and low demand, traders said. But prices recovered on reports of renewed Mideast tension. Eleven of 18 contract months, including November, fnished higher for the session. In Lebanon, an Israeli army unit battled Shiite Moslem guerrillas and leftist militiamen Thursday near a village believed used as a base to attack Israel's self-declared security zone. ``The Israeli troop shootings today increased tension, and we were right back from a fundamental mode to a psychological mode. It shows how susceptible the market is to any crisis overseas,'' said Peter Beutel, energy director for Pegasus Econmetric Group in New Jersey. Mild weather on the East Coast depressed heating oil prices, he said. Crude oil settled 54 cents lower to 32 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in November at $36.80; heating oil was 1.53 cents to 4 cents lower, with November at 96.51 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .44 cent to 2.25 cents lower, with November at 92.96 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures finished higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Gold and silver trading mirrored the crude oil market, with prices down earlier in the day but recovering at the close. Gold settled $2.80 to $3.40 higher, with the contract for October at $370.10 a troy ounce; and silver .1 cent to .2 cent higher, with October at $4.198 a troy ounce. Wheat futures prices were mostly higher, but corn and soybean prices were off on the Chicago Board of Trade. News that China was bidding for an additional 450,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat supported trading. Traders were unimpressed with the U.S. Agriculture Department announcement overnight that the Soviet Union had purchased 350,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. ``They're saying `Who cares,''' said Chicago grain analyst Mickey Luth of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Luth also said that demand for soybeans are below what they were a year ago. Wheat settled unchanged to 1{ cents higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $2.63} cents a bushel; corn was } cent to 1} cents lower, with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower, with December at $1.23 a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent to 4{ cents lower, with November at $6.10\ bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures were stronger and pork prices weaker. Paul Hare, an analyst with Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago, said the cattle pit has been supported by renewed packer interest in the Southwest and Midwest cash markets. ``This is good news because traders have been concerned about recessionary pressures,'' Hare said. Hog futures have gone the other way recently. After a supportive hog inventory report at the last month, prices have fallen back due to weaker product demand. Cattle settled .22 cent to .55 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in October at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .48 cent higher, with October at 86.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .15 cent higher, with October at 57.22 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to 1.70 cents lower, with February at 66.00 cents a pound.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new third graf with Affiliated results, ADDS three grafs with details.
DOC.HEAD: Profits Down at New York Times Co., McClatchy Newspapers, Affiliated
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times Co. said Thursday its profit skidded 95.6 percent in the third quarter from results a year ago that were fattened by a big onetime gain on the sale of its cable television operations. But even without counting the cable sale gain in 1989, the diversified media company said its income from continuing operations was down 43.9 percent from a year ago because of a decline in advertising linage at its flagship newspaper and costs related to two new plants. Affiliated Publications, owner of The Boston Globe, also cited reduced advertising revenues in reporting its earnings dropped by more than 50 percent. Newspaper companies have reported generally weak earnings this quarter as demand for ad space has shrunk in some regions as the economy weakens. McClatchy Newspapers Inc., meanwhile, reported its profit was down 14.8 percent in the third quarter from a year ago, mainly because of the costs of recent newspaper acquisitions and startup losses at a newsprint mill.

The New York-based newspaper, magazine and broadcast company said it earned $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $210.8 million, or $2.68 a share, a year earlier. The 1989 results included $2.47 a share for the gain on the sale and results of NYT Cable TV, which was sold in August 1989. Revenue in the quarter edged up 1.3 percent to $420.7 million from $415.3 million a year earlier. Income from continuing operations amounted to $9.2 million, down from $16.4 million a year earlier. Operating profit in the newspaper group dropped 43.8 percent to $19.6 million in the quarter from $34.9 million a year earlier. Ad linage was down 10.7 percent at the New York Times, but rose 4 percent at its 35 regional newspapers. The operating loss in the magazine group amounted to $2.3 million in contrast to an operating loss of $4.5 million a year earlier. Operating profit from broadcasting and information services rose to $3.3 million in the quarter from $2.6 million a year earlier. Depreciation and interest expenses on a new production center in Edison, N.J., and a new facility for the Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News reduced earnings by 9 cents a share in the quarter. For the first nine months of the year, New York Times Co. earned $52.6 million, or 69 cents a share, down 81.6 percent from $285.6 million, or $3.63 a share, a year ago. The 1989 results included $2.52 a share from the cable sale and operations. Income from continuing opoerations fell 39.7 percent to $52.6 million from $87.2 million a year earlier. Revenue for the nine months rose 1.5 percent to $1.32 billion from $1.3 billion a year earlier.

Sacramento, Calif.-based McClatchy said it earned $7.5 million, or 26 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $8.8 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said the decline stemmed from the costs of buying six newspapers in South Carolina in January and losses on its investment in a new newsprint mill, and that its profit would have risen slightly otherwise. Revenue for the quarter rose 12.8 percent to $107.0 million for the quarter led by the Sacramento and Modesto Bee newspapers from $94.9 million a year ago. For the first nine months, McClatchy earned $17.7 million, or 62 cents a share, down 25 percent from $23.6 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent to $309.7 million for the nine months from $279.1 million a year earlier.
DOC.HEAD: Affiliated Publications
DOC.TEXT: Boston-based Affiliated reported $4 million in net income, or 6 cents per share, on revenues of $130.40 million for the third quarter. In the same period last year, the company reported earnings of $8.48 million, or 12 cents per share, on $126.96 million in revenues. For the nine-month period ended Sept. 30, Affiliated reported $17.91 million in earnings, or 26 cents per share, on $396 million in revenues. That compares with $2.88 million in earnings, or 4 cents per share, for the same period in 1989. Affiliated officials also said operating income at its BPI Communications subsidiary was negatively effected by start-up costs of its broadcast monitoring service and costs from its acquisition of A-S-N Communications Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Reports 39 Percent Drop In Fourth-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. on Thursday reported a 39 percent drop in earnings for the quarter that ended Sept. 28. The computer maker attributed most of the decline to last year's sale of stock in Adobe Systems Inc., which produced abnormal gains of about $48 million. Apple said 1990 fourth fiscal quarter net income was $98.5 million, or 81 cents per share, on net revenues of $1.354 billion. In the same period last year, earnings were $161.1 million, or $1.24 per share, on net revenues of $1.384 billion. The results also reflected the slowing economy, cuts in prices on some products and the long-expected but just-announced switch to lower-cost Macntoshes, said Apple spokesman Christopher Escher. After several years of rapid growth, Apple's sales have slowed recently, with critics blaming the company's woes on the high price tag for the Macintosh computer. But earlier this week, the company introduced three new Macintoshes that cost less than comparable models in the current line. The least expensive, the Macintosh Classic, has a suggested retail price of $999 - the first time Apple has produced a computer to sell for less than $1,000. ``Because of our strategy to reach many more people with Macintosh personal computers, we are confident about our company's prospects in fiscal 1991,'' John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. ``As a result (of the new computers) we enter this new fiscal year in a much stronger competitive position and better poised for growth,'' he said. Net income for the year was $474.9 million, compared with $454 million for fiscal 1989. Per-share net income for the year was $3.77, up from $3.53. For the year, net revenues rose 5 percent, from $5.284 billion to $5.558 billion. ``While we experienced significant revenue and unit growth in our Apple Macintosh computer modular products during fiscal 1990, sales of some of our more established products declined,'' Sculley said.

DOC.HEAD: Marion Merrell Dow, Shering-Plough Report Third-Quarter Earnings
PRECEDE KANSAS CITY, Mo.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with Shering-Plough, PICKUP fourth graf pvs, In the . . .; ADDS eight grafs with Shering-Plough details.
DOC.TEXT: Marion Merrell Dow earned $134 million, or 47 cents per share, during the third quarter of 1990 and Shering-Plough Corp.'s earnings increased 23 percent, the drug companies said Thursday.

Marion Merrell Dow, which was created in December 1989 with the merger of Marion Laboratories Inc. and Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc., said its $625 million in sales were spurred by a strong performance of its cardiovascular drugs. Because the Kansas City, Mo.-based company is in its first full year of operation, no comparable financial figures from 1989 were available. In the third quarter of 1989, Marion Laboratories reported a net loss of $101 million, or 67 cents per share, on sales of $237 million. Those results were blamed on costs related to the settlement of stock appreciation rights. Nine-month results of Marion Labs through September 1989 showed a net income of $25 million, or 16 cents a share, on sales of $741 million. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported earnings of $375 million, or $1.33 per share, on sales of $1.8 billion. Sales for the company's Cardizem cardiovascular drugs - used to treat angina and high blood pressure - rose by 8 percent for the third quarter and by 16 percent for the first nine months of the year. The company's Seldane line of anti-allergy products also showed a 23 percent sales increase in the third quarter and a 28 percent increase so far this year.

Madison, N.J.-based Schering-Plough credited a 24 percent rise in sales by its worldwide businesses for part of the earnings increase. Net income for the third quarter increased to $140 million, or 62 cents per share, compared with earnings of $114 million, or 51 cents per share, at this time last year. Sales increased 7 percent in the third quarter to $793.8 million compared with $743.7 million in the same period in 1989. Third-quarter sales were reduced by the July 1990 sale of its Maybelline cosmetics business to a New York-based investment firm, said spokesman Linn Weiss. A pre-tax gain of $150 million from that sale was offset by the discontinuance of an anti-hypertensive drug, ongoing actions to improve efficiency and personnel restructuring programs, Weiss said. Profit for the first nine months of 1990 totaled $434.5 million, a 21 percent increase over $360.2 million the year before, while earnings per share rose 20 percent to $1.92 compared with $1.60 in 1989, the company said. Meanwhile, sales for the first nine months of 1990 were up 6 percent, to $2.52 billion compared with the $2.38 billion recorded last year. Schering-Plough is primarily engaged in the research, development, manufacturing and marketing of pharmaceutical and health care products worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: City Agrees To Phase Out Use Of Deadly Acid
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Oil Corp. agreed Thursday to a seven-year phase-out of deadly hydrogen flouride at its refinery here and to submit to review by an independent safety advisor. The agreement settles a lawsuit by the City of Torrance alleging that use of the toxic, cloud-forming acid endangered thousands of residents living nearby in the Los Angeles coastal suburb. The case was scheduled to go to trial Nov. 5. City officials called the agreement a landmark settlement, but warned that they expect a continuing battle over safety at the refinery. A trial would have ``shown the world how dangerous (hydrogen flouride) is and how poorly managed the plant was operated,'' said Councilman Dan Walker. ``I think we're going to have to fight every inch of the way to meet the goals of the settlement.'' The lawsuit, filed early this year, stems from a November 1987 explosion and fire that ignited when hydrogen flouride overflowed into a tank and mixed with another chemical. The blast caused some $17 million in damage and left four workers and six bystanders injured. Used to manufacture high-octane gasolines, hydrogen flouride forms a heavy cloud when exposed to open air. City officials feared an accident or leak at the refinery could send such a cloud drifting into residential neighborhoods. Under the agreement, Mobil would be allowed to develop and use a derivative of hydrogen flouride that would not form a cloud. Refinery Manager Joel Maness said he expected the settlement to end several years of acrimony between the city and Mobil. He said he had no concern about permitting an outside inspector to review the plant's operations. ``We feel strongly that we have a safe operation,'' Maness said. ``But I never mind having another set of eyes take a look at our operations and our procedures.'' The inspector, who will advise the plant on safety considerations, will be chosen by joint agreement between Mobil nd the city and bill be paid by the company, court documents said. The advisor will report to retired Superior Court Judge Harry V. Peetris, who will act as an arbitrator of future disputes over the phase-out program. Peetris also will be paid by Mobil.
